webTitle: Fletcher backs Hick to the hilt

fields.headline: Fletcher backs Hick to the hilt
fields.trailText: Paul Weaver on the Graeme Hick debate.
fields.body:
There seems little point in entering the Graeme Hick debate, because passions are polarised, positions cemented. You are either for him or against him.

Some feel a personal sense of betrayal because Hick has not lived up to the unrealistic expectations with which they burdened him when he first played Test cricket in 1991; other critics appear suspicious of his unEnglishness.

His supporters see a man who last week, almost unnoticed, played his 100th one-day international, who in 54 Tests has scored 3,005 runs at a respectable if unremarkable average of 34. Such fondly remembered warriors as Mike Gatting (35) and Allan Lamb (36) fared little better.

If you discard his first two disappointing series Hick's average is not much under 40, which means he strolls in the same country as Nasser Hussain and Michael Atherton, who are hardly close to being dropped. This is also a fan who cares enough to have wept in the England dressing room.

The good news for the side's most gifted yet enigmatic batsman is that the England coach Duncan Fletcher has given his firmest endorsement yet of the player's considerable talents.

Fletcher, who captained Hick when Zimbabwe came to England for the 1983 World Cup, said: "He's a top, top batsman. Even when I'm doing throw-downs I think, hold on, there's something different here.

"He'll hit six balls out of six in the middle of the bat; others will manage just four. He's a young 33. In training the other day he was out ahead of the others, and his arm is as strong as anyone's. And he looks more relaxed. He mentioned it to me the other day; he seems to be enjoying himself.

This is a stupendous player, one who might become the first to score 200 first-class centuries The figures, however, are only part of it, for here is a man whose nerve has faltered at crucial moments, whose five Test hundreds are not recalled for having been played in difficult circumstances.

Now, working with a coach in which he has immense faith, his Test career is on the verge of resurrection. "This is a difficult game and it's all about handling pressure. It's really up to Graeme," Fletcher added.

First, though, Fletcher hopes Hick can repair his one-day form which has seen him score only 50 runs in his five innings in the triangular series. England must beat Zimbabwe in Pretoria on Wednesday if they are to meet South Africa in the final.

fields.headline: South Africa ensure final place
fields.trailText: South Africa made sure of a place in Saturday's final of the triangular one-day series when they beat Zimbabwe by 53 runs in Port Elizabeth yesterday.
fields.body:
South Africa made sure of a place in Saturday's final of the triangular one-day series when they beat Zimbabwe by 53 runs in Port Elizabeth yesterday.

The other place will now be decided by a straight shoot-out between England and Zimbabwe at Centurion Park on Wednesday. But if that match is tied or rained off - hardly an unlikely scenario at this venue - England would go through on superior run-rate.

On a slow, low-scoring pitch, South Africa's score of 204 for seven was a tougher target than it looked and Zimbabwe never recovered from a three-wicket opening burst from Shaun Pollock.

Pollock dismissed Grant Flower, first ball, and then Craig Wishart and Alistair Campbell to finish with figures of 8-4-7-3. Zimbabwe only looked in control when Neil Johnson, their top scorer with 56, was batting with Andy Flower, who made 37.

But Johnson, who hit seven fours in his 82-ball innings, fell to a magnificent diving catch by Hansie Cronje and Flower was run out by a direct hit from Herschelle Gibbs.

Earlier, South Africa were made to struggle for their runs and only Jacques Kallis got on top of the bowling with some muscular straight hitting on his way to an unbeaten 98 from 132 deliveries. Even Lance Klusener failed to hit a boundary in his 29 from 53 balls.

fields.headline: Third Division round-up
fields.trailText: Darlington moved into fourth place in the division yesterday, goals from Marco Gabbiadini and Neil Wainwright sealing a 2-0 victory over Peterborough.
fields.body:
Darlington moved into fourth place in the division yesterday, goals from Marco Gabbiadini and Neil Wainwright sealing a 2-0 victory over Peterborough.

 Leo Fortune-West struck the winner just before the break as Rotherham hit back from a goal behind to see off Macclesfield 2-1 and ease back to the top. Gregor Rioch converted a fifth-minute penalty to give visiting Macclesfield the lead but Chris Sedgwick levelled with another spot-kick after 31 minutes.

 Barnet also got a shock at home when Cheltenham went in front through Martin Devaney after only two minutes on their first visit to Underhill. But two goals from Ken Charlery, taking his season's tally to 11, and Scott McGleish's eighth of the season put the game beyond doubt before Russell Milton's injury-time penalty for the visitors.

 Northampton are fourth after a 3-0 home win against York. Ian Sampson gave Northampton the lead two minutes before half-time and Roy Hunter, after 56 minutes, and Sean Parrish 10 minutes later sealed a comfortable win.

 Hartlepool had the teenager Andy Boyd to thank for their 1-0 home win over struggling Shrewsbury, his injury-time winner lifting them to fifth place before they were overtaken by Darlington yesterday.

 Rochdale moved into the play-off zone by overcoming rock-bottom Chester 2-1 with goals from Graham Lancashire and David Bayliss.

fields.headline: Second Division round-up
fields.trailText: Preston moved to the top on goal difference despite being held to a 2-2 draw with struggling Reading at Deepdale. Nicky Forster struck for the visitors after 39 minutes before Jon Macken, with his 18th league goal, and Michael Jackson seemed to have put North End in control just after the restart. But Martin Butler, a £750,000 signing from Cambridge, grabbed a vital point for Reading.

Preston moved to the top on goal difference despite being held to a 2-2 draw with struggling Reading at Deepdale. Nicky Forster struck for the visitors after 39 minutes before Jon Macken, with his 18th league goal, and Michael Jackson seemed to have put North End in control just after the restart. But Martin Butler, a £750,000 signing from Cambridge, grabbed a vital point for Reading.

 Burnley had their leading scorer Andy Payton sent off for violent conduct against the former leaders Bristol Rovers in the vital promotion encounter at Turf Moor but took the points through a 69th-minute Glen Little goal.

 Wigan remain unbeaten away from home after a draw at bottom-of-the-table Cambridge but, after Stuart Barlow's 20th goal of the season, Tom Youngs levelled in injury-time for United.

 Millwall had their leading scorer Neil Harris sent off for violent conduct and it became 10-a-side when Oldham's Matthew Tipton was dismissed for serious foul play. But the Lions took the points thanks to Paul Shaw's last-gasp penalty.

 Oxford's troubles continued after John Murphy's early goal gave their fellow strugglers Blackpool a 1-0 win at the Manor Ground.

 Brentford had their captain Paul Evans sent off for a second bookable offence and fell to a 2-0 home defeat by Notts County. Francis Tierney put County ahead and Kevin Rapley sealed the points after 70 minutes.

fields.headline: International football latest
fields.trailText: Lazio on top in Italy. Cameroon are through to the semi-finals of the African Nations Cup.
fields.body:
Lazio moved back to the top of Serie A after a 4-2 victory at Torino yesterday. The visitors appeared to be cruising to victory with goals from Nestor Sensini, Fabrizio Ravanelli and Sinisa Mihajlovic, but the Yugoslav was then sent off for punching Marco Ferrante.

Ferrante pulled one back from the penalty spot and Fabio Galante added a second before Marcelo Salas sealed victory in the last minute.

Juventus trail by a point after Ciro Ferrara's equaliser earned a draw at Udinese on Saturday. Roma closed the gap on them by thumping Venezia 5-0 while the champions Milan swept past Bari 4-1. Hernan Crespo converted an injury-time penalty in Parma's 1-1 draw with Internazionale.

Cameroon reached the semi-final of the African Nations Cup yesterday, beating Algeria 2-1. Samuel Eto'o opened the scoring and West Ham's Marc-Viven Foé headed a second in the 24th minute.

But Abdelhafid Tasfaout reduced the deficit with 11 minutes to go and later missed a good chance to equalise.

webTitle: Calls mount for Barnes to resign

fields.headline: Calls mount for Barnes to resign
fields.trailText: John Barnes's position as Celtic manager is becoming increasingly untenable after the latest disaster at home to Hearts.
fields.body:
The Celtic manager John Barnes would have neither heard nor seen the small group of fans outside the front door of Celtic Park asking for his resignation. He was still with his team, who had just given up a two-goal lead to lose 3-2 to Hearts on Saturday. But the pressure is mounting and, if Barnes goes, he would be the ninth manager to leave Celtic in little over 10 years.

The charges against Barnes are not just the usual fans' grumblings. Instead and in short they are that a club of Celtic's size should not have given the reins to a beginner. There is a growing feeling that £15m spent on new players such as Eyal Berkovic, Olivier Tebily and Stilian Petrov has not bought the quality expected from that outlay.

Celtic's defeat came after Lubomir Moravcik and Mark Viduka scored first-half goals. Two from Colin Cameron and another from Gary Naysmith then made them redundant. It hardly amused a 60,000 crowd and there were acres of empty seats before the end.

The match marked the end of a bad eight days for the club. The previous Saturday the Scottish Cup tie against Inverness Caley was postponed when part of the roof fell off and there has been venomous media criticism this week over reports that the chief executive Allan MacDonald called on a behavioural psychologist to study the body language of the referee Hugh Dallas after a controversial Old Firm game last spring.

fields.headline: Wise cracks it for Keegan
fields.trailText: Tottenham Hotspur 0 - 1 Chelsea
fields.byline: Jeremy Alexander at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
International football is all about timing. Darren Anderton is starting matches again for Spurs. England must have a championship coming up.

As if to confirm it, Kevin Keegan was here to see. Anderton, wide right in midfield, was fully engaged as Spurs, the league's biggest tacklers, took on the biggest foulers (20% more than Leeds, who are next). But has he lost the inch of that galloping stride that took him clear of tackles? In any case, how would he fit with David Beckham?

There were others to check. Sometimes, when Dennis Wise is suspended, Chelsea have nothing to show the England coach. But Chris Sutton is the preferred partner to George Weah. Again, timing comes into it. At his current gestation rate in new surroundings, Sutton is already too late to hatch goals in Euro 2000.

He moved well, looks lean and must be hungry. But Ian Walker palmed away an early chance, just as a commentator blared "Sutton must score", and even Gianluca Vialli must wonder when he will.

Walker may have impressed Keegan. He had made a similar save from Weah, staying up so long it was reaction not guesswork. But he was slow to organise a wall at the free-kick that brought the goal. As potential bricks looked for cement or instruction Wise took it quickly and Bernard Lambourde, spiriting in unseen, scooped the ball over Walker.

Vialli called it "a moment of great imagination from two of my players". It was a moment of great inattention from 11 Spurs, who have not beaten Chelsea in 22 games. Excepting the early chance and later goal, Sol Campbell had a day of towering reassurance to Keegan.

Spurs pressed strongly in the last half-hour without posing much threat. Before the match the crowd was treated to an interview with Jürgen Klinsmann and a score of his Spurs goals on the big screen. Then came Steffen Iversen and Chris Armstrong; and Chelsea had Gianfranco Zola and Tore Andre Flo on the bench.

Spurs crave quality and the wit to get men in the box for David Ginola's crosses. Marcel Desailly was untroubled and Chelsea's injury crisis in defence still had Frank Leboeuf surplus. Jon Harley, at left-back, may be more comfortable further forward but one run hinted at Davidson in his pedigree.

He may be one for Keegan's future. For now, there was also Wise. Vialli, registering as a player last week, said "getting kicked makes you feel a man". Wise and Tim Sherwood will have felt men after their battle. No English player is more influential than Wise; Vialli says his leadership stems from his fitness and he remains captain as Didier Deschamps is "not so good at the language". Blimey.

Wise is a self-confessed disciple of Ken Bates and the previous week, behaving like a cretin, he was sent off for the 11th time. Can he be trusted against Argentina this month?

webTitle: Wenger concedes as two Deans teach a painful lesson

fields.headline: Wenger concedes as two Deans teach a painful lesson
fields.trailText: Bradford City 2 - 1 Arsenal
fields.body:
The black dog tormenting Arsène Wenger was a powerful counter-argument to the theory that defeat in the Premiership race is not so tough to bear now that there is the considerable compensation of the Champions League at hand.

Losing to Bradford City hurt, conceding the title to their bitter adversaries in Manchester more hurtful still, and the Arsenal manager admitted to feeling depressed on Saturday night. Not that there was any need to invite him to write off his team's chances alongside United and Leeds; it is a common Wenger tactic - offloading pressure on to his rivals - and one did not have to peer too far to see it coming.

"There is still a lot of football to be played and many more twists and turns to come" - that was Paul Jewell's verdict though his gaze, naturally, was on the scramble for life at the foot of the table. Wenger saw no reason for any such qualification, United's nine-point lead with a game in hand apparently too big for Arsenal to close.

"That's it for us and the championship", said Wenger. "We can forget about Manchester United. The championship is played in England, not in dreamland."

For there to be more mileage in the Gunners' challenge they surely had to be disposing of the likes of Bradford, which is no disrespect to the Yorkshire club, admirably fighting - and playing - their way towards Premiership security. Arsenal were the smarter in possession but uncharacteristically conceded soft goals at the same early stage of each half and paid a heavy price.

They quickly cancelled out the first through the opportunism of Thierry Henry but could not find a repeat, though they came desperately close. Henry bounced a lob over Aidan Davison on to the bar and Wayne Jacobs cleared off the line from Davor Suker.

"We had most of the possession but we were not dangerous enough," said Wenger. "It is very depressing to lose here but Bradford fought for every ball and their two strikers went for everything. Manchester United are so consistent and every bad result kills us. When we come close and don't win the game, it hurts. Is it a lack of finishing power or creativity? I think it's a combination of both."

The twin Deans, Saunders and Windass, queried Bradford's need for new signings last week amid negotiations for both Stan Collymore and Jorge Cadete. They then went out to underscore those remarks by worrying the life out of the Arsenal defence every time Bradford managed to get the ball forward.

Their first goal was wonderfully impudent, Windass stroking the ball high into the far corner direct from a free -kick while David Seaman was still lining up his wall by the opposite post. The second was thumped through Seaman's legs after Gareth Whalley sent Saunders clear of the last line.

They were not enough to lift Bradford out of the bottom three, nor to delay the arrival of Cadete, who has signed on loan from Benfica for the rest of the season. Ironically, he checks in at a time when they are finding goals not so hard to come by, though one can never have too many penalty-box predators or, for that matter, enough goalkeepers. Davison, playing because of injuries to Gary Walsh and Matt Clarke, brilliantly stopped Freddie Ljungberg's header with the score 1-1. It proved crucial.

fields.headline: Wednesday on suicide watch
fields.trailText: Derby County 3 - 3 Sheffield Wednesday
fields.body:
The secret of success is picking up points when performing poorly. So congratulations Sheffield Wednesday on finding the recipe for relegation: throwing away points when playing well. Forget injury-time, at Hillsborough they should announce how much suicide-time is being added.

Two minutes was ample here for Wednesday to blow a two-goal cushion, and the consequences may be devastating. Losing ground on Bradford, Southampton and Derby was bad enough but think also of the bitter psychological blow. Danny Wilson ought to make his players walk dogs to teach them how to hold a lead.

When Wednesday went 3-1 up after 88min 47sec, thousands streamed for the exit. Wednesday's defence apparently decided to follow. Before you could say "consolation strike", one Derby goal had become two.

"Probably it's a mental thing," said the Wednesday striker Gilles de Bilde. "Every time we concede a goal we panic and run backwards. Every game we are waiting for something to go wrong. It's a normal reaction as a person and a footballer: you start to doubt yourself."

De Bilde said Wilson had shouted at the team for their stupidity but had stressed how well they had played. Wednesday showed quality, particularly in the first half, which made a mockery of their position. But being "absolutely superb", in Wilson's words, for "98% of the game" is like owning a Ferrari without the key. It looks impressive but does not get you very far.

Wednesday are eight points adrift of safety and Saturday's home game against Southampton looms large. They are good enough to survive but on this showing are neither ruthless nor nerveless enough. They have conceded almost a third of their goals in the last 15 minutes.

Derby's comeback not only prevented them falling into the bottom three but disguised worrying signs. Jim Smith gave short shrift to the local radio reporter who suggested the players and coaches were not good enough to keep the club up: "You don't want me to swear, do you? We've gone seven games and lost one." But his side are in serious danger.

Level on points with Bradford, they were abject before half-time and fortunate that De Bilde's header was the only goal. Not until Georgi Kinkladze was introduced in the 61st minute did they really come to life. The Georgian could have been in Cyprus with his country but is determined to make his loan move from Ajax permanent at around £3m. He set up two goals.

Smith believes Kinkladze is too much of a defensive liability to start in this situation. But the midfielder provided the verve and skill Derby were lacking. Their fate could rest on a left foot so revered by Manchester City fans that they still watch him train. "With the close control and beating players I've not seen many, if any, better," Smith said.

Before Kinkladze crossed for Branko Strupar to head in, Gérald Sibon put Wednesday 2-0 up with a brilliant volley. It seemed over when Simon Donnelly raced clear to restore Wednesday's advantage shortly after Strupar hit a post. But first Craig Burley shot in after Strupar's header was blocked and then, from Kinkladze's cross, Malcolm Christie scored via Pavel Srnicek's arm.

fields.headline: Taylor fits into Royle's pattern
fields.trailText: Nottingham Forest 1 - 3 Manchester City
fields.byline: Mark Tallentire at the City Ground
fields.body:
"What was the Barnsley- Ipswich score?" inquired Joe Royle, who as manager of Manchester City is more than accustomed to looking over his shoulder.

After establishing that the Suffolk club had triumphed in the meeting of the third- and fourth-placed teams, who duly swapped places, Royle expressed his delight at seeing City overturn Chris Bart-Williams' scintillating opener from 25 yards to stay in second place after their seventh away win of the season. "One less than our promotion target if our home form stands up."

The foundation of the win was City's back four who, unlike Forest's, contested everything and won most of it, while in midfield the admirable Ian Bishop knocked the ball around with aplomb. "He's a bit old-fashioned, he passes the ball to a player in a shirt the same colour," remarked Royle.

To top it all for the City manager, the equaliser came from Bob Taylor, who had quickly become a target of some City fans but left the pitch to a standing ovation from the visiting contingent. It was only his second goal for the club, the product of a neat piece of control and a deft turn past Chris Doig before he fired into the roof of the net.

"It's nice when you pay £1.5m for someone and they start to look the part," Royle said. "He's getting better by the day and he gives us something extra."

Four minutes later Shaun Goater, whose pass had supplied the former Gillingham striker for the equaliser, took advantage of hesitant defend ing by Riccardo Scimeca and Doig to latch on to a ball from Bishop and deftly lob it over Dave Beasant in goal.

Though Forest came close to an equaliser in the second half, notably when Dougie Freedman shot wide from eight yards after splendid work by Jim Brennan and Alan Rogers on the left, Goater finished it as a contest when he met Mark Kennedy's free-kick at the near post and powered an unstoppable header past Beasant.

"David Platt's a football genius," mocked the 6,000 City supporters as the home fans headed for the exits, but it is difficult not to sympathise with the Forest manager. His team are short of confidence but they link well and managed some decent approach play.

"He knows what he wants and doesn't need my advice," said Royle. "It's not working for them at the moment but they are not as bad as their results and position suggest. I don't see them as relegation candidates."

Many do, however, and next Saturday's visit to Walsall, also on 30 points, has taken on added significance. "Unless we compete it's going to be pretty difficult between now and the end of the season," said Platt.

"City go out and play with each other, for each other, and don't give up. That's why they are second in the league.

"I like a challenge and I can't wait for the next game. I'm totally enveloped in this, in all honesty probably to the detriment of my personal life."

The last time Forest entertained City in the First Division was two seasons back, the visitors likewise winning 3-1 only to begin the next season in the Second Division whereas Forest went up as champions. Unless Platt can find somebody who can convert chances, there will be two divisions between them again next term.

webTitle: Stewart proves his worth at Bassett's expense

fields.headline: Stewart proves his worth at Bassett's expense
fields.trailText: Barnsley 0 - 2 Ipswich Town
fields.body:
Dave Bassett has established a reputation as a successful motivator and he certainly did the job impressively at Oakwell. The Barnsley manager's pre-match words played a crucial factor in the game. Unfortunately they inspired Ipswich.

Bassett's openness is often refreshing but he paid the price now for saying that Ipswich had paid too much for Marcus Stewart.

The striker, who moved for £2.5m from Huddersfield in mid-week, read his views and then, almost inevitably, produced the perfect riposte with an individual goal that secured the three points and lifted Ipswich above Barnsley in the table.

Bassett is not alone in believing Stewart was over-priced: Bradford City refused to match the Ipswich offer and Middlesbrough, Everton and Celtic have all declined to follow up their interest in the 26-year-old this season.

"I heard what the manager here said and, yes, it did wind me up," said Stewart. "In fact he could hardly have done a better job. We all have our opinions but I was a bit disappointed in the way it was said. Obviously he hasn't checked my goalscoring record."

Ipswich, with an industrious performance, stretched their unbeaten run to 14 games after a crucial moment of good fortune. They had been under pressure for 30 minutes when Jamie Scowcroft shaped to knock the ball across goal and then watched it float into a top corner. That was in the 59th minute, and Barnsley were still contemplating their bad luck when Stewart ran 40 yards almost straight from the kick-off and went past two defenders before rolling in the second.

His 16th goal of the season was a sweet moment and he now wants to show those top-flight clubs they were wrong. "Ipswich are a footballing side. They're ambitious and that's what I want, a chance in the Premiership." Bassett was generous afterwards in his praise for Ipswich. "They showed their pedigree," he said.

webTitle: Saint Hoddle sees only a green light

fields.headline: Saint Hoddle sees only a green light
fields.standfirst: David Lacey at the Dell
fields.trailText: Southampton 2 - 1 West Ham
fields.body:
When the names of the home team were announced on Saturday the Dell responded with a series of half-hearted cheers which might easily have been mistaken for groans. Apparently a victory over Everton had not increased the fans' faith in Southampton's chances of staying in the Premier League.

Glenn Hoddle, then, could hardly have been given a better cue. Palms were not exactly strewn in the redeemer's path but a generous number of hands came together as the crowd rose to its feet to give him a standing ovation.

Twelve months earlier the Football Association, not standing for Hoddle's muddled pronouncements on reincarnation, had terminated his contract as England coach. Now all that seemed to belong to a past life as he slipped seamlessly back into club management with a smile, a wave and a win, albeit through an own-goal.

There could hardly have been a greater contrast between Hoddle's final fraught press conference with England, when he announced his departure to the accompaniment of raucous noises off from a garrulous gatecrasher, and his relaxed mood on Saturday after Southampton had beaten West Ham United 2-1 to ease their predicament near the bottom.

Maybe managing England is football's equivalent of having to die in order to be born again. Certainly Bobby Robson looked years younger within three months of leaving the England job to take over at PSV Eindhoven.

Ostensibly Hoddle is in charge at the Dell on a 12-month contract so that David Jones, who kept Southampton up against the odds last time, can concentrate on defending charges of child abuse when he goes on trial in November. But realistically Hoddle is there for the foreseeable future, irrespective of the Jones verdict.

He has begun in the manner of one who expects to be there long-term. Jones's way of playing may have preserved Premiership football at the Dell for another season but Hoddle is already contemplating grander glories.

"If the club set their minds a little bit higher, who knows what we might achieve," he declared, "although first of all we've got to avoid relegation. We go to Sheffield Wednesday next. We've got to make sure we don't get beaten there."

In fact, Southampton are already in a healthier position than they were at a similar stage last season, when they lay in the bottom three with six fewer points from the same number of games.

Predictably Hoddle has wasted no time in changing their way of playing. On Friday Marian Pahars, a central striker, returned from international duty with Latvia to be told that he would be playing wide on the right against West Ham, as the new man intended to employ Kevin Davies as a lone striker.

Given that Pahars had not scored for Southampton since October and the team had found the net only seven times during the same period, it was not that much of a gamble but Hoddle still had to get across to the Latvian what he wanted.

"He only had a day to think about it, so I had quite literally to walk him through certain areas where I wanted him to play," Hoddle explained, "winning the ball in one place then going out wide when we had possession. We got him facing defenders rather than playing with his back to goal."

Nine minutes after half- time Hoddle's change of tactics was vindicated. A weak, low hash of a clearance by Igor Stimac allowed Chris Marsden to find Pahars with an excellent through-pass and a confident shot into the far corner ended the Latvian's barren spell.

The goal briefly roused West Ham from a generally torpid performance and, with John Moncur stiffening their midfield, Frank Lampard equalised 11 minutes later from Steve Lomas's astute pass. But with four minutes remaining Gary Charles, whose rash challenge had earlier put Patrick Colleter out of the game, turned a low centre from Jo Tessem into his own net to give Southampton the victory their earlier domination had promised.

Hoddle punched the air when the match ended but later allowed himself only cautious optimism. "The main thing was to get the team right and get the right result," he said. "Today I threw a completely new shape at the team and they took it on board. This will give them confidence.

"But in the Premiership, given the ability of so many teams, it's horses for courses. There's no use me having in mind a set way of playing. You've got to get the best out of the players you have."

It is not as if Hoddle is a stranger to the survival business. "When I took over at Swindon they were fourth from bottom with only eight games to play and we lost the first match," he recalled. "That was an unnerving situation. And after six months at Chelsea I came down here, we lost 3-1 and were next to bottom. But the next day we won at Newcastle and eventually turned things around."

Hoddle has impressed certain principles on his new squad but was not prepared to go into details, apart from revealing that they involved passing the ball rather than "lumping it" as well as certain things off the field.

He was probably thinking about the team's eating habits. Obviously the fact that Southampton's new stadium will be built near the city's red light district, with fans being exhorted to park and ride, had nothing to do with it.

fields.headline: Phillips puts Tyneside under spell
fields.trailText: Sunderland 2 - 2 Newcastle
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
It was, according to Kieron Dyer, the best atmosphere he had known. Alan Shearer described the match as more important than the FA Cup final, and the Newcastle manager Bobby Robson likened the rivalry to that of Celtic and Rangers. The result may have had little impact on the Premiership but this was never going to be, as Robson's predecessor Ruud Gullit infamously once blasphemed, "just a normal game".

Had Gullit been here the Dutchman would probably still be choking on his words. For if this were routine, football would surely have to carry a health warning for those of a nervous disposition.

Such was the level of testosterone engulfing Sunderland's palatial home that the beating of chests was louder at times than the pre-match beating of tribal drums. But if Operation Tyne-Wear was not a place for the faint-hearted, those of stronger stuff will remember the 120th derby as that collectors' item, a game that lived up to all the hype with an atmosphere to match. The upshot of a captivating north-east skirmish brimming with blood and thunder, not to mention occasional moments of thud and blunder, was a deserved point apiece but indisputably a moral victory for Sunderland after salvaging an improbable draw to go with the 2-1 win that hastened Gullit's removal from office at St James' Park last September.

At one stage it had looked like a damage-limitation exercise after early goals from Didier Domi and Helder had given Newcastle the chance to wrench back local bragging rights. But that view did not take into account the predatory instincts of Kevin Phillips, the man who used to clean Shearer's boots and now threatens to fill them as the country's finest striker.

His near-telepathic understanding with Niall Quinn made sure Newcastle's two- goal lead lasted little more than 60 seconds and his equaliser eight minutes from time, albeit from an apparently offside position, sparked unbridled scenes of pandemonium among all but 2,000 of a 42,902 stadium-record crowd. Perhaps it had been tempting fate for Newcastle's Greek defender Nikos Dabizas to dismiss Phillips' little-and-large partnership with Quinn as "predictable". "I suppose it has become a bit predictable, them scoring all the time," mused Peter Reid.

Through clenched teeth Robson declared that he had enjoyed the occasion, but his demeanour told another story. Newcastle had enough first-half chances to put the game beyond doubt, and the broken leg suffered by their left-back Alessandro Pistone in a heavy challenge from Gavin McCann added to the irritation. "I didn't like the tackle, put it that way," said Robson.

Phillips has now scored 21 goals in only 22 Premiership games - already more than the previous two Golden Boot winners - and this month he may well partner Shearer in England's attack against Argentina. There is certainly no one better qualified.

"England have a lot of good strikers but Kevin recommends himself," said Sunderland's midfielder Stefan Schwarz. "The best striker I have ever played with is Gabriel Batistuta [at Fiorentina] but Kevin is almost there. He is not happy with what he has achieved; he always wants more, and that makes him a special player."

webTitle: Miller issues Rangers with a warning

fields.headline: Miller issues Rangers with a warning
fields.trailText: Hibernian 2 - 2 Rangers
fields.body:
Hibs last night contrived not only to gain the better end of a draw against Rangers but, more important, they demonstrated that some clubs in the Scottish Premier League are not going to throw in the towel when Dick Advocaat's team comes to town.

Kenny Miller, that most promising of young home-grown strikers, took advantage of two Rangers mistakes and twice gave his side the lead. Rangers, though, eventually claimed a point thanks to Barry Ferguson's pass to the substitute Neil McCann nine minutes from time, the goal fashioned and finished by the only true Scots in blue jerseys on the field.

By going in at half-time on level terms Hibs had suggested that Rangers' seemingly irresistible charge towards the title was about to be checked. The fact that there was very little good football played in that period hardly mattered. Hibs' plan was simple: they allowed Rangers no time to settle on the ball, which deprived the champions' midfield of their customary swagger.

The problem was that in all the hurrying and scurrying no one could put his foot on the ball to create a clear chance. Rangers' best moment came in the sixth minute when Giovanni van Bronckhorst, picking up a pass from Andrei Kanchelskis, hit a sudden left-foot shot out of the reach of the goalkeeper Nick Colgan, only for the ball to thud back into play off the post.

The gale-force wind hardly helped and it was not until six minutes before the interval that Rangers made another opening, with Kanchelskis this time hitting a long cross for Van Bronckhorst, who volleyed the ball high over the bar.

But four minutes after the break Hibs took the lead when Craig Moore could only prod the ball out to Miller and a fierce shot from 12 yards beat Stefan Klos. Then in the 68th minute Rangers, who do not often shoot themselves in the foot, let Miller in for a second.

Arthur Numan came up short with a back-pass and Miller shrugged aside a series of challenges to restore the lead which had been taken away 12 minutes earlier when McCann crossed for Rod Wallace to head home. McCann, though, had the final word.

webTitle: Merson the fat controller derails Taylor

fields.headline: Merson the fat controller derails Taylor
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 4 - 0 Watford
fields.body:
Football looks different from here in the heartland. Graham Taylor is a genius, Paul Merson should be in the England team and Benito Carbone is a highly motivated and disciplined young man. Whatever your perspective, however, Villa and their manager John Gregory remain an enigma.

Which Villa are we to believe in, the crabbed and fearful bunch that nicked a 1-0 win at Chester City in September, or the team that knocked Leeds out of the FA Cup and, in 12 explosive minutes in the second half on Saturday, scored three stunning goals?

The home fans were sincere in their greeting for Taylor, who enjoyed a successful spell here 10 years ago, but they reserved their warmest approbation for Merson, who was substituted to a standing ovation in the 83rd minute after scoring two of the goals, one of them sublime, the other merely brilliant.

"Merson's finishing killed us off, didn't it?" Taylor said. "There's very few players can do what he did."

Merson scored his first with a running chip from 20 yards over Chris Day into the far top corner in the 57th minute. Two minutes later he controlled an Alan Wright cross on his chest and volleyed it just inside the far post with his back to goal.

"It shows how far I've come in three or four months," he said. "It shows how much confidence I've gained."

Taylor gave him the first of his 21 international caps eight years ago and Merson seemed pained at the way he had repaid the former England manager. "It's a shame because I've got so much respect for the man," he said. "He stuck by me, gave me my chance and put me in all the squads. Shame it has to be against Watford."

Such ironies abound in football and it seems they have a natural home at Villa. This is the team who slumped to 15th in the Premiership in December, then lost their only reliable striker. They are now up to eighth and are in the FA Cup quarter-finals, with only one defeat in their past 13 games.

Gregory is still concerned about his side's finishing - the Argentine striker Gustavo Bartelt has just been signed on loan for the rest of the season - but the forward formation forced on him by Dion Dublin's injury seems to serve the side well enough.

The team's resurgence has also forced many to reassess Gregory's ability, not least in the transfer market. George Boateng, the Dutch-Ghanaian midfielder bought for a lunatic £4.25m, is now the anchor of the midfield after an unhappy spell out on the right flank. Steve Stone, the damaged goods for which Gregory paid £5.5m, has recovered fitness and confidence and enjoyed a rare and encouraging full game on Saturday, highlighted by a wonderful volleyed goal. And, though £6.75m still seems a lot to have paid for an overweight 31-year-old engine which has been off the rails a few times, Merson is the man once more.

webTitle: Hunt fetches and carries a hatful

fields.headline: Hunt fetches and carries a hatful
fields.trailText: Stockport 1 - 3 Charlton First Division
fields.body:
There is just no stopping Charlton right now. More to the point, there is no stopping Andy Hunt, and Stockport will be glad to see the back of him should the current league leaders win promotion.

Charlton's seventh successive league win, their ninth if one includes the FA Cup successes against QPR and Coventry, was secured by Hunt's third hat-trick of the season and his second in consecutive league games. Sandwiched in between was the late winner that knocked Coventry out of the Cup. Life for Hunt, already good, is getting better by the game.

Last season's struggles in the Premiership, when he had only five goals to his credit by this stage, are a distant memory, though the player himself remembers them all too well.

"A year ago things were very tough for me, with people on my back," he said. "Things have turned around and I'm doing all right. But I know that's because the team is doing well, so there is no way I will let all this go to my head."

Hunt's boss, Alan Curbishley, took the former West Brom striker on a Bosman free two seasons ago after 76 league goals in 5 years with the Baggies. It was an impressive reference, but the goals dried up last season when Curbishley and Charlton needed them.

"I had to do a lot of fetching and carrying and defensive work, whereas this season I've been allowed to concentrate more on attacking," said Hunt, 29. "I didn't really have a kick in this game until I scored. Then the first two chances went in and that's how it happens when you are in a run."

Stockport's defenders have seen rather a lot of the back of Hunt this season. They could not keep up with him when he banged in his first hat-trick of the campaign in a 4-0 thrashing at The Valley in September, but he left it until the 88th minute on Saturday before completing his double after his first two goals in four minutes before half-time overturned Karin Fradin's 25th-minute opener.

"Last time we came here we lost 3-0 but went on to the play-offs with 88 points and were promoted," said a cautious Curbishley. "I've an idea we may need more than that to get promoted this time."

fields.headline: Nigeria overcome heroic Senegal
fields.trailText: Teenage sensation Julius Aghahowa scored a dramatic double as Nigeria grabbed a late equalizer before overcoming the obstacle of Senegal, the surprise team of the African Nations Cup, 2-1 in extra time to set up a semi-final clash with South Africa.
fields.body:
Teenage sensation Julius Aghahowa scored a dramatic double as Nigeria grabbed a late equalizer before overcoming the obstacle of Senegal, the surprise team of the African Nations Cup, 2-1 in extra time to set up a semi-final clash with South Africa.

Having trailed for 78 minutes, the hot favourites to win the cup looked like falling to its first home defeat for 19 years. But 17-year-old substitute Aghahowa raced through Senegal's defence to make it 1-1 five minutes from the end of regulation time.

Aghahowa, who scored as a substitute in the first round against Morocco, again celebrated with his impressive acrobatic skills as the spectators went into a frenzy.

Two minutes into extra time, Aghahowa was first to a cross from the left and kept his composure to give the Super Eagles the lead. That goal sparked chaotic scenes as thousands of spectators - perhaps in the belief that the golden goal rule applied- invaded the pitch, holding up the game for more than 15 minutes.

The fans' relief came after Senegal had grabbed a seventh-minute goal and survived intense home pressure until Aghahowa's dramatic intervention.

The National Stadium was silenced when Bruges striker Kalilou Fadiga punished woeful marking to finish with superb angled volley. With the Super Eagles' defence lacking mobility, Henri Camara twice came close to doubling the visitor's lead on quick first-half counterattacks.

Nigeria stepped up a gear and piled on the pressure. Benedict Akwuegbu and Jay-Jay Okocha, who had earlier clipped the top of the crossbar with a free kick, both wasted good opportunities as The Lions looked like pulling off a huge upset.

In the closing seconds, Okocha was sent off for elbowing Mbaye Badji but Nigeria, making its first appearance in the African Nations Cup since winning the trophy in 1994, held on to secure a semi-final match against South Africa.

Nigeria Ike Shorunmu; Gbenga Okunowo (Sunday Oliseh, 80), Godwin Okpara, Taribo West, Celestine Babayaro; Tijani Babangida (Julius Aghahowa, 68), Mutiu Adepoju, Austin Okocha, Finidi George; Nwankwo Kanu, Benedict Akwuegbu (Emmanuel Amunike, 62)

Senegal Oumar Diallo; Omar Daf (Mbaye Badji, 70), Omar Traore (Papa Daouda Sene, 67), Cheikh Sidy Ba, Assane Ndiaye; Papa Malick Diop, Ousmane Diop, Moussa Ndiaye, Pape Niokhor Fall; Henri Camara, Kalidou Fadiga (Abdoulaye Mbaye, 105)

webTitle: Collymore not a gamble says O'Neill

fields.headline: Collymore not a gamble says O'Neill
fields.trailText: Leicester City 2 - 1 Middlesbrough
fields.body:
The future of Stan Collymore, which has involved more twists and turns than a Brian Rix farce, should be resolved today or tomorrow when Leicester decide whether to give the unsettled Aston Villa striker a final chance to resurrect his controversial career.

As Leicester's chairman John Elsom left Filbert Street after his club's first Premiership win since the end of November, he said the issue had to be sorted out to end the speculation. "It will have to be decided Monday or Tuesday," said Elsom, whose Villa counterpart Doug Ellis apparently fell ill before the weekend and could not conclude talks for Collymore's move across the midlands in time for him to play against Middlesbrough.

The main sticking point continues to be whether Leicester must pay a fee for Stan The Man, and how much. Leicester's manager Martin O'Neill said there was still "a fair amount of work to be done" between the chairmen before Collymore joins.

O'Neill insists he is not worried about plunging in where others fear to tread. Last week Tottenham's George Graham, who needs strikers just as badly, said he would never take a player of Collymore's reputation for fear of upsetting team spirit. But O'Neill, who also believes in a one-for-all philosophy, thinks differently of the player who cost Villa £7m from Liverpool but has hardly repaid the vast outlay.

So limited were Leicester's attacking options on Saturday, with Emile Heskey, Tony Cottee and Ian Marshall all injured, that Matt Elliott was again forced to play up front, this time partnered by Muzzy Izzet, converted from midfield. "The way we're going we could do with any centre-forward who's alive," said O'Neill.

"Whether Stan is the man or not, I'm not entirely sure. I don't expect to pay hospital bills or anything like that. But if it materialises, I don't think it would be a gamble. If Stan was to sign for anybody, he'd have to know that it would be his last chance. I wouldn't expect to get any more from him than any other manager. I would think any motivation that there is would come from within."

Even without Collymore, Leicester were too strong for a hugely disappointing Middlesbrough, who have suddenly been sucked into the bottom six and have something of a striker crisis of their own. They gave Leicester their two goals, the first as Keith O'Neill put into his own net in the opening minute, the second through terrible defending when Andy Impey was left unmarked on the far post and shot home off Mark Schwarzer. Andy Campbell, Boro's lone striker, struck a superb volley to reduce the deficit but Boro rarely threatened thereafter despite plenty of possession.

Bryan Robson said: "I still can't believe the way we lost the game. Leicester had just had a couple of hard cup ties and we spoke about not giving them anything that would encourage them. Then we concede a goal in the first minute."

fields.headline: Cole carries the United dream
fields.trailText: Man United 3 - 2 Coventry
fields.body:
Now that the bookmakers, Leeds and Arsenal have ceded the title back to Old Trafford the only danger to United is the enemy within: the transparent belief that superior ability will bring an inevitable reward. Sir Alex Ferguson has a forthright word for it: complacency.

Complacency seeped through this performance as United continued to struggle to shake off the rust of Rio. The ever-grander Old Trafford superstructure, heaving with yet another Premiership record crowd, was often reduced to pin-drop silence as home action failed to meet expectations. But on this day superior ability ultimately held sway notably in the vibrant skills of the returning Andy Cole.

Gordon Strachan tellingly noted that United "had four chances and took three; that's real quality". For Coventry's manager the race has already been run and he admitted: "I would imagine they've won the league again." Only sheer carelessness, he and most of his fellow managers agree, or the magnificent distraction of Europe, can thwart United .

Ferguson had changed the habits of a lifetime by criticising his players in print - they went "too far" in haranguing the referee Andy d'Urso the previous Saturday, he wrote in the match programme - but he reverted to type by teatime, cautioning that next month's congested programme was pivotal to United's season. Yet, with knowing understatement, he declared: "It's been a good day for us."

Domestically, as Leeds and Arsenal obligingly made way, United have room to manoeuvre. Ferguson knows it, venturing a target: "We've got 15 games left and, if we win 10 of them, we've got a chance of winning the title." Even that appears cautious, for it would bring 83 points, four and five points more respectively than the championship marks of the past two years.

Put more boldly, that means United can afford to lose at Leeds, now six points adrift, on Sunday week while Arsenal, nine points off the pace, attempt to retrieve a seemingly lost cause. And United are nine points better off than at this stage last season.

United now have three successive away games but Ferguson is more concerned with next month, when his side have four successive midweek dates in Europe."I just hope we can keep a good, strong squad for March," he said. "With the Champions League, it will be a hard month for us."

Even if Ferguson enjoys the luxury of four high-quality strikers, he must hope that Dwight Yorke will return refreshed by his international leave, a commitment which eased the manager's decision to relegate him to the bench. After a superb start to the season, Yorke's form and goals have faded.

A mini-break has certainly worked for Cole, returning here to partner Teddy Sheringham, who had replaced him with opportunistic zeal in the previous two games. Perhaps Yorke has more to fear from the 33-year-old's re-emergence, as Ferguson insisted that Sheringham's form demanded a place while Cole, far from being doubted, has been "excellent" this season.

Ferguson paid Cole the ultimate compliment of comparing his magnificent first goal to "one of [Eric] Cantona's a few years ago". The reminiscence was understandable as Cole, outmanoeuvring Gary Breen, switched from left foot to right to chip over Magnus Hedman.

Such precision mocked United's slipshod, inhibited approach for the previous 38 minutes. Coventry's massed midfield, leaving the powerful Cedric Roussel as lone striker, made life that much harder.

Cole's second goal was mundane, a simple header from David Beckham's free-kick, and the crucial third, by Paul Scholes, a further slight to Coventry's disciplined endeavours. Hedman slipped as the midfielder's speculative 25-yard shot found its target.

Both Roussel's goals stemmed from John Eustace's intelligent play, with the Belgian's fierce cross-shot in injury-time at least slowing the stream of early leavers.

fields.headline: Bracewell silences Cottage rumour mill
fields.trailText: Fulham 1 - 0 WBA
fields.body:
Both Brian Little and Paul Bracewell wear increasingly haggard looks. But while the Albion manager has not tasted victory in 14 games and Fulham's is flirting with the play-offs, only one is constantly reminded his job is on the line.

"Even when we were unbeaten at the start of the season, I had Joe Kinnear, Glenn Hoddle and Terry Venables after my job," said Bracewell, after his side moved to within four points of that crucial sixth place in the table. "I'm getting used to the speculation."

After Eric Cantona's, Ruud Guillit's was the latest name to be linked with Craven Cottage. But the Fulham PR man Max Clifford scoffed at the rumours. "Mohamed Al Fayed was with Michael Jackson in the States last week," he said. "No doubt he'll be the next one in the frame."

After watching his side lose to Fulham's only shot on target, the pressure is of a very different kind for Little. "If you don't win a game you can't win an argument," he sighed. "I don't have an argument today."

In fact he did. "Whenever we went in for a challenge, a free-kick was given. The referee was poor. We deserved at least a draw."

And so they did. Local bookies offered 8-1 against a blank day, generous odds given Fulham had not scored a league goal in more than 12 hours. A bland first half heartened only the 0-0 punters but Barry Hayles dashed their hopes in three minutes of the restart.

The Fulham striker was apparently muscled to the ground by Jason van Blerk. "My defender had his arms in the air, so it can't possibly be a foul," Little claimed afterwards.

"It was a penalty," retorted Bracewell. The end was nigh for Fulham's goal drought.

"I stood there with Lee Clark and Karlheinz Riedle, two Englishmen and a German," said Hayles. "Who do you think was going to take the penalty?"

Riedle duly converted and, after 12hr 54min of league football, a Fulham player had scored. Albion's Lee Hughes should have equalised when clean through but he, apparently like all those rumours, was wide of the mark.

fields.headline: Ashcroft deepens Swindon's despair
fields.trailText: Swindon 0 - 1 Grimsby First Division
fields.byline: Mark Redding at the County Ground
fields.body:
Here is a simple exercise in nostalgia. Take out your News of the World Football Annual and turn to page 238. There, under the heading "Arrivals and Departures", is a list of clubs, from Stalybridge Celtic in 1923 through Accrington Stanley to Scarborough in 1999, who have dropped out of the Football League.

Here is another exercise in nostalgia. Open the book of Players' Records and look up Rogers, Donald Edward, born Paulton 1945, appearances for Swindon Town, 411.

Last week the administrators came knocking on the door here and it was not just the quietly thriving Wiltshire town which took a step backwards in dismay. Clubs the size of Swindon frequently pass through the spotlight and disappear as quickly as they have come with barely a flicker of public recognition. But on March 15 1969 Swindon Town stamped themselves indelibly on the public consciousness when, Third Division no-hopers on a filthy day at Wembley, they beat the mighty Arsenal 3-1 in the League Cup final. Rogers, his black mane drenched and white shirt splattered with mud, scored twice in extra-time.

Hence the widespread concern when news broke of Swindon's £25,000-a-week losses, the £4m debt and the arrival of administrators aiming to ensure that the Robins do not become the first club since Aldershot and Maidstone in 1992 to leave the league for financial reasons. "It's a sad case but it doesn't come as a surprise," said Rogers, who now runs a sports shop in the town. "I knew something was very wrong."

A glimpse of glory more than two decades after that League Cup triumph proved the club's undoing. In 1993 Glenn Hoddle took them into the top flight for the first time but they lasted only one season. "The club invested in players to try and get back into the Premiership and is left with the expenses of that investment," explained David Buchler of the administrators Kroll Buchler Phillips.

Attendances fell 40% as the team began to struggle and drastic measures had to be taken. Thirteen players were sold in a year. The assistant manager Mike Walsh and 14 backroom staff were released before Christmas. Meanwhile the club sits ingloriously at the foot of the First Division.

On Saturday fewer than 6,000 watched a disheartened Swindon lose their seventh game out of the last nine, the winner, a deflected shot from Grimsby's Lee Ashcroft, coming 10 minutes from time. Such is life when you are struggling.

The player-manager Jimmy Quinn could hardly find words. "I said to the lads, if you've chucked the towel in already then it's a poor show. Our fans certainly deserve a lot better than that; they know the situation at the club and they stick by us, but the players aren't giving them enough." With Swindon now 11 points from safety it seems inevitable that they will be playing Second Division football in August, but their immediate future is not yet clear. The administrators say that it will take three months to restructure the club, but the new chief executive Bob Holt says that weekly losses have been reduced and, of the £4m debt, only £1.5m needs to be raised at present: "If it wasn't for that debt then we could trade on a platform of just about breaking even." Public sentiment is behind them.

fields.headline: Campbell's fling has Dons reeling
fields.trailText: Wimbledon 0 - 3 Everton
fields.body:
For Bill Kenwright, who without hesitation cites match day as the most important part of a week that commonly includes some hobnobbing with the rich and famous, this must have been wholly satisfying. With the ink barely dry on his takeover papers his team go and make merry away from home.

Everton's goals all came in the space of 10 second-half minutes and caught everyone by surprise because of the mundanity of the first half. Kevin Campbell helped himself to a couple but for honours he had a close challenger in Danny Cadamarteri, who set up both and treated the Wimbledon defence to an exhibition of his startling pace all afternoon.

For a player who would seem to have a limited future at Goodison it was a hefty nudge towards the manager and Campbell was quick to give over his man-of-the-match champagne to his team mate. "Danny's still young and inconsistent but he has a good attitude and it was pleasing that two goals came from his crosses," said Walter Smith.

Victories for Bradford and Southampton 24 hours before had reminded both these sides that they were uncomfortably close to the relegation places. Everton are much healthier now while Wimbledon are casting anxious glances over their shoulder. "Of course we are worried about that," conceded Egil Olsen, "especially as we have difficult matches ahead against Chelsea and Manchester United. But I am confident we will survive."

Everton might have scored from a second-minute corner - indeed those directly in line were adamant that the ball spilled by Neil Sullivan had passed over the line before a red-faced goalkeeper retrieved it - but the linesman sided with the hosts. Thereafter the first half meandered away, Everton's 4-0 defeat of these opponents back in August receding further as a dour struggle ensued to find fluency on a surface not conducive to possession football.

The header that Cadamarteri aimed straight at Sullivan when David Unsworth drove in a deep cross from the left was a sign of what was to come for Wimbledon. The marking was poor and it proved their undoing after the break.

Cadamarteri was more assured when delivering the ball for Campbell to score Everton's first, after 53 minutes, though it owed much to Sullivan as well. Perhaps Scotland's No1 was still reliving that early aberration. There was also a suspicion that he slipped as he came to meet the cross; the result was that Campbell got there first and Everton were off and running.

"The game could have gone either way until the first goal and of course I am disappointed with both the result and the performance," added Olsen. "However, I thought we played better in the second half than we did in the first despite conceding those three goals."

Another Cadamarteri cross on the hour found Kenny Cunningham looking for offside and that granted Campbell a free header and the chance to register his 12th Premiership goal of the campaign.

Herman Hreidarsson was the next Wimbledon player at fault, this time with a loose pass which went straight to Don Hutchison, who immediately sent Campbell clear. His low cross was turned home by Joe-Max Moore for his third goal in only four appearances.

Altogether not a bad return for a visiting side missing both Nick Barmby and Francis Jeffers.

fields.headline: Enduring love
fields.standfirst: Michael Foot and the film maker Jill Craigie were married for 50 years. Two months ago, following a fall, she died. In the first interview since then, the former Labour leader tells  Sabine Durrant  how she will always be his only one
fields.trailText: Michael Foot and the film maker Jill Craigie were married for 50 years. Two months ago, following a fall, she died. In the first interview since then, the former Labour leader tells  Sabine Durrant  how she will always be his only one
fields.body:
"Her house," says Michael Foot, standing alone in a sitting room in Hampstead. "Her garden." He is leaning against the door jamb, the weight of his body seemingly held in one gripped hand. He says this in a curt, matter-of-fact way. He nods his head towards the bay window, but he doesn't look through it. "Her garden. Nothing to do with me. All hers. I'm afraid." And then he makes a strange noise, a sort of audible full stop, "ny'hem", which sounds like a laugh but could be a groan.

He is very rickety. He bangs his body with his hands as if reminding himself where it is, thumps his knee as if urging his other limbs to be still. When he loses a word he puts a finger in his ear as if trying to retune. And when he walks, it's a negotiation between the world and his one good eye, one arm out to judge the distance. You have to keep remembering that he is 86 and that he has always been frail; that even as Labour leader during the 1983 election, he had the appearance of an old man. He does it to clothes too. There was the famous donkey jacket back then and today there is a voluminous knitted cardigan, coffee-stained and ink-splattered, that looks as if it's 50 years old. He got it for Christmas. But, for all this, everyone always said that in the company of his wife he lost years, that he twinkled, that they teased and flirted, that he always had one arm on her. Now that arm flails in the empty air.

He took a time getting to the front door (and opening it, but that, to use one of his phrases, "is another matter altogether"). He had been looking at Byron's Letters, which he had read with her in Venice. "It was 1978 when I was supposed to be in the bloody government and have no other interests but that. But we had a wonderful holiday. I suppose that's how we could afford it. We had some great holidays together. We've been to Venice many, many times. And then more recently to Dubrovnik, but that's another matter. Come to that later. But it was in Venice, in 1978, I first got on to Byron. Very late in life. I'm sorry to say. She was critical of him on some matters but gradually I put the case. So that was done with Jill. As everything." He slows down and takes a deep breath between each word. "Pretty. Well. Was."

It is less than two months since the death of Jill Craigie, film-maker, feminist, socialist, political and literary sparring partner. She was 85. She and Foot had been married for 50 years. She made her last film, Two Hours from London - a documentary about the Yugoslav conflict, paid for out of their life savings - only four years before. This time last year, she was giving sprightly interviews about her rape by Arthur Koestler in 1951. (She had always kept quiet about it, but the matter surfaced in a spat between David Cesarani, Koestler's biographer, and Frederic Raphael, who believed Craigie and Koestler's other victims should have been "honoured".) "A good witness," said Foot fondly of his wife at the time.

Then, last summer, she slipped in the bathroom and fractured her hip. There were complications with her heart, and for her last six months she was either in the Royal Free or in a bed in this sitting room, a room like all the rooms in the house, full of pictures and faded colour and books. Foot read to her every day.

"I still thought, you know, that we would have three or four more years when she'd come back," says her husband. He is talking with the same declamatory cadences one might use to give a political speech. "Especially in the garden which was looking wonderful all the year so . . ." He waves towards the window but still doesn't look up. "BUT," the word comes as an explosion, out of the side of his mouth, "when it actually happened finally there was a complication with her kidneys and the rest of it. Didn't work. SO it happened much more suddenly."

They had talked a bit in the past about who would go first. "We thought the chances were just about even." They had no children together, though she had a daughter from a previous marriage. Would she be worrying about you? "Huh." He looks down at his hands, which are doing invisible crocheting. "I don't know. She'd be laughing." I ask rather hopelessly if he still sees her in the house around him. "No," he says. "Both of us had the same views on these matters. We didn't believe in any afterlife or that kind of stuff. So . . . aaaaa, aye . . . aa . . . no, she's, you know. I'm not saying we didn't have a number of quarrels at varying times, I'm not going to go into that. But over the last 10 years I suppose we were getting closer on many things. So. It knocks the charm out of life."

They married in 1949 - "up there at Hampstead town hall" - but had been lovers since they had met four years earlier in Plymouth, where Craigie was making a film and Foot was an MP. There were holidays even then, first in Nice. "It was just after the end of the war and we were in this huge great palace hotel and hardly anyone else in the bloody place. But we were so nervous about bloody scandal we had to book two different rooms and I crawled around this big hotel late at night . . ." When they got back to Hampstead there were reporters on the doorstep. "And I said if they print anything derogatory about us, we'll print something derogatory about their proprietors in Tribune the week after. I knew about Beaverbrook, obviously, and even more so about the antics of Lord Rothermere. And they dispersed."

Jill, "My Jill" as he says at one point, charmed everyone he knew. Beaverbrook, who employed him on the Express. His father, who adored her. Tom Driberg, "who would come back from one these escapades in Moscow and used to walk up and down this room and pour things out to Jill he wouldn't mention to me". Henry Moore and Stanley Spencer, about whom she made a film. Everyone fell in love with her, then? "You bet. Yes. You bet. The whole lot." And did he find that difficult? He gives a grim laugh. "That's a different question altogether."

When he talks about their life together, it is people, but mainly books, that come to mind. The things they read, the things they talked about, disagreed about, came together over: Byron and Oscar Wilde and William Morris, and Rebecca West, whose rehabilitation he is adamant is due to the friendship and encouragement of Craigie. He refers to the last book Craigie read to herself, Francis Wheen's biography of Karl Marx ("and she was very much in favour of it"); the last book he read to her, Rebecca West's Letters in typescript.

Politics, on the other hand, seem to impinge very little on his memory. Political discussions, yes. Craigie's arguments with Barbara Castle: "Many here in this room". Watching Nye Bevan speak in Devonport, and Craigie saying "here's the chap to lead us". Friendship with Donald Dewar, who used to live in the flat upstairs: "not exactly a raging leftwinger, but a very fine chap". But on the nitty gritty, the victories and the massive defeats of his political involvement, he is supremely detached. Of his own involvement he says "supposed" a lot, and is free with his expletives. "When I was leader of the House of Commons and responsible, I suppose, for the legislation that was going through the bloody House of Commons . . ." he says at one point. When, just after he had been elected leader of the Labour party, he went into hospital with a broken leg, "I didn't want to take those damned Blue Books, so I took Don Juan." People often said, he goes on, that Jill had "put me up to standing as leader, but that's not true at all". However, she would, he says, "have run Chequers very well, believe me".

Was she happy with Blair's government? "N'yaaaaaaa," he says. "I don't see it. No, she was anxious about a lot of things, you know." Her main disagreement, he says, "was about the bomb and all that, because Jill is still, both of us, strong CND supporters. The government could certainly do much much more along those lines, and we still think they might. I miss her terribly on that front. Everything that happens . . . since . . . I'd like to have known what her views are."

In her last few weeks she was very interested in the Hamilton trial. "I used to go in there every day for the last week and say, 'What do you want first? The Hamiltons or not?' Not that she was a sadist - she was quite the opposite - but she was also interested in gossip and she thought the business of politicians taking these bloody bribes was a disgrace and she was very glad to see it exposed. She would have been very satisfied, in my opinion, with the result but I fear that it happened just two or three days after her . . . death."

Foot has been holding a cup of coffee during the interview, which at times has looked as if it might spill on to the sofa cushions below his waving hand. Only now does he take a long gulp. He wipes his mouth. He says he has things he can get on with. The memorial service is behind him now, but there is to be a celebration of Craigie in Dubrovnik, where she is "the uncrowned queen". There is talk of a biography. He has a "junket" to Bermuda. Something else in Paris.

Was she as proud of you, I ask, as you obviously were of her? He stutters for a while. He taps his leg. "I don't know. She was wonderful to me without any doubt. Most of the fun I've had out of life is due to her and the things we did together. Was she proud of me? I don't know. She was not . . . ah . . ." He opens his mouth but nothing comes out. Finally, he starts again: "On political questions she was in agreement with what I wanted to do."

There is a long silence while he fiddles with his ear. Then he says, "She said, 'Lots of people will come and look after you, you know.' And I said, 'You're the only one I want.'" And we both look out at the garden then.

Tom Driberg, "who would come back from one these escapades in Moscow and used to walk up and down this room and pour things out to Jill he wouldn't mention to me". Henry Moore and Stanley Spencer, about whom she made a film. Everyone fell in love with her, then? "You bet. Yes. You bet. The whole lot." And did he find that difficult? He gives a grim laugh. "That's a different question altogether." When he talks about their life together, it is people, but mainly books, that come to mind. The things they read, the things they talked about, disagreed about, came together over: Byron and Oscar Wilde and William Morris, and Rebecca West, whose rehabilitation he is adamant is due to the friendship and encouragement of Craigie. He refers to the last book Craigie read to herself, Francis Wheen's biography of Karl Marx ("and she was very much in favour of it"); the last book he read to her, Rebecca West's Letters in typescript. Politics, on the other hand, seem to impinge very little on his memory. Political discussions, yes. Craigie's arguments with Barbara Castle: "Many here in this room". Watching Nye Bevan speak in Devonport, and Craigie saying "here's the chap to lead us". Friendship with Donald Dewar, who used to live in the flat upstairs: "not exactly a raging leftwinger, but a very fine chap". But on the nitty gritty, the victories and the massive defeats of his political involvement, he is supremely detached. Of his own involvement he says "supposed" a lot, and is free with his expletives. "When I was leader of the House of Commons and responsible, I suppose, for the legislation that was going through the bloody House of Commons . . ." he says at one point. When, just after he had been elected leader of the Labour party, he went into hospital with a broken leg, "I didn't want to take those damned Blue Books, so I took Don Juan." People often said, he goes on, that Jill had "put me up to standing as leader, but that's not true at all". However, she would, he says, "have run Chequers very well, believe me". Was she happy with Blair's government? "N'yaaaaaaa," he says. "I don't see it. No, she was anxious about a lot of things, you know." Her main disagreement, he says, "was about the bomb and all that, because Jill is still, both of us, strong CND supporters. The government could certainly do much much more along those lines, and we still think they might. I miss her terribly on that front. Everything that happens . . . since . . . I'd like to have known what her views are." In her last few weeks she was very interested in the Hamilton trial. "I used to go in there every day for the last week and say, 'What do you want first? The Hamiltons or not?' Not that she was a sadist - she was quite the opposite - but she was also interested in gossip and she thought the business of politicians taking these bloody bribes was a disgrace and she was very glad to see it exposed. She would have been very satisfied, in my opinion, with the result but I fear that it happened just two or three days after her . . . death." Foot has been holding a cup of coffee during the interview, which at times has looked as if it might spill on to the sofa cushions below his waving hand. Only now does he take a long gulp. He wipes his mouth. He says he has things he can get on with. The memorial service is behind him now, but there is to be a celebration of Craigie in Dubrovnik, where she is "the uncrowned queen". There is talk of a biography. He has a "junket" to Bermuda. Something else in Paris. Was she as proud of you, I ask, as you obviously were of her? He stutters for a while. He taps his leg. "I don't know. She was wonderful to me without any doubt. Most of the fun I've had out of life is due to her and the things we did together. Was she proud of me? I don't know. She was not . . . ah . . ." He opens his mouth but nothing comes out. Finally, he starts again: "On political questions she was in agreement with what I wanted to do." There is a long silence while he fiddles with his ear. Then he says, "She said, 'Lots of people will come and look after you, you know.' And I said, 'You're the only one I want.'" And we both look out at the garden then.

webTitle: Lions lack bite but still book semi spot

fields.headline: Lions lack bite but still book semi spot
fields.trailText: Cameroon need to work on their wayward shooting before taking on defence-minded Tunisia in Thursday's African Nations cup semi-final in Accra.
fields.body:
Cameroon need to work on their wayward shooting before taking on defence-minded Tunisia in Thursday's African Nations cup semi-final in Accra.

Their coach Pierre Lechantre admitted as much yesterday after The Indomitable Lions managed to reach the last four despite a series of almost comical misses in front of goal in beating Algeria 2-1 on Sunday.

"It's true we have had a multitude of missed chances recently, I can't explain this phenomenon," said the Frenchman. "Maybe some players had adapted badly to the rhythm of the competition. We are going to work on this in training. The positive side is that we are a team that creates chances."

Cameroon scored twice in the first half-hour through Real Madrid's Samuel Eto'o and West Ham's Marc-Vivien Foé but had to hang on grimly after Abdelhafid Tasfaout pulled a goal back 11 minutes from time.

Algeria were left to contemplate their next challenge, the World Cup qualifiers which begin with a trip to the Cape Verde Islands for the first match of a two-game preliminary round tie. Once a major power in African football, Algerian soccer has declined as a result of the civil conflict which has engulfed the country.

However reaching the last eight may be a sign that Algeria, champions when they hosted the event 10 years ago and famous for a 2-1 win over West Germany in the 1982 World Cup, are making a recovery.

"If we had played with the same determination in the first half, there's no telling what we could have achieved," said assistant coach Abdelghanin Djadaoui.

He hinted at changes to the squad but Algerian officials said it was likely that coach Nasser Sandjak, only appointed last October, would stay on.

webTitle: Good times for Badra as Tunisia advance

fields.headline: Good times for Badra as Tunisia advance
fields.trailText: Tunisia dashed Egypt's hopes of retaining the African Nations Cup yesterday with a narrow 1-0 quarter-final victory in the Nigerian city of Kano.
fields.body:
Tunisia dashed Egypt's hopes of retaining the African Nations Cup yesterday with a narrow 1-0 quarter-final victory in the Nigerian city of Kano.

Khaled Badra's 20th-minute penalty, awarded after Egypt's defender Ibrahim Said foolishly tripped Tarek Thabet, was enough to secure victory in a cat-and-mouse match and earn Tunisia a semi-final tie against Cameroon in Accra on Thursday.

Egypt's veteran striker Hassan Hossam, playing in his last African Nations Cup match, worked tirelessly to extend The Pharaohs' six-match winning streak, but Tunisia's back four, marshalled by Radhi Jaidi, kept them at arm's length.

Hossam, who scored seven times when Egypt took the title in 1998, carved out his team's best chance in the 42nd minute but saw his shot kicked out by goalkeeper Chokri El Ouaer. Chokri also kept out a long-range Hossam free kick just after half-time.

Egypt, four-times the African champions and the only team to win all three of group matches this year, began as the favourite against a Tunisian side that had squeezed through to the last eight on goal difference and have never won the title.
