webTitle: One system for this, another for that..it is all absurd

fields.headline: One system for this, another for that..it is all absurd
fields.standfirst: Devolution has helped to show up the madness of the way we vote
fields.trailText: Devolution has helped to show up the madness of the way we vote.
fields.body:
Anorak time. Who wants to talk electoral systems (in English local government or anywhere else), when there are so many more pulsating things to get chomping over - like Haider and the rise of Austrian fascism? Who cares about single transferable tedium when fear stalks Europe? Even Roy Jenkins must be tempted to lift the claret jug of forgetfulness.

And yet, of course, everything connects. Electoral reform, in its desiccated arithmetic, may strike nine out of 10 Labour MPs as a losing game they have no further interest in playing - but voting systems are not mere concoctions. They are willed means to calculated ends. They carry their own logic with them. Get that wrong and you get all kinds of nasty surprises, Jorg Haider for one.

We can, if we wish, exhaust ourselves in learned dissertation on the Austrian psyche: but my Viennese friends are much less cerebral than that. Too many chokingly cosy coalitions thrown up by a PR list system which may have suited a country recovering from the trauma of war, but has long passed its sell-by date: too little scope for the blessed relief of change. Haider's there because he is the only change on offer. Cere-digion comes to the Tyrol.

Austria's little nightmare has been a disaster waiting to happen for years an infinitely predictable disaster. And the trouble is that when you start mismatching voting methods to evolving societies, such predictions may be made almost mechanically. Those who (like the usual Tory culprits) are now thinking aloud about the proportional frailties of Europe have surely got another think coming. The next predictable disaster is here in Britain.

Remember simply that the way we are asked to vote has always been designed by somebody with profound purpose in mind. Thus, Ireland chose the single transferable vote in 1922 because De Valera thought it fairer than England's first past the post and better able to reflect minorities who lived within the new state's borders. (No question about that: it is one of the few things north and south agree about). Thus, Germany in 1947 turned its back on simple-minded PR and plumped for a mixed member proportional way to encourage stable coalitions. Thus, South Africa, emerging from apartheid, picked national list PR because it was inclusive, reflecting all shades of opinion. Everywhere you look, with one exception, there is always evidence of minds at work: concerned, logical, reflective.

So to the one exception - the topsy-turvy of a non-system which has just grown under New Labour. Consider: we elect our local councils in England, Wales and Scotland using first past the post. Scotland would possibly like to change this to PR, but hasn't yet (and the councillors are revolting). Northern Ireland, of course, is relentlessly different at every point.

Move a stage up on the mainland, though, and Wales and Scotland do their own additional member thing (two votes: one for your constituency, one for the party list). That will apply to the London assembly, too, but not to the election of the mayor (a supplementary vote arrangement). Other mayors and other assemblies will presumably emerge in similar fashion.

Then there is Westminster, first past the post and rumbling grimly about staying that way Strasbourg, with our MEPs chosen on closed party list PR and the Lords, where an uncertain number of senator-peers may be elected from `regional lists' in proportion to the number of votes, not seats, cast in general elections.

I have diligently consulted experts on voting systems around the world. They, to a man, can't think of another country lumbered with such a spatchcock collection of methods. It is not unusual to find varying methods selected for contrasting purpose: the two houses of the Australian parliament do that. Nor is it impossible to find more complex mixtures: the French blend first past the post, list systems and two-round systems on the way up the chain from parish council to national assembly - but their mixing, in the spirit of Napoleon, is determined and precise. We are humiliatingly alone in our incoherence.

Does that matter, though? I mean, it is all sort of democracy, isn't it? Alas: it matters hugely - not because of some affront to abstruse ideology, just practicality. The fledgling Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly aren't wobbling into renewed crisis this week by accident. They are wobbling because their foundations don't fit.

The logic of additional member PR for devolution looked impeccable. The Liberal Democrats wanted it, of course, but the arguments ran rather deeper. Devolution was Labour's way of ditching the Scots Nats. The electoral system, therefore, had to deliver a succession of coalitions which would keep Salmond's stags at bay in perpetuity in a way that first past the Edinburgh post could never do. There was much talk of kinder, gentler, more consensual politics. But is that really possible when the rhythm of national politics is still so overwhelmingly set by Westminster? Politicians like Donald Dewar, Jim Wallace and Salmond himself wear two irreconcilable hats, one Scottish, one British. The issues they bat back and forth - Section 28, student fees - have the same two dimensions, the calm and the ritually confrontational. Soft words turn inevitably to wrath in this two-ring circus.

Wales charts the shape of things to come most ominously. Already, just a handful of months in, Alun Michael's minority regime stands on the edge of collapse. Kinder, gentler? Just watch New Labour's FPTP byelection in Ceredigion turn up the PR heat in Cardiff. The two systems aren't separate, producing different kinds of behaviour. On the contrary, the Westminster way infects those who have to work in its shadow.

See Dewar reel soon when Labour loses Ayr. That verdict will be conveniently read in Millbank as Scotland's verdict on its first devolved chief minister - but in fact the judgment of the voters will be delivered by a system specifically excluded from the Scottish dimension. Crazy! The Nats may not be able to throw Labour out of the Edinburgh action, but they can keep on driving first posts through its heart on the London line.

The coming disasters, so considered, are absolutely foredoomed. They aren't the debacles of proportional representation or the old, hallowed model. They have nothing to do with Europe and everything to do with a muddled apology for a system which doesn't make sense. Austria couldn't keep Haider in his bottle. Tony Blair will haplessly guarantee the Nats their eventual glory unless he can make the pieces fit. He has started the roll of reform: he has no option, whatever his suddenly alarmed foot soldiers say, but to finish it in Westminster. Not to keep Charlie Kennedy sweet: to keep the whole project from turning sour.

webTitle: Nomvete earns South Africa a semi-final berth

fields.headline: Nomvete earns South Africa a semi-final berth
fields.trailText: Ten-man South Africa eliminated co-hosts Ghana 1-0 to progress to the semi-finals of the African Nations Cup.
fields.body:
Ten-man South Africa eliminated co-hosts Ghana 1-0 to progress to the semi-finals of the African Nations Cup.

Striker Siyabonga Nomvete, one of the few players at the tournament to play for a club in his own country, gave South Africa a 1-0 win over the Black Stars in Kumasi, Ghana's second city.

Four times champions Ghana played nearly the entire second half with an extra player after Eric Tinkler, the hard man of the South African midfield, was sent off for a second bookable offence in the 48th minute.

South Africa and Kaizer Chiefs striker Nomvete missed three gilt-edged chances, but in the 42nd minute he headed in a pinpoint cross from fellow striker Shaun Bartlett. It was the first game Bartlett, who remained tournament top-scorer with four goals, had failed to get on the scoresheet.

Ghana, who scraped into the last eight despite losing their final group game 2-0 to Ivory Coast, gave another inept performance which could cost Italian coach Giuseppe Dossena his job.

They repeatedly lost possession in midfield, showed no real sense of urgency and were restricted to a couple of long range shots as they failed to trouble goalkeeper Andre Arendse. Their best effort came when Bayern Munich defender Samuel Kuffour headed against the crossbar in the 49th minute.

South Africa earned a trip to Lagos for Thursday's semi- final against the co-hosts Nigeria or Senegal, who meet on Monday.

webTitle: RBS chief welcomes talk of Lloyds bid

fields.headline: RBS chief welcomes talk of Lloyds bid
fields.trailText: Royal Bank of Scotland last night found itself on the wrong end of bid speculation after reports that it is about to become the target of a hostile offer from Lloyds TSB.
fields.body:
Royal Bank of Scotland last night found itself on the wrong end of bid speculation after reports that it is about to become the target of a hostile offer from Lloyds TSB.

The speculation comes at a crucial time in RBS's own battle in competition with Bank of Scotland to take over NatWest Bank but chief executive Sir George Mathewson was quick to try to turn the situation to his bank's advantage.

"Clearly, Royal Bank of Scotland is seen as credible and capable of launching a major challenge to Lloyds TSB and beyond. Every business needs a good competitor and Lloyds TSB would view RBS-NatWest in this light."

With the influential investors in NatWest, such as Prudential, Phillips & Drew and Schroders, expected to decide today or tomorrow which of the outcomes for the clearing bank to support, rumours about a heavy hitting bid by Lloyds has the potential to cause further confusion.

Lloyds refused to comment, but industry observers played down the chances of its wading into the battle, pointing out it had its hands full with its takeover of Scottish Widows, which is expected to be completed next month. It might also face competition concerns in Scotland where TSB, which it took over four years ago, has a substantial business.

Sir George, along with his counterparts at BoS and NatWest, will this week meet big investors for the last time, to try to win their support. While smaller investors on NatWest have started to make their decisions public, the City is anxious to learn the verdicts of the bank's biggest shareholders for evidence that a body of support is lining up behind either of the Scottish banks or NatWest's revamped management teams.

With just days to go before the Valentine's day deadline by which shareholders must de cide, it was still far from clear last night what the outcome would be. Concern continued to swirl that NatWest would survive for the wrong reasons. Rather than a strong backing for NatWest's new management, recently bolstered by Gordon Pell from Lloyds TSB, shareholders admit the bank could remain independent because the vote is split between the two Scottish bids.

Of the smaller shareholders to show their hands, Britannic Asset Management, with 0.8% of NatWest, has backed Royal Bank, while Edinburgh Fund Managers has given its support to BoS.

The deciding votes are expected to be cast by Pru, Schroders, Mercury Asset Management and Phillips & Drew, which has pledged to make its decision public this week. Index-tracking firms Legal & General and Barclays Global Investors also hold big stakes as does Standard Life in Edinburgh, which has ruled out backing NatWest.

fields.headline: The Wall Street flash
fields.standfirst:
With a £36m relaunch, one of the world's most famous papers is combining its web and print. Chris Barrie talks to the man in charge

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: This is going to be big. The Wall Street Journal, one of the world's most famous newspapers, unleashes its long-awaited onslaught on European markets today with a redesign of its European edition, hefty investment to back expansion plans, and much improved coverage of the e-economy.
fields.body:
This is going to be big. The Wall Street Journal, one of the world's most famous newspapers, unleashes its long-awaited onslaught on European markets today with a redesign of its European edition, hefty investment to back expansion plans, and much improved coverage of the e-economy.

Backed by $60m (£36m) of investment and more staff, the European strategy is also designed to boost subscription numbers to the Journal's online edition and marks a huge escalation in the battle for eyeballs on business news websites.

Frederick Kempe, editor and associate publisher of the Wall Street Journal Europe, says the move coincides with a change in European attitudes to business - as the euro begins to knit European business closer together and ordinary families begin to buy into share ownership.

This enthusiasm for buying shares, Kempe says, is being fanned by the creation of a new economy. Technology is driving change into the way people work, invest and live. The Journal has covered technology more comprehensively than most papers for some time. With its reach into the west coast of America one way, and its strength in Asia the other, Kempe hopes that his new European edition will give readers a far better service than is available from, say, the Financial Times.

If this sounds familiar, it should. The FT, owned by the media group Pearson, recently unveiled a joint venture with CBS.MarketWatch.com to set up a European business news service aimed at the private investor.

But there is a huge difference between the Journal and the services offered by the Financial Times and its affiliates. Pearson is wedded to the concept of giving its online news content to users free, making money from advertising and e-commerce.

The Journal is taking precisely the opposite line. Peter Kann, chairman and chief executive of Dow Jones which publishes the WSJ, says he is committed to the paid model, where users subscribe to the online service. This, he argues, protects the printed paper from being devalued by association with a give-away service, and will be better for advertisers too.

In Europe on a flying visit to launch the redesign, Kann admits that neither he nor any newspaper publisher can know what the internet will do to their businesses in the long run. But he seems unflustered by the prospect of steering one of the world's most eminent papers on to the web.

Formerly a staff reporter who worked in the Pittsburgh and Los Angeles news bureaux, Kann was the paper's first resident reporter in Vietnam and, from 1969 to 1975, covered Asian affairs. It was another war, though, that brought him into the limelight. In 1972 he won a Pulitzer for his coverage of the conflict between India and Pakistan.

Kann is keen to protect the value of the WSJ brand by charging a hefty amount for the paper too. The cover price of the European edition will be cut from today to £1 from £1.25 as part of the plan to put the squeeze on the FT (price 85p).

Kann's philosophy appears to fly in the face of conventional wisdom about how to succeed on the web, where users are accustomed to free services. In reality the marketing strategy makes more sense once the wealth of the European Journal's readership is known: 80% of the paper's readers are European nationals with an average household income of more than $330,000 (£205,000).

Kann is aware that most US newspapers have made a hash of switching their content to the online world. Dow Jones has decided that it must try to leverage its different operations so that each reinforces, rather than detracts from, the other. This is not a new approach in the communications industry, where technology is forcing companies to operate in several media at once. At the Journal, the most obvious sign of this approach is in the redesigned European edition, where a navigation bar across the first page is a clear indication of its integration with wsj.com.

Dow Jones will also be using its wire services to update wsj.com. Bylined pieces from the wires are already used in the paper. The aim is to take the wire feeds and re-edit them for a wider audience via the website. In this way wsj.com should emerge as a strong blend of analysis and moving news.

Dow Jones executives argue that the wires may prove to be their best weapon in the battle ahead: no other rival internet-based service could justify the cost of 800 staff to provide dynamic news, but Dow Jones has this number on its wires already. The printed Journal, by contrast, has 600.

Kann is also explicitly linking the online and paper editions by giving European subscribers to the printed Journal a free subscription to the online version for the rest of this year.

"The two can coexist and complement each other, performing different functions," he says. He also stresses that different people subscribe to the online version. Two-thirds of wsj.com's 375,000 subscribers do not take the printed paper (paid global circulation, 2.3m). Kann says wsj.com growth will come from both online-only subscribers and people taking it as a package with the paper.

That people should want both may seem strange, given the surfeit of information already flying around. But it may be evidence that the Journal is managing to strike a balance between its different services.

Kann says people turn to the paper for analysis and to the online edition for up-to-date breaking news. But he stresses that the common denominator is quality of information. And that in turn leads him to a defence of traditional media as much more reliable in the main than fledgling internet start-ups. "In defence of traditional media, it has standards and generally doesn't want to sacrifice these across different media and that is right."

Kann faces some tough challenges ahead, not least in the management of his people. He has yet to make up his mind on how to incentivise the staff and ensure that they are not poached wholesale by rivals, but points out that the company already offers bonuses to some.

He has also to decide how far integration of the wires, online edition and printed paper should go. For the moment, not that far seems to be the view. He says the editors of the different editions work alongside one another while remaining focused on their respective charges. He dismisses out of hand the concept of a centralised editing team to act as a clearing house for material - "just another level of bureaucracy" - and is happy for now with this looser arrangement.

Kann acknowledges that the Journal is not a typical publication. The average household income of its readers is high, and its content based mostly on one slice of life. But other newspaper publishers will be watching the Dow Jones strategy closely, and not just in Europe. For if Kann succeeds, he may shatter forever the notion that the internet has to be based on free delivery. Publishers, if not readers, will be grateful.

webTitle: Continuity IRA admits hotel bomb attack

fields.headline: Continuity IRA admits hotel bomb attack
fields.trailText: The Continuity IRA (CIRA) admitted responsibility this evening for last night's hotel bomb attack at Irvinestown, County Fermanagh. Talks have continued today in an effort to preserve the rupturing peace process as politicians across Northern Ireland joined in condemning the attack.
fields.body:
The Continuity IRA (CIRA) admitted responsibility this evening for last night's hotel bomb attack at Irvinestown, County Fermanagh. Talks have continued today in an effort to preserve the rupturing peace process as politicians across Northern Ireland joined in condemning the attack.

The CIRA republican faction was responsible for the Enniskillen bombing in 1996 and is the only terrorist splinter group not to have declared a ceasefire. It broke away from Sinn Fein fourteen years ago.

Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson met political representatives in Belfast to try and head off a suspension of the province's assembly over IRA decommissioning. Prime minister Tony Blair yesterday said that he was not insisting that the IRA start giving up its weapons this week, but he demanded that they make a verbal commitment to the peace process.

Even though its immediate future is in doubt, the new Northern Ireland assembly met at Stormont, where deputy first minister Seamus Mallon attacked the dissident republicans.

"This assembly, along with the other institutions, was established as a result of a process designed to end violence on these islands. Last night's act was a calculated attempt to place them in jeopardy," he said.

SDLP leader John Hume, who was in Irvinestown with the constituency's Ulster Unionist MP, Ken Maginnis, for the launch of a rural transport initiative said he was appalled by what he described as a "horrible act".

Dissident republicans spoke for very few people, he said, adding: "I hope they will learn to respect the will of the people and stop this violence." As forensic experts combed through the debris at the Irvinestown blast, blamed on the Continuity IRA, the Irish Republic signalled its willingness to use tough new anti-terrorist laws to deal with any threat to the peace process.

Deputy premier Mary Harney said: "Once again a small group of people are trying to derail the peace process. But they are not going to succeed. The government brought in very tough legislation after the Omagh bomb (August, 1998). We are determined if necessary to use that legislation."

The post-Omagh laws included the granting of longer periods for questioning terror suspects, stricter bail rules and the possible confiscation of property where arms were found.

Ms Harney coupled her condemnation of the Irvinestown incident with a renewed appeal to the IRA to make a move on arms decommissioning.

"We hope that the outstanding issue of decommissioning will be dealt with and resolved over the next couple of days," she said, "so that the institutions can stay in place and the Good Friday Agreement can continue to operate in its totality. Decommissioning at one level is symbolic, but it is a very important symbol."

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Bollywood accuses Indian government of "cultural terrorism" ¥ Kate Winslet turns down Bridget Jones ¥ The Matrix tops trailer awards ¥ War claims Lord of the Rings victims ¥ El Savador censors allow Stigmata ¥ Tom Cruise on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Bollywood, the Indian film industry, has accused the Hindu nationalist-led Indian government of submitting to "cultural terrorism" after the Canadian director Deepa Mehta was forced to stop shooting her new film, Water, in the holy city of Varanasi.

The order came after a supporter of the militant Hindu Shiv Sena party tried to commit suicide in protest against the film, the last part in the Indian-born director's trilogy about her homeland. The script which has been kept under wraps because of right-wing violence during the making of Mehta's first two films, Fire and Earth, is thought to be about the sexual exploitation of impoverished widows during the 30s and an inter-caste relationship. Home Secretary L.K. Advani has said that there must be consensus between the producer and the protestors before the film can continue.

 Despite her recent negative pronouncements on feminism Kate Winslet has turned down an opportunity to play every feminist's bete-noir, Bridget Jones. Hollywood has just finished the complicated translation of Helen Fielding's fragmentary novel, The Diary of Bridget Jones, to screenplay, and hopes to start filming this summer with someone of Winslet's stature playing the role of the helpless thirty-something desperate to get a man, but Winslet isn't interested. A source close to star says, "Kate is a serious actor, so how could she be expected to be convincing as a woman who agonises between an expedition to the fridge or a journey to the bathroom scales?"

The news should please Fielding, who has always indicated that she would prefer an unknown actor to bring Bridget's diary to life. She says, "I keep seeing girls who would be perfect for the role - my favourite was a girl in the gym who was sitting on a machine reading a magazine and not exercising at all. I nearly walked up and offered her the part."

 Forget the Golden Globes, the Golden Hitch is the accolade that all film-makers now seek. The prestigious award honours the best trailers and this year The Matrix came out top, winning four out of the eight categories: best action; best use of music; best teaser, tied with The Blair Witch Project and best overall. Austin Powers: The Spy who shagged me was voted funniest, and Notting Hill the most romantic. The Sixth Sense was voted most stylish while the most steamy was Eyes Wide Shut - which as we all now know had little bearing on the content of Kubrick's final film.

 Beleaguered Lord of the Rings director Peter Jackson has had another set-back in the filming of the first part of Tolkien trilogy. The 15,000 extras that he had hoped to recruit from the New Zealand army have been called up to act as peace keepers in the in East Timor civil war, leaving the director desperate for experienced horse riders to fill the battle scenes. Casting agents are now scouring New Zealand - where the film is being shot - for anyone who can ride in battle. It's the latest in a string of disasters to beset the much-anticipated film. Jackson sacked Stuart Townsend, who was cast as Arogan, two days into shooting citing creative differences, and the entire set was recently washed away by freak floods.

 The censors in El Salvador have overruled their decision to ban Stigmata and are now allowing the film to be shown, provided the audience is over 18. The official Public Performance office has also decreed that the film can only be shown at limited times of the day and that the advertising must be drastically reduced. The film had been condemned as an attack on the Catholic church.

 Mike Leigh has signed a deal with Studio Canal Plus, the Paris-based pay television company, to finance his next three films. The director, whose take on the costume drama, Topsy Turvy is released on February 18, will start work on his first project in September.

 Ian Fleming's passport goes up for auction at Sotheby's this month with fans expected to bid up to £3,000 for it. The creator of James Bond was a spy during world war two and used the passport whilst passing secret plans to American double agents in Gibraltar during an undercover operation codenamed Goldeneye.

 Sky Television will screen this April's Bafta film awards after outbidding the BBC for the rights to broadcast the ceremony. The television Baftas will continue to be screened by the BBC and ITV on an alternate year basis.

Casting couch

 Tom Cruise has bought the rights to Celia Brayfield's next novel - due to be published in June - with a view to developing it as a vehicle for his wife Nicole Kidman. Heartswap is about two best friends who get engaged at the same time and during their drunken celebrations decide to test their fiances fidelity by seducing the other's partner. Needless to say, the men fail the test and complications ensue. The film, which will star Kidman as one of the friends, will go into production once Cruise and Paramount Pictures find a suitable writer to develop the screenplay.  Kevin Kline is to make his directorial debut with an adaptation of The Palace Thief, a short story about a schoolteacher who realises, after a reunion with a former student, how ineffectual he has been during the key moments of his life. Production starts later on in the year with Kline probably taking the lead role.

 Vincenzo Natali, the writer/director of low-budget indie thriller Cube - which made as much money as The Matrix - is to make a film about four people, one of whom has Munchausen's, one who has Munchausens-by-Proxy, one who is severely agoraphobic, and one is an obsessive-compulsive with an Oedipus complex. The black comedy starts shooting later on the year.

fields.headline: Afghanistan
fields.standfirst: More about the Stansted hijacking
fields.trailText:
What is an Afghan jet doing at Stansted?
Hijackers seized the jet to demand the release of a dissident opposed to the Taliban regime, a stark reminder of a war that has raged for nearly quarter of a century in Afghanistan. The Ariana Afghan Airlines Boeing 727 was on an internal flight because it is the country's only surviving western jet aircraft after the USA imposed crippling sanctions in response to the Taliban's alleged harbouring of international terrorist Osama bin Laden.
fields.body:
What is an Afghan jet doing at Stansted?
Hijackers seized the jet to demand the release of a dissident opposed to the Taliban regime, a stark reminder of a war that has raged for nearly quarter of a century in Afghanistan. The Ariana Afghan Airlines Boeing 727 was on an internal flight because it is the country's only surviving western jet aircraft after the USA imposed crippling sanctions in response to the Taliban's alleged harbouring of international terrorist Osama bin Laden.

Who are the Taliban?
The Taliban, or students of Islam, were a guerrilla group who sprang up in 1994 from the teeming and squalid refugee camps of Pakistan - around six million Afghans, a third of the population, fled the country after 1979. The movement was fostered by the government in Islamabad which wanted to restore the traditional domination of the powerful Pashtun ethnic group. Deeply committed to the establishment of a rigid theocracy, they claimed to oppose secularism and feudalism with equal passion. They seized power in the south-western city of Kandahar and swiftly attracted mass support among Afghans heartily sick of war. The Taliban swept into the remains of Kabul in 1996 and have since established their sway over some 90 per cent of the country.

So how stable is the state under the Taliban?
Rival groups control other strategic strongholds, while a swathe of land in the north, with an ethnically diverse population, remains under the sway of the Tajik coalition recognised by the UN as the government of Afghanistan. That dangerous deadlock persists, while all of Afghanistan suffers. There is some western outrage about the plight of Afghan women under the brutally mysogynistic Taliban regime, but little taste for providing reconstruction aid to a country destroyed by superpower rivalry.

How did things get this bad?
A landlocked Central Asian country, Afghanistan has an ancient and bloody history of conflict. But no era has been more bloodsoaked than the present one, which has seen the country disintegrate as a coherent entity. War erupted in the late 1970s, after the last Afghan king, Zahir Shah, was ousted by his cousin Daoud, who was in turn assassinated in 1978 by the deeply factionalised communist movement, which seized power in Kabul and the other main cities, but which was never able to pacify the intensely conservative rural majority.

An Islamic jihad, or holy war, erupted in 1979 following a brutal massacre of anti-communists in the western city of Herat. One of the early leaders of the mujahedin - the holy warriors - was Ismail Khan, who witnessed the horrors of Herat and whose release is reportedly being demanded by the Stansted hijackers.

When did Russia get involved?
The rapid spread of the mujahedin movement, and the savage struggle within the Afghan communist movement, led the Soviet Union to launch a disastrous invasion at the end of 1979. For much of the 1980s, tens of thousands of Russian forces waged an often barbaric war against the mujahedin, who were lavishly funded and equipped by the USA, Britain and others, providing military aid throughout the decade worth an estimated £400m a year. By the time the Russians acknowledged defeat in 1989, the Soviet Union itself was on its knees, one million Afghans were dead, and the country was reduced to rubble.

Who took over when the Russians left?
With the mujahedin chronically divided, there was no simple transfer of power. The main Pakistan-based alliance had seven bitterly competing main factions and a host of sub-factions. Another coalition of guerrillas was based in Iran, and there were still more inside Afghanistan. In spring of 1992, the communist regime in Kabul evaporated, when the mujahedin entered the city peacefully enough, held 24 hours of frenzied celebrations and started fighting each other.

For a time Kabul was terrorised by wild Uzbek warriors, before the more orderly Tajik forces led by Ahmed Shah Massoud restored some calm to the city. A fragile sort of administration was established by the leader of Massoud's Jamiat-i-Islami movement, Professor Burhannuddin Rabbani, but from the start it was embroiled in savage fighting with rival ethnic and religious factions.

They seized power in the south-western city of Kandahar and swiftly attracted mass support among Afghans heartily sick of war. The Taliban swept into the remains of Kabul in 1996 and have since established their sway over some 90 per cent of the country. So how stable is the state under the Taliban? Rival groups control other strategic strongholds, while a swathe of land in the north, with an ethnically diverse population, remains under the sway of the Tajik coalition recognised by the UN as the government of Afghanistan. That dangerous deadlock persists, while all of Afghanistan suffers. There is some western outrage about the plight of Afghan women under the brutally mysogynistic Taliban regime, but little taste for providing reconstruction aid to a country destroyed by superpower rivalry. How did things get this bad? A landlocked Central Asian country, Afghanistan has an ancient and bloody history of conflict. But no era has been more bloodsoaked than the present one, which has seen the country disintegrate as a coherent entity. War erupted in the late 1970s, after the last Afghan king, Zahir Shah, was ousted by his cousin Daoud, who was in turn assassinated in 1978 by the deeply factionalised communist movement, which seized power in Kabul and the other main cities, but which was never able to pacify the intensely conservative rural majority. An Islamic jihad, or holy war, erupted in 1979 following a brutal massacre of anti-communists in the western city of Herat. One of the early leaders of the mujahedin - the holy warriors - was Ismail Khan, who witnessed the horrors of Herat and whose release is reportedly being demanded by the Stansted hijackers. When did Russia get involved? The rapid spread of the mujahedin movement, and the savage struggle within the Afghan communist movement, led the Soviet Union to launch a disastrous invasion at the end of 1979. For much of the 1980s, tens of thousands of Russian forces waged an often barbaric war against the mujahedin, who were lavishly funded and equipped by the USA, Britain and others, providing military aid throughout the decade worth an estimated £400m a year. By the time the Russians acknowledged defeat in 1989, the Soviet Union itself was on its knees, one million Afghans were dead, and the country was reduced to rubble. Who took over when the Russians left? With the mujahedin chronically divided, there was no simple transfer of power. The main Pakistan-based alliance had seven bitterly competing main factions and a host of sub-factions. Another coalition of guerrillas was based in Iran, and there were still more inside Afghanistan. In spring of 1992, the communist regime in Kabul evaporated, when the mujahedin entered the city peacefully enough, held 24 hours of frenzied celebrations and started fighting each other. For a time Kabul was terrorised by wild Uzbek warriors, before the more orderly Tajik forces led by Ahmed Shah Massoud restored some calm to the city. A fragile sort of administration was established by the leader of Massoud's Jamiat-i-Islami movement, Professor Burhannuddin Rabbani, but from the start it was embroiled in savage fighting with rival ethnic and religious factions. fields.headline: Clinton's embarrassment of riches
fields.standfirst: Debate
fields.trailText: After decades of trading blame for the deficit, American politicians now face an unfamiliar dilemma: what to do with a federal budget surplus totalling $1.9 trillion (£1.2 trillion) over the next 10 years.
fields.body:
After decades of trading blame for the deficit, American politicians now face an unfamiliar dilemma: what to do with a federal budget surplus totalling $1.9 trillion (£1.2 trillion) over the next 10 years.

Democrats want to rescue public welfare and accelerate repayment of national debt. Republicans favour returning the money through tax cuts.

But well before his successors get their hands on it, president Clinton may have to explore an uncomfortable "third way" of directing the surplus: propping up Wall Street with a massive share-buying programme.

Socialists sometimes bemoan the way postwar Labour governments nationalised a handful of "commanding heights" instead of buying small stakes in all the leading private companies, which would now be worth many times the increasingly overstretched national insurance fund.

Pragmatism may force the US government to repeat the experience of free market paragon Hong Kong, which spent $12bn of official reserves to buy into its own equity market in August 1998.

Most investors had bet heavily on either the exchange rate or the equity market falling. By buying stocks to stabilise the index while raising interest rates to stabilise the currency, the government won the bet.

Today, scared by emerging-market experiences, the world's bulls are clustered in New York. The bet has been even more heavily one way, and the stakes are even more uncomfortably high. After their chart-topping start to 2000, US equity markets are waking up to the improbable profit growth needed to justify their present valuations.

In letting reckless equity investors and their creditors off the hook, Fed chairman Alan Greenspan hoped that they would stop the boom becoming a bubble. But the counterpunch against credit crunch proved too successful.

"Momentum" investing resumed its inversion of traditional buy low logic, and a flood of "virtual" collateral opened the way for penniless day traders to chase profitless internet stocks. The Dow has doubled to almost 12,000 since Greenspan's warning of "irrational exuberance".

Until their latest, longest upturn, Americans tended to put their money where their stock market strength was. Some even credited the US with the world's first private-sector socialism, as employees acquired the means of production through mutual and pension funds. "Pension fund socialism" drew strength from low taxes and low interest rates and from commercial bank separation from equity business, pushing savers towards corporate shares and bonds for the best long-term return.

But New York's present bull market has inverted the old virtue, leading private socialism into the temptations that tripped up the public version.

US households have stopped saving, relying on rising equity wealth to let them spend more than they earn. Mr Greenspan now risks being damned if he tightens monetary policy in order that stock prices "correct" and doubly damned if he stays off the brakes so the bulls continue rampaging.

Little wonder that the Fed chairman has recently rediscovered his Ayn Rand roots, and subtly signalled his conversion to the "new economy".

The story goes that the United States is leading the world into a new era of technology-driven productivity growth, permitting output to rise without inflation and profits to outpace real wages despite full employment.

The Americans can sustain their trade gap and even watch their currency rise against that of the externally balanced euro zone, because Japan and other high-saving economies are willing to invest their export surpluses in US financial assets.

The Asian "tigers" need to feed the American bear because no other economy can spend so far above its means as to absorb the export surpluses with which post-Asian crisis debts must be repaid. But even if they do exist free lunches cannot last forever. No consumer, however hegemonic, has indefinite, unsecured credit.

The global demand gap now in prospect when the US finally turns around its current account, and the likely downward overshoot of the dollar if it does not, threaten to make the present pattern of globalisation - the poorest lending to help the richest buy them out of poverty - as economically unsustainable as it is immoral.

Enter the president and the federal budget surplus. Mr Clinton's opening plea is for spare funds to be set aside for a state employees' and low-paid baby boomers' retirement party. But ever the compromiser and faced with the stormiest sort of market forces, his last act may be to bargain away both the tax cut and the debt repayment plans - and persuade congress to put in the money where panicked investors are taking it away.

Both sides agree that returns sufficient to fund next generation pension and Medicare bills can only be attained on the equity markets. With looming Fed rate rises and earnings disappointments finally threatening to reinsert some traditional valuation methods into new economy madness, Washington's budgetary cushion may have arrived just in time to combat New York's vertigo.

With correct timing, Mr Clinton could kill two bulls with one stone: scooping post-"correction" bargains on behalf of America's poorest citizens while breaking the fall of the middle-class gamblers.

 Alan Shipman is an economist at Judge Institute of Management Studies and author of The Market Revolution and its Limits.

fields.headline: Eight hijack passengers freed
fields.standfirst:
Live ITN video feed from the hijacked aircraft

More about the Stansted hijacking
fields.trailText: Eight passengers were freed from the hijacked jet at Stansted airport today as negotiations continued to secure the release of the remaining 157 hostages.
fields.body:
Eight passengers were freed from the hijacked jet at Stansted airport today as negotiations continued to secure the release of the remaining 157 hostages.

Two women and a man were released from the rear of the Boeing 727 shortly after 3pm - 13 hours after it touched down at the Essex airport.

Shortly after midday today, five hostages - one woman, two children and two men - left the aircraft parked at Stansted.

Essex police said the released hostages, who were taken to an undisclosed police station following their release, appeared to have been well treated by their captors.

An Essex police spokeswoman said: "The five are being spoken to at a police station and early indications are that they were treated well. The other three released will also be spoken to by police."

The release of the passengers, which included a family of four, was followed by the delivery of food supplies to the jet, parked on an isolated concrete apron close to the perimeter fence on the northern side of the airport.

A number of boxes containing provisions for a hot meal were unloaded from a police Land Rover parked to the rear of the aircraft shortly before 4pm as negotiators embarked on a series of "confidence-building" measures.

The Boeing 727 flown was seized after leaving the capital Kabul en route to Mazar-e-Sharif at 5.30am GMT on Sunday. There were 165 people on board when the aircraft touched down at Stansted, including 23 children, 20 women and 14 crew. One of the hostages was suffering from a kidney complaint, according to police.

Police negotiators at Stansted made contact with the jet soon after it arrived, after a flight from Moscow across western Europe.

The airport was closed in the wake of the hijack drama, but a near-normal service was expected to be operated from the busy hub from later this evening.

Tony Blair was woken to be alerted about the hijack shortly after British authorities learned it was heading for UK airspace at around 1am, the prime minister's official spokesman said.

The decision to allow the aircraft into Britain was taken by foreign office minister John Battle, who was the duty minister, while the cabinet office immediately formed its emergency unit designed to deal with such crises.

Senior police officers underlined their priority was the care and safety of the passengers on board the jet as they entered their 36th hour of captivity.

Essex's deputy chief constable Charles Clark told reporters that the hijackers had asked for supplies to make the hostages' ordeal more comfortable.

He said: "This clearly remains a very sensitive and difficult situation. We are still working towards a peaceful resolution and that remains our primary aim.

"I understand that the occupants of the plane are as comfortable as they possibly can be."

Requests made for the passengers included tea bags and cans of soft drink as well as the hot food which was later delivered.

The Afghan Islamic Press, an independent news agency in Pakistan, reported that the hijackers were demanding the release of Ismail Khan, a key opposition figure who was jailed by the ruling Taliban fundamentalist regime in 1997.

Mr Khan was detained by the Islamic Taliban movement after it swept to power in 1996 on its way to controlling some 90% of the war-torn state.

But a representative of the Afghan government in Europe said his government would not negotiate with "terrorists" led by opposition leader Ahmed Shah Masoo, who he claimed were behind the hijack.

General Rahmatulla Safi said he was confident that the "professionalism" of the British forces would bring an end to the hijacking.

He said: "We are not going to have any negotiations by any means or under any circumstances with hijackers. We are condemning terrorism. This is terrorism."

Stansted is the latest airport of call for the hijacked plane and is the usual destination when planes taken over by terrorists are ordered to land in the UK.

After being seized, the plane first landed in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, then took off after about four hours after 10 passengers were allowed off.

The plane was next forced to land in the northern Kazak city of Aktyubinsk because of a leak in its right fuel tank.

Kazak special forces surrounded the aircraft and officials negotiated with the hijackers before allowing it to leave.

The plane later landed at Moscow where a further nine passengers were reported to have been released before it took off again last night.

It is understood that the hijackers had specifically requested to come to London.

The hijacking comes six weeks after an eight-day hijacking of an Indian Airlines plane ended peacefully in southern Afghanistan. The hijackers in that case freed their hostages after India released three pro-Kashmiri militants from jail.

The Taliban condemned both hijackings, which created headaches for a movement already swamped with security problems. The ruling Taliban militia, with its rigid application of Islamic law, has been ostracised by all but a handful of nations since taking control of most of the country in 1996. The UN imposed sanctions against the Taliban at US prodding after Washington accused Afghanistan of harbouring suspected Saudi terrorist Osama bin Laden.

webTitle: The Sikh sergeant blamed for race hate mail

fields.headline: The Sikh sergeant blamed for race hate mail
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Sergeant Gurpal Virdi has been suspended on full pay since April 1998, accused of sending race hate mail to ethnic minority colleagues at Ealing police station in west London.
fields.body:
Sergeant Gurpal Virdi is probably unique among officers in the Metropolitan police. Not because he is a Sikh, though there are precious few in the 26,000 strong force. And not because he is still committed to the job, despite the battering the Met has received in the wake of the Macpherson report on the Stephen Lawrence investigation.

Mr Virdi's special status centres on a disciplinary hearing which begins today. He has been suspended on full pay since April 1998, accused of sending race hate mail to ethnic minority colleagues at Ealing police station in west London. It is one of the strangest cases investigated by Scotland Yard's criminal investigation branch, and promises to heap more ignominy on the Met if, as Mr Virdi's lawyers will claim, he has been framed because he challenged white officers he thought were apathetic about racially motivated crimes.

If CIB is right, then Mr Virdi, 41, was sour because he had been ignored for promotion. He sent the letters in calculated preparation for a race discrimination case.

The result of the hearing may turn on a new piece of evidence, which has been seen by the Guardian. It is a letter from the forensic science service which says that DNA tests on one of the offensive letters "indicated that the envelope and stamp had been licked by a female".

Before he was arrested and suspended, Mr Virdi had an unblemished record throughout 16 years service.

His life turned upside down on April 15 1998, when he returned home to Cranford, near Heathrow, to find 12 officers from a CIB anti-terrorist surveillance squad searching his house.

They were looking for material which might link him to an abusive letter that had been sent to him and 12 other black and Asian officers at his Ealing and Hanwell stations on Christmas Eve, 1997.

The letter was initialed NF, had an image of a black man, and read: "Not wanted. Keep the police force white so leave now or else." A few days later, further racist messages were sent to six officers and civilian staff.

CIB had reason to investigate Mr Virdi. Officers discovered the first batch of letters had been typed by someone using his secret log-on at 3.25am, when he was on duty.

The second set, which were sent on January 18 1998, had been printed off by someone using a different password - but from a terminal close to where he worked.

Mr Virdi is confident of his alibis. He will tell the hearing he was driving a colleague home to Feltham when the first letters were being written, and has witnesses to confirm he returned to Acton station to stand in as custody sergeant.

The six other letters were printed at Hanwell station between 7.02 and 7.12 on January 18, yet Mr Virdi said he logged off and left the station half an hour before. Other racist letters have been received by officers since his suspension.

"That is further proof that Gurpal was not behind this campaign," said Sathat, Mr Virdi's wife and spokeswoman - he cannot speak to the media until proceedings have finished.

The Virdis, who have children aged eight and 12, thought he had been vindicated last February, when the crown prosecution service said it was dropping the case against him. He also won the support of his local council and Peter Bottomley, Tory MP for Eltham, the constituency where Stephen Lawrence was murdered. But the Met decided to press ahead with an internal disciplinary hearing, to be chaired by Deputy Assistant Commissioner Richard Cullen.

Mrs Virdi, 35, believes her husband has been victimised because he threatened to expose the allegedly lacklustre way fellow officers were investigating a race attack in Hanwell on March 21 1998.

A gang of white youths set upon an Iraqi teenager and an Indian boy, stabbing them 13 times, and shouting racist abuse. Mr Virdi, who was one of the first officers on the scene, was angered that the incident was not initially recorded as a racist crime, and that the mother of one of the victims had still not been contacted by detectives three days after the attack.

Mrs Virdi said her husband complained to senior officers, but was reprimanded.

"The Macpherson inquiry had just started and tension within the force about race crimes was very high. I think Gurpal was targeted to discredit him. We went on holiday shortly after the attack and when we came back, he was arrested."

She added: "Gurpal was a dedicated officer. This has been so traumatic for us as a family. I don't think there is any future for him in the police, but he is determined to clear his name and try to go back to work. He loved being an officer, and this is destoying him."

The Met confirmed the hearing was due to start today, but a spokesman said it would be "inappropriate" to comment further at this stage.

webTitle: Planning ahead, Promising to return and Punching the air

fields.headline: Planning ahead, Promising to return and Punching the air
fields.trailText: DJETOU SUMMIT
fields.body:
DJETOU SUMMIT

They've already won the Premiership, so apart from the small matter of trying to win Big Cup, Manchester United have nothing left to do this season except plan ahead for next year. It must be thrilling to follow them.

As a result, Alex Ferguson has been on the hunt for new players, and the Fiver has been told he likes the cut of Monaco defender Martin Djetou's jib. The 25-year-old from the Ivory Coast would cost £7m and is tall, strong and fearsome - so he should complement Jaap Stam nicely, then. Djetou looks like arriving in the summer, especially now that Monaco spokeswoman Genevieve Berti-Banide has said, "We are not prepared to lose him."

However, if you want to embellish your squad with new talent like Djetou, you've got to ship some old faces out first. Which would explain Fergie's efforts to get rid of bald-but-also-bouffanted Jordi Cruyff. He's touted him around Premiership clubs, but none were interested in the midfielder or striker (or whatever he's supposed to be).

Having tried and failed to persuade Liverpool to take Cruyff for the rest of the season, Fergie offered the ex-Barca player to Leicester. For free. But Martin O'Neill declined, as he's more interested in signing Stan Collymore. At this point, Fergie thought it best to step in and save Cruyff's honour. "Jordi is going nowhere," he insisted. You're right there, Alex.

BUY JORGE

Poor Jorge Cadete. All he wanted to do was to sign for Bradford. Today, having finally skipped, danced and heel-clicked all the way to West Yorkshire to put his name to a short-term contract, his whole world came crashing around him. Actually, that's a bit melodramatic - the transfer's only been put on hold while he recovers from the flu. Still, when you get that close to your dream...

Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond explained the situation: "Jorge Cadete is returning to Benfica for the next seven to 10 days. At this moment in time he is recovering from a slight hamstring injury. Additionally he is on a course of antibiotics following a fever last week. He is obviously unable to undergo a medical... both parties, however, are confident there will be no problem."

Cadete certainly hasn't let this setback get him down. "My aim is to fully recover and play for Bradford against Aston Villa at the end of the month - should the gaffer pick me," promised the modest Cadete. "I am very happy to move to Bradford and the club is also happy with my move," continued a man clearly not from the same stock as Stan Collymore. The Fiver keeps its fingers crossed for him.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I've worked with some terrific strikers - Gary Lineker, Andy Gray, Graeme Sharp, Clive Allen and Wayne Clarke - and he's certainly up there with the best of them." - Peter Reid compares Kevin Phillips to four of the greats.

DON'T REED TOO MUCH INTO IT

Referees are impartial paragons of sound judgment and fair thinking. The Fiver is not, and was surprised when card-flourishing favourite Mike Reed was spotted punching the air in triumph as Patrick Berger scored the crucial goal for Liverpool against Leeds on Saturday.

Reed says his goal celebration was simply a spot of professional self-congratulation for allowing an advantage to be played: "The ref loves to see the ball in the back of the net when he has played an advantage," Reed explained. He'll have to tell that one in a written report to the Premier League.

Liverpool last loved Reed in 1996, when he denied Newcastle a blatant penalty at Anfield during Liverpool's 4-3 win. A year ago, he lost his popularity on Merseyside for sending off Jamie Carragher against Charlton. An FA inquiry cleared Reed, leaving Gerard Houllier to call him "biased" and the decision "the greatest injustice of my life".

Reed retires at the end of the season and obviously wants to make amends for a career antagonising virtually every club in the land. One down, 91 to go.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Sergei Rebrov is a £12m target for Arsenal and Chelsea, according to the Daily Mail. The Dynamo Kiev striker is also wanted by AC Milan and Barcelona.

Juventus are interested in Sol Campbell and Darren Anderton from Spurs. Campbell would cost the Turin giants in the region of £15-20m but Anderton is available on a Bosman free come the summer.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Stan Collymore's proposed move to Leicester is on hold. Leicester manager Martin O'Neill said: "There is still a fair way to go yet. I have left it with my chairman to try to agree a fee with Aston Villa. Until that has been resolved there is no way we can go any further."

Henrik Larsson has made a remarkable recovery from a double fracture of his right leg and is ready to resume playing. The Celtic and Sweden striker suffered the injury during a Uefa Cup game against Lyon last October and was not expected to play again this season. But Larsson has had a steel pin inserted in his right leg, and a run-out in the Celtic under-21 side before the end of the month has been mooted.

Wendy Toms will become the first woman to officiate in a major Wembley final when she runs the line at the Worthington Cup final.

Aston Villa striker Dion Dublin has returned to light training after breaking a bone in his neck against Sheffield Wednesday in December.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Nationwide Football Extra (12.35am)

Featuring the stunning goal-free extravaganza from Glanford Park.

Sky Sports 1: Football Special (8pm)

A review of the season. Depression guaranteed.

You're On Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 2.15am)

Don't speak when you're being interrupted to.

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 7pm SS1, 11pm SS1)

"Tate Modern. Will it challenge the way we look at art?" asks Lee Clark.

British Eurosport: African Nations Cup (9.15pm)

Eurosport goes on holiday.

Eurogoals (10pm)

Eurosport comes back home with a bag of duty-free and a straw Angus Loughran under one arm.

Radio 5 Live: Football Forum (8pm)

Famous figures from the world of football read out short stories from a saucy magazine. We assume.

fields.headline: Beyond the trash can
fields.standfirst: Zad Rogers on the battle to make the net more than a dumping ground for old media dressed up as new
fields.trailText: Zad Rogers on the battle to make the net more than a dumping ground for old media dressed up as new
fields.body:
If you're proud of the fact that you've finally gone online or think you are ahead of the game with an innovative dot com proposition, then this will read like bad news. You, unfortunately, are just entering phase one of the new media revolution. In the US they are hitting phase three. Phase three is total convergence. It will see the internet move from a print-based medium to an audio- and visual-based medium accessible via telephone, television or computer. As the power of the computer chip doubles every year and bandwidth explodes, enabling more content to be received by more people, the whole world will soon be wired for interactive communication.

I am a television producer interested in the future of our medium. I travelled to the US last week with a working party funded by Scottish Enterprise. We are putting together a paper outlining a Scottish strategy for new media, to be presented to the Scottish parliament. I was amazed at what we saw.

The key question is: has anybody in the burgeoning world of information outlets actually got anything to say? New media is experiencing a phenomenon best described as a content gap; technology has run ahead of our ability to do anything interesting with it. The cyber-revolutionaries have the cash and the technology, but can they find a creative use for either?

For example, the mobile telephone giant Ericsson controls 40% of the world's cellular infrastructure and so is typical of a new media player entering phase three. Ericsson's telephones can access the web and stream video, its palm-tops are mini-computers, whilst its computers are telephones. If you want technology then Ericsson has got it. If you want to know what to do with the technology, well, have you got any ideas? Jonas Peterson, business development director at the Ericsson cyber-lab in New York, compares Ericsson's position to a bookshop with no books - without the books no one will enter the shop. Ericsson needs ideas to drive the sales of its handsets and increase the use of its extensive global cellular infrastructure.

Ericsson is not alone in the search for original content or the killer application. Thousands of miles away in the cultural vacuum of Dallas the billionaire owners of Broadcast.com are struggling with the same issues as they search for content that will justify their multi-million dollar investment in new broadcast technology. Broadcast.com has the ability to broadcast live concerts, events, radio, television networks and corporate messages online, completely blurring the historic divisions between television, radio, computer and video-phone.

Its single-storey warehouse in a tough part of downtown Dallas resembles a prison and not the office of some of America's wealthiest new media moguls. Inside is row after row after row of servers pushing out video and audio to the computers of the world. Marc Montoya of Broadcast.com likes to think of the company as a giant stage, but with a global audience. The only problem is that at the moment the stage is empty.

NTL is another victim of the content gap. Its cabling networks circle the globe, it is the biggest independent telecommunication company in Britain, it has done the unthinkable and sponsored two of football's greatest sporting rivals, Celtic and Glasgow Rangers, and it has done a deal with Microsoft. NTL's use of a Microsoft platform will enable it to deliver enhanced interactive television services as part of its digital terrestrial television and telephony packages for UK customers.

This will include interactive programming, "personal TV" and core internet services such as web browsing, email and chat. The service will also offer "personal TV", where a built in digital video recorder can download programmes and interactive services to a hard drive; not tape. This will give the viewers the ability to schedule their own viewing selection, in essence making channel schedulers a thing of the past. But what are they going to put on it? As the chairman, Berkley Napp, says "what we don't have is the value proposition that will drive the traffic". NTL's recent acquisition of shares in Aston Villa might do the trick, but for how long can distributors rely on premiership football to fill the space that ideas have left behind?

In the search for content, the Ericsson cyber-lab has gone a step further. They are giving their technology and office space free to anybody that can come up with a good application for their mobile phones. They are not even doing an equity for space deal, they are not taking a cut of what these freelancers develop. Peterson justifies this generosity by saying that the more applications there are for the cellular phone "the more phones they will sell", and with the Chinese market just beginning to open up they are looking to sell a lot of phones.

Ericsson is based in Silicon Alley, New York's self-styled centre of new media content creators. Silicon Alley, surrounded by the vast wealth of Wall Street and the traditional media empires of publishing and television, is America's big hope for the big idea. The Alley is a stretch of once-cheap warehouse space that was set aside for new media by the New York City economic development corporation as part of an attempt to wrestle some new media business away from the West Coast.

The corporation's frank message - "we want your business" - has worked. Silicon Alley does not have the cash or kudos of its west coast namesake, Silicon Valley, but it trumps it on attitude and creativity. Silicon Alley has positioned itself as the hip ideas factory against the Valley's chip factory - the Alley is software, the Valley is hardware. At the heart of this New York phenomenon is 55 Broad Street which at some considerable expense has been re-wired for all media access and now hosts a dozen promising start-ups as well as multi-million dollar international conglomerates.

The Ericsson cyber-lab is on its 15th floor. The 5,000 sq ft of office space with a to-die-for view of the Hudson eschews the traditional office look in favour of stressed concrete, mobile furniture on outsized wheels and conceptual art work, badly hung on peeling walls. It has every appearance of a start-up, which is exactly its intention.

Like many established players, Ericsson feels it is missing out on the good ideas because the young wunderkinds only want to be involved in start-ups with their share options and goldmine pay packages. The cyber-lab is Ericsson's response to this brain drain. It is a well funded playpen for the under-30s and it works. A dozen cyber-kids pick their way across miles of cabling as they dedicate themselves to developing a wireless future. Where the Alley rubs shoulders with Broadway, a large banner reads: "DoubleClick welcomes you to Silicon Alley". DoubleClick, an online advertising company, is one of the Alley's huge success stories.

This once shoestring operation is now one of the most viable businesses on the net. It employs over 800 people in New York alone and occupies an office of overwhelming opulence. Last year it posted its one billionth advert online and now services 500m adverts on a daily basis. The technology to post ads anywhere within the net's one billion plus pages is awesome, and as a result DoubleClick's control room makes Nasa look like the driver's cabin of a double-decker bus.

DoubleClick is a typical third-phaser, it is awash with technology and cash, but like all third-phasers it needs traffic to justify its existence, and traffic is the by-product of original and innovative content which for all the Alley's creative pretensions is in short supply.

Success stories like DoubleClick keep the new media myth alive. In Silicon Alley, groups of creatives that have turned their backs on highly paid jobs in traditional media and finance live for the elusive online deal. A magazine, Ally Cat News, further promotes the group's sense of identity while street banners welcome the uninitiated. Warehouse gatherings turn into impromptu seminars, the cafes and restaurants are full of bright young things living in hope, and New York's business agencies are quickly setting up more "plug and go" offices to feed the demand.

New media groupies have colonised this slither of New York as much as the gay and arts communities colonised Greenwich Village in the 70s. It is ironic then that for all the internet talk of creating global, virtual communities not restricted by nationality or geography, actual physical communities are springing up all over the world built around this shared interest. Perhaps new media's seamless web of interactive technology is only a means to an end; a way of creating communities that add real content to the lives of all those involved.

Will Silicon Alley be a success? Financially yes, e-commerce is generating millions of dollars of new business, mostly through its ability to dramatically reduce overheads. To sell an air ticket over the counter costs $8 (£5); to sell it over the web costs $1 (60p), but is that it? Is the internet simply a way of re-configuring business models? Let's hope not. New media is a new industry and needs new ideas to fuel it. These ideas might come from traditional businesses, they might come from traditional media, but not necessarily so.

As a new industry, new media deserves radical new applications, it needs to redefine communities and find new ways of servicing their needs, not old ideas or old business models redesigned.

 Zad Rogers is director of Ideal World Media

webTitle: BBC loses British film awards show to Sky

fields.headline: BBC loses British film awards show to Sky
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC has lost the British film industry's most prestigious event to Sky just a week after Greg Dyke took over as director-general.
fields.body:
The BBC has lost the British film industry's most prestigious event to Sky just a week after Greg Dyke took over as director-general.

For the first time in the event's 52-year history, the satellite broadcaster will screen the Bafta film awards ceremony.

The loss of the British equivalent of the Oscars is the first on-screen setback for Mr Dyke, although the deal was done before he took over. In the latter days of Sir John Birt's director- generalship the BBC was criticised for losing Des Lynam to ITV, Test cricket to Channel 4 and the Oscars to Sky.

A Sky insider yesterday described its coup as "another nail in the coffin for the BBC's coverage of films and the movie industry".

Since poaching the film critic Barry Norman from the BBC two years ago, Sky has moved to capitalise on its movie channels to establish itself as the home of film.

Last year, when Sky swiped the Oscars, the BBC retaliated by saying that the American late-night timing of the Oscars made it unattractive to audiences. But the loss of the Baftas, which has attracted up to 10m viewers, is a far greater statement to British viewers.

Sky has been aiming to build up its film coverage for some time. Insiders say its strategy is to "own" film, in the same way that it has become the biggest broadcaster of sport. It is understood that Sky plans to emphasise its connection with the ceremony by treating the event like the Oscars: screening Bafta-winning films around the event and producing substantially more build-up coverage than the BBC ever did.

Bafta split its film and television awards, which used to be alternated as one ceremony between ITV and BBC1, into separate events in 1998. BBC1 won the right to screen the film awards last year. Sky is thought to be negotiating a further two-year deal to screen the event.

The BBC played down losing the Baftas yesterday. A spokeswoman said: "It comes as no surprise that the Bafta awards will be screened on Sky this year. The event has a minority appeal compared to the TV awards which will continue to be screened on an alternating basis with ITV." She confirmed, however, that the BBC had been trying to negotiate with Bafta.

Last year's Bafta ceremony was hailed as the most glittering yet as Hollywood stars including Elizabeth Taylor, who was awarded a fellowship of the academy, and Gwyneth Paltrow joined homegrown talent at a glittering bash in London.

This year's event will be on April 9 at the Odeon cinema in Leicester Square. Nominations for the awards will be announced next month.

Last year's Bafta ceremony was hailed as the most glittering yet as Hollywood stars including Elizabeth Taylor, who was awarded a fellowship of the academy, and Gwyneth Paltrow joined homegrown talent at a glittering bash in London. webTitle: Time to end this shrill campaign

fields.headline: Time to end this shrill campaign
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Well, at least we're on the last lap. By the end of this month - maybe even the end of this week - we will know the government's answer to the puzzle set by the Davies Report: should the BBC spend money on the new digital services? And, if so, where should it come from?
fields.body:
Well, at least we're on the last lap. By the end of this month - maybe even the end of this week - we will know the government's answer to the puzzle set by the Davies Report: should the BBC spend money on the new digital services? And, if so, where should it come from?

The casual reader might be forgiven for imagining that this issue was of peculiar significance for readers of News International publications. Repeatedly, the Times and the Sun have returned to the subject. In the past three weeks, Sun readers alone have been treated to three shrill leaders, as many "exclusive" articles and a spread of "big issue" readers' letters (all predictably hostile to the BBC, Greg Dyke, the licence fee and the digital licence fee).

The News of the World weighed in with a "digital licence fee illegal" story, and the Times has swung from headlines predicting that the digital licence fee would be uncollectable to reports that the BBC had cracked the problem of detecting digital viewers. Both the Times and the Sunday Times have carried an array of editorials and columns critical of Greg Dyke.

Of course, the News International titles are not alone in their coverage, or their criticisms. Nor do I suggest that an editorial line dictated from on high is inspiring the news reports. It is just that editors alert (for whatever reason) to the significance of a story make room for items that might otherwise not get space, and journalists alert (for whatever reason) to that interest search out the stories that will make it into print.

What is more important than the impression of another round of Murdochian BBC-bashing is the confusion in the News International camp as to what it really dislikes. Objecting to the idea of a digital licence fee, it argues that it would slow down digital take-up, in which it, through BSkyB, has invested heavily. But News International also objects both to a large increase in the main licence fee to fund BBC digital services, and as to a small increase, combined with a modest digital fee. Yet the "unfairness" of any increase in the licence fee to pay for "BBC digital channels no one wants to watch" is surely no greater than paying for them out of savings in the licence fee, which is the Sun's preferred option.

To add to the confusion, it also attacked Dyke for supporting the licence fee at all in his first interviews as DG, after he had previously described it as a "poll tax". Without a glimmer of embarrassment, the Sun ran a "Dyke slammed" story, quoting the "astonished" reaction to his "U-turn on TV licence" from a "spokesman for the Coalition of Commercial Broadcasters" (leading light, BSkyB).

The appearance of confusion was reinforced by the latest contribution to the debate from Tony Ball, BSkyB's chief executive. Funding services such as News 24 out of the licence fee was unfair on those who could not (or chose not) to go digital. Funding them out of a levy on digital households, whether or not such households wanted those BBC services, was also unfair. His solution? All new niche services must be commercially funded, paid for by their users.

But this logic surely also applies to the BBC's core services, especially as the number of users patronising them declines in a fragmenting market. The licence fee was designed for an age of national channels using scarce spectrum. In the digital age, one size will not fit all: the BBC's growing ambitions will eventually burst the seams of the licence system. The most recent Sun editorial implied that Dyke was right when he argued for the licence fee to give way progressively to subscription. Is that now the BSkyB position?

There is another danger in the increasingly shrill campaign of hostility to the digital licence fee. Broadcasters need the department of culture as much as it needs them. The future shape of regulation, the prospect of analogue switch-off, the possibility of looser ownership rules - all need a sympathetic and timely involvement from government. If quiet persuasion does not shift ministerial opinion, perhaps there's something wrong with the argument. Is the marginal negative impact of a digital licence fee really worth this degree of expenditure of political capital?

As for the BBC, it has gained a sure-footed public performer in Dyke, whose impromptu appearance on Today and planned interview on Frost on Sunday will have won many friends, not least in Whitehall. Yet if we examine the words he used about the licence fee, it is not so much the Sun's outrage at his U-turn that should demand attention as his assertion that the licence fee was fairer to the poor than subscription. Perhaps when Dyke thinks about the issue a little longer, he will realise that the precise opposite is the truth. One debate may be about to end: another will surely run and run.

David Elstein is the chief executive of Channel 5
