webTitle: Stunning win puts football in the shade

fields.headline: Stunning win puts football in the shade
fields.trailText: 2000: For those who had come to Rome for the novel but exquisite sight of watching Six Nations rugby in the Eternal City, the thrill of seeing Italy win their first match in the sport's oldest tournament was irresistible.
fields.body:
Yesterday morning, on another glorious day, the Azzurro awoke in almost nonchalant triumph. The world had said theirs was an impossible dream. But the world was wrong. They had made sporting history and, wherever they looked, Italy had the bounce of spring in its jaunty step.

For those who had come to Rome for the novel but exquisite sight of watching Six Nations rugby in the Eternal City, the thrill of seeing Italy win their first match in the sport's oldest tournament was irresistible.

And if the shock of the new brought its inevitable confusion, at least it was a shared bewilderment. Rugby union had finally made the Italian front pages. Yet, even in celebration, it was still swamped by a different sport: sailing rather than football.

Overnight the Italian yacht Luna Rossa had swept into the final of the America's Cup in Auckland by beating the American favourite in the deciding ninth race. Italy was captivated. Serie A, for once, stepped back in admiration.

But even the Italians could not ignore the magnificent feat of their habitually ignored rugby team. They are still bamboozled by the oval game but, in Rome, they always recognise a miracle.

The front page of Corriere dello Sport found the most representative way of fusing together a strange sporting trinity. A 'Luna Rossa, si!' banner headline dominated the more expected plea of 'Lazio e Roma, forza!' And then, at the very bottom, a heroic Six Nations debut effort was hailed - with the promise of more rugby on page 24.

For world rugby, however, Italy's astonishing 34-20 demolition of Scotland will remain the story of 2000. On a day when England and France reaffirmed their superiority by crushing Ireland and Wales, Italy saved the inaugural Six Nations weekend from numbing predictability.

Though the championship may be settled as early as a week on Saturday when England travel to Paris, the Italian adventure has just begun. European rugby should get down on its creaking knees in thankful tribute.

Yet, an hour before the match, it had felt markedly different. 'The day is very beautiful,' Giuseppe Perotti had murmured, 'but I think the result will be very ugly.' Like so many other ordinary Italian supporters, Perotti's flag twitched behind his back as he trudged towards Stadio Flaminio.

'Some of us,' he sighed, 'dreamed about this day since we were small boys. But now we are frightened.'

Perotti waved at a bunch of kilted Scots drinking beer down a side street. 'Maybe we shock you today,' he shouted at the flushed flowers of Scotland, 'or maybe we don't . . .'

The eventual shock was less that Italy were galvanised by the occasion into overcoming a slump which had seen them concede 599 points in their preceding 10 matches. It was more a surprise that Scotland were as terrible in Rome as they had been sublime in Paris when clinching the Five Nations last April.

Though the rugby was flawed, the drama was raw. After Diego Dominguez's four penalties and Kenny Logan's own woeful quartet of misses had produced a psychologically crucial 12,10 home advantage, Italy tore into the Scots after the interval - allowing Dominguez to land a cool trio of drops. The fly-half eventually took his personal tally to 29, including his conversion of a barging try, from the substitute prop Giampiero De Carli, which sent the stadium into delirium.

John Leslie, the new Scottish captain who was replaced after 12 minutes with an injured hip, suggested: 'I couldn't have written a worse script.'

If Leslie's composure was missed, Scotland struggled to hold on to possession even when their captain was present. The Scots were turned over repeatedly in the opening quarter, a failing which bolstered the Italians' growing confidence.

Their extraordinary coach Brad Johnstone transformed Italy in his first match - especially at half-time when, in the centre of the field, the former All Black hammered home the message that history was calling.

'I thought if we were going to win a game,' he said with his gruff twinkle, 'it would be this one because everybody expected us to be useless. Opinion in Britain even questioned whether Italy should be in the competition. I feel sorry for the Scots that they had to face us first. We'd worked on our basics: the scrum, second-phase rucking and mauling and defence. It's like putting down the foundation for a house before you build the walls.'

While assessing the impact of Italy's resurgence on the rest of the tournament, Johnstone underplayed the surrounding euphoria. 'I was happy with the result but we'll have to play much better against the other teams.'

When asked what he had said to Dominguez afterwards, Johnstone finally cracked. 'I said, ''Ciao'. That's about all I can say in Italian.'

Dominguez, the Argentine-born fly-half and former Puma who plays for Stade Francais, speaks fluent Spanish, Italian and French. His English is not bad either.

'The World Cup, for us, was catastrophic,' he said. 'But this victory cancelled that memory. We now must find at least one more victory from our four other games. It will be hard.'

For all his exemplary kicking and multi-lingual sophistication, Dominguez can seem curiously vulnerable. On Saturday evening his face became a sudden mass of twitches as he relived Italy's last terrible year.

'There was a lot of pain,' he said. 'Sometimes we wondered if we had missed our chance in the Six Nations. We had lost our humility when we had some good results a few years before. We thought we were among the best in the world but we weren't.

'So we suffered. But Brad Johnstone is strong and tough, like Bernard Laporte was at Stade Francais, hard but excellent. He rescued us.'

Yet Italy's victory was shaped by the boot. 'Personally,' Dominguez stressed, 'I don't think Kenny Logan is a kicker. If you watch him kick you see he's not natural. Each time we get a penalty we take the points and they miss.

'Their morale went down. Our confidence got bigger. We played a good match but we also made mistakes. So we don't get too excited. Rugby is still a small sport in Italy. But today will help . . .'

By the time he had headed up the stairs and out into the suddenly cold Rome night, only a few hundred fans were still waiting. 'Diego! Diego!' they chanted, with a fleeting burst of the exultation which Napoli fans had once shown Maradona. Dominguez whispered goodbye as he ducked through that short but adoring gauntlet.

Meanwhile, eyes turned to a stranger sight. Big Giuseppe, the fatalistic fan from before, ran through the darkness. 'Italia-Diego! Italia-Diego!' he cried, one name folding into the other. He wore a pair of shorts on his head like a hat. Two hours earlier he had raced across the field to receive them from a meaty Italian forward who had stripped to his underpants in delight at the final whistle.

On Giuseppe Perotti those sweaty rugby shorts suddenly flapped like a fantastic memento from an unforgettable Italian day, the day rugby and the Six Nations finally reached Rome.

webTitle: Me and my motor:  Leslie Ash

fields.headline: Me and my motor:  Leslie Ash
fields.trailText: What do you drive?
fields.body:
What do you drive?

A Wrangler US military Jeep.

What does that say about you?

That I'm practical.

What do you like about it?

It's fun and has fantastic power steering. In the summer you can take the roof off - but it's not the smoothest of rides.

What kind of driver are you?

My husband Lee says erratic, but I think I'm perfect.

Any bad habits?

I get distracted. I like to get up and go without mapping my journey out beforehand.

Any driving test tales?

I took it four times, the last in my own car. The examiner was wearing a noisy anorak which made a rustling sound and confused me into thinking it was time for the emergency stop. Every time I heard it rustle I almost put her through the windscreen.

What was your first car?

A white Mini.

Have you ever crashed/got a speeding ticket/got any points?

Two speeding tickets within 10 minutes of each other, and just small crashes when I went through my phase of reversing into things.

What do you use your car for?

Transporting the kids, shopping. Actually, I hardly ever get in it. My nanny uses it more than me.

Have you experienced road rage?

Yes. On one occasion a man cut me up really dangerously coming off a slip road. I was pregnant and had a baby seated in the back. He was laughing and I furiously asked him why he'd done it. But I would never advise anyone to do that. It's always dangerous - especially for women - to stop a reckless driver.

What's in the boot/glove compartment?

Wellies, umbrellas and all those things you can never be bothered to take out.

Have you ever had sex in a car?

Pass.

What do you listen to on the road?

Classic FM or a good play on Radio 4. My ambition is to get a video screen put in the back seat to keep the kids amused on long journeys.

What would be your dream car?

A Range Rover. My husband has one. When I'm lucky he lets me use his. It's like driving a big armchair.

Who would be your dream passenger?

My husband Lee. He enjoys criticising my driving and there's nothing I like better than a good row.

webTitle: As the lesson ended, Brian said, 'I've never met anyone with a less natural feel for driving'

fields.headline: As the lesson ended, Brian said, 'I've never met anyone with a less natural feel for driving'
fields.standfirst: Jess Cartner-Morley  on passing her driving test. At last
fields.trailText: It was my New Year's resolution, and I've achieved it already, so as you can imagine I'm feeling fairly smug. When I tell you that my New Year's resolution list has read "Learn to Drive" for three consecutive years, you might not think my achievement quite so impressive; but the fact that it's taken over two years and five attempts to pass my test made the day, when it finally came, all the more thrilling. When I embarked on the project, back in the dark days of January 1998, I had no idea what I was letting myself in for. I envisaged a few lessons, a test (although in my imagination even this part mainly involved good luck cards and attention), swiftly followed by lots of driving around in sunglasses with the radio on.
fields.body:
It was my New Year's resolution, and I've achieved it already, so as you can imagine I'm feeling fairly smug. When I tell you that my New Year's resolution list has read "Learn to Drive" for three consecutive years, you might not think my achievement quite so impressive; but the fact that it's taken over two years and five attempts to pass my test made the day, when it finally came, all the more thrilling. When I embarked on the project, back in the dark days of January 1998, I had no idea what I was letting myself in for. I envisaged a few lessons, a test (although in my imagination even this part mainly involved good luck cards and attention), swiftly followed by lots of driving around in sunglasses with the radio on.

That was at the beginning. (Actually, it wasn't quite the beginning; there was a brief prologue to my driving career a few years earlier, when as a student I took some lessons with a joyless man called Brian who told me at the end of my first lesson that he'd never in his career encountered anyone with less natural feel for driving, but - perhaps not surprisingly - my enthusiasm for the project quickly waned.) By January 1998 I was developing a three-cabs-a-day habit that, although handy for learning impressive short cuts, was clearly a road to financial ruin. Besides, at 24 years old, not being able to drive was becoming embarrassing. I bought a new set of L-plates and a course of 10 lessons with BSM, and hit the roads.

Like so many battles, my driving campaign didn't go to plan. Although my new instructor, Steve, was faultlessly diplomatic, by the time I'd written the cheque for the third course of lessons, I was beginning to suspect Brian's comment hadn't been sexist, or even mean, but simply honest. By the summer, the initial thrill of being in the driving seat had subsided, and I was dug into a demoralising struggle. Never before had a basic skill eluded me so completely: I was just terrible at driving. I'm terrible at singing, too, but I can live with that because singing well is a rare talent. Being terrible at driving, however, was utterly galling, because it seemed to be a piece of cake for almost everyone except me. Being sworn at by spotty 17-year-old drivers when I stalled at junctions was beginning to get me down.

But by autumn, I was making progress. Abandoning the admittedly unconventional standing-on-the-driving-seat technique made things more straightforward, and I had figured out which pedal was which. OK, I was still shaky on reversing around corners, but the car no longer hopped and lurched about like a rabbit with hiccups. In the absence of spatial skills or common sense, I had mastered the driving-by-numbers methods for reverse parking, with the help of bits of masking-tape on the windows to show me where to start and stop steering. By winter, I had been learning for a year; at Steve's prompting, I booked a test.

By the time Big Day Number One dawned, I was feeling fairly hopeful. Almost all my friends had passed first time, after all, and some of them still can't park eight years later. How hard could it be? I carefully chose my most responsible, I-never-coast-round-corners outfit, and even remembered not to wear the kitten-heeled mules that Steve had sweetly suggested weren't helping matters. Even my examiner's serial-killer eyes didn't faze me. I started the car and followed his instructions, ostentatiously mirror-signal-manoeuvring my heart out. When he asked me to pull over just past a corner, I knew what was coming. Steeling myself, I reversed around the corner with mathematical precision, but my jubilation quickly subsided when I realised that in my determination to maintain the correct distance from the kerb, I hadn't looked over my shoulder once - an automatic fail.

All pretensions at taking it on the chin evaporated back at work, when I burst into tears at the first inquiry as to how I'd got on. I began to see that telling absolutely everyone I knew that I was taking my test had been a mistake. The second time around, I told just a few people. Not that it calmed my nerves much: in fact, when Big Day Number Two dawned, I was far more nervous than at the first attempt. I was shaking so much that I could hardly get the key in the ignition. Not surprisingly, since I probably appeared to be a complete basket case, I failed. The reactions of those I had told were different this time around. The first time you fail, it's normal; the second, you get sympathy. By the third attempt (when I failed because of something to do with a roundabout) the tests were a closely guarded secret, but those who did know couldn't help trying to get me to see the funny side of it. After the fourth fail (hit the kerb during parking - schoolgirl error) no one knew what to say.

When I finally passed, it was the operative at my sister's paging company I told first. (He congratulated me warmly, which I thought was very sporting.) By this time, having had well over 100 lessons, even I could drive fairly competently; without the shakes, it went fine. When I heard the words "I'm pleased to tell you..." I almost fainted. As an Arsenal supporter being taught by a lifelong Manchester United fan, we'd been through a double for my team and a triple for his, with an hour each week to discuss them.

I don't think I'll get a car; I walk to work, and when I'm not at work I'm generally drunk (that's a joke, Mum). Besides, it wouldn't seem a particularly positive contribution to London's traffic problems when there are all those jolly buses and comfy black cabs out there. But that's not the point. I passed, and that's all that matters.

When I embarked on the project, back in the dark days of January 1998, I had no idea what I was letting myself in for. I envisaged a few lessons, a test (although in my imagination even this part mainly involved good luck cards and attention), swiftly followed by lots of driving around in sunglasses with the radio on. That was at the beginning. (Actually, it wasn't quite the beginning; there was a brief prologue to my driving career a few years earlier, when as a student I took some lessons with a joyless man called Brian who told me at the end of my first lesson that he'd never in his career encountered anyone with less natural feel for driving, but - perhaps not surprisingly - my enthusiasm for the project quickly waned.) Besides, at 24 years old, not being able to drive was becoming embarrassing. I bought a new set of L-plates and a course of 10 lessons with BSM, and hit the roads. Like so many battles, my driving campaign didn't go to plan. fields.headline: Quote of the week
fields.trailText:
Quote of the week: "The point of a ring road is simple. It allows cars to drive round a city centre rather than through it. So would someone please explain why Oxford's ring road is now being festooned with bus lanes - I mean, at this rate, some loony will build a bus lane on a motorway, for heaven's sake"
Jeremy Clarkson, the Sun
fields.body:

So would someone please explain why Oxford's ring road is now being festooned with bus lanes - I mean, at this rate, some loony will build a bus lane on a motorway, for heaven's sake"
Jeremy Clarkson, the Sun

Clock this: In a new survey, Masterquote insurance has found that Britons enjoy driving (82% say they do). More interesting driving facts: the average driver drives 5,379 miles a year, 80% of drivers admit to singing in the car and, perhaps more worryingly, 57% of those who use mobile phones when driving do not use a hands-free set.

Moonie buggies: The Unification Church of the Rev Sun Myung Moon is to build a car plant in North Korea. In a joint venture with the country's state-run Ryonbong Corp, the plant will assemble 100,000 Fiats a year. Production will start next year.

Top of the bops: This one we like: the above contraption is called the Dancikum Dream Commute. It works like this: you climb on, dance, and off you go, propelled by the power of the boogie. And it just got the bronze award in the Toyota Idea Olympics. Good work.

Running on empty: Police in North Wales are losing the battle against crime becasue they're running out of petrol, according to Plaid Cymru MP Elfyn Llwyd. Mr Llwyd says that police officers have told him that the rationing of petrol for patrol cars means that they can't go and investigate everything they ought to. North Wales Police deny there's a problem.

fields.headline: Test drive:  Think City
fields.trailText: Despite being very long and sparsely populated, Norway is as keen to cut global smog as your average Brit with a brace of Jags. Even there, 70% of car usage is within urban confines and, despite all those open roads, the average A-to-B speed of the average Norwegian car is a miserable 25mph. All of which raises the question: why buy a filthy fume-spewer when something battery-powered can do the job just as effectively?
fields.body:
Despite being very long and sparsely populated, Norway is as keen to cut global smog as your average Brit with a brace of Jags. Even there, 70% of car usage is within urban confines and, despite all those open roads, the average A-to-B speed of the average Norwegian car is a miserable 25mph. All of which raises the question: why buy a filthy fume-spewer when something battery-powered can do the job just as effectively?

And imagine if you didn't even need to burn fossil fuel elsewhere to charge your nickel-cadmiums, but could produce the necessary leccy via a local waterfall. Wouldn't everyone be happy? Clearly a Norwegian would, which is why this car is now rolling out of a plant near Oslo. Meet not only Norway's first self-built car, but a true e-car for Europe.

There are plenty of well-rehearsed arguments for lashing out on a three-pin plug and matching motor. However, they tend to wobble when you get behind the wheel, mostly because e-cars are dreadful to drive. Still, the team behind the Nordic Think City's design and marketing have some tidy balance sheets and diagrams to show how fleet operators will get a return on their investment, including such noteworthy trade-offs as no annual petrol bill for a few pennies' worth of Economy 7. Furthermore, in the Think's case, there is no need to budget for bashes because the panels are all made of sturdy anti-scratch plastic.

From this side of the flip chart, the Think, at £11,583 (plus a lease of about £100 per month for battery maintenance), seems, economy-wise, to be well thought out. However, even Bengt Heggertveit, Nordic's sales and servicing boss, admits that the private buyer makes a heart-led decision based on brand perception, with scant regard for long-term economics beyond the forecourt price. If governments incentivise e-cars by making them elegible for free road tax, no VAT and free toll passes (as they do in Norway), long-term wear and tear to the wallet looks reasonable. Ahead of a wider European launch after 2000, Think's initial sales target is Scandinavia, where it needs to prove itself as something more than an eccentric political statement. So is it?

Well, before it moves, it's off to a decent start. Deliberately designed to appeal to young high-spenders, the Think has more than a smattering of Smart Car about it, though it's more grown up; okay, it has only two seats, but unlike the Smart, the Think has enough space for four hefty suitcases. Lovers of the ironic-functional will adore Think's hit-me-please body. The panel gaps gape in places and the matt finish struggles to compensate for uneven contours, but this is a car you can nudge affectionately with a sledge hammer and it will not wince. In fact, because the thermoplastic powder that makes up the thick panels is the same colour throughout, there is no paint surface to worry about. In a cramped car park, it can be clouted a thousand times and still look spanking new. And if someone did devise a way to engrave your mobile Samsonite, you'd simply click off the panel during the next service and snap on a new one.

Think's parentage reveals a parts list of usual suspects, including Peugeot, Fiat and Ford. But inside, there's no suggestion of painful inbreeding. The dash is a bit minimalist and the vents hastily finished, but the seats are generous, and visibility - given a clever tailgate made of glass - is excellent. Time, then, to burn rubber.

Which, of course, is all this car will ever burn. It might be foolish to long for the rickety clatter of an old diesel Golf or the slack tappets of a knackered petrol Fiesta, but there's something sensorially deprived in going for an e-drive. Turn the key, flick the thing that looks like an ashtray cover but is the drive selector and you're away. Be warned: e-cars feel like death on a towrope, but amid the deafening silence the Think's perfect road manners and manoeuvrability trigger a critical short circuit. Dare I suggest it - it's actually fun. From static to urban jog speed it shows real urge, and on bends it rolls slightly but has true grip. Because the electric motor directly drives you along with no need to go via gear changes, acceleration is smooth and joint-free. So despite a 0-60mph time of, er, never, a 53-mile test drive of the Think (after which it needs a full eight-hour recharge) is an electrifying experience.

The best thing, however, is that although this newcomer does less damage to the environment than a flatulent elk and can crash-test EU dummies with all the finesse of a Renault Clio, they company didn't forget to build in some charm. Ford has its hand in the Think Nordic pie to the tune of 51%. Judging by the first test, its fingers will not be burned.

webTitle: We still need to have a nice day

fields.headline: We still need to have a nice day
fields.standfirst:
Northern editor Martin Wainwright tells us we should stop whinging about the dome and learn to look on the bright side to improve life around us
Plus: Run to earth
fields.trailText: Northern editor Martin Wainwright tells us we should stop whinging about the dome and learn to look on the bright side to improve life around us
fields.body:
Britain will be the poorer if the dismal start to the dome's career discredits the value of optimism in our public life. The briefest glance at today's media shows how real this danger is: there are reams of gleeful reminders of the dome builders' hubris, all those vain and boastful predictions which now face ending up as so much Greenwich dust.

A French animateur of Mickey Mouse is scampering to the rescue? Hah! Pierre-Yves Gerbeau is already being written-off as the Disneyland Paris vice-president in charge of mending broken white-knuckle rides. Every sally is fired by revenge for a lot of irresponsible and haughty hype - can anyone forgive that complete nonsense from the New Millennium Experience Company about a "river of fire"?

However, the underlying tone is not amusing, but dreary: the familiar British one of delight in watching high achievers fail. That is why the alarm bells should be sounding while we all have a forgivable laugh as once cocky, but now battered millennial monuments are cut down to size. Look at the Earth Centre, the Royal Armouries and the National Centre for Popular Music which went down this humbling path last year.

Each made blithely wild predictions and claimed - just like the dome - to be something entirely new in the long (and in general principles unvarying) history of getting bums on seats. Comeuppance was simply a matter of time. But that does not mean that their bright ideas were misconceived or that they cannot succeed, given time to tweak and revise and settle down. The three northern attractions are duly chastened, realistic and showing sounder hopes of long-term success.

If optimism had been crushed out of the process, their doors would have closed by now. In the dome's case, without spirited believers like Simon Jenkins at the early stages, there would still be a dismal slagheap opposite Woolwich docks. A belief in making it happen is not an extra, but a national requirement for a post-imperial country which no longer commands cheap labour or runs colonies stashed with raw materials.

Where is the HQ of world optimism? The United States. Which is the world's most successful country? Ditto: the go-for-it federation which chucked out a stale, inhibiting British administration and set out to show that anything could be done. It gave us HJ Heinz, who made ketchup millions, went bankrupt and came back to make billions. It gave us two Gerbeau-alike machine repairers in a grotty garage, whose spin-off was the invention of powered flight.

We don't have to turn into Americans, but we abandon at our peril the good nature and the vim which the millennium and the end of a long, exhausted period of one-party rule brought about. As for the hype merchants, they need to read the American classic Colonising the Galaxy in Eight Easy Stages. With optimism, you CAN do anything. But you don't do it all at once.

Useful links
The millennium: special report
Nigella Lawson's Observer column: Our nation of whingers

Run to earth

It can only be good that the knock on the door has come to Tharcisse Muvunyi, the Rwandan former lieutenant colonel who has been accused of terrible genocidal crimes. He faces extradition to Rwanda from his bolt-hole in London in the same week that the Pinochet proceedings reach another "final stage" in one of the longest legal ordeals of modern times.

The two pursuits, and the parallel, patient operations against the war criminals of the Balkans, reassure those who naturally worry that the lessons of the Holocaust - so searing in its immediate aftermath - will inevitably be dulled by time. There has never been a period in human history when we have come so close to a global policy of No Hiding Place for those who outrage human rights.

Speed may not be the right word in the cumbersome context of the law, but the world is also reacting at a pace which reduces the chances of ancient monsters facing forgetful witnesses, as happens when Nazis in their 80s are run to earth. There could be no clearer justification for Anne Frank and Auschwitz in the national curriculum of every United Nations state.

Useful links
Pinochet on trial: special report
Kosovo: special report
United Nations

fields.headline: 'I'll always have my tuppence worth'
fields.standfirst: The Scotsman has lost its editor - again. And a lot of people are blaming one man, Andrew Neil.  Roy Greenslade  hears the case for his defence
fields.trailText: The Scotsman has lost its editor - again. And a lot of people are blaming one man, Andrew Neil. Roy Greenslade hears the case for his defence
fields.body:
Alan Ruddock's fragile grasp on the editorship of the Scotsman finally slipped away last week. He returned to his native Dublin to contemplate his difficult 21 months at the helm of the Edinburgh-based broadsheet. His departure was dressed up, as usual, as a resignation, but there isn't the least doubt that he was pushed.

He had gradually lost the confidence of the paper's publisher and editor-in-chief, Andrew Neil. The official reason offered by both men rests on the fact that Ruddock had grown weary of his weekly commuting from Ireland. "It just hasn't worked out as I expected," said Ruddock.

Sticking to the script, Neil said: "When Alan was appointed, it was agreed that he and his family would move to Edinburgh, but it never happened. Not only did the commute begin to take [its] toll on him, it meant he wasn't able to put his imprint on the paper in the way he should have done. You have to live and breathe Scotland if you're Scotsman editor. You need to be mixing with the people at the weekends to get the feel for the place."

There is no doubt that Neil retains a fondness for Ruddock, who is generally regarded as a charmer. He is also widely respected for his intelligence, but successful editors require a dynamism and ruthlessness which some say that Ruddock didn't exhibit.

Although Neil won't be drawn into criticising Ruddock's performance, and has shown faith in his abilities by offering him a post on the group's Sunday Business title, other executives say that their relationship has recently grown increasingly fraught.

Some staff whisper that Neil interfered too often in the editorial decision-making process. According to one of Neil's sympathetic executives, this was understandable - Ruddock was "so laid back he was practically horizontal".

What is certain is that Ruddock did not take the paper in the direction agreed in advance with Neil and his senior lieutenant, Sue Douglas, who spends one day a week in Edinburgh overseeing strategy for features coverage.

Neil scoffs at my suggestion that he has been a sort of puppet-master, pulling his editor's strings from London. "It's just not true to say that I've been micro-managing the paper," he says. "But I did begin to get frustrated by the lack of direction. In those circumstances, it's only human to push it along.

"I'll tell you what did happen. Things seemed to be lacking momentum and changes that we agreed should be implemented were just not being made. There is no question that I got more involved and it did get to the level that wasn't healthy for him or me.

"Look, I don't want to edit the Scotsman. I have too many other things going on. I have four newspapers to run and two dot com companies going gangbusters. We're looking to buy more newspapers all the time. I have my BBC career. I speak all over the place. I live in France part of the year. I spend a lot of time in New York.

Its political coverage is excellent, but that doesn't attract readers. He initially worked as a researcher in the Commons before becoming press officer to Donald Dewar - now Scotland's first minister - and for the Scottish Labour group.

In the 1987 election, he stood unsuccessfully as a Labour candidate before joining the BBC's Today programme as a producer. Stints as a foreign correspondent in the Gulf, Romania and Washington followed. He later spent two years as editor of news programmes at BBC Scotland. He joined the Scotsman in 1997, initially as deputy to Ruddock's predecessor, Martin Clarke.

fields.headline: Piers' pressure
fields.standfirst:
It started as a short report on page four of the Telegraph. Then all hell broke loose. Roy Greenslade and David Teather on share deals, city tips and a question of big-money ethics
Share tipping explained
fields.trailText: In an echo of Peter Mandelson when he resigned his cabinet post after his unorthodox housing loan, Mirror editor Piers Morgan is describing the events of the last five days as "a humbling experience". But Morgan has not lost his job. After a swift inquiry into his share-dealing activities, the board of Trinity-Mirror has decided that, though he has been foolish, he has not broken the law nor even breached the industry's ethical code.
fields.body:
In an echo of Peter Mandelson when he resigned his cabinet post after his unorthodox housing loan, Mirror editor Piers Morgan is describing the events of the last five days as "a humbling experience". But Morgan has not lost his job. After a swift inquiry into his share-dealing activities, the board of Trinity-Mirror has decided that, though he has been foolish, he has not broken the law nor even breached the industry's ethical code.

Independent investigations by the Stock Exchange and the Press Complaints Commission may yet reach different conclusions, which could conceivably threaten his position, but Trinity's own probe appears to have been thorough enough to dispel any immediate worries.

Morgan survives, his giant ego bruised and his credibility severely undermined, but the problem itself is far from over. A claim in yesterday's Sunday Times that his deputy, Tina Weaver, also bought shares in a company tipped by the Mirror's City column now requires explanation.

There are also question marks over the activities of the paper's two share-tipping journalists, Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell, who run the City Slickers column. Investigators are particularly interested in Bhoyrul's ownership of shares in two companies that he has persistently tipped, Belgo and Dialog, and in dealings in four others companies - Amstrad, Blakes Clothing, Medi@invest and NewMedia Spark - which saw their prices rocket after being tipped by the Slickers.

In spite of these revelations, and allowing for the possibility that more might emerge in the coming days as rival City hacks trawl through share registers, it is important to maintain a sense of proportion. Morgan has, as one Trinity director observed, "once again illustrated his immaturity and inexperience, but the lad hasn't done anything wrong. He wasn't up to no good. We're convinced of that."

He added: "A lot of what's happened is because of the Sun taking advantage of the situation. They've made capital out of it."

Indeed they have, which is hardly surprising. Ever since David Yelland became Sun editor, Morgan has taken every opportunity in the Mirror to pour scorn on his rival and, would you believe it, his old friend.

Yelland was hardly likely to miss this kind of opportunity. The Sun splashed the story twice, ran four leaders and on Saturday published a vicious cartoon which drew a parallel between Morgan and the late Robert Maxwell.

To equate Maxwell's theft of £600m pension funds with Morgan's £20,000 investment is, of course, ridiculous, but Fleet Street wars are like that. The Sun saw that there was a commercial advantage in attacking the Mirror. Even so, who can deny that it was a genuine story? Every other paper gave it lots of space too.

The episode began on January 17 when Morgan bought a £20,000 stake in Viglen Technology, owned by Sir Alan Sugar. Later that night, at about 11.30pm, as he was going through his paper's first edition, Morgan says he noted "with amusement" that his City Slickers were tipping Viglen because it was launching an internet division. This "exclusive" was nothing of the sort. The internet revelation had been revealed weeks before and the Slickers had already tipped the share on January 1.

Morgan now realises that, next morning, he should have declared to his bosses his dilemma. He had bought the shares openly, in his own name, through his usual broker. He didn't know that his City pair were going to write about it. Evidently, it's not his habit to read the City page until it is published, an admission which has rightly earned him criticism from the rest of Fleet Street. Tabloid editors usually know every page lead and, in most cases, read virtually every word in their paper before publication.

Morgan didn't and the result of the Slickers' story was a surge in the share price of Viglen from 181p to 366p. If Morgan had cashed in his holding straight away he would have made £20,000 profit.

The fact that he didn't do so is the most significant pointer to his innocence. He held on to his stake because, as he later explained, it was always meant to be a long-term investment. Well placed sources on the Trinity-Mirror board say that the fact that he didn't make a killing clears him of any culpability.

Nor, on the face of it, is he guilty of breaching the editors' code of practice. He had not profited from advance financial information. Though his paper had previously tipped Viglen shares, he had not bought the shares with any personal intention of his paper writing about them.

Once the storm broke, Morgan was summoned to explain himself to his board, which brought in the legal firm, Lovells, to help in the inquiry. Morgan gave them details of all of his share dealings in the past five years, amounting to some 30 transactions. No correlation was found between any of these dealings and stories in the Mirror, nor was any link discovered between the trades and City Slickers' tips since their column began in April 1998.

Morgan, mortified by his own naivete and distressed at the media coverage, immediately decided to sell his Viglen stock, which had begun to fall once more, and donated the profit, by now some £13,000, to charity.

That might just have drawn a line under the affair. But the Guardian's revelation that Bhoyrul had bought stock in Belgo, a restaurant chain he had repeatedly tipped, ensured continuing interest. The Stock Exchange immediately widened its probe and the PCC accepted a second complaint.

Bhoyrul's defence is ingenious. Though he has clearly broken the letter of the code, which outlaws journalists buying shares in companies "about which they have written recently or intend to write about in the near future", he takes the view that his actions have been transparent. He has made it clear in his articles that he is "piling in" on a certain stock. "Readers like that," said a Mirror editorial executive. "They like to see a man putting his money where his mouth is."

Bhoyrul is adamant that he has done nothing wrong. "I have volunteered my share holdings to anyone who has asked me," he said, speaking in detail for the first time about the row. "In the past two years I have tipped 692 companies and written positive stories about another 500 maybe. I've owned shares in just four of those: Mirror Group, Belgo, Booth and Dialog. My total investment has been about £2,000, of which I'm sitting on a loss of £800."

In company with Morgan, and at least one other Fleet Street editor, Bhoyrul thinks it's a fuss generated largely by the Sun. "To devote a leader calling for my resignation is so pathetic," he says. "Who the fuck am I? Do the Sun's millions of readers really care? What annoys me is that they are jealous of the success of the Slickers column."

He sees it as an extension of the competition with the Sun's own City columnist, Ian King, who the Slickers have lampooned endlessly. Bhoyrul says: "They have turned this into a personal vendetta and I won't forget those tossers. The Sun has created this air of dodginess about me. In the past few days I've been accused of having accounts in Malaysia and properties across the UK.

"They can keep checking but they'll get nothing. I was asked by one journalist why I was on the electoral register twice. The fact is, I wanted to keep hold of my car park permit at my former flat, and I admit to that scam which, OK, is naughty but nothing more."

The phenomenon of the City Slickers, modelled on the kind of showbiz column pioneered by Morgan in his Sun days, is evidence of the changed nature of investing and investors. Bhoyrul, 33, and Hipwell, 34, were specifically engaged by Morgan and Kelvin MacKenzie, when he was at Mirror group, to reinvent business coverage.

They make an unlikely pairing. Hipwell is a quiet, deliberate character with public school accent, deep base laugh and a weakness for horseracing - he part owns a horse with the Mirror's lawyer Martin Cruddace. Bhoyrul is the more cavalier charmer who takes delight in the absurd.

The two met at Tom Rubython's short lived Sunday Business in which Bhoyrul was a director and, briefly, editor. The ride there was no less colourful than the Mirror. He escaped charges of contempt two years ago when Rubython's paper ran a series of pre-trial articles about the Bruce Grobbelaar match-fixing case. Two judges at the high court cleared him after deciding that the paper's circu lation was too limited to have made it likely a juror would have read the articles.

Morgan believed that the rash of get-rich-quick stories from investors in info-tech shares, along with the ease of online dealing and an increasingly financially-literate audience meant the City had become the province of the red tops. The fact that a single story in the Mirror did indeed affect the market is testimony to Morgan's vision.

But the Slickers' approach remains controversial, drawing criticism even from within the Mirror Group. One senior figure likened Bhoyrul and Hipwell to the characters in Wayne's World. But the affair raises several important questions. Is share-tipping by newspapers ethically sound? Most papers refuse to do so because they think it wrong. But the Mirror sees it in much the same way as tipping racehorses.

The difference is that the effect of a horse tip sends the price down, while a share tip tends to send the price up. So the City tipster stands to benefit from his or her tip, unlike his racecourse colleague. Should newspaper editors deal in shares? Inquiries by the Guardian reveal that almost none of them do so. Some do have shares in their own companies and have savings in managed funds, but they don't deal. Most financial journalists avoid dealing in equities too. The Financial Times and Sunday Business have clear rules which demand transparency within their offices.

We contacted seven national newspaper editors - six of them stated that they do not deal in shares and nor do they believe that they should be allowed to do so.

What matters here is perception. Even if everything is above board, the kind of dilemma faced by Morgan shows how difficult it is to convince people of the truth. By dealing at all, an editor lays him or herself open to charges of having inside knowledge.

Should the editors' code be tightened? It is doubtful whether the code itself, which is considered fair by sensible financial journalists, needs amending. But there has been a flurry of activity in every paper's legal department since the Morgan story broke because, frankly, few papers ever considered this kind of problem before.

There appear to be only unwritten custom-and-practice guidelines in place. One City editor said he uses "the Private Eye test". He asks his staff to think before they buy shares: "How would this deal look if it appeared in Private Eye?"

In the circumstances, it would surely be wise for the PCC to encourage papers to draw up guidelines for staff, especially editors and senior executives, in order to satisfy the public, and sceptical politicians, about the probity of editorial share-dealing.

Undoubtedly the best advice, followed by the majority of editors past and and present who I have called in the past couple of days, is not to trade at all. As one former editor said: "The present bunch are already earning a fortune. Why do they need to make more?"

What is certain is that the previously cocksure Morgan has learned a lesson and is unlikely to add to his portfolio in the coming months. "It's the worst thing I've had to endure," he says.

Two judges at the high court cleared him after deciding that the paper's circu lation was too limited to have made it likely a juror would have read the articles. Morgan believed that the rash of get-rich-quick stories from investors in info-tech shares, along with the ease of online dealing and an increasingly financially-literate audience meant the City had become the province of the red tops. The fact that a single story in the Mirror did indeed affect the market is testimony to Morgan's vision. But the Slickers' approach remains controversial, drawing criticism even from within the Mirror Group. One senior figure likened Bhoyrul and Hipwell to the characters in Wayne's World. But the affair raises several important questions. Is share-tipping by newspapers ethically sound? Most papers refuse to do so because they think it wrong. But the Mirror sees it in much the same way as tipping racehorses. The difference is that the effect of a horse tip sends the price down, while a share tip tends to send the price up. So the City tipster stands to benefit from his or her tip, unlike his racecourse colleague. Should newspaper editors deal in shares? Inquiries by the Guardian reveal that almost none of them do so. Some do have shares in their own companies and have savings in managed funds, but they don't deal. Most financial journalists avoid dealing in equities too. The Financial Times and Sunday Business have clear rules which demand transparency within their offices. We contacted seven national newspaper editors - six of them stated that they do not deal in shares and nor do they believe that they should be allowed to do so. What matters here is perception. Even if everything is above board, the kind of dilemma faced by Morgan shows how difficult it is to convince people of the truth. By dealing at all, an editor lays him or herself open to charges of having inside knowledge. Should the editors' code be tightened? It is doubtful whether the code itself, which is considered fair by sensible financial journalists, needs amending. But there has been a flurry of activity in every paper's legal department since the Morgan story broke because, frankly, few papers ever considered this kind of problem before. There appear to be only unwritten custom-and-practice guidelines in place. One City editor said he uses "the Private Eye test". He asks his staff to think before they buy shares: "How would this deal look if it appeared in Private Eye?" In the circumstances, it would surely be wise for the PCC to encourage papers to draw up guidelines for staff, especially editors and senior executives, in order to satisfy the public, and sceptical politicians, about the probity of editorial share-dealing. Undoubtedly the best advice, followed by the majority of editors past and and present who I have called in the past couple of days, is not to trade at all. As one former editor said: "The present bunch are already earning a fortune. Why do they need to make more?" What is certain is that the previously cocksure Morgan has learned a lesson and is unlikely to add to his portfolio in the coming months. "It's the worst thing I've had to endure," he says.

fields.headline: Let's have a chat
fields.standfirst: John McCain rocked America last week when he beat George Bush Jr in New Hampshire. We all could learn from his media style, argues David Smith The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: So here's the story you didn't hear or read from that battleground for all Washington correspondents, the New Hampshire primary. More than a thousand hacks of all hues and nations attended - but there was precious little journalism.
fields.body:
So here's the story you didn't hear or read from that battleground for all Washington correspondents, the New Hampshire primary. More than a thousand hacks of all hues and nations attended - but there was precious little journalism.

It's not just that spin doctors have become the commissars of thought in any political campaign. It's not just that the number of reporters and camera teams have doubled since my first presidential campaign, in 1992, meaning scores, even hundreds, now wait for a soundbite or photo opportunity where once it was a handful.

No, it's more than that, and really quite simple. Most of the significant contenders for the presidency don't want the cut-and-thrust of serious question-and-answer, or the danger of unrehearsed conversation - the mother's milk, after all, of any political journalism worthy of the name.

And these days their handlers go to extraordinary lengths to prevent it. You lose count of the times it happens in this campaign. There you are, standing on the rope line that segregates media from one of those carefully-choreographed campaign stops. The candidate inches towards your camera, shaking hands, patting backs, dispensing kisses and hugs. He is six feet away from you, looking your way, knows who and what you are. Then the minder appears, ducking below your camera, pointing the finger, whispering "no questions, no questions".

If you do your job, and shout your question anyway, you get a yellow card and a handler takes your name and organisation, hinting darkly about privileges denied. That happened to me twice last week, once with Al Gore and again with George Bush. A BBC colleague thought he was about to be arrested one day for trying to get up too close and too personal to a candidate, in his case Bill Bradley.

This is a far cry from Bill Clinton's campaign in 1992, even Bob Dole's in 1996. Clinton once told me how useful he found the banter on the rope-line, felt it made him a sharper candidate. "I learn what's on your mind from your questions, I have a sense of the day's news agenda from talking to you all," he said.

"These days it's a farce, compared to what it was, and what it should be," says Joe Klein, writer for the New Yorker magazine. "Politicians who say they want to talk to people now go out of their way to avoid journalists."

The foreign correspondent in me knows that, of course, you are worth few votes. The years teach you that you represent a low priority for the campaign gurus, understandably so.

In my world, on a campaign like this, you make your own luck. You engineer your chances to talk with a candidate, and you shoot straight when the moment comes. You cultivate those close to them, asking whatever is on your mind. You talk to as many ordinary people, those voters, as you can, constantly weighing the discrepancy between spin and reality. But you never treat a spin doctor as a friend, because that's when you stop asking your questions.

What's so telling is that US journalists, even the important and illustrious, often have time with most of the candidates on strict, new terms. Questions are invariably pre-agreed, limited to specific areas, confined to three or four soundbites that a campaign wants to communicate that day. "It's a bit embarassing," says one network producer as she waited for Governor George Bush to be interviewed. "You want your correspondent to be seen asking questions, but the answers are pre-scripted bites . . . it's all formula now."

Of course, some journalists go beyond that. A handful do spend time with the candidate of their choice, they do have unfettered access. But, increasingly, that does not produce impromptu exchanges that might take us beyond the daily diet of spin and prescribed messaging.

One of the sights of this New Hampshire campaign was Ted Koppel, the doyen of TV news questioners, using his undoubted access to ask Vice-President Al Gore why he doesn't stop and talk to reporters, take questions, speak to the millions on the other end of the cameras. "I'm too busy trying to talk to the people," Gore insisted before abruptly ending their conversation.

When we saw Koppel the day after, he was wondering aloud about the state we are all in. "It's getting harder all the time to do real journalism," he remarked. Three days later, in the immediate aftermath of Gore's victory, Koppel asked the vice-president the same, relatively simple question three times on the air. He didn't get an answer.

Happily, there has been one notable exception to the Rule 2000, the code of candidate silence - John McCain. To watch McCain, on a rolling press conference of a bus called the Straight Talk Express, is to watch a seasoned practitioner at work: a candidate comfortable enough with himself, his views, his strengths, his weaknesses to shoot the breeze with reporters at any time of day or night. A politician smart enough to know he can talk his way on to an airwave that might, otherwise, cost him a fortune.

Having spent a morning with him in the dark days of last November, when he barely registered a blip on the radar poll, and having seen him again last week, I know McCain's candidacy was built this way. He knows no other way. And, in any event, there wasn't the cash for anything else.

"I was a bit sceptical about his wish for open access at the beginning, I imagined all the holes he might dig for himself," says Mike Murphy, the witty, rather quirky Republican figure who is McCain's campaign guru. "Then you think about the image he creates. There he is, night after night, riding our bus, taking questions from all you guys. It's a powerful image of authenticity and open government."

Significantly, exit pollsters found voters making positive reference to those TV images of candidate candour on McCain's bus as they gave McCain a landslide victory in New Hampshire. "I believe it is the most important message coming out of New Hampshire," says Klein, who works harder than most at asking his questions. "After Clinton, people want to know they have a guy who can take any question, look them in the eye, and tell them what he knows or believes. McCain does that every day, on the bus or at town meeting, and people sense that."

And so this campaign moves on to South Carolina, Michigan, New York, California. The window for asking questions, for a candidate's straight talk, grows ever smaller. Before long, this race will be defined by paid advertisements on the telly. But the opening round suggests the ultimate variable - public opinion - is demanding a lot less spin machinery: a little more journalism. Alastair Campbell might want to watch.

David Smith is Washington correspondent for Channel 4 News. This is the first of his regular reports from the campaign trail.

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Interview: Nick Brown
fields.trailText: Newspapers: Everyday reading is the daily Labour party media brief, Maff press cuttings, the Guardian and the Newcastle Evening Chronicle. And I try to read as many Sundays as I can. I read stuff I agree with and stuff I don't agree with. I think Steve Bell is tremendous.
fields.body:
Newspapers: Everyday reading is the daily Labour party media brief, Maff press cuttings, the Guardian and the Newcastle Evening Chronicle. And I try to read as many Sundays as I can. I read stuff I agree with and stuff I don't agree with. I think Steve Bell is tremendous.

Magazines: Private Eye is a must. I think St Albion Parish News is very, very funny, although of course not accurate. I just enjoy the irreverent humour. I also have a subscription to Tribune.

Books: Anything relating to humour, politics, biography and history (particularly 17th-century history). Favourites are George MacDonald Fraser's Flashman novels and anything by Tom Sharpe. Also: C V Wedgwood's Essays on History and the English Civil War. The last books I read were Fatal Protein (The Story of CJD, BSE and other Prion Diseases) by Rosalind M Ridley and Harry F Baker and Every Man a King: The Autobiography of Huey P Long.

Film: I especially like gangster films, political and crime thrillers. My all-time favourite films are Miller's Crossing, The Long Good Friday and Fargo. The last films I saw were Elizabeth, Shakespeare in Love and Gods and Monsters. I saw the lot on a long-haul flight to New Zealand. I thought Elizabeth was the outstanding one of the three. The direction was particularly imaginative.

Television: Regular viewing is The Simpsons and Sunday lunchtime political coverage. I don't get to see very much TV because of the hours I work - the truth is, if I've got spare time to myself I will almost certainly spend it listening to music, mostly classical.

Radio: Today, the Sunday omnibus of The Archers and Desert Island Discs are all regular listening.

Ads: None. All go straight out of my head.

Multimedia: AOL News, plus regular online shopping for books and CDs. I can never pass up on the Freecell card game - it's incredibly addictive. I also have a digital camera.

fields.headline: Whitehall's war on me
fields.standfirst:
First he was arrested. Then he was blacklisted. Then came the poison-pen letters. So what had journalist Tony Geraghty done? He'd refused to 'volunteer' his book for official censorship. Here, writing for the first time since the ordeal ended, he relives his year-long nightmare

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: First he was arrested. Then he was blacklisted. Then came the poison-pen letters. So what had journalist Tony Geraghty done? He'd refused to 'volunteer' his book for official censorship. Here, writing for the first time since the ordeal ended, he relives his year-long nightmare
fields.body:
Censorship arrived on my doorstep before dawn one December morning in 1998 on 12 legs, two of them female. As a nocturnal Celt I am not at my best before 10am. So when I answered the insistent knock, I had to count the legs and divide by two in order to register the reality of Freedom of Expression in Blair's Britain. A team of six detectives from the ministry of defence clustered together on the path before my tiny Herefordshire cottage. In the gloom they might have been a collective, pantomime dragon.

Undeterred by the fact that I am a civilian and that their jurisdiction covers Defence property and people, they arrested me and searched the house (including the soiled linen) for almost eight hours. When they left, my computer, files and floppies went with them, never to return. I was ushered into their unmarked car and we went in search of the local nick. I, their prisoner, had to direct them there so that they could begin a five-hour session of interrogation and imprisonment.

The cause of all this fuss is still, in some significant details, unclear but I gathered that it all had to do with my most recent book, The Irish War, an account of The Troubles. They have got me into trouble more than once. During the illegal military curfew imposed upon the Falls Road, Belfast, in 1970, I was arrested at gunpoint (theirs, not mine) and accused of behaviour likely to break the peace. As it happened, I was the only person in sight who was not armed and dangerous . . . but that is another story.

This time, to judge from the questions put to me, the trouble was that I had mentioned the generic names of some software programmes and had somehow breached section 5 of the official secrets act 1989. There was one small problem with this scenario. Nothing I had written had damaged military security (as the law sensibly requires for a crime of this sort to be proved). Nor had I put lives at risk. Even more curious, those pursuing me already had a shrewd idea that they were barking up the wrong tree. My own inquiries since have confirmed that the MoD knew that I had caused embarrassment to one or two sensitive souls but no damage to military operations.

Thirteen months later, a newly appointed attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn, intervened to halt the prosecution of me. I had lost most of a year's work - a serious matter for a professional, self-employed writer - and much else. The MoD felt confident enough to write to my publisher, HarperCollins, strongly advising the firm not to publish the paperback version of a book that remained on sale as a hardback, untouched by official action. HarperCollins, colluding with this act of censorship, obligingly suppressed the book.

My work as military consultant to a television drama team was blighted by the MoD's warning that I was, effectively, blacklisted from setting foot on military property. The drama, entitled Bomber and screened as a two-parter earlier this month, was shot at an army camp.

The knife was twisted further by a claim that the "damage" I had caused was financial - around £170,000, the alleged cost of changing software names - and that I should be forced to make it good. And then, coincidentally, came a series of poison-pen letters and telephone calls to my allies around the country, made by an anonymous "friend of Tony Geraghty", and calculated to blacken my reputation. What might have started as a legal process now looked more like a private vendetta.

To begin to comprehend this bizarre series of events, it is necessary to look at what television drama calls "the back story". Over the years, as an experienced military writer, I have learned to trust my sources and discuss with them, on equal terms, the way I am shaping their experiences. It is a sophisticated version of the journalistic lobby system. I have learned not to trust the officially appointed channels for such transactions. The MoD has more than one. Civilian writers are expected to volunteer their unpublished work for "clearance" by the secretary of the defence, press and broadcasting advisory committee.

This body includes token journalists to give it a patina of democratic cover. In practice, manuscripts submitted to it by gullible, if patriotic, authors are leaked to a variety of departments, ranging from MI5 to the SAS. These in turn run a textual analysis on the material and begin a mole hunt for the author's sources. How do I know that such leaks occur? Because I was the intended beneficiary of one: a proof copy of the uncensored version of Mark Urban's book about Ireland, Big Boys' Rules.

The other, more powerful censorship team is run from the secretariat, home and special forces of MoD. It is this department which feels sufficiently confident to instruct publishers what they will and will not publish, without troubling with such trifles as injunctions or other legal processes. Through the back stairs of the ministry, the avuncular secretary of the D-notice committee, as my inquiries have discovered, works in practice for the secretariat, a body which does not include journalists among its ranks.

In August 1998, two months before The Irish War was due to appear, the secretary - a retired rear-admiral - contacted HarperCollins, seeking sight of part of the book devoted to the activities of the SAS. I refused access. Not only did I distrust the system: I had tried, at the outset of my research, to involve the army at a senior level, on lobby terms, in my attempt to reconstruct the essential truths of Britain's last colonial war. This time, following an unannounced restriction on co-operation of that sort, I was left to go my own way. That was no problem. But I assuredly resented the implication that when the work was done, I would accept the hidden hand of the censor to edit the manuscript. I said as much to HarperCollins.

The admiral was not a happy sailor. He took advice and decided to let the matter go rather than seek an injunction and accept the odium of public censorship. Had he followed that legal route, it would have blown the hypocritical cover that the D-notice system is voluntary. Still, he wrote to say that once the book was published he would look at it again and notify HarperCollins of anything he thought necessary. The book appeared. He took no action. But his controller in secretariat, home and special forces, did move. The result was the raid on my home; two interrogation sessions, an appearance in the dock at Bow Street and prosecution for an offence which, on conviction, could have put me in prison for two years.

At the end of it all, the crown prosecution service concluded that there was insufficient evidence against me. Or, to put it another way, the prosecution did not have a viable case. The MoD will not have entirely wasted its time. The next time an author is invited to "volunteer" his work for censorship, he will think twice before refusing. Refusal, as my case demonstrates, may be followed by a year's harassment, threat of financial ruin and imprisonment. That is how it is in the Kingdom of the Blair, where the one-eyed man, if he is wise, will pretend to be as blind as the rest.

There is no unalloyed pleasure in this life, even in Whitehall. The negative outcome of the aborted action against me will tempt some bold writers to use classified documents without inhibition in future, so long as they avoid damage. The signs are that this is beginning to happen. Within days of my release from official harassment, BBC Radio 4 uniquely announced that it was quoting from "classified" military material to reveal shortcomings in the British invasion of Kosovo. Clearly, knowledge of such failures would help the next potential enemy. But no one seemed anxious to raid the BBC or arrest its excellent correspondent, Andrew Gilligan.

fields.headline: Trust the people
fields.standfirst: Last week, judges dismissed the BBC's bid to televise the Lockerbie trial. So will we all miss the chance to see justice in action?  Nick Catliff wonders why we're not able to . . .

fields.body:
It has been a fraught few days in the increasingly murky story of the televising, or probable non-televising, of the Lockerbie trial. Edinburgh's legal circles are always awash with delicious rumours and scandals. Like legal gossip everywhere, these are usually of a parochial nature but the build up to the Lockerbie trial is spawning a new level of conspiracy theory.

The rumour now being circulated by well-placed lawyers is that the trial is being partly funded by the American justice department. Part of the price for that funding is the presence of a private camera in the courtroom. That camera will send an encrypted signal to the victims of the relatives and, one assumes, justice department officials in Washington. A sort of private television show, not for use by the general public.

That's what I'm being told off the record, but what is as clear as day is that the Scottish legal establishment seems determined not to allow any other camera into their courtroom. Last Wednesday, lawyers representing BBC Scotland applied to the high court in Edinburgh for leave to discuss allowing television reporting of the Lockerbie trial.

The judge dismissed the application without even hearing the BBC's case because, he decided, that the BBC had "no locus". In other words, it had no right to be heard at all and the question of whether the trial should be filmed was simply nothing to do with them. No cameras in court was the emphatic message.

I heard the news from a well-placed insider in Edinburgh legal circles. He and I have been talking about the Lockerbie issue on and off since autumn 1998. At times, we have been optimistic about the chances of filming this trial, but increasingly our mood has been one of utter frustration. It has been announced that the BBC will go back to court for another try next month but the Scottish judiciary looks determined to keep the cameras out of what will be the most important criminal trial in British legal history. In the process, they will waste a golden opportunity to show the world that this trial is fair.

In 1998, when the issue first arose the atmosphere was very different. Scotland's senior judge, the Lord President, reassured interested parties that filming of the trial would be possible and that it would be governed by the usual guidelines.

These guidelines had been drawn up in 1994 to allow limited filming of trials in Scotland. This was possible simply because the 1925 criminal justice act, which banned cameras in court in England and Wales, had never been passed in Scotland.

In the early 90s, Scotland's progressive and self-confident judiciary felt that it would be a good idea to allow limited television access, and so open up the administration of justice to an audience rather wider than the scattering of oddballs that usually inhabits the public gallery.

That this spirit of glasnost seemed likely to extend to the Lockerbie trial echoed the flexibility and imagination shown by Scotland's senior judiciary and prosecuting authorities in their handling of the Lockerbie case throughout 1998. Their masterstroke had been to arrange for the trial to take place under Scottish law, but in the safe neutral venue of a disused military base in the Netherlands.

As soon as they knew the trial was definitely going to take place, television news organisations turned their attention to getting their cameras into court. Led by BBC Scotland, the arguments for getting access to the court, and for amending the 1994 guidelines, were prepared.

As they stood, the guidelines would only allow filming of a trial for use in a "documentary" to be transmitted after the case was over. As a documentary-maker, that has always suited me, but BBC Scotland, like every other UK and American news operation, wanted on-the-day news access.

The usual argument against this is that contemporaneous coverage could prejudice a jury. But in this case there was to be no jury, just a panel of senior judges, and so no risk of prejudice. This was one of the issues that the BBC wanted to argue in court.

But the arguments never got aired and it seems that the whole issue was decided privately in a series of quiet chats among senior legal figures in Edinburgh some time last year. The Lord Advocate has let it be known that the trial would not be filmed.

Quite why the announcement came from the prosecution side as opposed to the court administration is unclear. Either way, it looks like a fait accompli since this hard-line stance appears to have been accepted by all parties. Many are surprised that the defence appears happy to miss the opportunity for their trial to take place under the scrutiny of television coverage, although I do know that one of their solicitors, Alistair Duff, is opposed to allowing cameras into court as a matter of principle.

Equally, we don't know why the judiciary wants to keep the case as low-profile as possible. On a personal level, I find it ironic that the Lockerbie trial judge is Lord Sutherland, whom I worked with in 1994, while making the BBC series The Trial. Then he calmly and very happily presided over the first ever trial to be filmed in a Scottish high court.

But the policy of quietly ruling out any filming has caused some problems. "What about us?" say the families of the victims, who understandably aren't happy about having to spend months in the Netherlands if they want to see the alleged murderers of their loved ones face justice. After all, the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia down the road in The Hague successfully allows continuous coverage of its cases, so it's perfectly possible.

The answer the families received seems clever but is in fact bizarre. Last August, Lord Hardy told the relatives that they would be able to watch the trial via a specially encrypted narrow-cast available only to them. The world's news cameras will have to wait outside the courthouse while inside the entire proceedings will be filmed and shown to select audiences in Scotland, England and the US.

It appears that the US justice department's office for the victims of crime will pay for the satellite link back to America. It is an idea lifted from the Oklahoma bombing trial, where it was felt that live coverage of that recent and appalling crime might prejudice a local jury.

Yet with Lockerbie the case is more than 11 years old, and there is no jury. The truth is that there is no technical or legal reason why their signal should not be pooled with TV news, which is another issue the BBC and interested news organisations would have liked to raise in court.

What puzzles me and anyone else who knows the guidelines and the system for filming in Scottish courts is how the court can justify the presence of a narrow-cast system. The guidelines refer only to the presence of cameras - not the audience to which those pictures will be shown. Live or near live coverage of criminal trials is specifically banned. In addition, cameras are only allowed into court with the consent of everyone who will be filmed. At Wednesday's brief hearing, the issue was raised in conversation and much confusion ensued. Those who were present tell me that it was abundantly clear that neither the trial judge nor the defence had ever been asked for their consent. So, seven months after the victims families' had been promised their own private coverage of the trial it transpired that the key players had not been consulted.

Yet by Friday morning, Joshua Rozenberg, the BBC's legal affairs correspondent, was running a news piece saying that Lord Sutherland had agreed to allowing coverage. My understanding is that a meeting took place in Lord Sutherland's chambers soon after the embarrassing scenes in the high court and a deal was struck. What infuriates many onlookers is that such a deal can be cut in private while the perfectly legitimate interest that the world's media have in applying to film the trial doesn't even get heard in court.

Even more puzzling is the question of how that deal could be so quickly arranged. And what about the strict rules that require every witness to have given written consent before the camera is switched on? There was no mention of this in the announcement and there is no way that every witness has given their consent in advance. Perhaps the court has decided that the viewing rooms in the US, London and Dumfries can be treated as annexes of the court in the Netherlands and so the guidelines can be ignored. We don't know because no explanation has been offered. What is clear that the existing rules which are applied with such rigour to the people they were intended to help, television companies, have been hurriedly waived in order to keep the influential and vocal American relatives, and the US justice department, happy.

None of the media or legal figures I have spoken to has with keeping the relatives properly informed via a TV link. What we all object to is the way in which the deals have been done behind closed doors, and organisations, such as the BBC, which do have a legitimate interest in covering the trial, have been totally shut out.

If the Scottish judiciary are worried that on-the-day news coverage will cause problems then they can simply stick to the existing rules and allow documentary filming that will only be shown after the trial is long over. Perhaps they are concerned that witnesses may be unhappy about being filmed, but this problem has been overcome in previous cases by the simple expedient of instructing the camera operator not to film the witness's face.

Perhaps they are worried that the presence of cameras will turn Lockerbie into an OJ-style media bun fight. Yet the dry and meticulous nature of this case, added to the distinctly non-celebrity status of the two accused, means that any such fear is groundless.

By bending the rules to suit the Americans, the Scottish legal establishment have set the scene for a difficult few months. The trial begins on May 3. Before then, the BBC will have returned to court in a final attempt to be allowed to film. Several American news organisations are planning to join the action in what will be a formidable transatlantic alliance.

It will be increasingly difficult for the Scottish courts simply to ignore the application. By agreeing to allow narrow-casting of the trial, their position has been seriously weakened. In the past they could argue that modifying the guidelines to allow, say, news coverage, was not an option.

But now they have been seen to drive a coach and horses through the existing rules and can no longer argue that they are sacrosanct. Of course, they can stick it out and simply refuse to countenance allowing TV coverage but the pressure is going to mount and mount. Perhaps they should now show the same flexibility, and courage, that has characterised their handling of the Lockerbie saga so far, and rethink their position. If they don't, they will miss a chance to show a worldwide audience that justice is being done.
