webTitle: Stunning win puts football in the shade

fields.headline: Stunning win puts football in the shade
fields.trailText: 2000: For those who had come to Rome for the novel but exquisite sight of watching Six Nations rugby in the Eternal City, the thrill of seeing Italy win their first match in the sport's oldest tournament was irresistible.
fields.body:
Yesterday morning, on another glorious day, the Azzurro awoke in almost nonchalant triumph. The world had said theirs was an impossible dream. But the world was wrong. They had made sporting history and, wherever they looked, Italy had the bounce of spring in its jaunty step.

For those who had come to Rome for the novel but exquisite sight of watching Six Nations rugby in the Eternal City, the thrill of seeing Italy win their first match in the sport's oldest tournament was irresistible.

And if the shock of the new brought its inevitable confusion, at least it was a shared bewilderment. Rugby union had finally made the Italian front pages. Yet, even in celebration, it was still swamped by a different sport: sailing rather than football.

Overnight the Italian yacht Luna Rossa had swept into the final of the America's Cup in Auckland by beating the American favourite in the deciding ninth race. Italy was captivated. Serie A, for once, stepped back in admiration.

But even the Italians could not ignore the magnificent feat of their habitually ignored rugby team. They are still bamboozled by the oval game but, in Rome, they always recognise a miracle.

The front page of Corriere dello Sport found the most representative way of fusing together a strange sporting trinity. A 'Luna Rossa, si!' banner headline dominated the more expected plea of 'Lazio e Roma, forza!' And then, at the very bottom, a heroic Six Nations debut effort was hailed - with the promise of more rugby on page 24.

For world rugby, however, Italy's astonishing 34-20 demolition of Scotland will remain the story of 2000. On a day when England and France reaffirmed their superiority by crushing Ireland and Wales, Italy saved the inaugural Six Nations weekend from numbing predictability.

Though the championship may be settled as early as a week on Saturday when England travel to Paris, the Italian adventure has just begun. European rugby should get down on its creaking knees in thankful tribute.

Yet, an hour before the match, it had felt markedly different. 'The day is very beautiful,' Giuseppe Perotti had murmured, 'but I think the result will be very ugly.' Like so many other ordinary Italian supporters, Perotti's flag twitched behind his back as he trudged towards Stadio Flaminio.

'Some of us,' he sighed, 'dreamed about this day since we were small boys. But now we are frightened.'

Perotti waved at a bunch of kilted Scots drinking beer down a side street. 'Maybe we shock you today,' he shouted at the flushed flowers of Scotland, 'or maybe we don't . . .'

The eventual shock was less that Italy were galvanised by the occasion into overcoming a slump which had seen them concede 599 points in their preceding 10 matches. It was more a surprise that Scotland were as terrible in Rome as they had been sublime in Paris when clinching the Five Nations last April.

Though the rugby was flawed, the drama was raw. After Diego Dominguez's four penalties and Kenny Logan's own woeful quartet of misses had produced a psychologically crucial 12,10 home advantage, Italy tore into the Scots after the interval - allowing Dominguez to land a cool trio of drops. The fly-half eventually took his personal tally to 29, including his conversion of a barging try, from the substitute prop Giampiero De Carli, which sent the stadium into delirium.

John Leslie, the new Scottish captain who was replaced after 12 minutes with an injured hip, suggested: 'I couldn't have written a worse script.'

If Leslie's composure was missed, Scotland struggled to hold on to possession even when their captain was present. The Scots were turned over repeatedly in the opening quarter, a failing which bolstered the Italians' growing confidence.

Their extraordinary coach Brad Johnstone transformed Italy in his first match - especially at half-time when, in the centre of the field, the former All Black hammered home the message that history was calling.

'I thought if we were going to win a game,' he said with his gruff twinkle, 'it would be this one because everybody expected us to be useless. Opinion in Britain even questioned whether Italy should be in the competition. I feel sorry for the Scots that they had to face us first. We'd worked on our basics: the scrum, second-phase rucking and mauling and defence. It's like putting down the foundation for a house before you build the walls.'

While assessing the impact of Italy's resurgence on the rest of the tournament, Johnstone underplayed the surrounding euphoria. 'I was happy with the result but we'll have to play much better against the other teams.'

When asked what he had said to Dominguez afterwards, Johnstone finally cracked. 'I said, ''Ciao'. That's about all I can say in Italian.'

Dominguez, the Argentine-born fly-half and former Puma who plays for Stade Francais, speaks fluent Spanish, Italian and French. His English is not bad either.

'The World Cup, for us, was catastrophic,' he said. 'But this victory cancelled that memory. We now must find at least one more victory from our four other games. It will be hard.'

For all his exemplary kicking and multi-lingual sophistication, Dominguez can seem curiously vulnerable. On Saturday evening his face became a sudden mass of twitches as he relived Italy's last terrible year.

'There was a lot of pain,' he said. 'Sometimes we wondered if we had missed our chance in the Six Nations. We had lost our humility when we had some good results a few years before. We thought we were among the best in the world but we weren't.

'So we suffered. But Brad Johnstone is strong and tough, like Bernard Laporte was at Stade Francais, hard but excellent. He rescued us.'

Yet Italy's victory was shaped by the boot. 'Personally,' Dominguez stressed, 'I don't think Kenny Logan is a kicker. If you watch him kick you see he's not natural. Each time we get a penalty we take the points and they miss.

'Their morale went down. Our confidence got bigger. We played a good match but we also made mistakes. So we don't get too excited. Rugby is still a small sport in Italy. But today will help . . .'

By the time he had headed up the stairs and out into the suddenly cold Rome night, only a few hundred fans were still waiting. 'Diego! Diego!' they chanted, with a fleeting burst of the exultation which Napoli fans had once shown Maradona. Dominguez whispered goodbye as he ducked through that short but adoring gauntlet.

Meanwhile, eyes turned to a stranger sight. Big Giuseppe, the fatalistic fan from before, ran through the darkness. 'Italia-Diego! Italia-Diego!' he cried, one name folding into the other. He wore a pair of shorts on his head like a hat. Two hours earlier he had raced across the field to receive them from a meaty Italian forward who had stripped to his underpants in delight at the final whistle.

On Giuseppe Perotti those sweaty rugby shorts suddenly flapped like a fantastic memento from an unforgettable Italian day, the day rugby and the Six Nations finally reached Rome.

While assessing the impact of Italy's resurgence on the rest of the tournament, Johnstone underplayed the surrounding euphoria. 'I was happy with the result but we'll have to play much better against the other teams.' When asked what he had said to Dominguez afterwards, Johnstone finally cracked. 'I said, ''Ciao'. That's about all I can say in Italian.' Dominguez, the Argentine-born fly-half and former Puma who plays for Stade Francais, speaks fluent Spanish, Italian and French. His English is not bad either. 'The World Cup, for us, was catastrophic,' he said. 'But this victory cancelled that memory. We now must find at least one more victory from our four other games. It will be hard.' For all his exemplary kicking and multi-lingual sophistication, Dominguez can seem curiously vulnerable. On Saturday evening his face became a sudden mass of twitches as he relived Italy's last terrible year. 'There was a lot of pain,' he said. 'Sometimes we wondered if we had missed our chance in the Six Nations. We had lost our humility when we had some good results a few years before. We thought we were among the best in the world but we weren't. 'So we suffered. But Brad Johnstone is strong and tough, like Bernard Laporte was at Stade Francais, hard but excellent. He rescued us.' Yet Italy's victory was shaped by the boot. 'Personally,' Dominguez stressed, 'I don't think Kenny Logan is a kicker. If you watch him kick you see he's not natural. Each time we get a penalty we take the points and they miss. 'Their morale went down. Our confidence got bigger. We played a good match but we also made mistakes. So we don't get too excited. Rugby is still a small sport in Italy. But today will help . . .' By the time he had headed up the stairs and out into the suddenly cold Rome night, only a few hundred fans were still waiting. 'Diego! Diego!' they chanted, with a fleeting burst of the exultation which Napoli fans had once shown Maradona. Dominguez whispered goodbye as he ducked through that short but adoring gauntlet. Meanwhile, eyes turned to a stranger sight. Big Giuseppe, the fatalistic fan from before, ran through the darkness. 'Italia-Diego! Italia-Diego!' he cried, one name folding into the other. He wore a pair of shorts on his head like a hat. Two hours earlier he had raced across the field to receive them from a meaty Italian forward who had stripped to his underpants in delight at the final whistle. On Giuseppe Perotti those sweaty rugby shorts suddenly flapped like a fantastic memento from an unforgettable Italian day, the day rugby and the Six Nations finally reached Rome.

webTitle: Scream 3 slashes its way to the top

fields.headline: Scream 3 slashes its way to the top
fields.trailText: Scream 3 slashed its way into the American cinemas this weekend, earning more money than the combined total of every other film in the top 10 and becoming the highest February opener for any studio
fields.body:
Scream 3 slashed its way into the American cinemas this weekend, earning more money than the combined total of every other film in the top 10 and becoming the highest February opener for any studio. It earned an estimated $35.2m in ticket sales, a new record for the last - purportedly - in the ironic horror series.

Described by director Wes Craven as a "real mind twister" the film promised to give the "reality behind the reality behind the reality'' and to answer all the unresolved questions left by its predecessors. The film has proved to be a hit with the critics as well as the public. Kevin Thomas described the movie in the Los Angeles Times as "genuinely scary and also highly amusing ... a razzle-dazzler that delivers the goods for horror fans".

For those in the dark, the Scream films revived the slasher genre and gave it an ironic spin for the post-modern audience. Scream and Scream 2 referenced classic horror films with their predictable plot twists but also poked at the media and its effect on people.

In Scream 3 the survivors of the slasher's murder sprees, including the straitlaced heroine Sidney (Neve Campbell) reunite in Hollywood during the filming of Stab 3: Return to Woodsboro' which is based on Sidney's troubled past. When a murder takes place on set, an aggressive TV news reporter Gale Weathers (played by Courteney Cox Arquette) rushes to the crime scene believing she can provide insight into the murder based on her past experience covering Sidney's story. She meets up with Sidney and her old flame, the Woodsboro deputy Dewey Riley (played by husband David Arquette) who has been hired as a technical advisor for the movie and who is now in love with the actress playing Weathers (Parker Posey) in the film. Complicating the plot is that each of the old characters is being played in the movie by an actor, giving audiences two sets of potential killers at large - the ones from the Scream movies and the ones from the Stab movies.

webTitle: Signing up to a new role

fields.headline: Signing up to a new role
fields.standfirst: Matt Stringer was an actor who worked with deaf people. Now he's a PA. But in his new job, his old skills are vital, as Hilary Whitney explains
fields.trailText: Matt Stringer was an actor who worked with deaf people. Now he's a PA. But in his new job, his old skills are vital, as Hilary Whitney explains
fields.body:
Matt Stringer was working for a campaigning theatre company when he decided he wanted to develop his acting career through a course on theatre for deaf people. "We had to learn sign language as part of the course," says Stringer, 37. "Well, as there were three hearing people to six deaf people, it was essential." When the course finished, he ran a successful theatre company for five years with one profoundly deaf woman and another who was partially hearing.

When the company came to its natural end, however, he found himself working predominantly as a theatre interpreter for deaf people. "It was great fun but exhausting, and the idea of working in an office suddenly seemed very attractive!"

Stringer was fortunate to find a job perfectly suited to his skills, as PA to Maggie Woolley, the director of Shape London, an organisation dedicated to opening up access to the arts for disabled and older people. Although he has no formal secretarial training, the post provided an opportunity for him to channel his experience of working in the arts in a different direction.

His ability to sign is extremely useful as Woolley is deaf, but he emphasises that he is employed as Woolley's PA, not her interpreter. "On my first morning I said to Maggie, 'There's one thing we have to get clear. I'm not an interpreter; I'm a PA.' To my great relief, Maggie reassured me that I'd not been employed to interpret for her." A freelance interpreter is booked for two days each week and Stringer tries to fit as many of Woolley's meetings as he can into these days. "I make sure the interpreter knows where to go and has the necessary papers. I also try to let them know who else will be there and how formal or informal the meeting might be." But he does not mind having to sign occasionally. "Sometimes Maggie has an urgent phone call to make or there's a meeting that can't wait until the freelance interpreter comes in, and I'm always happy to help out in those circumstances."

When Woolley is in the office, she and Stringer meet up for half an hour each day to go through the post and discuss any issues that have arisen. Apart from that, there is no strict daily routine, for which he is grateful after years of working freelance.

However the two have had to devise certain systems: "If you work for a hearing manager, you can shout out if you have to leave the office, to collect the post say, or make coffee. I can't do that with Maggie. If she's at the computer she'll have her back to me and probably won't realise I've gone until she looks round because she needs me. I can't tap her on the shoulder every time I want her attention because if she's typing she might be in the middle of a sentence and I'll ruin her concentration - anyway, it would be very irritating for her." The solution is an adhesive board that is visible to Woolley when she is at her computer. Stringer has designed notes to stick on the board, which let her know why he is away from his desk - out to lunch, collecting the post, or having a cigarette.

Shape is responsible for many schemes that enable disabled and older people to participate in the arts and, as funding is limited, Stringer works alongside Woolley on numerous fundraising activities, such as the annual event at Whiteley's Shopping Centre with the Kensington Symphony Orchestra. Last year the event raised £4,000 and the money is used to support a ticket scheme to help disabled and older people visit a huge variety of arts venues to see shows at reduced prices. Shape will also book tickets and provide volunteer escorts and drivers.

Woolley had not had a PA for eight years and was so used to working on her own that she was reluctant to let go of certain areas of her work, such as maintaining staff attendance records. "I've been here two and a half years now and she's learnt to trust me," says Stringer. "She's so busy and has to be out and about so much promoting the organisation that she appreciates having someone back at base to sort out her diary and deal with things on her behalf. We still do the filing together though."

Because Woolley cannot hear, Stringer usually communicates with her in sign language, but as Woolley has a clear speaking voice she will not normally sign back - unless they wish to have an entirely private conversation. "Sign language can be very useful in an open plan office!"

fields.headline: Claude Autant-Lara
fields.standfirst: Classic French film director whose hostility to the new wave was channelled into far-right politics and anti-semitism
fields.trailText: Classic French film director whose hostility to the new wave was channelled into far-right politics and anti-semitism
fields.body:
In 1989, almost every member of the European parliament walked out when the French MEP and former film director Claude Autant-Lara, who has died aged 96, spoke on behalf of Jean-Marie Le Pen's National Front. For those to whom Autant-Lara meant quality French cinema in the 1940s and 1950s, associated with memories of Jean Gabin, Fernandel, Bourvil, Odette Joyeux, Gerard Philipe and Danielle Darrieux, it must have been a shock to realise that the neo-fascist and the once leftish film creator were one and the same.

Autant-Lara subsequently resigned as an MEP, and as vice president of the Academy of Fine Arts, after the furore over his anti-semitic comments about Simone Weil, a former president of the parliament and Nazi death camp survivor. He told the left-wing magazine Globe: "She plays the violin about that. When I hear talk of genocide, I reply, 'Well, they missed old Weil.' Whether you like it or not, she is from an ethnic group that is political and tries to take root and dominate."

Some people pleaded that these were merely an old man's ravings; others pointed to a hatred, born out of disappointments in his film career. The turning point seems to have come when Autant-Lara was beached by the French new wave, which, he said in 1963, had "made a mess of our industry and undoubtedly most of them will sink . . . Those intellectual pictures like Last Year In Marienbad are terrible and boring. People only went to see them out of snobbery. They are twisted in some way."

As late as 1977, at the time of his last film, Gloria, a circus melodrama, he was still complaining that the new wave had emptied the cinemas, although he had shared the credits with Jean-Luc Goddard as one of the six directors on The Oldest Profession (1967).

Autant-Lara had been an essential part of mainstream cinema for 30 years, and he saw new-wave upstarts shoving him aside. François Truffaut, in particular, through the pages of Cahiers du cinema, condemned the "well-made" film or the "cinema du papa" as exemplified by Autant-Lara. Like Marcel Carné, who blamed his lack of acclaim and difficulties in getting films made on "a government too close knit with the Jews", Autant-Lara attacked the "decadent left" and the "Jewish conspiracy", in which he had included the directors that had displaced him - none of whom was Jewish.

This paranoid anti-semitism might have dated from the late 1930s, when his Jewish producer boss, Maurice Lehmann, insisted on claiming a co-director credit on three films which Autant-Lara had virtually directed himself. One of them had been Fric-Frac, a slangy comic heist movie starring Arletty, Michel Simon and Fernandel.

Autant-Lara was the son of architect Edouard Autant and actress Louise Lara. Because of his mother's pacifist views (which she instilled in her son), she exiled herself and the child to England during the first world war. When they returned, Autant-Lara studied art at the Ecole des Beaux Arts, before entering films in his teens as a designer.

With Fernand Léger and Alberto Cavalcanti, he de signed sets for Marcel L'Herbier's modernist L'Inhumaine (1924), and was responsible for the lavish decor and costumes of Jean Renoir's Nana (1926). In later years, Autant-Lara wrote scathingly about Renoir, although the latter had given the 23-year-old his best opportunity to date. After assisting René Clair on a couple of films, he made a number of avant-garde shorts, including Construire Un Feu (1927), the first film to achieve a widescreen effect through the use of Henri Chrétien's anamorphic lens.

In the early 1930s, Autant- Lara was hired by MGM to direct the French versions of several comedies in Hollywood, including two starring Buster Keaton - Parlor, Bedroom And Bath and The Passionate Plumber. He returned to France to make his first feature, Ciboulette (1933), based on Reynaldo Hahn's charming operetta.

During the war, he directed four light and elegant films (only "escapist" pictures were possible under the Nazis), starring Odette Joyeux. Among them was Douce, about an aristocratic daughter in late 19th-century Paris who falls for her manservant. Joyeux also played the 16-year-old heroine in Sylvie Et La Fantome (Sylvie And The Ghost), who becomes enamoured of a nobleman she sees in a painting. It was an entertaining comedy- romance in which Jacques Tati, as the ghost, made his first feature film appearance.

Postwar, Aulant-Lara's reputation was established as a tormenter of middle-class morality. In Le Diable Au Corps (Devil In The Flesh, 1947), Gérard Philipe, as a 17-year-old schoolboy, has an affair with a young married woman (Micheline Presle) while her husband is away at the front. The film caused outrage in some quarters, although the film can now be seen as a sensuous love story, framing two touching performances.

Occupe-Toi D'Amelie (1949), a sparkling adaptation of Feydeau, with Danielle Darrieux as the Parisian cocotte, incurred local bans in Britain, and enraged American critics, who considered it lewd and immoral. The film retains the theatrical proscenium but, using a provincial family visiting the theatre for the first time, moves out into the audience, the streets, and back again, to maximum effect.

It took the British censor six years to pass The Red Inn (1951) uncut because of its allegedy blasphemous aspects. Amusing and macabre, it had Fernandel as a 19th-century monk trying to prevent a coachload of travellers from being robbed and murdered. Le Ble en Herbe (The Ripening Seed, 1953) intelligently adapted from Colette's tender triangular tale about an adolescent boy's seduction by an older woman (Edwige Feu- illere), was condemned as "immoral and obscene" by the church, and banned in Nice and Chicago.

Two sumptuous, if superficial, Technicolor adaptations from classic novels, Le Rouge Et Le Noir (1954) and The Gambler (1958), had the advantage of Gérard Philipe's sensitive embodiment of both Stendhal's and Dostoevsky's heroes respectively.

One of Autant-Lara's best pictures was La Traverseé De Paris (A Pig Across Paris) in 1956, with Jean Gabin and Bourvil transporting four suitcases of blackmarket pork across Paris during the occupation. The only work exempted by Truffaut in his attack on Autunt-Lara, it was one of the first French films to recognise that there was cowardice, stupidity, apathy and hypocrisy among the populace during the period.

Autant-Lara's prolific output in the 1950s included a number of films whose attraction abroad lay in what was then considered French naughtiness: Marguerite De La Nuit (1955), an art deco updating of the Faust legend to the 1920s, with Yves Montand and Michele Morgan; En Cas De Malheur (Love Is My Profession, 1958), based on a Georges Simenon novel, with veteran Gabin as a lawyer being vamped by his young client Brigitte Bardot, who had an obligatory nude scene; and La Jument Verte (The Green Mare's Nest 1959), the film comedy in which Bourvil first became widely known outside France.

Autant-Lara continued to court controversy towards the end of his film career with two well-meaning, didactic films, Thou Shalt Not Kill (1962) and Journal d'Une Femme en Blanc (Woman in White, 1965), which argued the rights of women to contraception. The theme of the former, sympathetic to a second world war conscientious objector, lost him financial backing. It was eventually made in Yugoslavia, and denied a release in France and Italy for some time.

Perhaps this was a further factor in turning Claude Autant-Lara into an embittered old man.

 Claude Autant-Lara, film director, born August 5 1903; died February 12 2000

webTitle: The new guidelines on sex education

fields.headline: The new guidelines on sex education
fields.standfirst: These are the guidelines announced by David Blunkett today on the teaching of sex education in schools, including the treatment of homosexuality
fields.trailText: 'The new guidance will clearly state that sex and relationship education (SRE) should be firmly rooted within the framework for Personal, Social and Health Education (PSHE). This sets out that children should be taught about the importance and nature of marriage and family life in bringing up children.
fields.body:
'The new guidance will clearly state that sex and relationship education (SRE) should be firmly rooted within the framework for Personal, Social and Health Education (PSHE). This sets out that children should be taught about the importance and nature of marriage and family life in bringing up children.

'The PSHE framework will help pupils develop the skills and understanding they need to live confident, healthy and independent lives. It will play an important role, alongside other aspects of the curriculum and school life to help pupils deal with difficult moral and social questions that arise in their lives and in society.

'This is the first time that schools have had a national PSHE framework to support work in this area. It is the first time that we have set into a framework that pupils should be taught about the importance of marriage, family life, love and stable relationships in bringing up children. Marriage and the family are the key building blocks of community and society.

'Sex and relationship education should not be delivered in isolation. It should be firmly rooted in the framework. The new guidance will firmly set the delivery of sex and relationship education within that context and that of the National Curriculum which lies at the heart of the GovernmentÍs policies to raise standards and expectations of young people. The objective is to help young people learn to respect themselves and others and by so doing move from adolescence into adulthood with confidence.

webTitle: The first step in tackling genocide - but not the last

fields.headline: The first step in tackling genocide - but not the last
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's deputy foreign editor Victoria Brittain explains why the arrest of Lieutenant-Colonel Tharcisse Muvunyi on an international warrant for the United Nations' War Crimes Tribunal in Rwanda is just the start
fields.trailText: The Guardian's deputy foreign editor Victoria Brittain explains why the arrest of Lieutenant-Colonel Tharcisse Muvunyi on an international warrant for the United Nations' War Crimes Tribunal in Rwanda is just the start
fields.body:
Britain's arrest of Lieutenant-Colonel Tharcisse Muvunyi on an international warrant for the United Nations' War Crimes Tribunal in Arusha is a step forward for the principle of accountability for crimes such as genocide and torture.

But, like the Pinochet case, in which the Home Secretary has given at least the appearance of stepping back from the decisive action he could have taken so manymonths ago, the Muvunyi case reveals a good deal of British ambivalence about the new principle.

Muvunyi was a very big fish indeed in Rwanda's genocide. In the southern province of Butare where he was in charge of waves of killing in April, May and June, there are dozens of survivors who know only too well what he was responsible for.

When he came here two years ago and was given political asylum the Home Office made an extraordinarily ill-informed decision. So, sadly, did the various church authorities who chose to back him. And once here, as well-documented media exposures of his past grew, there was no excuse for the Home Office not knowing just how shameful it was that he had been given the right to live here with his family. And now, with the decision to arrest him and send him to the International Tribunal at Arusha, rather than back to Rwanda to face the country's own justice system, Britain has ensured that he will be saved from the death penalty he would be likely to get in Kigali. Each of these cases has a different dynamic, largely dependent on its familiarity to those who read, and write, the western media. Another case, now going on in West Africa, has possible repercussions of great importance. This is the attempt in Senegal by numerous Chadian nationals to bring to justice the former leader of Chad, Hissene Habre, for extensive human rights violations. Mr Habre now lives in Senegal.

Various African human rights lawyers wish to build on this principle and have the former Ugandan leader Idi Amin brought to justice. Mr Amin has been in exile in Saudi Arabia since 1989 when he fled from Uganda under pressure from an invading army from neighbouring Tanzania, which included Ugandan exiles. His crimes while in office were widely known, but in the climate of respect for the sovereignty of individual countries which prevailed in the 1980s, Britain remained embarrassingly close to him and might prefer not be reminded of that slice of history.

fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.trailText: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.body:
Steve Outing, Stop the Presses! column at mediainfo.com.

Here are some ideas on how web news sites might take advantage of the increasingly close link between TV and the net:

 Ally with broadcast outlets. It's common in metro markets for TV stations and newspapers to join forces on the internet.

 Promote online content as complementary to TV. If there's a big TV-oriented event, developing related online content is the way to grab an audience that otherwise will be sitting in front of the TV.

 Provide informational content viewers can't get on TV but might want as they're watching.

James Ledbetter, Columbia Journalism Review

It's one of the most fundamental questions of the media business: how many people see, hear, or read what you produce? Yet try to get a single answer about how many visitors a website has and you will encounter dissembling and dissent.

The main reason for knowing such figures precisely is to attract advertisers and charge them accordingly. For journalists, knowing exactly how many readers read which pieces might be useful, but it can be dangerous. There is a thin line between meeting readers' needs and pandering. The temptation to put salacious headlines on articles could become severe. Writers at Salon say their rule of thumb is that articles with "sex" in the headline get twice as many hits as average, articles with "oral sex" three times the average.

Judith Shulevitz slate.com

The remarkable thing about the the Super Bowl dot com commercials was that the cutting-edge technologies employed the world's most old-fashioned advertising method - provoking a sense of alienation and insecurity in the viewer. The soda, the car and the beer manufacturers wanted you to perceive their brands as an integral part of a happy lifestyle. The dot com folks wanted to impress on you that you are a Luddite and a fool for failing to use their products.

Michael Stroud wired.com

Hollywood bigwigs may find the medicine prescribed last week at the Variety Interactive Summit hard to take. The pundits suggest:

 Give employees equity: people in Silicon Valley know that if they work hard and their options flower, they can get rich.

 Give artists more control: few Hollywood creative types have any control over how their work is used.

 Get real with your web marketing: most studios spend a fraction of their budgets on marketing films on the web. The Blair Witch Project earned more than $100m (£60m) thanks to its web marketing.

fields.headline: Republican terrorists: the factions
fields.trailText:
Irish Republican Army
The main republican paramilitary group, the IRA was founded nearly 80 years ago to fight for an independent Ireland. The IRA has historic links to Sinn Fein. In 1969, the IRA split into the Official IRA and the Provisional IRA. The Official IRA took a more socialist line while the Provisionals became more militant, initially defending Catholics against loyalist attacks then going on the offensive.
fields.body:
Irish Republican Army
The main republican paramilitary group, the IRA was founded nearly 80 years ago to fight for an independent Ireland. The IRA has historic links to Sinn Fein. In 1969, the IRA split into the Official IRA and the Provisional IRA. The Official IRA took a more socialist line while the Provisionals became more militant, initially defending Catholics against loyalist attacks then going on the offensive.

The Official IRA still exists, but when people refer to the IRA nowadays, they usually mean the Provisional IRA. This group restored its ceasefire in July 1997 - a move which allowed Sinn Fein to join the peace talks.

Continuity IRA
The only republican terrorist group not to have declared a ceasefire, it is violently opposed to any deal not based on a united Ireland. It is the terrorist wing of Republican Sinn Fein, a dissident group headed by former IRA chief of staff, Ruairi O Bradaigh. Republican Sinn Fein broke away from the main Sinn Fein in 1986, when Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness dropped the party's policy of boycotting the Irish parliament. The Continuity IRA was responsible for the 1996 bombing of the Killyhelvin Hotel in Enniskillen

Real IRA
This dissident republican faction has emerged as one of the most dangerous groups opposed to the Good Friday settlement. It is reportedly led by the man who resigned as the IRA's quartermaster-general in October 1997 after he broke with Sinn Fein because of its support for the peace process. Membership is reportedly at between 50 to 70 dissidents. It is believed to be responsible for a series of attacks, including a 500lb car bomb which devastated the market town of Banbridge, Co Armagh in August 1998.

The Real IRA was responsible for the Omagh bombing on 15 August 1998 in which 29 people died. The group apologised for the civilian deaths claiming it was aiming for commercial targets. The Real IRA called a ceasefire less than a month after the Omagh atrocity. The ceasefire has not been recognised.

Irish National Liberation Army
. Formed in 1975, mainly from disaffected members of the IRA unhappy at the ceasefire, the INLA is a relatively small group and its attacks seem to come in waves. It has operated in the past in concert with other republican groups - three of the 10 republican hunger strikers who died in 1981 were in the INLA. Now, however, it has the reputation even among militants of being extreme.

It first gained notoriety when it planted the bomb which killed Conservative Northern Ireland spokesman Airey Neave at the House of Commons in 1979. The group was also responsible for the murder of leading loyalist paramilitary Billy Wright inside the Maze prison on 27 December.

webTitle: The rise and rise of the third party

fields.headline: The rise and rise of the third party
fields.standfirst:
Independents are making a surprisingly good showing

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Smart opinion in the Beltway and media still looks down its nose at the third party phenomenon, just as it did in 1860 when a third party candidate won the White House. Name of Abraham Lincoln.
fields.body:
Ralph Nader, the prophet of the consumer and citizen movements, wants to be president of the United States. I expect he will throw his flame-tested hat in the ring very soon and the various Green parties across the country will back him, as they did in 1996, when he won 682,000 votes though he spent only the astounding total of $5,000 and was kept off the ballot in most states.

It is safe to predict that the big party machines will affect not to take him seriously. The Republican party bosses, in particular, are transfixed by the humiliating prospect that the maverick John McCain will beat their golden boy, George W Bush. But there is a very real connection that both big parties should note between Nader and McCain. It is in their appeal to the independent voter disgusted by money's pollution of the democratic process.

McCain likes to invoke comparisons with President Theodore Roosevelt, who bucked the official machine in 1912, but his modern debt is less to Teddy and more to Ralph. The main plank in his platform, an attack on the corrupting "soft" money, is pure Nader. It is Nader, unfashionable year in year out, who put campaign finance on the reform agenda and saw it taken up by hundreds of citizen pressure groups. Nader personifies the independent voter. He has been one of the principal forces keeping the idea alive, and with it the notion that alternative parties will invigorate the American system. The sensation in New Hampshire was McCain's interruption of the Bush coronation, but the deeper significance was how he did it by winning 61% of the independent vote. That was 41% of the total of all votes cast. McCain took independent voters from Bill Bradley - independents can vote in either primary - but Bush was the main loser. He attracted only 19% of the independents.

The Bush managers thought they were smart in proclaiming how far ahead he was in raising money, supposedly an object of veneration by all Americans. But the modern voter, it seems, dislikes being told his vote has been paid for in advance. Something is stirring in the American political soul. In the 60s, only 1% of voters described themselves as independent. Now 15% do, and they are more inclined to bother to vote. Third parties are burgeoning. The internet is alive with rebellion.

Arianna Huffington, the former president of the Cambridge Union, but more recently a loyal Republican wife and campaigner, epitomises the mood. Her Republican friends will wake up one day this week to discover she has deserted the party with a fighting book entitled How to Overthrow the Government. It is a denunciation of both party machines, but also a bomb-makers' handbook for civil disobedience.

The strength of the tide can be gauged by how vigorously the parties, in all regions, are blocking reforms that would enable more third parties to get on ballot papers and the televised debates. In addition to the Greens and Jesse Ventura's Reform party, there is the Natural Law party, the Libertarians, the Constitution party, and the Workers' World party.

The US is the only nation in the world in which the rules for ballot access in national elections - for Congress as well as president - are not written by the national government but by the states. They demand high numbers of endorsement signatures, from which the main parties are exempt, then fix ridiculously short periods for their collection; and the rules may be different for presidential, gubernatorial and congressional races. The Reform party, for instance, is on the ballot in 21 states, but will need another 360,000 to get on the ballot in all 50 states this year. Georgia and Texas are currently making sure nobody can vote for Nader.

The mainstream media has been paying no attention to this scandal of the states, but McCain's victory propelled the issue to the front pages last week. The pro-Bush governor of New York State, George Pataki, has had to retreat from his moves to keep McCain off the ballot in the state presidential primary on March 7.

It is a warning to the apparatchiks in the rest of the country. At their back, they should hear the electronic chariots hurrying near. Soon enough under-funded candidates will be able to dispense with buying TV time, the curse of US elections, by getting their message out through continuous video on the internet. Emailers are raising money and hell. MoveOn.org was founded by two Silicon Valley entrepreneurs convinced the public was frustrated by the way congress was distracted by the Lewinsky scandal. They were soon able to mobilise 450,000 supporters committed to spend at least $25 to unseat any congressman who voted for impeachment.

Smart opinion in the Beltway and media still looks down its nose at the third party phenomenon, just as it did in 1860 when a third party candidate won the White House. Name of Abraham Lincoln.

fields.headline: Section 28 helps bullies, study shows
fields.standfirst:
Related stories from today's paper
Assaults lead to climate of fear for Scottish gays
An end to hate
fields.trailText: Section 28, the controversial legislation banning the promotion of homosexuality, has encouraged the spread of homophobic bullying, according to independent research published today.
fields.body:
Section 28, the controversial legislation banning the promotion of homosexuality, has encouraged the spread of homophobic bullying, according to independent research published today.

The study came as the government faces a crushing defeat over repeal of the clause in the Lords tonight with up to 40 rebel Labour peers expected to join forces with Conservatives and crossbenchers.

The resistance has been strengthened by a statement from Chris Woodhead, chief inspector of schools, that there was no evidence of section 28 causing problems for teachers.

But a study by the institute of education at London university has found the clause created "an atmosphere of confusion and fear" that was discouraging staff from intervening to stop an epidemic of homophobic abuse in school playgrounds and corridors.

The problem was explored in in-depth confidential interviews with teachers. "Because they do not know how to comply with section 28, they err on the side of caution. As a result, they choose to ignore homophobic harassment and bullying whenever possible. This creates a permissive environment in which pupils believe they can, and do, get away with it," said Debbie Epstein who led the interviews.

One teacher told her: "Schools have been intimidated out of making sexuality part of equal opportunities. Certainly the huge amount of bullying is manifested as homophobic abuse."

Dr Epstein said the problem impacted on all pupils - lesbian, gay, bisexual or heterosexual. "It is the most widespread form of abuse in schools. Any child who seems different may be subjected to it.

"Boys struggle to avoid being called gay, poofter, bumboy, queer or whatever the local term is. Boys who work hard are often labelled as gay and this may deter them."

Her findings reinforce earlier work by the institute showing 82% of teachers were aware of homophobic verbal bullying and 26% of homophobic physical abuse. While almost all schools had anti-bullying policies, only 6% of these dealt with homophobic abuse.

Four in five teachers wanted further clarification of section 28 and 56% said its continuing existence made it difficult to meet the needs of lesbian, gay and bisexual pupils.

Hilary Armstrong, the local government minister, yesterday said Labour had a "duty" to tackle discrimination. "Children and young people, growing up in what is a very difficult environment, need appropriate and sensitive counselling and guidance," she told Sky News.

"No one is talking about promotion. What we are talking about is giving young people the right framework so that they can face problems, concerns, fears and do that in confidence that their teachers will work with them."

The government will be able to rely tonight on the votes of 54 Liberal Democrat peers. But ministers are braced for up to 40 defections among Labour peers and Catholic ones who take their cue from the strong opposition by their church's hierarchy.

Labour has around 200 peers. Faced with 160 crossbenchers, many of the 26 bishops and the 227 Conservatives, most of whom are expected to vote no, that will not prove enough.

Lady Young, the former Thatcher cabinet minister, is leading the campaign to retain section 28 which forbids local authorities to use public money to "promote" gay sexuality. She is staging displays of "gay propaganda" in the Lords to the dismay of some colleagues.

Labour's best chance is an amendment tabled last week by Michael Nazir-Ali, the Anglican bishop of Rochester, who has a compromise to entrench what he calls "the provision of comprehensive and ethically-based sex education".

Peter Tatchell, of the gay rights group OutRage! said: "Baroness Young is creating an atmosphere of anti-gay intolerance that will almost certainly lead to an increase in queer-bashing violence. All that we want is for teachers to encourage acceptance."

The problem was explored in in-depth confidential interviews with teachers. "Because they do not know how to comply with section 28, they err on the side of caution. As a result, they choose to ignore homophobic harassment and bullying whenever possible. This creates a permissive environment in which pupils believe they can, and do, get away with it," said Debbie Epstein who led the interviews. One teacher told her: "Schools have been intimidated out of making sexuality part of equal opportunities. Certainly the huge amount of bullying is manifested as homophobic abuse." Dr Epstein said the problem impacted on all pupils - lesbian, gay, bisexual or heterosexual. "It is the most widespread form of abuse in schools. Any child who seems different may be subjected to it. "Boys struggle to avoid being called gay, poofter, bumboy, queer or whatever the local term is. Boys who work hard are often labelled as gay and this may deter them." Her findings reinforce earlier work by the institute showing 82% of teachers were aware of homophobic verbal bullying and 26% of homophobic physical abuse. While almost all schools had anti-bullying policies, only 6% of these dealt with homophobic abuse. Four in five teachers wanted further clarification of section 28 and 56% said its continuing existence made it difficult to meet the needs of lesbian, gay and bisexual pupils. Hilary Armstrong, the local government minister, yesterday said Labour had a "duty" to tackle discrimination. "Children and young people, growing up in what is a very difficult environment, need appropriate and sensitive counselling and guidance," she told Sky News. "No one is talking about promotion. What we are talking about is giving young people the right framework so that they can face problems, concerns, fears and do that in confidence that their teachers will work with them." The government will be able to rely tonight on the votes of 54 Liberal Democrat peers. But ministers are braced for up to 40 defections among Labour peers and Catholic ones who take their cue from the strong opposition by their church's hierarchy. Labour has around 200 peers. Faced with 160 crossbenchers, many of the 26 bishops and the 227 Conservatives, most of whom are expected to vote no, that will not prove enough. Lady Young, the former Thatcher cabinet minister, is leading the campaign to retain section 28 which forbids local authorities to use public money to "promote" gay sexuality. She is staging displays of "gay propaganda" in the Lords to the dismay of some colleagues. Labour's best chance is an amendment tabled last week by Michael Nazir-Ali, the Anglican bishop of Rochester, who has a compromise to entrench what he calls "the provision of comprehensive and ethically-based sex education". Peter Tatchell, of the gay rights group OutRage! said: "Baroness Young is creating an atmosphere of anti-gay intolerance that will almost certainly lead to an increase in queer-bashing violence. All that we want is for teachers to encourage acceptance."

webTitle: Tax could make film industry a sleepy hollow

fields.headline: Tax could make film industry a sleepy hollow
fields.standfirst: London's movie boom in jeopardy because incentives offered by Canada and Australia threaten to lure away the big Hollywood studios
fields.trailText: The movie boom which turned London into the film capital of Europe is in jeopardy unless film-makers get bigger tax breaks, ministers have been warned.
fields.body:
The movie boom which turned London into the film capital of Europe is in jeopardy unless film-makers get bigger tax breaks, ministers have been warned.

The claim comes despite new figures showing that American studios spent more than £400m on shooting big-budget productions such as Sleepy Hollow and The End Of The Affair last year in Britain, a jump of more than half on the previous year.

Foreign investment has tripled in the three years since Labour changed the tax rules shortly after taking office. But Steve Norris, the British Film commissioner, said all that could slip away rapidly because we could not compete with the incentives being offered in Canada and Australia. "Five years ago we had a strong lead over Canada and Australia. That is no longer the case. We are in danger of being overtaken if we are not careful," he said.

With only one big US project being shot here this winter - Steven Spielberg's Band Of Brothers mini-serial - alarm bells have been sounding.

Late last week the trail-blazing US studio, Miramax, cut its links with its British arm, whose highly rated new version of Jane Austen's Mansfield Park is about to be released.

Nervousness within the industry was further compounded by rumours that Universal - which last year swallowed up Polygram, the last big Anglo-European studio - might be about to offload its film interests.

Removing the cap on tax incentives so that films with budgets bigger than £15m can take full advantage of them is the only way to attract Hollywood back, Mr Norris said. "At the moment the studios look at Britain and see that a £50m film gets no more tax break than a £15m one, so they think, 'It's not designed for us. It's just there to help smaller films'. The simple fact is that if we don't have the big Hollywood films we won't have an infrastructure to build our own industry on.

"We did fantastically well for most of last year despite the final demise of Polygram, and the strong pound. But the real worry is we had nothing in the final quarter, and this year has been no better.

"The signs are not good. Apart from Spielberg there is nothing on the horizon but the hope that Warner Bros might do their version of the Harry Potter books here."

The film council, the new body led by the director, Alan Parker, is urgently reviewing ways in which the tax regime could be reformed.

The competition posed by the raft of new studios in Toronto has not only resulted in lost sleep here. So great is the Canadian threat that Hol lywood itself has been thrown into a panic about "runaway productions" which have moved north to take advantage of cheaper Canadian facilities.

Canada and Australia are not the only countries which would like to steal Britain's lu crative slice of the cake. South Africa is also muscling in on the scene, and Ireland, which has lost out to Britain in recent years because of uncertainly about its section 481 tax exemption scheme, is beginning to tempt film-makers back.

"We have got to get an edge and keep it," said Mr Norris. "We have so many strengths in terms of talent, facilities and the skills of our artists and technicians. The fact that this is a pretty cool place to be right now if you're a Hollywood star also helps.

"I am not sure how much longer the strength of our technicians and artists alone will be enough to sustain the UK as a production centre."

The government, however, is much more upbeat. The culture secretary, Chris Smith, who has been credited with helping to turn round the for tunes of British film, is said to be "making sure the chancellor is aware of the arguments". But a spokeswoman for the department of culture said trends were encouraging.

"This is a film-friendly government. Ninety-eight films were made here last year, which shows the benefits of the simple low-rate tax system we introduced in 1997. However, if it was down to tax alone we would have lost out long ago to Canada and Australia. Our talent base and great reserves of expertise are also a major factor."

webTitle: Low budget East is East wins accolade

fields.headline: Low budget East is East wins accolade
fields.trailText: The low budget comedy East is East last night won the best film title at the 27th Evening Standard British Film Awards.
fields.body:
The low budget comedy East is East last night won the best film title at the 27th Evening Standard British Film Awards.

The sometimes bleak comic tale of a traditional Muslim father forced to review long-held beliefs by his seven rebellious children scooped the award at a ceremony in London.

Jeremy Northam was named best actor for his roles in An Ideal Husband and The Winslow Boy, and Samantha Morton's performance in Dreaming of Joseph Lees won her the best actress prize.

Tom Stoppard capped a phenomenally successful year for the multi-Oscar and Bafta-winning film Shakespeare in Love by winning the best screenplay prize.

Notting Hill, the highest-grossing British film of all time, won the Peter Sellers award for comedy.

The special award for lifetime achievement was presented to cinematographer Freddie Francis by Jessica Lange, who worked with him on the 1992 remake of Cape Fear.

Allocating this year's awards was a difficult process, largely because of the number of candidates eligible for each prize, said film critic Neil Norman, who was one of the judges.

"Among those which caused a bit of debate were Notting Hill, The Winslow Boy, The Warzone, Orphans and Ratcatcher," he said.

"In the best actor category, Terence Stamp was seriously discussed by us for his performance in The Limey."

This year's awards and winners were:

Best film: East is East

Best actor: Jeremy Northam for An Ideal Husband and The Winslow Boy

Best actress: Samantha Morton for Dreaming of Joseph Lees

Peter Sellers award: Notting Hill

Best screenplay: Tom Stoppard for Shakespeare in Love

Most promising newcomer: Peter Mullan for Orphans

Technical achievement: John de Borman for Hideous Kinky

Lifetime achievement: Freddie Francis

fields.headline: The new entrepreneurism
fields.standfirst: "Diana was the upstart challenger, an entrepreneur who used new technology to  outmanoeuvre the established but tired incumbent. For the royal family, read  IBM: for Diana, read Microsoft."
fields.trailText: "Diana was the upstart challenger, an entrepreneur who used new technology to outmanoeuvre the established but tired incumbent. For the royal family, read IBM: for Diana, read Microsoft."
fields.body:
We are all in the thin-air business these days. It is slightly frightening to work out just how little supports most of our livelihoods. In the past, people made their living by extracting ore, mining coal, making steel, manufacturing cars, bringing cattle to market. They mined, they made, they forged. Work was hard physical labour. As Bertrand Russell, the philosopher, put it in In Praise of Idleness: "Work is moving things around at or near to the earth's surface." The output of this labour could be weighed on scales, shipped in railway cars, measured with rules, stockpiled.

These days most people in most advanced economies produce nothing that can be weighed: communications, software, advertising, financial services. They trade, write, design, talk, spin and create; rarely do they make anything. The assets they work with are as ephemeral as their output. Of course many of us work in large buildings, offices and factories and we work with machinery and equipment, computers and robots. Yet the real assets of the modern economy come out of our heads not out of the ground: ideas, knowledge, skills, talent and creativity. Indeed, the richer and more powerful the person, the more likely it is that they make their money by manipulating ephemera and intangibles rather than from labour in any recognisable sense.

There is no better example of this than one of the most successful thin-air businesses ever created, the British Royal Family, and one of the world's leading practitioners of thin-air economics, the late Diana, Princess of Wales.

The British Royal Family has no output other than symbolism, a vague sense of well-being it occasionally induces in its citizenry and a lot of gossip. Of course, the Royal Family is very rich. It owns a lot of prime real estate. But that is not the source of its power or standing. People do not come to see Buckingham Palace because it is a beautiful or striking building. They come because the Queen lives there. The Royal Family's value is as a national symbol: it's a brand. Its power and influence stem entirely from the ephemeral world of gestures and symbols. Its most precious assets are not physical but intangible: public popularity, loyalty, affection and the dwindling stock of human capital that are its members. Princess Diana proved particularly adept at thriving in this thin-air business.

While the Royal Family remained rooted in the past, imprisoned by the assets and protocol which were once its strength, Princess Diana exploited one of the first laws of thin-air economics: those with the best image and ideas are more agile, quicker to adapt and better able to communicate directly with people than those weighed down by tradition, trapped by protocol or encumbered by physical assets which have outlived their usefulness. The Royal Family was trapped by its past, like a lazy, complacent incumbent in an industry it had long dominated: the very lucrative monarchy franchise for the United Kingdom.

Diana was the upstart challenger, an entrepreneur who used new technology to outmanoeuvre the established but tired incumbent. For the Royal Family, read IBM; for Diana, read Microsoft and the new challengers in the computer industry which have emerged in the last decade. For the Royal Family read Barclays and NatWest; for Diana, read First Direct and the telephone and electronic banks which are the new competitors.

Diana's celebrity was a product of modern economics. She was a celebrity on a global scale because we live in an era of global media, which allows a kind of global gossip. Celebrities have risen in tandem with the communications technology that makes them possible: it started with telegraph and wireless, now it is satellites and the Internet. When Charles and Diana got married in 1981 there were 11.7 television sets per 100 people in the world; now there are 23 per 100 people and broadcasting has been transformed by a digital revolution which is spawning hundreds of channels.

It took 38 years for radio to reach 50 million users in the US. It took 16 years before the same number of Americans used personal computers. The Internet reached 50 million Americans within four years of being available to ordinary consumers. Global communications allow instant distribution of news and images at little cost to tens of millions of people. Pictures travel better than words. Words have to be translated; Diana's face was universal. Lennon and Churchill came up with memorable phrases; Diana came up with memorable looks. Gestures and symbols are the currency of global communications. Diana became a celebrity in the era in which Coke, McDonald's, Nike and Calvin Klein all became truly global brands, with symbols that could be recognized instantly from rural Turkey to Tokyo. So did Diana's smile. Images cross geographic and social borders far more easily than words. Diana was a largely silent star in a cacophonous age. Her life was meant to be seen, not heard. When she opened her mouth she destroyed her classless appeal and we remembered that she was just another Sloane. Princess Diana was a creature of the modern communications revolution. The current Royal Family, like so many of our other outmoded institutions, is rooted to its Victorian origins.

But visual images alone do not sell; brands need personality. We seem increasingly attached to celebrities, through whom we live vicariously. Although Diana was rich, jetted about for endless holidays and lived behind high railings, she managed to conjure a reputation for being popular and accessible. She broke through protocol and convention to talk in public about bulimia and adultery. Celebrities of old were meant to be flawless heroes who were held up as moral exemplars: intrepid explorers, ingenious discoverers, inspired performers, visionary leaders.

Diana, on the contrary, was compelling because she was flawed and seemed to acknowledge it. We knew more about Diana than most of us know about our neighbours. Diana was an intimate celebrity. Intimate celebrities - the famous people that ordinary punters feel close to and can trust - are among the most valuable commodities in the modern economy. They sell global products.

Consumer-goods companies increasingly use celebrities to promote their brands: they want that mixture of excellence, ubiquity and intimacy that celebrities offer. Nike is the prime example of a company which built its brand around its association with idolised sporting celebrities: Michael Jordan and Tiger Woods. There is a good economic reason for this. It's a response to competition. As markets become more crowded and competitive, it becomes ever more important for products to stand out by being distinctive. One way to achieve that is to associate the product with a celebrity the consumers admire, by investing his or her character in the product. Consumer-goods manufacturers have a vested interest in celebrities who can front their products to help them stand out from the crowd.

It should be no surprise that after Diana's death the biggest controversies were about her after-life as a brand, in particular who should control the rights to use her name and image to promote products and make money. Our emotional response to Diana's death was fleeting. The anniversary of her death drew a muted response. Her commercial value will be more enduring. Fame is the basis for some of our most important industries: entertainment, music and sport. As Diana's career in the Royal Family was unfolding, so was this structural shift in the character of the British economy. Britain earns more from exports of rock music than it does from steel. She started her royal career as a blast from the past: a gawky adolescent, seemingly bred for a life of duty, wellies, gun dogs, children and forbearance. She metamorphosed into the embodiment of global chic, style and independence. She went from old Britain of landed aristocratic wealth to a new Britain in which wealth comes from the media, fashion, styling, branding. Diana was just one product of this celebrity economy.

Diana's reach exemplified another aspect of modern economics: the power of directness. Diana went direct to the people by using the media. She bypassed formal channels. The Royal Family found that the protocol designed to entrench its power left it marooned, out of touch, unable to learn about the world around it. Diana, by contrast, seemed spontaneous, youthful, unstuffy. As Diana's brother, Earl Spencer, put it in his funeral oration, she was very British yet she had a global following (a combination British Airways still yearns for).

The Royal Family was a national industry, trapped by its dependence upon a safe local market. The Windsors were cut off, locked in the past, introverted, trapped by their own past success: not a bad description of many established companies, for example the high-street clearing banks. In financial services, as much as the royalty business, the rewards will go to those who go direct to the consumer.

fields.headline: Where's my share?
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Who wants to be a millionaire? The answer is that we all do. But the latest twist to the old song is that the internet now allows us to nurture our dreams without having to endure the torment of Chris Tarrant.
fields.body:
Who wants to be a millionaire? The answer is that we all do. But the latest twist to the old song is that the internet now allows us to nurture our dreams without having to endure the torment of Chris Tarrant.

Media analysts have been saying for some time that the value of online information is as much the information itself as the fact that the internet allows us to read it and play with it from anywhere in the world, at any time.

"Content"- what is put on the web - was a buzzword long before America Online, the world's largest internet service provider, confirmed its value with last month's bid for Time Warner, the apotheosis of an old media group.

The buzz has highlighted greater opportunities for journalists themselves. Accustomed to working in a business that sometimes prides itself on working for nothing, journalists are suddenly finding the laws of supply and demand working in their favour. News organisations have seen their West Coast bureaux used as springboards for dot com careers, while reporters have taken to using their leaving speeches to deny rumours that they have already been given a stake worth millions in their new online start-up.

Caught in the headlights of the online competition beaming on to their businesses, media groups appear to have woken up to the staffing implications in recent months. But how does an old media group compete with the lure of internet millions and continue to recruit and retain top-notch staff?

One solution is a join-them-if-you-can't-beat-them strategy. The New York Times became one of the first traditional media companies to take a definite step into this arena two weeks ago when it announced plans to issue shares that reflect the performance of its separate internet division rather than that of the entire company. Viacom is to make a similar move by offering shares in the web operations of MTV.

The attraction of issuing shares designed to track the performance of an online business is that the shares are no longer hindered by their connection to a slow-growing old media group. This attraction can be powerful. America's six largest publicly traded newspaper groups, which together own 140 newspapers and 54 television stations, were valued by the US stock market at about two-thirds of Yahoo, the internet portal.

The NYT is hoping to raise about $100m (£63m) by spinning off the nytimes.com and its other loss-making internet operations. The listing is not just designed to furnish the company with more money. In announcing its decision, the company declared that some of the shares will be available for staff members.

Few details of the offering are available because of US financial regulations and several questions remain about how these shares are going to be allocated.

The first is, does the company offer most shares to the dot com-savvy staff members they most fear losing to online rivals? The answer for most industry executives is often yes. The problem is that online websites such as nytimes.com are largely fuelled by the editorial staff of the paper edition. Why should these dull.co drones not be equally rewarded for their contribution?

Also, if a media group's internet operations are spun off, what happens to the value of existing assets? What investors will want to buy shares in a company faced with falling circulation, escaping classified advertising and disaffected staff?

Pearson, owner of the FT, has recently decided against a similar tracking stock for its online operations. Instead, the group raised money for its internet ambitions simply by issuing more shares of its own. This did little to answer the personnel problems, however, and the group - which has seen three FT technology reporters leave for dot coms in recent months - is set to announce a new staffing incentive scheme over the coming weeks. This is expected to spread Pearson share options throughout the newsroom.

Such options are unlikely to lead to the sorts of riches now part of internet lore. However, groups such as Pearson hope that the added bonus will retain loyalty to a less risky media business.

It remains to be seen how such schemes work. But they do represent one way of giving incentives to staff that are not open to the few remaining media companies with no route to the stock market. Notable examples include the BBC and the trust-owned Guardian.

Other industries have adopted different strategies to keep valued members of staff. Leading law firms in the US are understood to have increased pay by as much as 50% since the beginning of the year for some associates. Any journalist hoping that traditional media companies might follow suit would be wise not to leave that as their final answer. As Chris Tarrant might say.

webTitle: Hijacked aircraft lands at London Stansted airport

fields.headline: Hijacked aircraft lands at London Stansted airport
fields.standfirst: Live ITN video feed from the hijacked aircraft
fields.trailText: A hijacked Afghan aircraft with 150 people on board landed at Stansted airport today. Essex Police said the aircraft touched down just after 2am after a flight from Moscow across western Europe.
fields.body:
A hijacked Afghan aircraft with 150 people on board landed at Stansted airport today. Essex Police said the aircraft touched down just after 2am after a flight from Moscow across western Europe.

At Stansted, the aircraft came to rest at a secluded spot on a runway on the north side of the airport, about half a mile from the main terminal, with it's lights flashing. Several fire engines, ambulances and police cars were assembled nearby.

"The police will be trying to make some sort of contact with the hijackers and begin negotiation to establish what they want," said a spokeswoman for the Home Office, speaking on customary condition of anonymity.

"Obviously, we are hoping for a peaceful solution to this situation. At this stage, we are not aware of any demands or requests from those on board the aircraft."

The hijackers, who have released 19 hostages, seized the aircraft en route from Kabul to the Afghan city of Mazar-e-Sharif yesterday.

Over the last 20 years Stansted Airport has featured from time to time in hijack dramas. When planes have been taken over by terrorists and crews have been ordered to land in the UK, it has become routine for Stansted to be designated as the destination for the hijacked aircraft.

Stansted has been chosen because planes have been able to land there and be kept well away from the terminal building and other aircraft while negotiations can be carried on with the hijackers.

Stansted's record in this respect has been good with most hijackings ending peacefully with no passengers hurt and the terrorists surrendering.

The plane first landed in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, then took off after about four hours. Ten passengers allowed off the aircraft in Uzbekistan before it departed said there were eight to ten hijackers, armed with pistols and automatic weapons.

The plane was next forced to land in the northern Kazak city of Aktyubinsk because of a leak in its right fuel tank. Kazak special forces surrounded the aircraft and officials negotiated with the hijackers before allowing it to leave.

The plane later landed at Moscow where a further nine passengers were reported to have been released before it took off again last night and headed west.

Before leaving Moscow, Russian security sources warned the Boeing 747 could make "a European capital, possibly London", its next stop.

The hijackers are said to be demanding the release of an opposition figure opposed to the Taliban regime in Afghanistan.

fields.headline: All webbed up
fields.standfirst: Every Monday we talk to a county cricketer about what he's been up to during the close season. This week Simon Cook, the Middlesex seamer, tells us about his alter ego on the internet
fields.trailText: Simon Cook, 23, is a seam bowler for Middlesex. Last season he played ten Championship matches, before getting injured, and took 27 wickets at 35.33.
fields.body:
Simon Cook, 23, is a seam bowler for Middlesex. Last season he played ten Championship matches, before getting injured, and took 27 wickets at 35.33.

"Other cricketers keep asking me what I've been doing this winter. When I tell them, they go "aaghh". Basically, I work as a web author at bluewave.com, a web-design company that makes sites for people like BA and Glaxo Welcome. Designers hand the sites over to me and then I make them work.

I joined bluewave (who wrote the Middlesex website) in September of last year. I've always wanted a back-up career (I've got coaching qualifications but wanted something else), which is why I've not gone out of my way to tour.

I've done things the wrong way round, as usual. I left school at 16 and worked for a computer company for three-and-a-half years. That was when the internet was beginning to take off, so I started mucking around with html when I was there. Then I got signed by Middlesex at the beginning of 1997 and left to play cricket.

Unfortunately I got shin splints and only played one Benson & Hedges match that summer, which we lost. That winter I worked with a friend of mine who had his own reprographics company. He said to me, "I need a website, you need to learn how to do it - so let's kill two birds with one stone." I really got into it that winter and the following winter (1998-99) I wrote sites freelance.

This is the first winter I've been down in London and it has been great to socialise with the Middlesex lads. However, this internet job has taken over my life a little bit. It is one of those industries where you are paid from 9-5.30, but work for a lot longer. There is a fairly relaxed attitude to work here, providing it gets done. We are a very young company and a pretty liberal bunch so I socialise with them quite a lot. There is a good team environment, so in that way it is similar to being involved with Middlesex. The company are very keen on stress-management techniques - we've got table football, pool and other games.

I've kept in touch with John Buchanan [Middlesex coach in 1998, now coach of Australia] and it is possible that I might go to Queensland for the winter next year, or the year after. He gave me a lot of ideas. He was one of the first people to introduce Statmaster software to county cricket. He brought a laptop over with him and documented where the ball pitched, what percentage of shots were going through backward point etc, and then you got a printout at the end of the day. I travelled with the first team and worked the computer for him for the four months that I was injured. He is doing really well in Australia - I'm very pleased for him.

I've probably got another ten years in cricket if I stay fit but I'm very conscious of the fact that bowlers break down easily. I want to play for England and if the time comes when I think I won't be able to play for England, I'll get out. I'm not going to stay in the county system until I'm 34 or 35.

I'm not one for setting goals, but Gatt has said he would like me to get 500 runs and 50 wickets this season. I believe that is realistic, though if he'd said the same thing to me last year I would have been a little bit apprehensive. I've spoken a lot to our fitness guy John Neal about how I can usually only believe that I can do something once I've done it. I want to turn that around so I believe it before I've done it.

I don't train with the rest of the Middlesex boys because they train during the day, and I try and go two or three times a week to a gym in Richmond, where I live.

I've got two brothers Adam, 20, who has had trials with Middlesex and Northants, and Ben, 15, who plays U-16 cricket for Oxfordshire. They will both be better than me. I don't see as much of them as I want. When I moved down to London I said I'd try and go back home to Oxford once a month, but that just hasn't worked out. I will definitely go back before Middlesex start again on March 1. I only leave bluewave on February 28 so I haven't got much leeway. There is a Middlesex tour to South Africa on March 21, and I hope to get on that."

Simon Cook was talking to Tanya Aldred

fields.headline: The best loving couple scene
fields.standfirst: House on Haunted Hill
fields.trailText: With the group of strangers he has - apparently - invited for a night of terror assembled downstairs, millionaire showman Steven Price (Geoffrey Rush) shares a moment with his wife Evelyn (Famke Janssen).
fields.body:
With the group of strangers he has - apparently - invited for a night of terror assembled downstairs, millionaire showman Steven Price (Geoffrey Rush) shares a moment with his wife Evelyn (Famke Janssen).

"You see those people downstairs?" he enquires. "They're not the ones I invited."

"Yeah?" comes his spouse's reply, contempt dripping from her voice. "Then who are they?"

"You tell me. I don't know how you managed to hack into my computer..."

He hovers behind her.

"... but bravo!"

"Oh come on, you think I invited that bunch of rejects?"

"Well, it wasn't me, and if you say it wasn't you, then who the hell was it Evelyn? Ghosts?"

"Oooh, spooky ."

Evelyn turns, sneering slightly.

"You know, if you really loved me you'd find a way to drop dead in the next three seconds."

"Finding ways for me to die is really your deal isn't it Evelyn? Let's not forget the OJ knife with the not-quite-retractable blade."

He leans over her shoulder.

"Or your Jim Jones Kool-Aid."

Evelyn wanders away airily.

"Accidents. All accidents until proven otherwise."

Steven glares across the room.

"I'd be so happy if that were really true, Evelyn."

See also: American Beauty, The Last Seduction, Barton Fink, Prizzi's Honour

Don't see also: War Of The Roses

Pointless trivia: Famke Janssen has a degree in English Literature from Columbia University.

More pointless trivia: She made her screen debut in a 1992 episode of US soap Melrose Place.
