fields.headline: Virtual college for heads
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's plans for an educational Sandhurst will move a step forward today when more than 1,000 new head teachers will help launch revolutionary technology that will be at the heart of the national college for school leadership.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's plans for an educational Sandhurst will move a step forward today when more than 1,000 new head teachers will help launch revolutionary technology that will be at the heart of the national college for school leadership.

The heads - who have all taken up their first jobs in the past year - will take part in online discussions and debates using free laptops given to them by the government.

As members of a virtual learning community, they will get the chance to put questions to "expert witnesses" who are likely to include senior education figures such as the schools minister, Estelle Morris.

The setting up of the college is key to the government's drive to raise standards in schools, and will underpin its strategy to enhance the quality of leadership in teaching.

It will be housed in a £20m building, yet to be designed, on Nottingham university's Jubilee campus alongside its education and business schools. But next to it will be the potentially much more exciting virtual college - opening in September - which will offer heads learning and dialogue "at a distance" via laptops.

The technology, using software provided free by Oracle, has been designed by Stephen Heppell, the website expert who designed Tesco's successful SchoolNet 2000.

webTitle: Jittery Labour quits race to lead NUS

fields.headline: Jittery Labour quits race to lead NUS
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power: special report
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Labour has pulled out of elections for the next president of the National Union of Students amid fears that a Blairite candidate would have been trounced by a standard-bearer for the hard left.
fields.body:
Labour has pulled out of elections for the next president of the National Union of Students amid fears that a Blairite candidate would have been trounced by a standard-bearer for the hard left.

After 18 years of unbroken Labour control of the top job in student politics, the party's decision to avoid a contest reflects its dismay at a sea change in campus opinion since the introduction of undergraduate tuition fees and abolition of the maintenance grant.

Labour has routinely won national student elections since Jack Straw, the home secretary, became the NUS president in 1969. Until 1982 the party pulled this off in alliance with Communists and other non-Trotskyite factions, but since then it has controlled the office on its own terms.

In addition to Mr Straw, five other former NUS presidents are now Labour MPs: Charles Clarke, Phil Woolas, Stephen Twigg, Lorna Fitzsimons and Jim Murphy. Until last week Labour Students, the official party organisation in universities and colleges, had been planning to run Ben Monks, the Welsh student president, for the top job. But by the time nominations closed at the weekend, he had been switched to run for the post of national secretary.

Andrew Pakes, the current national president, said Labour Students decided to concentrate instead on campaigning to build campus support for the party in the run-up to the next parliamentary elections.

"During my time as president, I faced constant suspicion that I was out to stitch students up because I am a member of the Labour party. That made it difficult to carry out necessary changes in the NUS or undertake political campaigns. Labour Students now want to be more forthright in campaigning for Labour values among a largely apolitical student movement."

The organisation could do this better by standing back from the internal wrangling about the presidency, although it will run candidates for other positions on the executive, he said. Other sources in Labour Students privately accept, however, that the party would have fought to retain the presidency if it had a chance of winning. The leading candidates for the job are expected to be Owain James for the Greens, Chris Fabby for the non-aligned left, and Alison Angus for hard left groupings including SWP, Socialist Organiser and Socialist Action.

Mr Pakes won with slender majorities in 1998 and 1999 and is obliged by union rules to step down at the end of a two-year term. He said Labour Students got their priorities wrong when they focused on campaigning against tuition fees without paying enough attention to the impact of abolition of maintenance grants on disadvantaged students.

The NUS decided in 1994 that it was no longer realistic to demand bigger student grants.

webTitle: Critics chilled by far-right warning: we'll be watching you

fields.headline: Critics chilled by far-right warning: we'll be watching you
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: The rise to power of Jörg Haider's Freedom party has injected a new element of fear into the day-to-day politics of the citizens of this EU member state.
fields.body:
The rise to power of Jörg Haider's Freedom party has injected a new element of fear into the day-to-day politics of the citizens of this EU member state.

"I'm sorry but, before we go any further, would you mind showing me your press card?" asked the young man in the black anorak. "Now, you never know." He was one of up to 2,000 people who joined a marathon, nine-hour demonstration through the streets of Vienna on Saturday night. He said he had come along because "it is the only thing I can do so as to be able to say to myself: 'Whatever happens now, I have done something'."

After seeing the press card, he said that he was a unmarried sound engineer with one son, but refused to give his name.

Before the Freedom party took office as an equal partner in Austria's coalition government last Friday, Mr Haider warned that it would be watching its critics closely. As a high percentage of police are thought to be Freedom party sympathisers, it is clear that a lot of people are taking him at his word.

One smartly dressed young woman fled into the main body of the march as soon as I began to ask her opinions.

Blocked from entering the city centre by a ring of police, the demonstrators turned their protest into something of a pilgrimage. They marched out to the inner ring road, back to parliament, round the town hall and out to the inner ring road again, before finally being allowed into the centre. They then traced a circuitous route through its cobbled alleys to the headquarters of the Freedom party.

There, shortly before 2am, they began a sit-in in front of police in full riot gear, backed by a water cannon. But, in contrast to previous nights, there was no violence.

The only incident came when a young man was arrested after balloons filled with paint were hurled at a bank near the Hofburg palace.

The protesters blew whistles, banged gongs and drums, and let off firecrackers. In a moment of high farce, they marched in a cacophony around an open-air ice rink where skaters had been gliding about to the strains of a Strauss waltz. Some of those who marched brought their dogs; others carried or wheeled young children.

Miriam Mkzoch, who gave her name only after asking, "Do you think that this could have any consequences for me?", carried a placard with the words "A peaceful no". She said the idea of such a long march was "so that lots of people see it".

Student Ronja Vogl said: "I think that maybe now people will wake up. I think that now maybe awareness will grow."

Maybe. Vienna has seldom seen anarchic scenes such as those of the past few nights, and that could help to shock Austrians into a change of tack.

In the protest's waning moments, a passionate argument about Mr Haider erupted between a woman in an expensive-looking coat and one of the members of her party.

But ultimately the most striking thing about this dogged protest were that it was almost entirely composed of the young and that, on an evening when most of Vienna's residents' commitments were purely social, no more than a brave couple of thousand could be found to openly voice their dissent against a party that only captured 27% of the vote.

webTitle: Haider hints at 'political treason' by opponents

fields.headline: Haider hints at 'political treason' by opponents
fields.standfirst:
Austria in crisis Freedom party leader mixes soft words with threats, but protesters defy the politics of fear

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Jörg Haider, whose far-right Freedom party is an equal partner in Austria's new government, yesterday urged that efforts be stepped up to compensate Jewish victims of the Nazi era. This was among several gestures intended to allay international fears about his movement's rise to power.
fields.body:
Jörg Haider, whose far-right Freedom party is an equal partner in Austria's new government, yesterday urged that efforts be stepped up to compensate Jewish victims of the Nazi era. This was among several gestures intended to allay international fears about his movement's rise to power.

Mr Haider set aside a threat to block decision-making in the European Union and promised not to interfere with the running of his country's new administration. But, more ominously, he also used a live television interview to float the idea that Austria's president, Thomas Klestil, and the former chancellor, Viktor Klima, face a parliamentary investigation to answer charges of "political treason".

Though the president has made plain his dismay at the new coalition, he and Mr Klima have denied reports abroad that they helped to stir up the angry reaction to the new government from Austria's EU partners.

Mr Haider said an inquiry would help to clear the air. "It would also be in the interest of those under suspicion to prove in a credible way to an investigative committee that they have nothing to do with it, that they have not committed some sort of political treason against Austria," he added.

His other remarks, however, were in stark contrast to those of last week when he reminded Austria's EU partners that they required unanimity to make major decisions in the union and could find themselves blocked if they refused to deal with Vienna.

Yesterday, the Freedom party leader deftly reversed the equation. "We must cooperate in a trusting manner because unanimity is called for in some cases. We must ensure that the EU is able to act," Mr Haider said.

"Austria must now contribute to a de-escalation. We must build up confidence with the EU quickly so that normal conditions are restored."

Mr Haider has stayed out of the cabinet which the conservative People's party of chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel has formed with the Freedom party, instead staying as governor of the southern province of Carinthia.

He told his interviewers: "I would be a fool if I ruined this historical success, this change brought about by the Freedom party in Austria, by constantly launching crossfire from Carinthia."

Few political observers are convinced. He has secured the appointment of his most trusted adviser as vice-chancellor and, since leaving Vienna before the swearing-in of the new cabinet on Friday, he has dominated international media coverage by giving a string of interviews.

Probably Mr Haider's most credible pledge was to encourage compensation for Jewish forced labourers and other Holocaust victims. Though he has played on xenophobic sentiment to argue for a reduction in immigration, even critics say that they believe him when he says he is not anti-semitic.

"A government that is patriotic must ... be ready to draw the consequences from the past, and where we have inflicted great injustice on our Jewish fellow citizens or wiped out their families, we must take pertinent measures," Mr Haider said.

He also called for compensation for Austrian prisoners of war and Sudeten Germans who were expelled from post-war Czechoslovakia. But, questioned further, he insisted that there would be no link between the two issues.

His offer nevertheless raised the intriguing question of whether he would be ready to pay compensation in respect of his family's estates. Mr Haider, who comes from a Nazi family, lives on 38,000 acres of land once owned by Jews forced to sell up after Germany annexed Austria.

Demonstrations against the new government were staged at the weekend in Salzburg, Graz, Klagenfurt and Bregenz. But unlike Friday's protests in Vienna, they were peaceful.

webTitle: BSkyB reaches content supply deal with Vodafone

fields.headline: BSkyB reaches content supply deal with Vodafone
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: BSkyB is understood to have reached agreement with Vodafone to supply the company with sports, news and entertainment content for its next generation of mobile phones.
fields.body:
BSkyB is understood to have reached agreement with Vodafone to supply the company with sports, news and entertainment content for its next generation of mobile phones.

Under the terms of the deal Sky Sports, Sky Movies and Sky One branded content will be made available to Vodafone customers with wireless application protocol or WAP phones. Users will be able to receive football scores and news headlines in real time from March. As technology advances Vodafone users will be able to watch live BSkyB sports and news broadcasts via their handsets.

The deal is BSkyB's first major content deal with a mobile phone company and is understood to have been brokered by John Swinge wood, BSkyB's head of new media. A spokesman for BSkyB would not comment but it is likely chief executive Tony Ball will confirm the accord when BSkyB announces its full-year results on Wednesday. A Vodafone spokesman was unavailable for comment.

Mr Ball is expected to outline BSkyB's new media investment and distribution following investments in toyzone.co.uk, Sportal and gameplay.com Analysts are keen to see how BSkyB plans to leverage its content off new distribution platforms.

webTitle: Day of mourning at refuge in Vienna mourn hopes

fields.headline: Day of mourning at refuge in Vienna mourn hopes
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: A black flag hangs from a window of Integrationshaus (Intergration House) in Leopoldstadt, in Vienna. It marks the harmful effect that Austria's new far right government could have on relations between Austrian citizens and foreign residents.
fields.body:
A black flag hangs from a window of Integrationshaus (Intergration House) in Leopoldstadt, in Vienna. It marks the harmful effect that Austria's new far right government could have on relations between Austrian citizens and foreign residents.

"One of our biggest fears is that anti-foreigner feeling will now become socially-acceptable," said Andrea Erasland-Weninger, the manager of Integrationshaus, a temporary home to 106 refugees and asylum seekers.

"If our top politicians are saying asylum seekers are criminals, and that there is 'Uberfremdung' (too many foreigners) in Austria, then it won't be long before we hear such simplistic statements expressed by ordinary people."

She is worried that Integrationshaus, funded by the state, Vienna city council and the EU, may be under threat.

The project is the most extensive of its kind in Austria, offering German language classes and help with integration at school and in the work place. When it was established five years ago, it received support from all political parties - except for Jörg Haider's Freedom party.

The new government's programme - including plans to cut the number of pupils in classes "for whom German is not the mother tongue", to halt further immigration, to make Austrian citizenship harder to obtain and to ditch plans to introduce dual nationality - threaten its existence, said Ms Erasland Weninger.

The project needs £800,000 a year, but the asylum seekers now fear that state subsidies will be cut, and that the EU will withdraw crucial support.

A 33-year-old Bosnian man who has lived in Austria for seven years said: "Just the fact that more than one in four Austrians voted for the Freedom party is enough to make us think twice about staying here. After all, where was Hitler born? In Austria."

webTitle: BBC flexes muscles with sports website launch

fields.headline: BBC flexes muscles with sports website launch
fields.standfirst:
The future of the BBC: special report
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC will launch a dedicated sports service on the internet as part of plans drawn up by director general Greg Dyke to make better sporting coverage a top priority of his early days in office.
fields.body:
The BBC will launch a dedicated sports service on the internet as part of plans drawn up by director general Greg Dyke to make better sporting coverage a top priority of his early days in office.

In one of his first big policy decisions Mr Dyke has authorised the creation of a sports website providing text, pictures, graphics, audio and video on domestic and international sporting events.

The site will have up to date news, including a results service. Although the budget has yet to be set, staff have already begun work on the site.

Mr Dyke is understood to see the site as a means of winning back some of the ground lost by the BBC to rival broadcasters in the battle for sports rights.

The BBC has come in for fierce criticism over its failure to bid high enough for big sporting events. Some MPs have voiced concern that the loss of sport to commercial services such as BSkyB is eroding support for the BBC and now causing real damage to its future.

Mr Dyke hopes that the new internet service will be a window on to the BBC's sports coverage, pulling its disparate elements together into a powerful display of what the broadcaster has to offer.

The site is being developed by BBC News Online, but will be run by BBC Sport. Bob Eggington, project director at BBC News Online, said the new site would be launched to coincide with the cup final of the Euro 2000 football championship in the summer.

The site, to be found at BBCsport.net, will offer dedicated sections for "six or seven" of the most popular sports. There will also be coverage of a huge range of other sports not normally given prominence.

BBC executives are keen to ensure the site is running in time to cover the Olympic Games in Australia in September and next season's football.

Mr Eggington said that the broadcaster would acquire enough internet sports rights to offer a "substantial" multi-media service, including video streaming.

webTitle: Archer 'asked agent to alter libel evidence'

fields.headline: Archer 'asked agent to alter libel evidence'
fields.standfirst: The fall of Archer: special report
fields.trailText: Jeffrey Archer is facing more embarrassment after claims by his former literary agent that the disgraced novelist asked him to alter his evidence during his 1987 libel case against the Daily Star.
fields.body:
Jeffrey Archer is facing more embarrassment after claims by his former literary agent that the disgraced novelist asked him to alter his evidence during his 1987 libel case against the Daily Star.

Richard Cohen, who played a key role in establishing the millionaire's writing career, is to tell detectives that Lord Archer asked him to give an inaccurate account of his movements on the night that the peer was alleged to have slept with a prostitute.

The intervention by Mr Cohen follows Lord Archer's five-year expulsion from the Tory party after he admitted asking another friend to provide a false alibi for his libel action.

William Hague underlined his anger with Lord Archer yesterday when he accused him of "kicking" the party by failing to admit his dishonesty.

Lord Archer's latest setback will come when Mr Cohen tells Scotland Yard detectives, who are investigating the novelist's false alibi admission, that he was asked to push back the time he left a restaurant on the night that Lord Archer was alleged to have slept with the prostitute Monica Coghlan.

Mr Cohen told the high court in 1987, during the libel case, that he had dined with his then wife, Caroline, Lord Archer and other friends at Le Caprice restaurant in Mayfair, central London. Mr Cohen said that he left the restaurant at 10.30pm.

His refusal to change the time he left the restaurant - Lord Archer asked Mr Cohen to say he had left at 11pm - meant that the peer needed to concoct an alibi for later that evening. That was provided by the theatrical agent, Terence Baker, who has since died.

Mr Cohen, who now lives in New York, told the Sunday Telegraph: "Jeffrey rang me and said he felt we left the restaurant closer to 11pm and would like me to say so. Everyone knew I was to be a witness in the trial.

"He was unhappy that I wouldn't change my version of events. I told him that I would have to stay with the story."

The disclosure by Mr Cohen will greatly add to the pressure on Lord Archer and may ensure that he is never allowed to rejoin the Conservatives. Some MPs felt that he was lucky to have been expelled for just five years by the party's ethics and integrity committee.

Mr Hague made it clear yesterday that Lord Archer would not be welcome back in the party as long as he remained Tory leader.

Speaking on Breakfast with Frost, on BBC1, Mr Hague said: "I have felt very let down and very disappointed about Jeffrey Archer. He kicked us when we were just getting up. It's tough."

He added: "We have got to rid ourselves of the problems of the past. We have got to rid ourselves of the idea that people can behave in any way and get away with it."

webTitle: More sackings to come in revamp

fields.headline: More sackings to come in revamp
fields.standfirst:
Frenchman from Paris theme park aims to revive fortunes of London landmark

The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: More heads are expected to roll at the Millennium Dome today as senior management is purged in the wake of the extraordinary sacking of the chief executive, Jennie Page.
fields.body:
More heads are expected to roll at the Millennium Dome today as senior management is purged in the wake of the extraordinary sacking of the chief executive, Jennie Page. The position of her number two, Liam Kane, was last night said to be barely tenable and several other senior figures also looked likely to go in the shake-up following Ms Page's replacement by Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, a hitherto obscure executive at Disneyland Paris.

Publicity for the dome was yesterday being handled by an outside company, and other functions such as marketing may also be taken out of the hands of the New Millennium Experience Company.

The government is pinning all its hopes of salvaging the dome on the 34-year-old Frenchman, described last night as a "whizzkid and high-flyer who knows how to put bums on seats".

Bizarre

Mr Gerbeau, who takes over today, was number six in Disneyland before he left last year to go back to university. He was not the main driving force who turned round the then failing Euro Disney theme park in the mid-90s. And whereas Disney spent millions on new attractions to rescue its renamed Paris operation, no more money is likely to be lavished on the dome, which has already cost nearly £500m of lottery cash. Only on Friday the Millennium Commission refused to loan the dome an extra £60m to cover its cashflow crisis, and asked it to make do with half.

The bizarre details emerged last night of how Ms Page, 55, was unseated in a coup led by several disgruntled sponsors and board members who had been meet ing behind her back since the opening night debacle on New Year's Eve, when thousands of invitations were not sent out and VIPs were kept waiting for hours at Stratford tube station by security staff.

With the disastrous attendance figures for the first month about to be made public, and Manpower, which sponsors the work zone, calling for her head, Ms Page is understood to have agreed to Mr Gerbeau working alongside her as chief operating officer after a stormy meeting with Lord Falconer, minister for the dome, and 10 of the sponsors on Wednesday evening.

But in a strange u-turn, the chairman of the board, Bob Ayling, called her to another meeting the next day and told her she would have to resign or be sacked. The combative Ms Page, who is known to have had several shouting matches with Lord Falconer about government interference in the project, refused to go.

The angry exchange ended with Ms Page neither resigning nor having been sacked from the £150,000-a-year hot seat. She will meet NMEC later this week to discuss her severance terms. The £200,000 bonus she is owed for completing the dome on time has not yet been paid.

Ms Page, a career civil servant who previously ran English Heritage, was reportedly in tears as she cleared her desk at the dome on Friday. She refused to answer questions at her Cambridgeshire home yesterday, but friends said she felt betrayed by her board and the government.

"This is the most scandalous, disgusting, stomach-wrenching example of scapegoating I have ever witnessed," said Geoff Wainwright, former head of archaeology at English Heritage. "Jennie is steadfast, loyal and as straight as a die. She was given an impossible brief and she performed a miracle. No one else could have opened that building on time. If the contents are not all that some might have hoped, it is because others let her down and the government and sponsors did not know what they wanted and interfered at every step of the way."

Adam Nicolson, the dome's official historian, said although he had clashed with Ms Page and often "came away spitting with anger and frustration at her bullying", he respected her as a manager. He said her sacking was "one of the most nauseating pieces of scapegoating I have ever come across" and added: "This dismissal is as shameful an act as this government has indulged in."

The decision to unseat Ms Page was far from unanimous and at least two board members are believed to be unhappy at the manner of her departure. The shambolic nature of her dismissal could also cost the NMEC dear if it she decides to take legal action, notwithstanding the further embarrassment the affair could cause the government if it is aired in the courts. Ms Page had a good rapport with Peter Mandelson, the original minister for the dome, but her relations with Lord Falconer have been fiery - though last night he strongly denied that he played a part in her sacking.

"This is a board decision, they took judgments on the basis of business. The dome can't be run by politicians or people from Whitehall. This has got to be run by people who know how to run a visitor attraction."

However, William Hague said her departure was a blatant example of political interference. "She is a scapegoat," the Tory leader said.

Critical

Pressure began to built on Ms Page last week as the deficit caused by poor advance ticket sales and three of the sponsors withholding payments became critical. Ian Herbertson, managing director of Manpower, called for "a fresh person at the top with fresh ideas" and other sponsors at Wednesday night's meeting demanded changes to their zones and complained that Ms Page was not taking their opinions seriously.

In a cruel twist, the dome had one of its best weekends, with more than 20,000 visitors on Saturday and yesterday.

Mr Gerbeau, who speaks fluent American and likes to be called YP, visited the dome twice last week when he was being wooed by NMEC. A dome source said he expected him to "tweak" some of the zones and add further attractions outside.

Ms Page has long been linked with the Royal Shakespeare Company, which will start interviewing for a new chief executive later this month.

Why crowds have stayed away from the 'greatest show on earth'

Problem: The dome has, not to put too fine a point on it, an image problem.

Solution: A new name worked with Euro Disney, but few think that Pierre-Yves Gerbeau will repeat the same trick with the dome.

The "one amazing day" slogan seems likely to go, however, as many feel it gives the impression the dome can be seen in just one day.

Problem: Inflexible and some say high ticket prices.

Solution: Although the dome claims its £50 family tickets are better value than most theme parks, industry insiders say the £20 adult charge is steep for such a derided day out.

More flexible ticket prices, with big discounts mid-week when the dome is usually very empty, would boost numbers.

Problem: Lack of foreign visitors.

Solution: Despite claims that the dome is admired abroad, only 11% of visitors so far have been foreign tourists.

With the home market so wary of the dome, experts argue advertising should be aimed at wooing visitors from the US, Europe and Japan.

Problem: What is the dome for?

Solution: This is the riddle which no one has been quite able to explain. Marketing analysts say the public will only warm to the dome when they know what it is. The "greatest show on earth" label is misleading. Mr Gerbeau must come up with a convincing alternative.

Problem: How do you get there?

Solutions: Lingering worries about the reliability of the new Jubilee tube line, and a perception that it is impossible to drive to the dome are keeping people away. With the exception of a £30 National Express offer, there are few good all-in deals. Many hotel offers are only based on a one-day tour of the dome.

fields.headline: Dome scapegoat
fields.standfirst:
Let parliament identify the real culprits
The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: The good ship Dome is in danger of sinking, with a barrage of foul publicity, attendances - and therefore revenue - hopelessly down on what was expected and needed, and sponsors becoming mutinous. So the nearest thing it has to a captain - Jennie Page, chief executive of the company that runs it - is required to walk the plank, making way for an entrepreneur who redeemed the fortunes of Euro-Disney, which got off to an even worse start than the Dome. There has to be a spectacular signal that change is under way and things are going to get better, and soon. Ms Page's presence is judged to be incompatible with that.
fields.body:
The good ship Dome is in danger of sinking, with a barrage of foul publicity, attendances - and therefore revenue - hopelessly down on what was expected and needed, and sponsors becoming mutinous. So the nearest thing it has to a captain - Jennie Page, chief executive of the company that runs it - is required to walk the plank, making way for an entrepreneur who redeemed the fortunes of Euro-Disney, which got off to an even worse start than the Dome. There has to be a spectacular signal that change is under way and things are going to get better, and soon. Ms Page's presence is judged to be incompatible with that.

Meanwhile the true culprits for the Dome's imperfections survive unscathed. It was not Ms Page who willed its creation without ever deciding what it was for. The real blame for what is wrong with lies with the politicians who dreamed it up but gave it no binding purpose - starting with Michael Heseltine, who devised it, and continuing through a procession of Labour politicians who, having damned it in opposition, warmed to it when they got into office. Chief among these was Labour's first "Dome secretary", Peter Mandelson, though Tony Blair too was instrumental in keeping the project alive when it might have been better abandoned. The money it has cost to create it - almost £800m - is not in the strictest sense public money, since it came from the lottery, but it is money that could have gone to other deserving causes had the Dome never been dreamt of. Politicians decided otherwise.

The Commons select committee on culture, heritage and the arts should launch the earliest possible inquiry into a trail of miscalculation which started right on its doorstep. For Ms Page and her management team to be the only ones to suffer for what has gone wrong would be a gross injustice - indeed they face a form of injustice which a parliamentary watchdog has a particular duty to prevent.

webTitle: Keep your feet on the ground

fields.headline: Keep your feet on the ground
fields.standfirst:
The London Eye has opened up a whole new view of the capital - and it's a messy one. Jonathan Glancey has a request for city planners

The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: Last week the London Eye finally turned for the first time. It was, this newspaper commented, "everything the Dome is not: inspirational, classy and fun".
fields.body:
Last week the London Eye finally turned for the first time. It was, this newspaper commented, "everything the Dome is not: inspirational, classy and fun".

It promises to be hugely popular, a ride into the moist London skyscape above the South Bank, offering a gull's-eye view of the Great Wen, the Thames writhing through its density, the architecture - good, bad and indifferent - blurring into a great carpet of concrete and brick, glass and stone, which stretches out to the hills that frame the Thames estuary.

The crowds turned out in force for a similar occasion 217 years ago in Paris when the Montgolfier brothers flew an exquisitely decorated hot-air balloon carrying a sheep, a duck and a cockerel over the city in the presence of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette. These animals were sent on their mission for the same reason that dogs were later sent into orbit by the Soviets - to prove that animals (and hence humans) could survive high above the earth. Unlike Laika, the Moscow stray blasted into space aboard Sputnik 2, the Montgolfiers' animals made it back to earth in one piece.

Pilatre de Rozier, a science teacher, and the Marquis d'Arlandes, an infantry officer, flew in a Montgolfier balloon three months later. They made a journey over Paris of five and half miles and lived to tell the tale. More than that, they came back with a new view of not just the French capital, but of cities in general.

It would be another 120 years before the Wright brothers finally got a heavier-than-air machine off the ground under its own power. Yet the bird's-eye view first described by de Rozier and d'Arlandes stirred a new perception of what a city might become if planned from an aerial perspective. That legacy is clear to anyone who has looked down on Paris from a plane or the top of the Eiffel Tower and been awed by Baron Hausmann's grand, militaristic avenues and the radiating streetscape that emerges star-like from the hub of the Arc de Triomphe. It looks as if some rational god - Blake's Ancient of Days perhaps - has set his compass on the face of Paris. This is urban planning carried out on a Napoleonic scale and with as much tender feeling as resides in the breast of a hovering bird of prey. After the Montgolfiers - la cité du ciel .

High in the sky, you can't help wanting to redesign what's laid out beneath you. The imperfections of cities like London seem all too apparent from the air, even though the glory of our capital is its mix of serpentine streets, wandering tidal river and lush parks overlaid here and there by sudden bursts of rational 18th-century town planning or the grid of later estates and inner suburbs.

The great Swiss architect Le Corbusier couldn't help but see things this way. In 1935 he produced a curious book, Aircraft, in which he looked down from the great height of an architect's eye and saw cityscapes revealed in all their muddle and vulnerability. He knew, and said, that this view was a revolutionary one. Now we could see what was wrong with cities (the clogged, yet romantic density that holds such appeal to so many of us today). Now we could see how to replan them with surgical precision, to separate cars from pedestrians, workshops from homes, the bourgeoisie from the proletariat.

The dangers of this way of thinking about cities are easy to see. As well as gaining a perspective, you may lose one. A colossal city with a rich, miasmic life can become less than an anthill - an artefact rather than a dwelling place. And what worked for a compact site like 19th-century Paris does not always work for a modern metropolis.

When a city grows so big that it's impossible to see across except from, say, a 443ft Ferris wheel, it becomes anonymous in key ways. On this scale - the scale of London, Los Angeles or Tokyo today - the imposition of giant grid-irons becomes the stuff of wind-swept avenues and plazas, overscaled buildings, an absence of the small-scale shops, alleys, markets, winding lanes and unexpected moments that make old cities, at their best, such a delight. Instead of people on the move we have traffic flow, instead of homes we have domestic units, instead of small-scale interventions by architects and planners, we have grand schemes that take little account of the people who live in particular areas.

This was notably true of the High Victorian city when huge swathes of housing (slums, it's true, for the most part) were scythed through to make way for the triumphal arrival of the railways. Or again, in the 1950s and 1960s when planners and city engineers, wired up by gung-ho local politicians, drove dual carriageways through the hearts of our urban centres.

City plans, drawn up by worthy academics and architects in the middle of the 20th century, began increasingly to resemble wiring diagrams at one level and air-charts on another. London, according to a plan of 1944, was to be rejigged to make way for no fewer than five circular roads (today's M25 is one, the North-South Circular another). Scale and distance had made the city, in the minds of those responsible for its development, into a featureless map. Looking down from an aerial perspective, the city appeared to be manageable in a scientific and rational way. Now it could be replanned, restructured and, above all - to use a word fashionable in planning circles in the post-war era - zoned. This land here would be for factories, this bit for "residential use", this bit for "retail", and roads would link them together.

It's difficult not to feel omniscient when looking out over a city from the height of the World Trade Center, the Eiffel Tower or the London Eye. It's the sort of view emperors and dictators have always adored and that developers love to show clients. But this high view of cities can be dangerous. This is the same view that bombers of the Luftwaffe's Condor squadrons had of Guernica, that Heinkel and Dornier crews had of London during the Blitz, that USAF and RAF crews had of Dresden. The view, more or less, that Nato pilots had of Belgrade: at the end of the 20th century, what military pilots really saw was a computer-generated infra-red target, removed as far as technology allowed from the reality of children waiting to go to school or an old dog asleep in a dusty square.

Viewed from such a distance, life-filled cities become nothing more than abstract patterns. Ride the London Eye by all means, but remember that the humble worm's-eye view of the city - the view from the alleys, unexpected piazzas and ragamuffin street markets - is just as important as the bird's-eye view of architects, planners, dictators and God.

webTitle: Incomplete portrait of a serial killer

fields.headline: Incomplete portrait of a serial killer
fields.standfirst:
John Sutherland on Shipman's motives

Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: For the police and prosecution it was an open-and-shut case. Only one mote remains to trouble the mind's eye. Motive. Why did he do it? Why did he do it so often? And why lovable old ladies?
fields.body:
For the police and prosecution it was an open-and-shut case. Only one mote remains to trouble the mind's eye. Motive. Why did he do it? Why did he do it so often? And why lovable old ladies?

The best the investigative journalists and Panorama's psycho-sleuths could come up with was that he "wanted to play God". But Fred Shipman doesn't fit the part. Godlike he is not. Physically he recalls Raymond Briggs's proletarian Father Christmas. If it weren't bad taste, one might send one of those "Are they perhaps related?" letters to Private Eye. Shipman represents, as Hannah Arendt said of Eichmann, the utter banality of serial killing. He could, one feels, bore you to death.

Most of us will have sought an explanation for Shipman's killing where we are most familiar with the phenomenon - crime fiction. Where, among all those imaginary murderers of page and screen, has one encountered anything like this horrible man? Has the human mind, in all its ingenuity, been able to invent anything like him?

Hannibal Lecter - although he's another physician in gross contravention of his Hippocratic oath - doesn't fit. Too glamorous, brilliant, and interesting. Inappropriately enough, the analogue that comes to mind is a comedy - Frank Capra's Arsenic and Old Lace. Two dear spinster ladies invite lonely old men into their home and "put them to sleep" (as we say about sick pets) with their special elderberry wine. Why? Because the poor old fellows look so happy as they drift off into eternity. The Misses Brewster kill out of sheer niceness.

At some point, as the circumstantial evidence piled up, Shipman must have thought of playing the Dolores Claiborne card. Stephen King's novel opens with the callous murder of an old woman by her housekeeper, as the guileless reader is led to believe. The motive seems clear - Dolores will benefit by a (forged?) will. The carer is a killer. It turns out that the real motive was euthanasia. Dolores was putting her beloved old mistress out of her misery.

Shipman could have claimed that he too was easing his tired victims' exit from the vale of tears. They died with grateful smiles on their faces: for this relief, much thanks. The "morphine and woolly jumper" defence would have been unconvincing in a court of law but might have got him the ounce or two of sympathy that he will sorely need over the next few years. (Other prisoners, I suspect, treat killers of old ladies as mercilessly as abusers of little girls. I rather hope they do.)

One of the few things one knows at this stage about Shipman's past is that his mother died prematurely, in pain, and that morphine eased her death. Is there perhaps, in the cellars of his mind, a mummified Mrs Bates? Are we in Psycho territory? Did Shipman, like that other incest survivor, Paul Morel in Lawrence's Sons and Lovers, actually kill his mother with an overdose of morphine?

The unexpunged guilt of matricide would explain the repetitive nature of his crimes. In John McNaughton's chilling 1990 movie, Henry, Portrait of a Serial Killer, the psychopath hero tells his apprentice that if you are to succeed in this grisly line of work you must change your modus operandi every time. Otherwise patterns build up and you're caught. If Shipman saw the movie, he didn't learn from it. Neither, unfortunately, did the Manchester police.

Perhaps there was no motive - at least, no felonious motive. One turns to the greatest of crime novels, Dostoyevsky's Crime and Punishment. Raskolnikov, a student, murders a harmless old woman. Why? Not because he wants her tatty possessions. He has no sexual or revenge urges. He neither likes nor dislikes his victim. His is "a gratuitous crime" - a test of his mettle. Raskolnikov wants to prove to himself that he is a Napoleon. Only the little people, as Leona Helmsley said, pay taxes. Great people are above the petty restrictions of criminal, tax and every other man-made law.

Raskolnikov discovers that he is, after all, a boring little man. Punishment follows, not in the form of the gallows, but as conscience and humiliation. It would be nice to think that Shipman will, over the years, suffer terrible pangs of remorse, and perhaps even atone as best he can. Alas, that probably only happens in crime fiction.
fields.bodyText: For the police and prosecution it was an open-and-shut case. Only one mote remains to trouble the mind's eye. Motive. Why did he do it? Why did he do it so often? And why lovable old ladies? The best the investigative journalists and Panorama's psycho-sleuths could come up with was that he "wanted to play God". But Fred Shipman doesn't fit the part. Godlike he is not. Physically he recalls Raymond Briggs's proletarian Father Christmas. If it weren't bad taste, one might send one of those "Are they perhaps related?" letters to Private Eye. Shipman represents, as Hannah Arendt said of Eichmann, the utter banality of serial killing. He could, one feels, bore you to death. Most of us will have sought an explanation for Shipman's killing where we are most familiar with the phenomenon - crime fiction. Where, among all those imaginary murderers of page and screen, has one encountered anything like this horrible man? Has the human mind, in all its ingenuity, been able to invent anything like him? Hannibal Lecter - although he's another physician in gross contravention of his Hippocratic oath - doesn't fit. Too glamorous, brilliant, and interesting. Inappropriately enough, the analogue that comes to mind is a comedy - Frank Capra's Arsenic and Old Lace. Two dear spinster ladies invite lonely old men into their home and "put them to sleep" (as we say about sick pets) with their special elderberry wine. Why? Because the poor old fellows look so happy as they drift off into eternity. The Misses Brewster kill out of sheer niceness. At some point, as the circumstantial evidence piled up, Shipman must have thought of playing the Dolores Claiborne card. Stephen King's novel opens with the callous murder of an old woman by her housekeeper, as the guileless reader is led to believe. The motive seems clear - Dolores will benefit by a (forged?) will. The carer is a killer. It turns out that the real motive was euthanasia. Dolores was putting her beloved old mistress out of her misery. Shipman could have claimed that he too was easing his tired victims' exit from the vale of tears. They died with grateful smiles on their faces: for this relief, much thanks. The "morphine and woolly jumper" defence would have been unconvincing in a court of law but might have got him the ounce or two of sympathy that he will sorely need over the next few years. (Other prisoners, I suspect, treat killers of old ladies as mercilessly as abusers of little girls. I rather hope they do.) One of the few things one knows at this stage about Shipman's past is that his mother died prematurely, in pain, and that morphine eased her death. Is there perhaps, in the cellars of his mind, a mummified Mrs Bates? Are we in Psycho territory? Did Shipman, like that other incest survivor, Paul Morel in Lawrence's Sons and Lovers, actually kill his mother with an overdose of morphine? The unexpunged guilt of matricide would explain the repetitive nature of his crimes. In John McNaughton's chilling 1990 movie, Henry, Portrait of a Serial Killer, the psychopath hero tells his apprentice that if you are to succeed in this grisly line of work you must change your modus operandi every time. Otherwise patterns build up and you're caught. If Shipman saw the movie, he didn't learn from it. Neither, unfortunately, did the Manchester police. Perhaps there was no motive - at least, no felonious motive. One turns to the greatest of crime novels, Dostoyevsky's Crime and Punishment. Raskolnikov, a student, murders a harmless old woman. Why? Not because he wants her tatty possessions. He has no sexual or revenge urges. He neither likes nor dislikes his victim. His is "a gratuitous crime" - a test of his mettle. Raskolnikov wants to prove to himself that he is a Napoleon. Only the little people, as Leona Helmsley said, pay taxes. Great people are above the petty restrictions of criminal, tax and every other man-made law. Raskolnikov discovers that he is, after all, a boring little man. Punishment follows, not in the form of the gallows, but as conscience and humiliation. It would be nice to think that Shipman will, over the years, suffer terrible pangs of remorse, and perhaps even atone as best he can. Alas, that probably only happens in crime fiction.

webTitle: Fleeing rebels bring war back to the villages

fields.headline: Fleeing rebels bring war back to the villages
fields.standfirst:
Chechnya's civilians pay the price as fighting leaves Grozny

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Throughout the night, the rumble of Russian mortars echoed through the village; from time to time the entire sky flashed alight, and the clatter of machine-gun fire droned endlessly on.
fields.byline: Amelia Gentleman in a village near Grozny
fields.body:
Throughout the night, the rumble of Russian mortars echoed through the village; from time to time the entire sky flashed alight, and the clatter of machine-gun fire droned endlessly on.

The Magomedova family slept peacefully as the windows rattled and the walls shook, apparently oblivious to the unsettling hum of planes flying low overhead.

After four months of war, they no longer have the energy to drag themselves out of bed each night to shelter in their cellar. The women have developed a certain fatalism; whatever will be, will be, they say, and in the meantime they prefer to sleep as comfortably as possible.

As daylight broke, the results of the night's work became visible. Every window in the village's only secondary school had been shattered when a rocket landed in the playground. Only four days earlier, locals had refitted the panes in preparation for the school's reopening. Russian bureaucrats provided the glass - as part of their campaign to restore life to normal in the areas of Chechnya they refer to as "liberated".

The rest of the night's damage was restricted to the woods around the village, where the army believed a group of rebels was hiding. By morning, the intensity of the attack had faded, but the shelling continued.

Across the vast western plains of Chechnya, Russian troops are searching for those Chechen fighters who withdrew en masse from the capital Grozny last week. Civilians unfortunate enough to live in the villages along the rebel's escape route have found themselves under fire again.

The inhabitants of this village, some 15 miles west of Grozny, had hoped they would never have to endure more direct attacks. They had suffered three weeks of intensive bombardment in November, as the Russians sought to take it under control, and most of the buildings still bear the scars of that attack.

During the war that raged through Chechnya from 1994 to 1996, this village came to symbolise the worst atrocities of Russia's campaign; even its name still evokes a sense of unease in every Chechen.

The presence of fighters in the region has again made life extremely dangerous for these villagers.

Most of the rebels who fled along this path left the village swiftly in the direction of the mountains. A few dozen remain, hiding with their families throughout the village, emerging only fleetingly or under the cover of darkness - their beards shaved off and their uniforms hidden. They know that if the Russian soldiers catch them, an attack of unrivalled ferocity will be unleashed on the village.

Only amid great secrecy would Isa, 23, a fighter wounded badly in the ribs as he fled from the capital, agree to discuss the future of the rebel campaign. He had to be driven from his house in a nearby village to another building elsewhere before he felt secure enough to speak.

His description of the state of the Chechen fighters was surprisingly bleak. The order to retreat from Grozny had been given, he said, because the fighters could no longer go on.

"We had suffered a lot of casualties. The Russian ring around the city grew tighter and tighter, and the smaller it became, the more difficult it was for us," he said. "Every day there were air strikes and more casualties.

He left the city on foot with hundreds of fellow rebels, received cursory medical help at the tiny hospital in Alkhan Kala, before walking through the night to his family in a village west of the city. There he buried his weapon, hid his uniform and retreated to a sick bed.

"In my sleep I'm always back in the city fighting again," he said. "When I wake up, I'm surprised to be alive."

Later that evening, three more fighters walked from an underground shelter in the forests outside the village, through the pitch-black streets to the house where we were staying, eager to discuss the progress of the war.

Despite the long-standing Russian promise to restore electricity to the areas of Chechnya under their control, this village has been without power for five months. As such, the men huddled in the basement around a gas lamp to tell their tales of war, their long shadows thrown on the walls around the room.

Ruslan, a front-line commander from Grozny, said: "It was the right decision to withdraw from Grozny. We were tired and the ruins of the city no longer seemed very important to us. We showed the Russians what we were capable of, inflicted many casualties, and now we are resting."

He said the fighters would retreat to bases in the mountains to the south of Chechnya and wait until spring, when their strength would be restored. There were more than 50 of them resting in a nearby shelter in the woods, he said.

They are in transit, although he admitted that they would have to move on soon; the shelter had recently ceased to be much of a safe haven, as Russian troops suspected its presence. During the afternoon, fighter planes circled above the woods, and later a helicopter gunship dropped several bombs on the area.

The rebels need money, he said, adding that it was quite possible that some commanders would organise kidnapping raids to finance the war.

"The war isn't over," Ruslan said. "We will continue the fight until Chechnya wins independence - otherwise all these lives will have been lost in vain."

webTitle: Railtrack's safety role unchanged by post-Paddington inquiry

fields.headline: Railtrack's safety role unchanged by post-Paddington inquiry
fields.standfirst: Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: Railtrack's overall authority for controlling safety is to be confirmed in a report which will mark the first official retreat by government from promises made immediately following the Paddington rail crash in October.
fields.body:
Railtrack's overall authority for controlling safety is to be confirmed in a report which will mark the first official retreat by government from promises made immediately following the Paddington rail crash in October.

The Rowlands report, commissioned by deputy prime minister John Prescott within days of the Paddington crash, is expected to say that Railtrack should continue to be responsible for safety matters.

The report will fly in the face of concerns shown by the government that responsibility for safety should be taken away from Railtrack.

This is the view often expressed by Mr Prescott when Railtrack has been criticised by the railway inspectorate for poor network maintenance.

But the Rowlands report, to be published in the next few weeks, is expected to say that responsibility for safety should remain with Railtrack but in a subsidiary company which would still have to report to the main Railtrack board.

The report is likely to cause widespread criticism because Mr Prescott had made a point of singling out Railtrack's role on the day of the Paddington crash and setting great reliance on the inquiry to test whether it should continue to control safety issues.

Railtrack's failure to respond to criticisms about policy on signalling and passing signals at danger came under close examination. It was ordered by the health and safety executive to impose limits of about 50mph on the approaches to Paddington station.

The report will be seen as a whitewash in some quarters because even before Paddington, the government was expressing reservations about Railtrack's right to conduct its own inquiries into safety issues. The Rowlands report will be seen in conjunction with another official report, yet to be published, on the safety mechanisms to be employed in drivers' cabs.

On the day of the Paddington crash Mr Prescott said "money would be no object" in deciding what safety equipment should be installed in trains to prevent them passing signals at danger.

He mentioned a figure of £1bn without saying who would have to foot the bill, although the onus to do it was laid on the industry.

But this inquiry has suggested a money-saving compromise. For now, only the most sophisticated equipment to stop signals being passed at danger will be sanctioned on new trains for routes like the west coast main line. A less expensive system only stopping trains automatically at up to 70mph is recommended for less important routes, at a saving of around £700m.

fields.headline: Disney on Thames
fields.trailText: Jennie Page is not to blame for the Dome fiasco (Not quite the ticket as Dome cash cut, February 5). It is virtually inaccessible to anyone outside the south-east.
fields.body:
Jennie Page is not to blame for the Dome fiasco (Not quite the ticket as Dome cash cut, February 5). It is virtually inaccessible to anyone outside the south-east. A train journey from Harlech would take two days to complete. A visit can cost anything up to £200, when you take into account travel, accommodation, meals etc.
Andy Fidler
Coleg Harlech, Gwynedd
andyfidler@hotmail.com

 A whizz-kid from Disneyland is appointed to head the Millennium Experience. Does this prove the Dome is a Mickey Mouse set-up?
Cllr Alan Bailey
Leicester
albailey@dircon.co.uk

 The dramatic conversion of Alan Amos (G2, February 4) and his acceptance as a prospective Labour candidate seems, to those of us acquainted with him in the late 80s, to be of Road to Damascus proportions. If Alan had moved any further to the right, he would have fallen off the edge. If Millbank issues Jeffrey Archer a card, I'm off.
Gordon Watson
Colney Heath, Herts
watsons@clara.net

 If Alan Amos has "genuinely changed" what on earth is he doing as a candidate for New Labour?
James Leith
Norwich
james@jleith.fsnet.co.uk

 So Julie Burchill earns £2 per word (Letters, February 5). Given that most of those words are I and me, that's a bloody high rate per letter.
Tom Freeman
Sheffield

 I'm confused. Was it Keegan or was it Dalglish (Letters, February 2) who did the converting? And can we be sure it was St John (February 3) who had to move over? The least we should expect from the Gospel writers is consistency.
Rev Charles New
Wilmslow, Cheshire
charles@cnew.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Don't disable the minimum wage
fields.trailText: As a member of People 1st, an organisation run by disabled people with learning difficulties, I was appalled by Mencap's recommendations that statutory guidance on the minimum wage act should be amended (Pay law triggers job cuts for disabled people, February 4).
fields.body:
As a member of People 1st, an organisation run by disabled people with learning difficulties, I was appalled by Mencap's recommendations that statutory guidance on the minimum wage act should be amended (Pay law triggers job cuts for disabled people, February 4). Removing the statutory guidance would encourage companies to exploit disabled people with learning difficulties. It suggests that their employment should be classified as special placements which will never develop into "proper" paid work.

Once someone has been labelled as able to produce under 30% of the required work they will never again be covered under the minimum wage legislation, even if their output improves.

The assessment system that Mencap is recommending would be open to abuse while disability employment advisors are under increasing pressure to meet targets to get people into work. And the government will not be required to pay the difference.

Nor is exempting workers with learning difficulties from legislation the answer if they want to work longer hours without affecting their benefits. What is needed is the Green party's citizens income initiative, where everyone is paid £50 regardless of earnings. This would mean that everyone would benefit from being paid the minimum wage while keeping their £50 benefit allowance.
Simone Aspis
London

 My 27-year-old son has learning difficulties and used to work for two days a week. This has been reduced to one day. People with learning difficulties are already victims because of their handicaps - isn't that enough, without giving them a wage-handicap?
Merrin Holroyd
London

 Social isolation is a problem for people with learning disabilities. Employment provides the chance to meet people, gain independence and workplace experience.

United Response believes in the minimum wage. However, we recognise that some people may not be able to work at the same pace as others and recommend that they are paid a percentage of the minimum wage at a level set by an independent assessor.
Su Sayer
Chief executive, United Response

fields.headline: Fair trial for Irving
fields.trailText: I consider David Irving a near-monster, but I was infuriated by your article on his libel case (Courtroom 73, where history is on trial February 5). You could wait for the verdict. Competing views of the same events are what a trial is all about, after all.
fields.body:
I consider David Irving a near-monster, but I was infuriated by your article on his libel case (Courtroom 73, where history is on trial February 5). You could wait for the verdict. Competing views of the same events are what a trial is all about, after all. So are fairness and open discussion.

The "Holocaust acceptance/denial" polarisation has got us nowhere. That a huge and terrifying atrocity was committed by the Nazis is not doubtable. The sad fact is that there are many questions about the Holocaust which haven't been answered satisfactorily. Among them: where did the 6m dead figure come from? It certainly wasn't a body count. Was it an estimate? How was it arrived at? Did we bomb the railways and contribute to a typhoid epidemic in the camps? If the guilty Germans sought to hide the Final Solution by dynamiting the gas chambers, why didn't it occur to them that the mountain of corpses that they'd left behind might spoil the illusion?

I've never heard or read answers for any such (sickening) questions. Is this just because of my own ignorance? If it's because of taboo, is it any wonder that those on the far-right use our frightened silence to propagate lies?
Garrick Alder
London
garrick23@hotmail.com

 David Irving's extreme scepticism about evidence for the Holocaust contrasts dramatically with his failure to apply the same kind of scepticism to his own position. If one must play such perverse games with the truth, then Irving's own evidence could just as well have been forged by a sinister Aryan group, beaten out of witnesses or produced by people who were out of their mind - to name but a few of his favourite ploys. When will the madness stop?
Nick McAdoo
London
nam8@tutor.open.ac.uk

 The Austrian people's democratic choice of a government ought to be respected, so long as that government abides by all its domestic and international obligations to respect human rights and treats the people within its borders fairly and with full respect for their common humanity. The real lesson to be drawn from the recent Austrian election is that each successive generation of young Europeans must be reminded of the horrors of Hitler's "Final Solution to the Jewish Question", so that they will ensure by their votes and actions that such a thing can never happen again. For the same reason, David Irving richly deserves to lose his case and be bankrupted.
Prof Howard Elcock
Newcastle upon Tyne
elcock@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Is it checkmate for men?
fields.trailText: Helena Cronin's and Oliver Curry's Darwinian analysis of our changing socio-economic situation could go further.
fields.body:
Helena Cronin's and Oliver Curry's Darwinian analysis of our changing socio-economic situation could go further. Where women have basic economic independence, they can afford to be more discriminating in their selection of a mate. His genetic potential becomes as important as his economic attributes. It is natural to prefer superior genes to join ones' sparse, high-investment eggs, although it may mean a lonely, impoverished old age when ones' highly eligible partner seeks fresh pastures. However, sociobiologists have reassured us that genes and the peer group have more effect on the offspring than parenting, as long as the parenting is "good enough". Children are robust, childhood is a victorian invention, while DNA goes on forever.

Evolution depends upon some individuals surviving and breeding at the expense of others. Without natural selection, the human race will remain the same. Serial monogamy reduces the opportunities for some men to breed and increases the relative con tribution to the gene pool of other men. It will take more than Cronin and Curry giving the average beer swilling, brainless, unemployed British male a job to make him desirable. In the meantime, I only want the best for my children.
Elizabeth Miller
London
lizzie.miller@talk21.com

 One can only assume that Helena Cronin voluntarily accepted a lesser proportion of the commission than Oliver Curry. The view that "as women become better off relative to men, the incidence and success of marriage is likely to decrease" seeks to undermine the ongoing struggle for equal pay. What are they advocating? That a woman can only earn a maximum of, say, 80% of the wage of a male doing an equivalent job? Or even, that a woman, once married, should not work at all? What must be remembered is that not all women choose to have families, or indeed, male partners. Why should these women be penalised in the pay stakes, for a problem that could equally well be attributed to a male inferiority complex?
Clare Barrowcliffe
Sheffield

 Why is it that so many utterances of the Neo-Darwinists positively ache with conservatism?A high divorce rate among high-income women suggests marriage isn't everything it's cracked up to be. Such common sense is the opposite of the view urged upon us by Cronin and Curry. OK, family break-up can be a savage example of human ways. But not quite in the league of the Darwinian processes which completely eliminated the hairy-bodied, the wrong-thumbed, the non-menopausal and the dim-witted. That we are uniquely able to overcome the limitations of natural selection is nicely illustrated by the sexual equality which presumably went into the writing of the article.
Tom Snow
London
tomsnow@dircon.co.uk

 It is unlikely that many people before the Neolithic age saw the causal link between a certain man, a certain moment and - nine months later - a particular child. Without an understanding of paternity, there is no family. A small, cohesive, egalitarian band of paleolithic people, which was the pattern of 98% of our existence, did not need the family unit; the family is divisive of community, as well as being the arena of male domination, exploitation and abuse. Studies of family life under paternal power are not much good at revealing the "fixed human nature" Darwinists claim to understand: not surprisingly, they justify the old Darwinian attachment to Victorian values and the need for more, better, kinder, male domination.
Dick Frost
Appleby, Cumbria

It is natural to prefer superior genes to join ones' sparse, high-investment eggs, although it may mean a lonely, impoverished old age when ones' highly eligible partner seeks fresh pastures. Without natural selection, the human race will remain the same. Serial monogamy reduces the opportunities for some men to breed and increases the relative con tribution to the gene pool of other men. fields.headline: Unhappy times
fields.standfirst:
Labour, like nanny, must learn to let go
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The next few days promise further signs of the decomposition of Labour's May 1997 political settlement. After Kilfoyle, there is the choice of a Labour candidate for the London mayoral race. In between - tomorrow sees a critical vote in the Welsh assembly - the party may be forced to make another choice: either it keeps its anal-retentive style of control, ideological silence and intolerance of dissent or it embraces a pluralism that positively welcomes Scottish and Welsh deviation, variety in town halls and renewal of debate inside the party about its values and direction in a new century.
fields.body:
The next few days promise further signs of the decomposition of Labour's May 1997 political settlement. After Kilfoyle, there is the choice of a Labour candidate for the London mayoral race. In between - tomorrow sees a critical vote in the Welsh assembly - the party may be forced to make another choice: either it keeps its anal-retentive style of control, ideological silence and intolerance of dissent or it embraces a pluralism that positively welcomes Scottish and Welsh deviation, variety in town halls and renewal of debate inside the party about its values and direction in a new century.

The Welsh assembly has to answer a solid fiscal question - whether the spending straitjacket into which it was born can be altered so the United Kingdom can offer matching funds that will capture grants from the European Union for Wales. The need is unarguable. Outside the glitz of downtown Cardiff and the Samsung plants, much of south Wales is stubbornly undeveloping. But the censure motion which Labour faces (Plaid Cymru will win if the Liberal Democrats and Tories join it) is also about political style. Alun Michael, like Donald Dewar in Edinburgh, has been painfully slow to see how, in devolution, successful leaders must dance prettily: he must be seen enjoy the confidence of prime minister and chancellor while regularly putting symbolic distance between him and them. Slavish adherence to the line - Mr Michael too often gets compared to Stalin - is counterproductive.

The Cardiff crisis was incipient in the results of the assembly elections, where Labour's poorish showing was partly caused by its short-sighted insistence on Mr Michael. Now Plaid, the wind in the west after its by-election victory, can render the assembly ineffective. That would be a disaster. As an experiment in practical democracy, Cardiff has been more than worthwhile. In the number of women in frontline positions, in its daily workings as a mini-legislature, it puts Westminster to shame.

The next move must come from Downing Street. Gordon Brown is nothing if not a foxy chancellor: no "additionality" rule or territorial spending formula need get in the way of finding a way to spring the money from Brussels. For his part, Tony Blair has to countenance Alun Michael's replacement as Labour leader. It does not have to be black beast Rhodri Morgan; it does have to be someone London will find less tractable.

fields.headline: No groans over Titus
fields.trailText: Gormenghast (How BBC made a crisis out of drama, February 5) is the most imaginative, lavish and riveting drama I have seen on TV for a long time. Traditional period dramas have easier plots and run to set formulas which audiences are used to, so of course they get higher ratings.
fields.body:
Gormenghast (How BBC made a crisis out of drama, February 5) is the most imaginative, lavish and riveting drama I have seen on TV for a long time. Traditional period dramas have easier plots and run to set formulas which audiences are used to, so of course they get higher ratings. I'm sure if Gormenghast was imbued with the "17 sex scenes" and "bodice-ripping" of ITV's Moll Flanders the figures would be higher. But I am glad to pay my licence fee to enable the BBC to make uncompromising, innovative and challenging drama which doesn't trade quality for a few cheap thrills in a desperate attempt to gain viewing figures.
David McCleery
London

 Your list of successful costume dramas omits the high watermark, the 1976 BBC adaptation of I, Claudius. I suspect that this would fare no better than Gormenghast were it to be shown today, reflecting the way our tastes in drama have contracted in 25 years. Its perceived failure makes it all the more likely that novels will be selected for adaptation on the basis of how easily they can be turned into soap opera in frocks.
Kate Halpin
Salisbury, Wilts

 Gormenghast is a thrilling, once-in-a-decade piece of film-making. What a pity the Guardian published a hatchet article, designed to deter watchers. Of course Gormenghast attracts a minority audience. Have you never compared your circulation figures with the tabloids'?
David Spiller
Barrow-upon-Soar, Leics
Barspiller@aol.com

fields.headline: Rent review
fields.trailText: The idea that housing benefit claimants might be given "shopping incentives" (Analysis, February 3) is highly problematic. Faced with benefit shortfalls, most would not move home, but simply use basic incomes to pay rent - and/or would get into debt.
fields.body:
The idea that housing benefit claimants might be given "shopping incentives" (Analysis, February 3) is highly problematic. Faced with benefit shortfalls, most would not move home, but simply use basic incomes to pay rent - and/or would get into debt. For the minority who would try to move, there is further difficulty. In the south, they would not be able to. In the north, pressure to push the poorest people towards the worst housing would run counter to the social exclusion agenda. If it is undesirable to force claimants to trade down (and there is no evidence that housing benefit leads them to trade up), then shopping incentives seem to be a non-solution to a non-problem. The real issues concern unaffordable rents.
Geoff Fimister
Child Poverty Action Group
