fields.headline: The storming of Norman
fields.standfirst: Heidi Kingstone  on the civil rights veteran who defended the Ku Klux Klan and suffered for it
fields.trailText: Enshrined in every American's heart is the belief in the First Amendment, the right to free speech, as fundamental as the need to breathe. It was his commitment to this basic civil liberty that enabled Norman Siegel, a New York civil rights lawyer, to defend the Ku Klux Klan.
fields.body:
Enshrined in every American's heart is the belief in the First Amendment, the right to free speech, as fundamental as the need to breathe. It was his commitment to this basic civil liberty that enabled Norman Siegel, a New York civil rights lawyer, to defend the Ku Klux Klan.

Siegel, the Jewish kid from Brooklyn, executive director of New York Civil Liberties Union, veteran of the civil rights battles in the South, had always championed the underdog: gays, lesbians, African Americans, Latinos. But he had had his fair share of repugnant clients, too: the anti-Semitic black nationalist Khalid Abdul Muhammed, and the Black Israelites, an anti-white pseudo-religious group.

His connection with the KKK was brought about by the actions of New York's Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, who had turned down the Klan's application to hold a rally last October. Siegel was worried that the Klan would ask the NYCLU to represent it, believing that, if the union took the case, it might alienate the bulk of its clients, despite all the excellent anti-discrimination work it had done. He had good cause to worry.

In 1978, the American Civil Liberties Union had represented a group of neo-Nazis who wanted to march through Skokie, Illinois. They lost an estimated 7,000 members as a result. For many reasons the Klan's case was one that 55-year-old Siegel felt he could do without. The KKK's right to demonstrate was not something he wanted to get involved with. He told his staff that with any luck the Klan would never call. But of course it did. The Grand Imperial Wizard, the Reverend Jeffery Berry, wanted Siegel to defend it, "and I said I probably would. We set up the meeting and agreed to take the case."

A child of the 60s, Siegel was a law student at New York University as the Southern civil rights movement took hold. The South was, he states, where he learned the importance of free speech. To Siegel "silence is equated with approval".

And, he says, "It's harder to defend someone when you don't believe in what they stand for. It's a different dynamic. And the Klan is repugnant, wrong-minded, bigoted." Which is exactly why he told them he didn't believe in anything they stood for, and that their beliefs were offensive.

"It was also important to me that they understood that I believed in the first amendment, and that was why I would defend them. I don't think it came as a big surprise. They didn't make a big deal about it. I want to advance the issues of equality and justice, to defend the accused, the powerless and the controversial. This is what I want to use my skills as a lawyer for. I learned that the first amendment expects me to defend the expression of bigots, not their conduct."

He thinks America's love affair with the right to free speech has historic links to England, but notes that the US has a long history of Big Mouths. "I don't agree with the Klan but I would defend to the death their right to free speech, to invoke Voltaire. I don't think of myself as a lawyer for the Klan but as a lawyer for the Constitution. Maybe that has a ring of Pollyanna about it. But it wasn't until I saw the headline in a local paper - 'Klan's Lawyer' - that it really hit me."

The core issue is the inherent right of anyone to hold a peaceful rally. Giuliani, invoking a never used anti-mask law, had turned down the Klan's application because they wanted to wear hoods and masks.

Siegel is adamant that the government cannot pick and choose who can have access to free speech. Government censorship scares him most. But he draws a firm line between speech and action. Speech is protected, conduct is not.

"It's easy to say you're for free speech when it's non controversial, but are you for free speech when the speaker is offensive? Some think our defence of the Klan was one of our finer moments. You don't allow government to coerce silence."

At the same time as he was defending the Klan, he was also advising counter-demonstrators. Siegel acknowledges that the Klan could have complained about a conflict of interest and asked him to stop but they didn't. On the day the Klan held the rally, with no hoods and no masks, only about 17 members turned up. They had expected about 80. But 7,000 to 8,000 counter-demonstrators (some masked) took over the streets of Manhattan.

Even the black leader Al Sharpton and New York's leading black newspaper, the Amsterdam News, supported the Klan's right to free speech. "That helped enormously," said Siegel. "Leaders in the black community thought: if Giuliani could turn the Klan down, who else could he turn down?" In the six years of the Giuliani administration, the NYCLU has challenged the mayor 25 times in first amendment cases, prevailing wholly or partly in 19. Two are still pending.

"I was proud when I was walking in Harlem and I got a better reception than usual. People went out of their way to say that I had done the right thing." Riding the subway with the KKK on the way to court, Siegel thought that New Yorkers, known for their confrontational style, might create some uncomfortable moments. But nothing happened.

For him the experience was emotionally wearing. He received harassing phone calls, and the militant Jewish Defense Organisation picketed the Manhattan apartment block where he lives with his partner. In the past, whenever Mordechai Levy, leader of the Jewish Defense Organisation, was barred from speaking or picketing, he would call Siegel, who would represent him. Now the tables were turned and he was outside Siegel's home.

"He was very angry that as a Jew I was representing the Klan. They distributed fliers in my neighbourhood saying that I was a traitor. That was not fun. I am proud to be Jewish, but I had to do what I had to do."

He advised the Upper West Side building's management where to allow the protesters to gather, and asked them not to call the police, in order not to catapult the demonstrators into the limelight. Hate calls echoed in the middle of the night, some threatening to kill his family. "That's very difficult to get through. It's pretty scary."

Sometimes he would try to talk to the callers; one even ended up calling him a "mensch", Yiddish for decent person. "I like talking to people, and as I get older I'm better at listening to them. It helps defuse the anger."

Soon he will be back in court for another round. He has filed papers so the Klan can gather in the spring, this time wearing their hoods and masks.

webTitle: Case of the week:  You can't sue me, I'm immune

fields.headline: Case of the week:  You can't sue me, I'm immune
fields.trailText: As human rights groups and Belgium make a last-ditch attempt this week to thwart General Pinochet's return to Chile, another torture case is re-surfacing in the courts. As it was in Pinochet's case, the issue is whether the doctrine of state immunity allows agents of the state to escape liability for acts of torture.
fields.body:
As human rights groups and Belgium make a last-ditch attempt this week to thwart General Pinochet's return to Chile, another torture case is re-surfacing in the courts. As it was in Pinochet's case, the issue is whether the doctrine of state immunity allows agents of the state to escape liability for acts of torture.

Sulaiman Al-Adsani, a British-born pilot formerly with the Kuwaiti air force, whose civil claim for damages against the Kuwaiti government was thrown out by the English courts because of state immunity, will take his case to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg tomorrow.

Al-Adsani, who says he was wrongly suspected of distributing a sex video featuring a member of the Kuwaiti royal family, claims he was tortured by state security guards, leaving him with burns to 25% of his body. The English Appeal Court dismissed his claim in 1996, ruling that state immunity barred his claim. This doctrine can be invoked by foreign governments to avoid liability in the courts for serious crimes and civil wrongs, leaving their victims without a remedy.

Al-Adsani and two others who were denied a hearing in courts in England and Ireland, will argue in Strasbourg that the use of state immunity in their cases breached the European Convention on Human Rights, which guarantees a fair hearing.

Mary Fogarty worked at the US Embassy in London for an arm of the CIA. She was sacked after winning a sexual harassment claim against the US government over the actions of a co-worker. When she kept being turned down for other jobs at the embassy, she decided to bring a victimisation claim. But the US played the state immunity card, stopping her claim in its tracks.

The third case has been brought by an Irish policeman, who alleges that he was assaulted by a British soldier in the Republic of Ireland. When he tried to sue the British government for his injuries, the Irish courts held that the claim was barred by state immunity.

fields.headline: Mystery over the Shipman tapes
fields.trailText: I was surprised to hear, on radio and television (and now on the internet), a tape of the police's questioning of Fred (as he's known, not Harold) Shipman. Surprised because, as I understand the law, the police own the copyright to their questions, but the interviewee has the legal control of his answers. When   Fred West's biographer Geoffrey Wansell wanted to publish the Qs and As of West's interrogation, he had to get two permissions, from the Gloucestershire police and from the official solicitor, who was responsible for West's estate.
fields.body:
I was surprised to hear, on radio and television (and now on the internet), a tape of the police's questioning of Fred (as he's known, not Harold) Shipman. Surprised because, as I understand the law, the police own the copyright to their questions, but the interviewee has the legal control of his answers. When Fred West's biographer Geoffrey Wansell wanted to publish the Qs and As of West's interrogation, he had to get two permissions, from the Gloucestershire police and from the official solicitor, who was responsible for West's estate.

The Mirror last week also had extracts from Shipman's letter to a fellow prisoner, and bits he'd written to his wife. The law - James Hewitt's case is an example - is that while the tangible letter belongs to the recipient, the words on it (like the Princess of Wales's) remain the writer's. I understand that Shipman has not given his consent to the use of the tapes and to publication of his letters. So, have the media (and the police) taken the view that it doesn't matter, because mass murderers don't sue over breaches of copyright?

Naturally, the Shipman case brought to mind the 1957 prosecution of Eastbourne GP Dr John Bodkin Adams for killing an elderly woman patient who had left him money in her will. There was only one charge, but everyone knew that he was suspected of dispatching dozens of similar elderly ladies. Public fascination with the case was extraordinary; it was truly one of the trials of the century. But I mention it here because it became a strange example of a kind of mass lapse of memory by the public and the media.

Over the years I've spoken to dozens of people who, recalling the trial, referred to Bodkin Adams's conviction. In fact the jury acquitted him. That false memory cost the media a lot of money. There were frequent references to his guilt in newspapers. Bodkin Adams spotted them and sued for libel, often. The papers had to pay up. When he died in 1983 he left more than £400,000, a combination of old ladies's wills and libel damages.

Very few English lawyers have written legal whodunits of excellence. Sarah Caudwell, who died last week, was one of them. She completed only three books, the last published in 1989 (her fourth was perpetually delayed by writer's block) but they were all gems. The main characters were five young barristers of Lincoln's Inn and their investigative friend, an Oxford law don called Hilary Tamar, whose sex was never revealed either in the books or by the author privately. They spoke in mannered legal circumlocutions, wittily and urbanely.

The books were very funny, as well as being beautifully written and plotted. The somewhat convoluted style and dialogue were not to everyone's liking, but, curiously, she was very popular in America. The chocolate éclair on the face of the agriculture minister Nick Brown reminded me of the importance of such éclairs in the law of defamation and the general reputation of barristers. This is a true story. In 1988 an item in the Dublin newspaper Sunday World told of two Belfast senior barristers who, finding one Sunday morning that their favourite cake-shop had just one chocolate éclair left, had a lively quarrel, in front of other customers, about who had seen it first and who should be entitled to it. The story was totally untrue.

The lawyers sued for libel. It was not defamatory, the newspaper responded. The lighthearted item showed the lawyers as human beings, and no one would think the less of them. Not so, said one claimant, hugely embarrassed to see himself "canvassed as an ass". Their livelihoods could be affected, the claimants argued. People might not wish to use barristers who had lost their gravitas and behaved like squabbling schoolchildren.

Astonishingly, the battle of the éclair went before a jury. The lawyers won, and each trousered £50,000 damages. Never underestimate the legal importance of patisserie.

"Justice Beach", the solicitor commented when served with an injunction emanating from that judge "has got his hand on his dick." I would not normally mention anything so rude in this column, but in the light of the proceedings taken by our attorney general against Geoffrey Scriven for breaking an undertaking to stop "scandalising the court" - calling judges lots and lots of names - I thought you ought to know how other countries deal with the problem.

The cross lawyer in question, in Victoria, Australia, was charged with contempt of court. The issue was, in effect - forgive me if I use technical legal language - is it contempt to call a judge a wanker? Last year, the Supreme Court of Victoria ruled. The words uttered may, by contemporary Australian standards, be offensive, but they did not undermine confidence in the administration of justice. So, no contempt. But I wouldn't try it in this country.

fields.headline: RAF in bomb controversy
fields.standfirst:
Britain accused of dropping cluster munitions in Kosovo after Pentagon ban

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The RAF continued to drop cluster bombs during the Kosovo war after Washington had ordered US pilots to stop using them, according to a report published today by Human Rights Watch.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor  in Munich and  Julian Borger in Washington
fields.body:
The RAF continued to drop cluster bombs during the Kosovo war after Washington had ordered US pilots to stop using them, according to a report published today by Human Rights Watch.

The White House issued an executive order stopping the use of cluster bombs after 14 civilians were killed during a raid on the Serbian town of Nis, the New York-based human rights watchdog discloses.

The RAF dropped more than 500 cluster bombs during the 78-day war, far fewer than the US and none of them close to urban areas. However, unexploded cluster bombs - which distribute hundreds of bomblets - have maimed and killed civilians in Kosovo since the conflict ended last June.

The HRW report says that about 500 civilians died in 90 separate incidents - three times the number of incidents involving civilian casualties the Pentagon has admitted. But it rejects claims by the Yugoslav government that 5,000 civilians were killed. The Pentagon is due to publish a report on the bombing campaign today.

Cluster bombs had already killed up to 150 civilians before the attack on Nis on May 7 last year. HRW - which has called for cluster bombs to be banned - says the Pentagon secretly ordered a halt to the use of the munitions in mid-May, but alleges that "British forces continued using cluster bombs even after US forces discontinued their use".

Officials at the international criminal tribunal for the former Yugoslavia at the Hague conducted an internal appraisal of the case against Nato in December, but the chief prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte issued a statement insisting that the alliance was not the subject of a formal inquiry.

HRW's estimate of about 500 civilian casualties, though well above Nato estimates, is a fraction of that claimed by the the Yugoslav government. Today's report also alleges that the 76 ethnic Albanian prisoners Belgrade claimed were killed by Nato bombing of the Dubrava jail in Kosovo, were in fact executed by Serb forces after the raid.

Both during and after the war, Nato spokesmen insisted that Yugoslav forces operated a "human shield" policy and the HRW report lends weight to those claims.

However, it still constitutes an indictment of Nato air commanders, who the HRW claims could have done much more to reduce what was euphemistically referred to at the time as "collateral damage".

Several of the worst incidents involving civilian casualties resulted from the bombing of refugee convoys or bridges mistakenly identified as military targets.

The report says "these civilian deaths raise the question whether the fact that pilots were flying at high altitudes may have contributed to these civilian deaths by precluding proper target identification." HRW concludes there is insufficient evidence to make a definitive judgment.

"Once it made a decision to attack Yugoslavia, Nato should have done more to protect civilians," Kenneth Roth, the director of Human Rights Watch, said.

However, by HRW's count, more than half the civilian deaths caused by Nato raids occurred as a result of attacks on illegitimate or questionable targets or misdirected raids.

The report singles out the attack on the Serb Radio and Television headquarters in Belgrade on April 23 in which 16 civilians were killed and 16 injured. It rejects a claim made at the time by British ministers that it was a "legitimate military target".

Human Rights Watch calls on Nato governments to set up an independent commission to investigate the incidents, and draw up a new targeting and bombing doctrine.

HRW's military consultant William Arkin, who led the assessment team, said: "For a war with the reputation of being the smartest in history, there is an unfortunate pattern of Nato ignoring many important lessons from previous conflicts."

fields.headline: The start of the affair
fields.standfirst: Do you believe in love at first sight? A new survey shows most of us do.  Louisa Young thinks she knows why
fields.trailText: "Would you believe in a love at first sight?" Ringo intoned lugubriously and the chorus answered him: "Yes, I'm certain that it happens all the time." I always liked Ringo. Not best - best, I liked John. Liked is not quite the word. Our eyes met across an empty bedroom, mine four years old, his on the cover of my big sister's copy of Please Please Me, and I loved him. But that's another story.
fields.body:
"Would you believe in a love at first sight?" Ringo intoned lugubriously and the chorus answered him: "Yes, I'm certain that it happens all the time." I always liked Ringo. Not best - best, I liked John. Liked is not quite the word. Our eyes met across an empty bedroom, mine four years old, his on the cover of my big sister's copy of Please Please Me, and I loved him. But that's another story.

Do we believe in love at first sight? I do, absolutely. First sight is great. You look at them, they look fabulous, you fall in love with them. Easy. Second sight is the problem. You look a little closer, they have feet of clay, contrary opinions, open pores, unpleasant shoes, unreconstructed emotional baggage, a nasty habit of wiping their nose on their fist, dull friends and a slightly odd view of the Pinochet business.

Obviously it's harder to love someone when you know them. Even Lloyd Cole knew that: "Why do you tell me all your secrets when it's hard enough to love you knowing nothing?" This, apparently, is when you have to dredge up some even older wisdom, that a little knowledge is a dangerous thing, and get to know the potential love object better, so you can love them deeply and truly.

This, I'm told, is the hard bit - and the most rewarding bit. I wouldn't know, me, because by that stage I've generally gone off and fallen in love at first sight with somebody else.

Anyway, Mills & Boon, who have an interest in this kind of thing, have just produced their tenth annual survey of attitudes to love and romance, asking 1,009 men and women across the country what they think. The results are astounding. It's not so surprising that three-quarters of them believe in love at first sight, but - and here I am amazed - they believe it can last.

A third of men and women say they have experienced it - again, not surprising - and half of those went on to marry on the basis of it. Half the people surveyed think they might be vulnerable to it; but only 7% of those would have the courage to make a date on the basis of it.

Aha! I smell the rat. This is not so much attitudes as revisionism. If only 7% of half would get so far as even try to make a date, how come half of one third are getting married? I am not a brilliant mathematician, but I can tell rewritten history when I see it because on that subject I am an expert. For example, in the days when I believed I would find a nice man and marry him, every time I met a nice man, I would look at him and say to myself: "That's the man I'm going to marry." The sole purpose of this was so that, 50 years later, I would be able to amuse my grandchildren with the smug tale of how on the day I met their grandfather, I said to myself: "That's the man I'm going to marry."

I was buying into the romance thing, this ridiculous idea (based on a combination of Jackie picture stories, grand opera, Beatles songs and Romeo and Juliet) that we all have some romantic destiny, some "right" to true love. Also, I was prepared to fake it and intending to inflict it on my grandchildren. Sick.

So that's the rub. We want it to have been love at first sight. It suits our idea of what is right and good. It makes us appear lucky and true. We were clear-eyed, we recognised each other at once, we were not misled by fickle notions and untrue loves.

But I suspect love at first sight is a bit more like giving up cigarettes. "Was it easy for you?" "Oh yes, so easy I've done it hundreds of times." Just as the hundreds of times we give up smoking fade away when we really do forever, so the hundreds of times we fall in love at first sight fade away when we find someone to marry. That particular love-at-first-sightee becomes the only one we ever had. It's part of the born-again virgin thing that happens to some brides. It's extraordinary the number of women who suddenly never had a boyfriend before, the moment they get engaged.

Maybe it has to happen. Maybe buying into the same dream keeps people together. But real love at first sight - that Abilene cowboy you never saw again, that beautiful despatch rider with the terrible tattoos, that four-times-married alcoholic Bolivian war correspondent with an ex-wife on every continent - was just as much the real thing. When it was happening.

fields.headline: The age of dissent
fields.trailText: This year, we have spurned holiday snaps. We have holiday videos. Daughter makes them on her camcorder. We also have birthday videos, fiddling round the house videos, kissing the dog videos and people doing nothing in particular videos. I have waited months for Daughter to transfer them to big tapes, so I can watch them and show everyone.
fields.body:
This year, we have spurned holiday snaps. We have holiday videos. Daughter makes them on her camcorder. We also have birthday videos, fiddling round the house videos, kissing the dog videos and people doing nothing in particular videos. I have waited months for Daughter to transfer them to big tapes, so I can watch them and show everyone.

It was not worth the wait. It is a horrid shock to see oneself on video. Body is seen from all angles, accompanied by the voice and behaviour. I now know that I am a hulking creature with bad posture, a widow's hump, no waist, tangled hair and squeaky voice. There I am, bustling around at Daughter's birthday party like a bossy capon, or lurching about in an ancient bikini, drinking and singing in an uninhibited way or kissing the dog. The dog looks browned off.

Do I really flap my hands, have those strange pointy fingers, make bizarre pouting faces and forget to comb my hair? Yes. There is the cruel truth on video. I am an elderly matron gone to seed, an embarrassment at parties. Everyone else has known it for years and not told me.

Perhaps holiday snaps are better after all. Depressed by the videos, I rang Fielding. He found that even a snap can be deeply upsetting. He came across one of himself sweeping leaves in the garden, a portly gent with double chins. Until this photo, he had imagined himself fashionably wasted, almost slinky, like a Rolling Stone. The photo wrecked his delusion. "I got that way by enjoying myself," said Fielding sternly. He kept it hidden in a drawer, like a memento mori, to remind himself he must never look like that again, then embarked on a brutal regime of dieting, running and Alexander Technique. And it worked! "I have my neck back," says Fielding proudly. "That photo was a defining moment!"

Perhaps the videos could be my defining three hours. I could get my whole body back. I like to be positive.

fields.headline: Babes in boyland
fields.standfirst:
Last week, Labour trumpeted again its intention to raise the number of women MPs. But beyond advising them to wear dark suits and avoid dangling earrings, what is it really doing to make that dream come true?

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: So, girls, now you know. The secret of selection as a Labour candidate is to don a fuchsia top, a dark suit and modest make-up - but, hey, watch out for those "distracting" earrings! The top tips newly issued by the party's Millbank headquarters to women would-be MPs make depressing reading, not to mention easy fodder for journalists happy to perpetuate the "Blair's Babes" phenomenon. Once again, the Labour machine - notoriously responsible for  that photograph of Tony Blair surrounded by the 101 female MPs swept in at the last general election - has shown an unerring ability to be caught reducing women to a series of walking trouser suits delivering manifesto pledges on cue.
fields.body:
So, girls, now you know. The secret of selection as a Labour candidate is to don a fuchsia top, a dark suit and modest make-up - but, hey, watch out for those "distracting" earrings! The top tips newly issued by the party's Millbank headquarters to women would-be MPs make depressing reading, not to mention easy fodder for journalists happy to perpetuate the "Blair's Babes" phenomenon. Once again, the Labour machine - notoriously responsible for that photograph of Tony Blair surrounded by the 101 female MPs swept in at the last general election - has shown an unerring ability to be caught reducing women to a series of walking trouser suits delivering manifesto pledges on cue.

Ironically, the guidance has come to light just as the party is groping towards a recognition of the need to take genuinely constructive steps (we're not talking earrings) towards ensuring that women win through in the still uphill battle for selection. A meeting today of the women's committee of Labour's ruling national executive is expected to set a target of securing half of all Labour's vacant Westminster seats (around 24 at present but set to rise) for women candidates at the next election. Last week, Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, sent a letter to all constituency secretaries, reminding them: "The party is committed to increasing the number of women MPs and therefore women parliamentary candidates, and urges all constituency parties to bear this in mind when making your selection."

But if the party is to inch nearer to its long-held and apparently often forgotten target of a 50:50 male-female ratio, the signs so far are not good. Before selection even starts, plans by four Labour women MPs to step down at the next election will bring the party's record total below the benchmark 100 figure.

In Scotland and Wales, where a substantial clutch of Labour's safest seats are falling free as incumbents retire or quit to concentrate full-time on jobs in the Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly, senior women fear a virtual wipe-out by male candidates. Some privately warn that the very selection mechanisms that ensured a rough gender balance in Labour candidates for elections to the devolved institutions have led to a backlash under which favoured local sons sidelined by the system have been all but promised safe Westminster seats instead.

The trade unions, meanwhile, are also mobilising to ensure that their candidates are in the front line for selections - and again the contenders are expected to be mainly men. Their argument, strengthened by the resignation of junior defence minister Peter Kilfoyle to speak up for traditional Labour voters, runs that the party must field people with real links to its working-class heartlands, rather than on-message, middle-class professionals, men or women, imposed by Millbank.

Women's campaign group the Fawcett Society accepts that women must beware of being the instruments of Millbank control. But director Mary-Ann Stephenson argues: "If constituencies are concerned about having female candidates imposed from the centre, then they are going to have to find them for themselves."

Former social security secretary Harriet Harman, a leading voice among those pressing the Labour leadership to renew its focus on women's votes, believes slates put forward by trade unionists and Blairite modernisers alike are set to exclude women. "I'm not arguing for separate women's slates," she says. "I want to see women integrated into any list of potential candidates."

If the prospects are not encouraging, there is little drastic action that Labour can take to guarantee women candidates at the next election. Last time, it famously used all-female shortlists to ensure women ran in safe seats, but the mechanism was successfully challenged at a tribunal and dropped by the party. Even though both Blair (who last week admitted to MPs he had privately thought the women-only lists a lousy idea) and McDonagh are now converts to the option of legislating to allow parties to run single-sex lists, that will not happen until after the next election.

Nevertheless, even sceptical women MPs and campaigners acknowledge that attitudes are changing up in Millbank tower. "It's amazing how an imminent election can focus men's minds wonderfully," comments one female MP. Party strategists have finally begun to take notice of the argument Harman, the Fawcett Society and others have been pushing strongly for at least a year: that Labour ignores women voters and spurns women candidates at its peril.

The campaigners have done their homework. Recognising that the boys at Millbank may not be able to get their gelled heads around the feminist case for equal representation but at least have a grasp of cold statistics, MPs and pressure groups are offering the electoral case for selecting women. A study by Deborah Mattinson of Opinion Leader Research focuses on Worcester Woman's Unfinished Revolution, arguing that women voters see the increased numbers of female politicians as an important step, but equally will interpret any backsliding as a negative development.

Winning Women, a Fawcett Society paper that analyses female voters' views after devolved elections in Scotland and Wales, also found women believed female representatives understood their concerns better than men. But it showed clearly that women, already more sceptical than men of Labour, will take any fall in the numbers of female MPs as an indication that efforts last time were merely an "electoral con" and will punish the party at the polls.

This hard-headed demonstration of the dangers of ignoring female voters was the lever that secured Labour's election-winning targeting of women last time. The party managed to close the gender gap - the difference between men's and women's support - from a massive 12% at its peak in the 1970s to just 2% in 1997. At 11%, the swing to Labour among women was higher than among men (9%) - a trend the party is anxious to maintain.

Today, Harriet Harman has been invited to the NEC to outline her proposal for Operation Women's Vote - a plan already spoken highly of by Paisley South MP Douglas Alexander, one of Labour's four leading strategists for the next election. The strategy proposes a three-pronged focus on policy, organisation and presentation in order to target both women in middle England (the famous Worcester Woman) and women in Labour's traditional heartlands. As well as pressure for women's selection, Harman advocates swifter progress on policy issues set as high priorities by women (including maternity pay reforms, help with work-life balance and support for carers) and "a total halt to macho language - big guns and big hitters - and all-male platforms".

Her call for greater promotion of the progress made by the new intake women MPs coincides with the first, long-awaited signs of a fightback in their ranks, with the publication of an account of their contribution by Fiona Mactaggart, respected MP for Slough. Helen Jackson, MP for Sheffield Hillsborough and a member of the NEC women's committee, welcomes the prime minister's Damascene conversion to positive action for women and insists that the party must push for 50% of new candidates to be women.

The question now is, will the new efforts work? Will women - with or without distracting earrings - win a way through the selection process and will Blair finally recognise that it is not a vote-loser to develop policies appealing to women? The answer should emerge over the next six months, as selections take place before an expected 2001 election, and it may well be that, as last time, women's voices are heard. Nevertheless, it is still deeply depressing that the democratic case for reflecting women's concerns and aspirations is never enough for the strategists of Millbank until the rattle of the ballot boxes can be clearly heard.

fields.headline: National round-up
fields.trailText:
Moving pictures
Outrage over plan to shift photographic collection
fields.body:
Moving pictures
Outrage over plan to shift photographic collection

A scheme that would send to Bradford a collection of 125,000 negatives and prints by a much-admired Liverpool photographer has been greeted with outrage on Merseyside.

Trustees charged with caring for the collection say the images must go to the National Museum of Photography, Film and Television where they can be catalogued and conserved.

Their opponents, including a local MP, insist the collection must stay in Liverpool and are threatening to seek an injunction this week to halt the move.

The row centres on the work of Edward Fiztmaurice Chambré Hardman, Liverpool's leading portrait photographer for 40 years. He made a good living taking pictures of babies and brides-to-be but his private passion was producing landscapes now hailed as classics of the pictorialist school of photography, including a haystack below billowing clouds.

Hardman also took pictures of the urban landscape on Merseyside.

When Hardman died in 1988, he left the bulk of his estate to a trust established to safeguard his work. The trust took over his Georgian house packed with the chaotic clutter of a professional and private life.

It launched an appeal to open the house as a museum but cannot meet the cost of health and safety requirements. The trust's chairman, Roger Prideaux, said: "I passionately believe that what we are doing is right for the collection." Louise Ellman, MP for Liverpool Riverside, said: "Liverpool is bidding to be European city of culture in 2008 and it is a great irony that something unique in our cultural history is about to leave the city."
David Ward

Virtual college for heads

Tony Blair's plans for an educational Sandhurst will move a step forward today when more than 1,000 new head teachers will help launch revolutionary technology that will be at the heart of the national college for school leadership.

The heads - who have all taken up their first jobs in the past year - will take part in online discussions and debates using free laptops given to them by the government.

As members of a virtual learning community, they will get the chance to put questions to "expert witnesses" who are likely to include senior education figures such as the schools minister, Estelle Morris.

The setting up of the college is key to the government's drive to raise standards in schools, and will underpin its strategy to enhance the quality of leadership in teaching.

It will be housed in a £20m building, yet to be designed, on Nottingham university's Jubilee campus alongside its education and business schools. But next to it will be the potentially much more exciting virtual college - opening in September - which will offer heads learning and dialogue "at a distance" via laptops.

The technology, using software provided free by Oracle, has been designed by Stephen Heppell, the website expert who designed Tesco's successful SchoolNet 2000.
Rebecca Smithers

Exotic birds make UK their home

New bird species are colonising Britain in increasing numbers, adding exotic plumage to the countryside while many native species are suffering continued decline.

There are 40 more species breeding in the UK than 200 years ago and in the past three decades 12 new "British birds" have been added to the official lists, according to the RSPB.

Some of the incomers, the collared dove and Canada goose, are now so numerous they are among Britain's most familiar birds. Parakeets from Asia are present in large flocks in south London and have migrated as far as south Wales, East Anglia and the west midlands. One third of the "new" birds have escaped from captivity, but the rest have arrived naturally.
Paul Brown

MP denies secret funds claim

Keith Vaz, the Europe minister, yesterday angrily rejected claims that he accepted thousands of pounds from a solicitor to fund his office while he was in opposition.

Mr Vaz, who is to be investigated by the parliamentary commissioner for standards, said the allegation was a "malicious falsehood" made by an anonymous person.

He told the World This Weekend on Radio 4 that he would be writing to the commissioner. "No money was received by me or my staff."

The parliamentary standards commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, has written to Mr Vaz about claims that his office received money from the law firm Zaiwalla and Co.

Ms Filkin, who has to examine complaints against MPs, said her inquiry did not mean there was "proof of wrong-doing".

The anonymous complainant, a former partner with Zaiwalla and Co, is involved in a legal battle with the firm's senior partner, Sarosh Zaiwalla. The source claims that a "young man" from Mr Vaz's office collected £2,000 in cash in 1994 which the MP failed to declare in the Commons register of members' interests.

Mr Zaiwalla accused the complainant of inventing the allegations to embarrass him.
Nicholas Watt

Murder case man's £600,000

A former soldier jailed for the M50 killing of Marie Wilkes is to receive compensation, believed to be £600,000, for his time in prison. Eddie Browning, who spent six years in jail, plans to buy a remote farmhouse to share with his new wife.

Mr Browning, 47, was released in 1994 by the court of appeal, which decided his conviction was unsafe because of evidence kept from his trial by the police.

The former Welsh Guardsman, from Cwmparc, Rhondda, south Wales, yesterday confirmed he was to receive the money, though he declined to give the exact amount. His brother, Dale, said Mr Browning had been sent a letter from the home office saying he would be getting £600,000 compensation.

The home office said it was not the department's policy to comment on such cases.

Ms Wilkes, 22, who was pregnant, was found dead in 1988 after her car broke down on the M50 near Bushley, Worcestershire.

Mr Browning said he was trying to buy a farm near Llandeilo, west Wales, so he could start afresh with his wife, Mereid, 34. "I am trying to get on with my life. I just want peace and quiet, it's as simple as that." Mr Browning, who was told of the compensation a few weeks ago, said the money would not properly compensate him for his six years in prison.

fields.headline: Study uncovers care home abuse
fields.trailText: A quarter of all reported abuse of elderly people takes place in hospitals and care homes, according to the largest British study of the problem.
fields.body:
A quarter of all reported abuse of elderly people takes place in hospitals and care homes, according to the largest British study of the problem.

Although their families believe them to be safely looked after, elderly hospital patients and care home residents are said to be subject all too frequently to beatings, neglect and theft, according to a report by the charity Action on Elder Abuse.

AEA, which based the study on calls to its helpline, is now calling on the government to set a five-year deadline for training all workers in elderly care in a recognised qualification and to foot the £500m bill.

Ginny Jenkins, chief executive of AEA, said: "It is shocking to find that a quarter of calls to our helpline are about mistreatment, exploitation and neglect in places where we expect that people will be professionally cared for."

The study analysed more than 1,400 calls between 1997 and 1999. Most were about abuse in an elderly person's own home, but what the charity describes as a "startling" 25% alleged maltreatment in residential settings.

As only 5% of elderly people live in residential or nursing homes, the findings suggest that the incidence of abuse may be six times as high in such homes as in the community at large.

There may even be substantial under-reporting of abuse in residential settings - while elderly people may be more likely to complain about maltreatment by paid carers than about abuse by family members, it will often be more difficult to do so without private access to a telephone.

Almost a third of helpline calls about hospitals and care homes concerned physical abuse and more than a quarter alleged neglect or "psychological abuse". Four in 10 of such calls complained about male nurses and care workers, despite the great majority of such staff being women.

Almost a fifth of all calls to the helpline came from workers themselves, some of whom had seen abuse by colleagues and were seeking advice on how to blow the whistle.

Three-fifths of calls to the helpline concerned alleged abuse of people over 75. The oldest person cited in a call was 101.

Ms Jenkins said: "While we know there are a variety of reasons why workers abuse - and some people are deliberate sadists - most incidents happen because workers react to pressure."

Research has shown that there was much less abuse where staff were properly trained and motivated.

"A member of staff who is stressed, overworked, and feels undervalued is more likely to lose their temper with an elderly resident when something goes wrong."

There are an estimated 800,000 untrained care staff working with older people. According to the charity, it would cost £600 each to ensure they had recognised qualifications.

A spokeswoman for the department of health said ministers would shortly be considering a national training strategy. What would be achievable by 2005 would depend on the government spending review, the spokeswoman said.

"We want to see the level of training and qualification improved throughout social care, but given that 80% of the workforce doesn't have a relevant qualification there is a large agenda to be tackled."

webTitle: Gore was avid pot smoker - book

fields.headline: Gore was avid pot smoker - book
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The drugs issue that seemed to have fizzled out of the US presidential campaign almost before it started returns today with claims in a new biography of Al Gore that the vice-president was an enthusiastic cannabis user in the 1970s.
fields.body:
The drugs issue that seemed to have fizzled out of the US presidential campaign almost before it started returns today with claims in a new biography of Al Gore that the vice-president was an enthusiastic cannabis user in the 1970s.

"We'd get stoned and talk about what we would do if we were president," John Warnecke, an old friend of Mr Gore, is quoted as saying in Inventing Al Gore: A Biography.

An extract from the book by Bill Turque, Newsweek's Washington correspondent, appears in this week's issue of the magazine. It comes at a time when the vice-president had appeared to be seeing off the challenge of Bill Bradley, the only other candidate for the Democratic Party nomination to run for president.

Rumours about the alleged drug use of the young George W Bush, who is fighting for the Republican nomination, subsided late last year after the withdrawal of a book that included discredited claims.

Previously, Mr Gore had said his cannabis consumption was "infrequent and rare". But Mr Turque's book also quotes another Gore friend, Andy Schlesinger - like Mr Warnecke and the vice-president, a former reporter on the Nashville Tennessean - as saying he smoked with him "at least a dozen times". This was in the months after Mr Gore returned from the Vietnam war in 1971.

"These were low times," says Mr Schelsinger, who remains a friend. "Al was upset and disgusted by Vietnam and what it was doing to America."

Mr Turque writes: "Warnecke and two other friends from Gore's Nashville days say Gore was an enthusiastic recreational user, smoking sometimes as often as three or four times a week; after hours at Warnecke's house, on weekends at the Gore farm or canoeing on the Caney Fork River."

Mr Warnecke, who had drink and drug problems that wrecked his first marriage, says Mr Gore tried in 1987, while running for vice-president, to stop his friend from revealing the cannabis use.

In November 1987, after Mr Gore had gone public about infrequent use, Mr Warnecke received a call from a reporter on his former newspaper. But he did not follow his old friend's request, says the book.

"Instead he told what he now says was a more authentic-sounding lie that he'd seen Gore smoke only once. Gore considered even this sanitised version of the past a betrayal and the two have not spoken since 1987."

fields.headline: Bodies of fishermen taken home
fields.trailText: The bodies of the seven men recovered from the Solway Harvester will arrive in their home villages today as efforts to raise the stricken fishing vessel have again been delayed.
fields.body:
The bodies of the seven men recovered from the Solway Harvester will arrive in their home villages today as efforts to raise the stricken fishing vessel have again been delayed.

Salvage experts said yesterday that it could take many weeks before the scallop dredger was lifted from the seabed, 10 miles off the Isle of Man. A fresh attempt to shift the vessel yesterday had to be abandoned because of poor weather.

Manx authorities have decided to call a halt to more attempts to lift the Kirkcudbright-registered vessel because of bad weather forecasts for the next fortnight and because the salvage vessel, the CSO Wellservicer, has other commitments.

"Our primary objective of re turning the bodies of the crew to their families has been achieved," said a Manx government spokesman, John Shimmin.

"However, we still have a responsibility to the coroner and have made a commitment to the families that the vessel will be raised when weather conditions allow. I have no doubt the Solway Harvester will be raised."

Chief Inspector Dudley Butt, of the Isle of Man constabulary, said they already had enough information to start an inquiry into the sinking. On Saturday the coroner said the refusal by the British authorities to pay for the recovery of the bodies was at best penny-pinching and at worst downright shameful.

The communities of the South Machars will hold seven separate funerals in the coming week.

webTitle: Ravers fight party ban in paradise

fields.headline: Ravers fight party ban in paradise
fields.trailText: For 25 years Goa has been the party and rave capital of India; the place to go if you want to hang out and dance until dawn. But for the thousands of British partygoers who flock to the beautiful coastal state their hedonistic nights may finally be coming to an end.
fields.body:
For 25 years Goa has been the party and rave capital of India; the place to go if you want to hang out and dance until dawn. But for the thousands of British partygoers who flock to the beautiful coastal state their hedonistic nights may finally be coming to an end after a court ruling banning outdoor music over 45 decibels.

The decision has delighted environmental groups, who have long campaigned to stop the raves, which they claim are destroying the fragile eco-systems of Goa's beaches and rainforests.

But Paul Schwartz, a UK dance promoter involved with the Goa Trance scene for 10 years, told the Big Issue that the ruling was a "disaster" for ravers. "The criminal justice act put a stop to the outdoor scene in the UK, and so everyone went to Goa. Now Goa is gone where can we go?"

Matters came to a head in December when a group of environmental protesters, calling themselves the Goa Environment Federation, took the organisers of a huge rave planned for Christmas and new year to the high court in Bombay. The 11-day party, billed as the biggest rave of the millennium, was stopped after the court heard evidence that the organisers had violated coastal regulation zone laws by erecting buildings on the beachside plot.

The environmentalists moved swiftly to consolidate their victory, filing a detailed petition describing loud music put on for tourists as a "public menace". They also complained about noise pollution caused by music blaring from loudspeakers on churches and temples.

Last month the high court passed the order banning loud music between 10pm and 7am. According to Claude Alvares, from the environmental group the Goa Foundation, the ruling has crippled the rave party scene. One party organiser who tried to hold a rave last week was issued with a contempt notice as well as being charged with violation of noise pollution laws.

Sue Wheat, of Tourism Concern, a pressure group based in London which espouses responsible and sustainable tourism, said the ruling was a victory for local people. "It highlights the fact that people do actually live in these areas and their everyday lives are not always helped by round the clock partying throughout the year. This is another example of communities standing up and saying this is not how we want tourism to be run where we live."

But not everybody is so convinced the move will benefit local people. David Abram, author of the Rough Guide to Goa, who has been a regular visitor to the coastal state for the past decade, said that rather than the big party organisers it would be the locals running small bars on the beaches and the stallholders who sell food and snacks to the ravers who would bear the brunt of the court order. According to reports, those who depend on the party scene for their living have formed a Goa Music Lovers Association to fight the court order and have been meeting local people to raise awareness of the ramifications of the music ban.

The association is expected to file an intervention application in the high court in Bombay today. Mr Abram said the extent of the rave scene in Goa has been consistently overhyped. "In people's minds Goa has become synonymous with parties and hedonism, but it is far removed from that nowadays. It is much more middle aged, much more laid back."

According to Mr Abram the main threat to the raves is not the courts in Bombay, but the local police. "The police have been demanding enormous bribes to let these parties go ahead, and the people organising them simply cannot get the money.

"Things have been made illegal in Goa before, but it's always the case that if you are willing to pay enough you can get round it. It will be no different this time."

fields.headline: Legalise cannabis hint from Mowlam
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam yesterday set herself at odds with Downing Street's hardline anti-drugs policy when she held out the prospect that cannabis could eventually be decriminalised.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam yesterday set herself at odds with Downing Street's hardline anti-drugs policy when she held out the prospect that cannabis could eventually be decriminalised.

Weeks after admitting that she smoked marijuana as a student in the early 1970s, the minister in charge of the government's drugs strategy said on GMTV: "I never cancel anything in or anything out."

Her remarks came after Keith Hellawell, the anti-drugs tsar, called on police to concentrate on the threat posed by hard drugs rather than be distracted by softer drugs.

In an interview with the Observer Mr Hellawell said: "What I have done is lift the stone on the hidden truth about drugs in Britain, which is that we need to discriminate between different drugs and the relative harm caused and then talk openly about the difference we can make."

Ms Mowlam, the cabinet office minister, agreed that the government and the criminal justice system were concentrating their resources on the "killer drugs".

She said: "Obviously the killer drugs - heroin, cocaine, ecstasy - we are focusing on harder. We have got a 10-year strategy ... It is not going to happen overnight but we are making progress."

Ms Mowlam insisted that she was not calling for cannabis to be decriminalised or for new laws to be introduced to allow offenders to escape prison as proposed in a forthcoming report by the Police Foundation.

Ms Mowlam hinted that changes could be introduced at a later stage. "At the moment there is no current intention so to do."

Her remarks came close to breaching the hardline stance of Tony Blair and Jack Straw. Clare Short was famously rebuked when she raised the possibility of decriminalising marijuana and it is no secret that other ministers are sympathetic to a more flexible approach.

But the Tory leader, William Hague, provided a timely reminder yesterday of why Downing Street has adopted such a tough stance. In an in terview with BBC1's Breakfast with Frost, Mr Hague said he was concerned by Mr Hellawell's remarks. "We shouldn't take our eyes away from cannabis and the other soft drugs because it is very clear, from talking to police around the country, that that often leads to the hard drugs."

Mr Hague said that policies to be announced this week will call for children to be taught of the dangers of illegal drugs through the national curriculum and for anyone caught with drugs within 400 yards of a school to be subject to heavier penalties. "There is a serious crisis in this country [including] many parts where you wouldn't expect it or suspect it".

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Boy questioned on rape claim
fields.body:
Boy questioned on rape claim

An 11-year-old boy who was questioned about the alleged rape of a girl aged 12 was released on police bail yesterday by detectives in Skegness, Lincolnshire.

The boy was arrested after a complaint by the girl's parents on Saturday night. He will face further questioning at a later date.

Queen Mother on the mend

The Queen yesterday said the Queen Mother, 99, was feeling much better after a cold she caught 11 days ago left her housebound.

Book returned 70 years late

A book due back at Motherwell library on March 13 1930 has finally been returned. The book was handed in during a North Lanarkshire council amnesty, avoiding a £900 fine.

Students plot to buy local

Students at Selwyn college, Cambridge, are considering a £45,000 buyout of their local pub's lease.

The Hat and Feathers is set to close because its landlord is moving away.

Son finds parents dead

Detectives are investigating after a son found the bodies of both his parents in their Buckinghamshire home yesterday.

Milton Keynes police are not looking for anyone else in connection with the death of the couple, both in their 40s.

Lottery rollover

Wednesday's lottery draw is a rollover after no ticket matched Saturday's six winning numbers - 21, 38, 40, 46, 47 and 49, bonus 48.

The winning thunderball numbers were 3, 8, 14, 25 and 31, thunderball 4.

webTitle: New terror fear after Ulster bombing

fields.headline: New terror fear after Ulster bombing
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Dissident republicans last night exploded a bomb outside a hotel in a predominantly Protestant town, raising fears of a renewed terrorist campaign in the wake of the government's threat to reimpose direct rule over Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
Dissident republicans last night exploded a bomb outside a hotel in a predominantly Protestant town, raising fears of a renewed terrorist campaign in the wake of the government's threat to reimpose direct rule over Northern Ireland.

The RUC said there were no reports of any injuries after guests were evacuated from Mahons Hotel in Irvinestown, County Fermanagh, following telephone bomb warnings from the Continuity IRA. The bomb exploded at the rear of the hotel at 7.20pm.

Warnings of another bomb at the Manor House Hotel, in Killydeas, outside Enniskillen, forced its evacuation but police reported no explosion.

The bombing will add to the pressure on the government which is facing its most difficult week in the peace process. Direct rule is due to be imposed by Friday if the IRA refuses to disarm.

The IRA confirmed last week that its ceasefire was still holding, but there is mounting anger in republican circles at the pressure on the provisionals to disarm.

Republicans are furious with the government for accepting unionist demands that the IRA should have started to disarm now, something which they claim is outside the terms of the Good Friday agreement. There was deep anger when the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, accused the IRA of betraying everyone in Northern Ireland, including republicans, because of its refusal to decommission.

Tony Blair made clear yesterday that the government had heeded the warnings from republicans when he indicated that the IRA would not have to meet unionist demands for an actual start to decommissioning this week.

Confirming that the government was looking for words rather than actions, the prime minister said: "I am not standing here as a British prime minister making demands. I am only saying that now is when we need to know whether [decommissioning] is going to happen or not."

His remarks will fuel unionist suspicions that the government is preparing the ground for a move on disarmament which will fall well short of the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble's demand for "product" - his description of a physical start to the process.

Mr Mandelson is due to reimpose direct rule later this week - if the IRA refuses to make a move on disarmament - to prevent Mr Trimble from resigning as first minister. Unionists fear the government would hold back from suspending the Northern Ireland power-sharing executive if the IRA agrees to a disarmament timetable.

The threat of a return to direct rule, and Mr Mandelson's attack on the IRA for "betraying" the people of Northern Ireland, prompted a furious republican response. The IRA issued a statement on Saturday saying it had not agreed any deals over disarmament. It reiterated its support for the Good Friday agreement which calls for decommissioning to be completed by May.

Sinn Fein issued a fresh warning yesterday that the government was gravely mistaken if it believed the threat of direct rule would influence the arms dispute.

Mitchel McLaughlin, the party chairman, said: "The British government, I think, are making a very, very serious mistake under the blackmail of a threat to withdraw by the unionists and that's where the crisis is coming from."

fields.headline: Hilfiger's highland fling fails
fields.trailText: The wilds of Scotland are possibly the last place you would expect to find the rock fan, sweatshirt king and all-American geezer, Tommy Hilfiger, yet this is where he attempted to seek inspiration for his autumn/winter 2000 men's and women's wear collection.
fields.body:
The wilds of Scotland are possibly the last place you would expect to find the rock fan, sweatshirt king and all-American geezer, Tommy Hilfiger, yet this is where he attempted to seek inspiration for his autumn/winter 2000 men's and women's wear collection, shown in New York yesterday.

The designer deserted rock references almost entirely in favour of a more refined look. "I visited Scotland with my family and was overwhelmed by the striking beauty of the land."

Luxurious fabrics - ponyskin, crocodile skin and cashmere - were mixed in with a liberal use of tartan: black leather jackets with tartan lining for men and tartan knee-length skirts and tartan chiffon evening dresses for women.

The collection was far from original.The man who made his money dressing hip hop kids in clean-cut casual clothes tried to cover all bases: combining "Scottish heritage" with "an all-American sensibility" was never a logical idea.

webTitle: Assaults lead to climate of fear for Scottish gays

fields.headline: Assaults lead to climate of fear for Scottish gays
fields.trailText: Gay men in Edinburgh are four times more likely to be attacked than heterosexual men, according to a government survey published today.
fields.body:
Gay men in Edinburgh are four times more likely to be attacked than heterosexual men, according to a government survey published today.

The report, commissioned by the Scotland office, found that 26% of homosexual men had been attacked in the city in the past 12 months but only a third had reported it to the police.

Most attacks were by strangers near gay venues or on the streets. It also found that 43% had been bullied about their sexuality at school or college.

The survey was carried out in 1998 before the furore over the repeal of section 28, which bans the promotion of the acceptability of homosexuality in schools.

A separate study, conducted at the same time, found that 37% of gay people in Edinburgh had been physically assaulted, a rate 14 times higher than that for the general public. Campaigners say the cli mate of fear for gays has worsened since the outcry over section 28.

"What this study shows is that there is still a minority who think gay people are legitimate targets for attack. Unfortunately section 28 says that we are," said Tim Hopkins of the Equality Network. "It says that our relationships are unacceptable. That's one of the reasons that 43% of men in this survey reported being bullied at school or college. Unfortunately some of the rhetoric used against the section 28 repeal has made gay people feel a lot more vulnerable."

The Scottish executive's deputy justice minister, Angus MacKay, said: "This research shows Scotland still harbours many unacceptable attitudes which result in hate crimes and which exclude many people from everyday life.

"We all have to be more aware of the fears and needs of vulnerable groups and must take steps to address them."

webTitle: Treasury loses out on billions from cloning of Dolly

fields.headline: Treasury loses out on billions from cloning of Dolly
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: The treasury has lost out on a share of billions of pounds that is expected to follow the commercial exploitation by British and American scientists of the cloning of Dolly the sheep.
fields.body:
The treasury has lost out on a share of billions of pounds that is expected to follow the commercial exploitation by British and American scientists of the cloning of Dolly the sheep.

The patent for the scientific breakthrough that could have brought long-term cash for the public purse was handed to a private company as part of a wholesale transfer of assets in research institutes by the Tory government, which allowed it to cut its science budget in 1995 and 1996.

After a deal on patents last month, private shareholders in California and Britain will now benefit from the public funding that helped develop the cloning of Dolly.

The implications of a deal done four years ago emerged during the examination of accounts and public hearings in the Commons by Bill Cash, the Tory MP for Stone. He said yesterday: "This is a matter that should be investigated by the Commons public accounts committee. In no way do I want to decry the work of the brilliant scientists who are behind this but it looks to me like another case of a British invention that will be exploited elsewhere. This is a classic case for a full-scale investigation for the national audit office."

The cloning of Dolly the sheep was one of the most remarkable breakthroughs of the decade by British scientists, raising the possibility of cloning new cells to fight degenerative diseases. These include diabetes, Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, heart attacks, hepatitis, cirrhosis of the liver, cancer, serious burns and muscular dystrophy. The commercial worth of the development is expected to reach billions of pounds.

The Tory government decided that its biotechnology and biological science research council should turn the Roslin Institute into a private non-profit-making company. Almost £3m worth of assets, equipment and existing patents were transferred to the company for "nil consideration".

The government also continued to fund research projects through public money, including £250,000 a year for the Dolly cloning project.

The patent for Dolly the sheep was jointly owned by the private company, the ministry of agriculture and the state-owned biotechnology council. The government and biotechnology council have now relinquished rights to the patent.

The new freedom from its government ties meant that Roslin could set up its own private commercial company, Roslin Bio-med, and assign patents to it. This commercial offshoot has now merged with a Californian company, Geron, to form Geron Bio-med, which holds the sole rights to cloning for the next 17 years. The government is continuing to fund the company's research.

The new company has increased in value from £6m to more than £20m.

Professor Grahame Bulfield, director of the Roslin Institute, yesterday defended the last government's decision by saying that it was Labour as well as Conservative policy to hand over patents owned by the government to research institutes.

"The government cannot have its cake and eat it," he said. "It cannot cut research and expect to benefit from it. Without the joint development with Geron these benefits would not be available at all. Geron's involvement will mean there will be inward investment into Britain."

However, Sir John Bourn, the comptroller and auditor general, is known to be concerned about Whitehall's handling of previous semi-privatisations of research bodies. National audit office reports have attacked the loss to the taxpayer over the disposal of the old Royal Observatory in Sussex and deals done by giving away agricultural research to private companies.

Almost £3m worth of assets, equipment and existing patents were transferred to the company for "nil consideration". The government also continued to fund research projects through public money, including £250,000 a year for the Dolly cloning project. The patent for Dolly the sheep was jointly owned by the private company, the ministry of agriculture and the state-owned biotechnology council. The government and biotechnology council have now relinquished rights to the patent. The new freedom from its government ties meant that Roslin could set up its own private commercial company, Roslin Bio-med, and assign patents to it. This commercial offshoot has now merged with a Californian company, Geron, to form Geron Bio-med, which holds the sole rights to cloning for the next 17 years. The government is continuing to fund the company's research. The new company has increased in value from £6m to more than £20m. "The government cannot have its cake and eat it," he said. "It cannot cut research and expect to benefit from it. Without the joint development with Geron these benefits would not be available at all. Geron's involvement will mean there will be inward investment into Britain." However, Sir John Bourn, the comptroller and auditor general, is known to be concerned about Whitehall's handling of previous semi-privatisations of research bodies. National audit office reports have attacked the loss to the taxpayer over the disposal of the old Royal Observatory in Sussex and deals done by giving away agricultural research to private companies.

fields.headline: Bombers hit hopes for peace
fields.standfirst:
Hotel guests escape unhurt after dissident republican group strikes in attempt to sabotage Ulster negotiations

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Dissident republicans last night exploded a bomb outside a hotel in a predominantly Protestant town, raising fears of a renewed terrorist campaign in the wake of the government's threat to reimpose direct rule over Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
Dissident republicans last night exploded a bomb outside a hotel in a predominantly Protestant town, raising fears of a renewed terrorist campaign in the wake of the government's threat to reimpose direct rule over Northern Ireland.

The RUC said there were no reports of any injuries when the bomb, planted by the Continuity IRA, exploded under an oil tank at the back of Mahon's hotel in Irvinestown, Co Fermanagh at 7.19pm.

The bombing will add to the pressure on the government, which is facing its most difficult week in the peace process. Direct rule is due to be imposed by Friday if the IRA refuses to make a gesture on disarmament.

Guests escaped injury when they were evacuated from the hotel 15 minutes before the explosion, after telephone warnings from the Continuity IRA. The kitchen and several cars were damaged in a fire caused by the explosion. It is believed that the bomb was driven into the hotel carpark in a limousine used for local weddings.

Warnings of another bomb at the Manor House hotel, in Killydeas, outside Enniskillen, forced its evacuation but police reported no explosion.

Tommy Mahon, the owner of the bombed hotel, said: "There has been quite a bit of damage. The bottom gable wall is half blown away and the ceilings in the kitchen and toilets have all been brought down."

Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, said: "The people of Ireland, north and south, rejected violence once and for all when they overwhelmingly supported the Good Friday agreement. This attack is not just wrong, it is against the democratically expressed wishes of the people. What can it possibly achieve?"

His remarks were echoed by Bertie Ahern, the Irish prime minister. He said: "We hoped the days of having to condemn bombings in Northern Ireland were over. Unfortunately, it appears there are still those who refuse to acknowledge the will of the overwhelming majority of people on this island."

The attack will have been designed by the dissident republicans to cause maximum disruption to the peace process at a delicate moment. Mr Mandelson will launch a last-ditch attempt this week to persuade the IRA to make a gesture on disarmament to prevent David Trimble from resigning as the province's first minister.

If the IRA fails to act, Mr Mandelson will reimpose direct rule, a move that has been condemned by Sinn Fein, which claims that the demand for immediate disarmament falls outside the Good Friday agreement.

The first signs that the bomb might have destabilised the peace process came last night when Ken Maginnis, the Ulster Unionist party's security spokesman, said it highlighted the need for disarmament.

"We are vindicated, I believe, by this activity tonight in saying we cannot allow to remain in existence any paramilitary organisation - republican or loyalist - which has illegal guns or illegal explosives."

However, ministers will have been encouraged when Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness condemned the bombing and called on the Continuity IRA to disband immediately.

Mr Adams, the Sinn Fein president, said: "I unequivocally condemn this attack. The people involved are not acting in the interests of Irish republicanism, they are not representative of any real section of the Irish people and they should disband."

The bombing came hours after Tony Blair issued an emotional appeal to republicans "from the depth of my heart" to make a gesture on disarmament to prevent the peace process slipping away. But the prime minister, who was speaking at the Labour party's local government conference in Blackpool, indicated that the IRA would not have to meet unionist demands for an actual start to decommission ing this week. Confirming that the government was looking for words rather than actions, Mr Blair said: "I am not standing here as a British prime minister making demands. I am only saying that now is when we need to know whether [decommissioning] is going to happen or not."

He made clear that he had taken stock of IRA unease over the disarmament issue when he said he was not asking the IRA to break its word or betray its republican beliefs. There was deep disquiet when Mr Mandelson accused the IRA last week of betraying everyone in Northern Ireland, including republicans, by its refusal to decommission.

Mr Blair's speech is likely to please the Irish government, whose officials have been holding intensive talks with the republican leadership to persuade the IRA to make a gesture on disarmament.

But the prime minister will have fuelled unionist suspicions that the government is preparing the ground for a move on disarmament that will fall well short of the demands of Mr Trimble for "product" - his description of a physical start to the process.

Unionists fear the government will hold back from suspending the power-sharing executive if the IRA agrees to a disarmament timetable.

Sinn Fein issued a fresh warning yesterday that the government was gravely mistaken if it believed the threat of direct rule would influence the decommissioning dispute.

Mitchel McLaughlin, the party's chairman, said: "The British government are making a very, very serious mistake under the blackmail of a threat to withdraw by the unionists."

The last bombing to hit Ulster was the attack on Omagh by the Real IRA on August 15 1998 in which 29 people died and more than 350 were injured. Only yesterday the RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, said the IRA offered no threat at present but the two dissident groups, the Real and Continuity IRA, did.
