fields.headline: Police hold genocide suspect
fields.standfirst: Genocide suspect arrested in Britain
fields.trailText: A former Rwandan army chief implicated in the slaughter of more than 100,000 people, who has been living in south London for almost two years, will appear in court today in the latest practical test of Britain's commitment to prosecuting international war criminals.
fields.body:
A former Rwandan army chief implicated in the slaughter of more than 100,000 people, who has been living in south London for almost two years, will appear in court today in the latest practical test of Britain's commitment to prosecuting international war criminals.

Tharcisse Muvunyi, 46, was arrested at the weekend by Metropolitan police officers acting on a warrant issued by the United Nations international criminal tribunal for Rwanda. It is the first time that anyone living in Britain has been indicted either by the UN's tribunal for Rwanda or the similar body set up at the Hague to prosecute those accused of human rights violations in Bosnia.

The arrest of Mr Muvunyi - known as "The Commander" in Rwanda - was welcomed by human rights campaigners.

He appears in court on the same day that three judges begin hearing a judicial review of the controversial decision by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to allow Augusto Pinochet to return to Chile.

Amnesty International said that Mr Muvunyi's arrest "seems to be the Pinochet effect in action".

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, said the arrest demonstrated the government's commitment to bringing to justice the abusers of crimes against humanity.

However, questions were raised over why it took so long for Mr Muvunyi to be apprehended, and why officials allowed him to enter Britain in the first place.

He arrived on March 29 1998, joining his wife and children. They live on state benefits in Lewisham, south-east London, and Mr Muvunyi is reported to have been granted political asylum until 2002. The crimes of which he is accused are well documented. He was a lieutenant-colonel in the Rwandan army during the genocide of 1994, in which as many as 800,000 ethnic Tutsis died at the hands of the Hutu majority.

He commanded two provinces where at least 100,000 people died between April and June 1994, when he allegedly ordered the murder of 25 children who had been hiding in a convent, where they had been given sanctuary. They were rounded up by soldiers said to be acting on Mr Muvunyi's orders, and killed with machetes, clubs and guns. Mr Muvunyi is wanted by prosecutors in Rwanda - whose own judicial system has also been dealing with genocide suspects - but there is no extradition treaty between Dar es Salaam and London. However, as a member of the UN, Britain is obliged to cooperate with the special tribunal, and must hand over anyone it indicts.

Two UN investigators flew to London in January 1999 to question Mr Muvunyi, but he refused to be interviewed. He has issued only one statement, in which he claimed to have struggled to keep control in the region under his command but said that it became impossible to stop the massacres.

Officials from the UN tribunal, which is based in Arusha, Tanzania, lodged the indictment alleging "genocide and crimes against humanity" with the British ambassador in Dar es Salaam on Friday. It was passed to the home office, ratified by a magistrate and then executed by police.

Mr Muvunyi's solicitor, Michael Fisher, said his client would "vigorously deny" the charges against him at Bow Street magistrates court today. Mr Fisher is likely to apply for a writ of habeas corpus, which will result in the case being transferred to the high court. In an indication that the legal process is likely to be protracted, Mr Fisher said last night: "We will be exploring every avenue of appeal."

Rakiya Omaar, who has in vestigated the activities of Mr Muvunyi and is director of the pressure group African Rights, welcomed his detention but claimed action should have been taken earlier. Britain lacked the political will to bring a prosecution here, she said, even though it had a "moral obligation" to do so.

Kingsley Moghalu, a spokesman for the tribunal, rejected criticisms that the process had taken too long.

"International criminal justice is a complicated process," he said, adding that cases had to be thoroughly investigated and evidence had to be of a high standard.

webTitle: Dissidents pick crunch time to strike

fields.headline: Dissidents pick crunch time to strike
fields.standfirst: Sinn Fein joins condemnation of bomb attack by Continuity IRA
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein joins condemnation of bomb attack by Continuity IRA
fields.body:
Northern Ireland's growing band of republican dissidents, who are determined to destroy the peace process, could not have chosen a more timely moment to strike.

On the eve of the most crucial week in the search for a political settlement, the Continuity IRA has struck at the heart of a Protestant town, threatening to send Northern Ireland's political leaders to the safety of their respective bunkers at the very moment when brave steps are needed.

Ulster Unionists, who are demanding immediate IRA disarmament as the price for their remaining in the new power-sharing executive with Sinn Fein, will be able to point to the bomb as a powerful sign of the need for a republican gesture on arms.

There will also be a suspicion among unionists that the Continuity IRA, which was formed after the IRA's 1994 ceasefire, has acted at the behest of the Provisional leadership.

Ken Maginnis, the Ulster Unionist security spokesman, wasted little time last night in saying that the bomb highlighted the need for disarmament.

"We are vindicated, I believe, by this activity in saying we cannot allow to remain in existence any paramilitary organisation - republican or loyalist - which has illegal guns or illegal explosives."

Republicans, who insist that the IRA is under no obligation to disarm until May, will be able to point to the bomb as a sign of what can happen when the political process stalls. Throughout last week, Gerry Adams spoke of a dangerous political vacuum.

Bombs by dissident republicans have, however, occasionally served to strengthen the peace process in recent years. The Omagh attack of August 1998, in which 29 people were killed by the Real IRA, cemented Sinn Fein's position in the political process when the party's leadership unequivocally condemned the attack.

Observers were encouraged last night when Sinn Fein's chief negotiator, Martin McGuinness, condemned the Irvinestown bombing within minutes of the explosion. He called on the Continuity IRA, which is the only republican terrorist group not to have declared a ceasefire, to disband immediately.

The local SDLP assembly member, Tommy Gallagher, described the bomb as madness. "This is very disappointing news. In fact, it is madness," Mr Gallagher said. "The great majority in this community know we have had this for 25 years and it has been absolutely wasteful."

Ministers will hope that Sinn Fein's prompt condemnation of the bomb will give some encouragement to the Northern Ireland first minister, David Trimble, who will face re newed pressure from unionist hardliners in the wake of the attack.

However, ministers will privately fear that the bomb may make it more difficult for them to pressurise Mr Trimble into accepting a deal on arms later this week which falls short of immediate decommissioning by the IRA.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, who has threatened to reimpose direct rule by Friday if the IRA refuses to make a gesture on arms, is understood to have accepted that the Provisionals have no intention of disarming. It is believed that Mr Mandelson has resigned himself to accepting a disarmament timetable from the IRA, a concession which Mr Trimble would have found too difficult to accept at any time, but even more so now.

Sinn Fein will argue that the bombing should have no impact on this week's negotiations because the Continuity IRA has nothing to do with the Provisional movement, unlike the Real IRA which only broke away in 1997.

The Continuity IRA is the terrorist wing of Republican Sinn Fein, a dissident group headed by the former IRA chief of staff, Ruairi O Bradaigh, which broke away from the main Sinn Fein in 1986. Mr O Bradaigh walked out of the Sinn Fein annual conference that year in protest at the decision by Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness to drop the party's policy of boycotting the Irish parliament.

The Continuity IRA launched its most devastating attack on the Killyhevlin hotel in Enniskillen, Co Fermanagh, in the summer of 1996.

The group was responsible for the bomb scare at the Kempton Park racecourse, in Surrey, last December which forced the evacuation of 20,000 racegoers

Mr O Bradaigh emphatically denies that he has any links with the Continuity IRA. However, he has been a trenchant critic of the Provisional IRA's ceasefire from the moment it was declared in August 1994.

On the day the IRA ceasefire was called, Mr O Bradaigh said that after every revolutionary wave, the time came when the political elite "cashed in the accumulated cheque to gain privilege and power for themselves".

His criticisms of the Provisionals have echoed the thinking of other republican dissidents in Northern Ireland.

Police believe that in the last year there has been a drawing together of breakaway groups, providing a pool of more than 100 terrorists.

The group consists of members of the Continuity IRA, disaffected members of the Provisional IRA, the Real IRA and the Irish National Liberation Army.

webTitle: Hope fades as search for scuba diver is called off

fields.headline: Hope fades as search for scuba diver is called off
fields.trailText: The search for a British scuba diver who went missing off the coast of Sydney, Australia, during a disastrous dive which left three others seriously ill was called off last night as storms hampered the rescue mission.
fields.body:
The search for a British scuba diver who went missing off the coast of Sydney, Australia, during a disastrous dive which left three others seriously ill was called off last night as storms hampered the rescue mission.

Hopes of finding Nicky Sheen, 24, from London, alive were described as extremely slim after she failed to resurface when the 10-strong group she was with got in to trouble off Bondi Beach on Saturday.

Police were yesterday investigating why the team was forced to race to the surface, apparently with little or no oxygen left. The ascent left one diver with the bends and two with breathing problems. Ms Sheen did not resurface.

Police said: "During the dive one of the men in the party suffered the symptoms of the bends and indicated he was in trouble. He was helped to the shore and airlifted to hospital.

"Two other divers came to the surface suffering from hyperventilation and were also transferred to hospital. In the light of evidence we have got at this stage, hope is extremely slim. There's not much chance of finding her alive."

fields.headline: Voluntary amputee ran disability site
fields.trailText: The row over a British surgeon's decision to amputate two men's healthy limbs intensified yesterday after it was revealed that the doctor knew that one of the men ran a website for people who are sexually interested in amputees.
fields.body:
The row over a British surgeon's decision to amputate two men's healthy limbs intensified yesterday after it was revealed that the doctor knew that one of the men ran a website for people who are sexually interested in amputees.

It has also emerged that the operations performed by Robert Smith at Falkirk and district royal infirmary were conducted against the advice of a top psychiatrist at the hospital.

The revelations have come as one of the amputees spoke for the first time about his operation. Kevin Wright told the Sunday Herald newspaper that he had known since the age of eight that he wanted his left leg removed.

"I didn't want it," he said. "It didn't feel a part of me. I did not understand why, but I knew I didn't want my leg."

Mr Wright and Hans Schaub, from Germany, both suffered from body dysmorphic disorder, a rare psychological condition which leads to sufferers focusing on a perceived imperfection of a particular body part.

The pair each had the lower part of one leg removed at Falkirk - Mr Wright in 1997 and Mr Schaub last April. They had been denied the operation at hospitals across Europe.

Mr Smith, who has defended his decision to operate, told the Sunday Telegraph yesterday that he had known of Mr Wright's involvement in the OverGround website and would not have agreed to the operation if he had felt that a sexual fetish had been a factor. He said the website was an information provider and covered the whole spectrum of the problem.

"I looked at the website before I decided what I was going to do and I wanted to make sure that I was dealing with the right problem," he said. "I do not feel I have been duped."

OverGround, which closed its website last week, described itself as "a support group for people who are attracted to those who have physical disabilities".

Mr Wright, a university teaching assistant from Essex, has defended the site as an information provider and said he found extreme sites on amputee fetishism "appalling".

He said his life has been transformed since Mr Smith had carried out the amputation.

It has also been reported that George Dodds, a senior psychiatrist at the Falkirk hospital, who was asked to study the men's case notes before the operations, disagreed with the conclusions of psychiatrists who had examined the men. Dr Dodds reportedly said he could not support a decision to operate.

The Forth Valley acute hospitals NHS trust said the operations were regrettable and unacceptable but Mr Smith had followed correct procedures and no action would be taken against him.

fields.headline: Blair blasts backbench critics
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday launched a scathing attack on backbench critics of New Labour, warning that the "politics of division" could cost the party the next election.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday launched a scathing attack on backbench critics of New Labour, warning that the "politics of division" could cost the party the next election.

In a powerful display of his anger with the former defence minister Peter Kilfoyle, who has accused the government of abandoning its traditional heartlands, the prime minister said Labour was transforming the lives of the less well-off.

Responding directly to Mr Kilfoyle's claim that Labour was concentrating too many resources on middle England in the south, Mr Blair told the party's local government conference: "The whole country is our core constituency."

Mr Blair's strong defence of his record in healing national divisions indicates that Mr Kilfoyle's attacks on the government, since resigning as a defence minister last week, have struck a nerve in Downing Street. Senior ministers are said to be growing alarmed at Labour's inability to inspire its core voters who have failed to turn out in a series of recent byelections, most notably in Ceredigion last week where the party trailed in fourth place.

Mr Blair made clear his dismay at such indifference when he told his audience yesterday that he had introduced a series of flagship policies, from the national minimum wage to the new deal for the unemployed, that were transforming people's lives.

Such achievements were not being helped by internal critics, who had accused the government of ignoring heartland supporters and favouring the south over the north.

"I reject the politics of division - those who want to see England fight Scotland, those who want to see north fight south," Mr Blair said. "I say the politics of division have damaged the country for far too long and are not the answer to the problems our country faces."

The prime minister, who is still haunted by the memories of Labour's disastrous divisions of the early 1980s, issued a blunt warning to the likes of Mr Kilfoyle and Ken Livingstone. Reminding the party that divisions had deprived Labour of a full second term throughout its 100-year history, the prime minister said: "We need that second term. Not just for us to be in power but to make the changes really take root in our country."

Downing Street will have been pleased when the conference cheered Mr Blair as he reminded them that he understood the concerns of core voters as a north-east MP.

Departing from his text, the prime minister spoke of his despair when he felt "utterly powerless" to influence any government until New Labour's grand coalition embraced both north and south in 1997.

To loud applause, he said: "I was never able to do anything for the unemployed or the poor in my constituency until we were capable of winning in the south as well as the north. So don't let us ever be pushed back into the position of saying, 'Here is one part of the country we represent, and some parts we don't represent.' We represent all of Britain."

Mr Blair's attempts to give the party a new focus of national unity after the damaging accusations of the past week were undermined by claims from the Labour chairman of the local government association, Sir Jeremy Beecham, that Labour exercised too much central control from Whitehall.

Last week Mr Kilfoyle, an old-fashioned Labour rightwinger, likened Labour's central control to that of the Militant tendency in the mid-1990s. Sir Jeremy, normally a Labour loyalist, did not quite go that far, but said: "We need government to acknowledge that in the long run central planning and the command society are as inefficient and incompatible with democracy as the command economy of the old eastern Europe."

webTitle: Portillo's challenge to Hague on tax

fields.headline: Portillo's challenge to Hague on tax
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo mounted a direct challenge to the authority of William Hague yesterday when he refused to back a key plank of Tory economic policy.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo mounted a direct challenge to the authority of William Hague yesterday when he refused to back a key plank of Tory economic policy.

Days after announcing u-turns on the minimum wage and Bank of England independence, the new shadow chancellor refused to support Mr Hague's guarantee to cut taxes if the Conservative party wins the next election.

His intervention, hours after Mr Hague reiterated his support for the Tory "tax guarantee", fuelled speculation that Mr Portillo is using his new high-profile post to undermine the Tory leader, who is still failing to make any impact in opinion polls.

Mr Portillo's challenge came during an interview on The World this Weekend on Radio 4, when he was asked whether he supported Mr Hague's tax guarantee. The policy, one of the central features of Mr Hague's "commonsense revolution", guarantees that taxes will be reduced as a share of national income regardless of the state of the economy.

Mr Portillo signalled his lukewarm support for the policy when he said: "Well. I am happy to discuss that."

He qualified his remarks by criticising the "incredulity" which had greeted the policy. He said Tory governments had succeeded in bringing taxes down.

However, Mr Portillo set himself at odds with Mr Hague when he was asked directly whether he would reduce taxes regardless of the economic circumstances. The shadow chancellor would only speak in general terms about the importance of cutting taxes.

"I believe it is extremely important that we should be reducing taxes as a proportion of our national income. Unless we keep control of our tax burden we are going to lose good people."

Mr Portillo's remarks indicate that while he shares Mr Hague's objective of reducing taxes, he does not believe that it can be guaranteed.

Labour has rounded on the Tory tax guarantee, saying it would inevitably lead to cuts in public services in the event of a recession. If the economy were to slow down, tax receipts would fall, forcing the Tories to cut public services to fulfil their pledge, Labour said.

The differences between the two most senior figures in the Tory party were underlined when Mr Hague insisted that he stood by his tax guarantee.

Speaking on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost a few hours before Mr Portillo, the Tory leader said that he could increase spending on health while cutting taxes.

"Can we [increase health spending] at the same time as the tax guarantee?" he asked. "Yes we can because the areas of government spending that need reducing are welfare and the spending on government itself."

Mr Portillo made clear that he was determined to plough his own furrow when he barely referred to Mr Hague. Asked about his u-turns on the minimum wage and the Bank of England he stressed his role in the decisions.

On the minimum wage, he said: "I regard myself as a practical person and the Conservatives have no need to abolish the minimum wage."

On the Bank of England, Mr Portillo said that he had been personally in favour of independence of its monetary policy committee "for some considerable time".

He also made it clear that Francis Maude, his predecessor, had badly slipped up with his dire predictions of a recession. "The economy is doing quite well for many people, but not for everyone."

fields.headline: Where's the beef?
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Muscle (BBC 1) is shown at 10 o'clock on Saturday night, so, as boozers and bouncers thump each other, we can think "Good thing we stayed in and watched telly." Not a thought that would normally occur to anyone on Saturday.
fields.body:
Muscle (BBC 1) is shown at 10 o'clock on Saturday night, so, as boozers and bouncers thump each other, we can think "Good thing we stayed in and watched telly." Not a thought that would normally occur to anyone on Saturday.

Martyn, Ronnie, Mike and who the one who looks as if he wishes he were somewhere else, Chris, work for Security Leisure in Bristol. They back up bouncers. "We", as Mike puts it, "are the elite. We are the answer to the problem."

Martyn is a cockney and, therefore, does all the chat. He talks with ease and a characteristic emphasis on certain words as in "I was amazed when I was arrested." Ronnie is a dark, gipsyish, leathery-looking bloke. It is hard to tell where the leather jacket ends and Ronnie begins. As he is still working on the precious gift of human speech, Martyn gives him a warm testimonial. "He has a very, very strong sense of decency, although it doesn't always come across in his persona."

Chris ("I'm not a violent man and, I'll be open and honest with you, I've had psychological problems in coping with it.") used to be a cop. Mike ("If somebody crossed me I could probably be quite evil.") will astound us all next week by becoming a born-again Christian.

They spent the bulk of this first programme battering away at punch bags or, in Ronnie's case, having heavy weights dropped on his stomach ("Go on! Go on! Ooargh!") The intention, in Martyn's beguiling phrase, was to shine with confidence.

Shining with confidence, they arrived at a Bristol pub where the bar staff had called for help. It seemed a normal, if noisy, night. A group of friends were celebrating. Martyn, as ever, was the spokesman. "The management want you out, folks. Finish your drinks. You've gotta leave."

It seemed to go from first to fourth gear in seconds. At first only Ronnie and a customer were shouting in each others furious faces, then the whole place started to heave like the sea. One man was starfished on the pavement. Then, said Martyn, "It was like a cork out of a bottle. Everybody just burst on the pavement. That's just what I wanted." It was not what Chris, with his police experience, wanted. "When it got on the street, I realised this was bad news. The last time I was in anything like that I was wearing a riot helmet, body armour and carrying a shield and baton."

The lurid orange lights of a city at night bounced off the parked cars. There were no bottles or knives. This was a real, old-fashioned, arm-swinging, testosterone-fuelled, rough house. Everyone seemed to have found, as in a dance, an enemy to thump and a friend to try and hold him back. The approaching police siren sounded as sweet as a lullaby.

The police would subpoena and study this footage. There would be five convictions for affray and a severe ear-chewing for Security Leisure for gravely mishandling the situation.

It is vivid and valuable viewing. You wonder what, apart from a seductive producer, inclined Security Leisure to cooperate with a TV crew for a year. Except, as a thuggee once said just before they executed him, "Is any man ashamed of his profession?"

The Mrs Bradley Mysteries (BBC 1) look very chic and picturesque and, with Diana Rigg in the lead, they have a head start there. They are based on Gladys Mitchell's detective stories and her Mrs Bradley looks nothing like that. She is a psychiatrist and latter-day witch because Gladys Mitchell, who sounds more interesting than her books, had two unusual interests for a pre-war schoolmistress: Freud and black magic.

Gladys Mitchell describes her as a black-eyed, beaky-mouthed, yellow-skinned, reptilian old lady. She is apt to cackle evilly. Don't tell me there are no saurian old crones with Equity cards perfectly capable of giving us this Mrs Bradley and glad of the money. Of course, it wouldn't sell so well in America.

In one of her books, Agatha Christie, appearing undercover as a detective-story writer called Ariadne Oliver, is quite acid about dramatists who take popular detectives and change then out of all recognition, make them younger, smarter, sexier.

In The Mrs Bradley Mysteries, George, the chauffeur, is now in love with her. The real Mrs Bradley would cackle evilly.

fields.headline: Yes, but will it fly?
fields.standfirst: A new ITV serial about the rocket-building exploits of a reluctant bridegroom-to-be is entertaining enough. But  Mark Lawson doesn't need to be a Nasa scientist to detect the whiff of drama by numbers
fields.trailText: It is sometimes the case that writers in different rooms tap into an atmosphere and a particular plot finds its time. The 1970s saw a vast web of different authors working on conspiracy theories, and here at the beginning of the 21st century - as divorce rates rise and families fragment - writers are rushing into marriage.
fields.body:
It is sometimes the case that writers in different rooms tap into an atmosphere and a particular plot finds its time. The 1970s saw a vast web of different authors working on conspiracy theories, and here at the beginning of the 21st century - as divorce rates rise and families fragment - writers are rushing into marriage.

And there seems to be especial interest in a particular position. A few days after Amy Jenkins (creator of BBC2's This Life) sold to Hollywood a novel about a newly-wed meeting an old lover on honeymoon, a similar crisis is explored in a new television drama Reach For The Moon (ITV, Friday, 9pm). Two weeks before the wedding of teacher Paul Martin (Jonathan Kerrigan), his first and unforgotten girlfriend Annie Bowman (Saira Todd) returns after a decade's absence to take a post in the same school.

Given the failure rate of modern relationships, it's no surprise that so many writers should be focusing on the precise moment of commitment: on the baggage which couples take on their honeymoon but which doesn't go on the airport carousel. This seven-parter by Matthew Graham (an EastEnders scriptwriter) is a superior weepie with moments of real smartness in the writing, but the series raises two recurrent problems with modern television drama: symbolism and tension.

There was once apparently a college creative writing course in America in which the seminars included one called "putting the symbols in". I increasingly wonder if British dramatists are having the same lessons.

Even in dramas with a strong central subject, there is a tendency for the central characters to have an appropriate or ironic dream life or hobby. The space race seems especially popular for this. Peter Kosminsky's excellent 1999 ITV drama about bullying - Walking On The Moon - had an unnecessary astronautical sub-text. And in Reach For The Moon the fianced teacher about to put his fingers too close to an old flame is also a space bore.

He is building a huge replica rocket which he plans to launch as one of his final acts as a bachelor. While his prospective mother-in-law nags him about table-settings and bridesmaids' dresses, the teacher is excitedly opening packages containing parts and fuel from Germany. He is going to launch the biggest amateur rocket ever, if only he can get the thrust and angle right.

Dr Freud would have cleared his diary for a week when Paul walked in, but peak-time ITV is less interested in the sexual implications of this ambitious erection and more in the suggestion of escape and flight. The series is set on the Isle Of Wight.

This decision to issue ferry-tickets to cast and crew is one of the most interesting aspects of the series. English playwrights have always struggled to find an equivalent to the "small town" setting which is such a staple for American authors. The compact topography of England means that it is hard to achieve a genuine sense of isolation, despite the impressive efforts of Virgin Rail in giving travellers an American sense of time, distance and the inaccessibility of major cities. The Isle Of Wight setting of Reach For The Moon, however, does offer on almost Iowan feeling of removal from the centre of affairs. There is a finality when people "leave the island". Those who remain do seem cut off. Paul's problem is that he should have travelled more before committing.

Even so, the second problematic area of the series, besides the symbolism, also gives an unwanted sense of quarantine from the real world. The characters just don't seem to have watched enough television drama. Episode one tries for two sources of tension. The first is whether Paul and Annie will resume their relationship even as his wedding presents begin to arrive. This works well enough, although it seems rather forced - Dr Freud cancels all lunches for a second week - that their first encounter follows the failure of his rocket to come off properly.

But the second narrative strand involves two sixth-form lovers - Josie Lake (Ania Sowinski) and Anthony Harris (JJ Field) - dealing, at the end of term, with the boy's impending departure for Cambridge while the girl stays on the isle. This plot-line echoes the way in which Paul and Annie broke up ten years before.

The problem is that the parallel young lovers are introduced with a scene in which the girl complains of being pale and peaky. ITV would hope to attract nine or ten million viewers to this drama and it's perhaps just possible that one or two of them will not yell at the set at this moment: "She's pregnant!" A later scene in which she emerges looking shattered from a lavatory stall is framed in mid-shot to obscure what she's holding in her hands. But can there be a viewer in Britain who would need a Predictor kit to tell them what the hidden object is?

In newspapers, memoranda occasionally circulate warning writers against certain words and phrases which have appeared too often on the pages. ITV now needs to e-mail scriptwriters with a warning against dramas which use the moon-shots as symbolism or which depend for tension on whether a young woman is pregnant. But Reach For The Moon will nicely fill Friday nights with a bottle of wine for those young couples in Britain who remain married.

And in Reach For The Moon the fianced teacher about to put his fingers too close to an old flame is also a space bore. He is building a huge replica rocket which he plans to launch as one of his final acts as a bachelor. While his prospective mother-in-law nags him about table-settings and bridesmaids' dresses, the teacher is excitedly opening packages containing parts and fuel from Germany. He is going to launch the biggest amateur rocket ever, if only he can get the thrust and angle right. Dr Freud would have cleared his diary for a week when Paul walked in, but peak-time ITV is less interested in the sexual implications of this ambitious erection and more in the suggestion of escape and flight. The series is set on the Isle Of Wight. This decision to issue ferry-tickets to cast and crew is one of the most interesting aspects of the series. English playwrights have always struggled to find an equivalent to the "small town" setting which is such a staple for American authors. The compact topography of England means that it is hard to achieve a genuine sense of isolation, despite the impressive efforts of Virgin Rail in giving travellers an American sense of time, distance and the inaccessibility of major cities. The Isle Of Wight setting of Reach For The Moon, however, does offer on almost Iowan feeling of removal from the centre of affairs. There is a finality when people "leave the island". Those who remain do seem cut off. Paul's problem is that he should have travelled more before committing. Even so, the second problematic area of the series, besides the symbolism, also gives an unwanted sense of quarantine from the real world. The characters just don't seem to have watched enough television drama. Episode one tries for two sources of tension. The first is whether Paul and Annie will resume their relationship even as his wedding presents begin to arrive. This works well enough, although it seems rather forced - Dr Freud cancels all lunches for a second week - that their first encounter follows the failure of his rocket to come off properly. But the second narrative strand involves two sixth-form lovers - Josie Lake (Ania Sowinski) and Anthony Harris (JJ Field) - dealing, at the end of term, with the boy's impending departure for Cambridge while the girl stays on the isle. This plot-line echoes the way in which Paul and Annie broke up ten years before. The problem is that the parallel young lovers are introduced with a scene in which the girl complains of being pale and peaky. ITV would hope to attract nine or ten million viewers to this drama and it's perhaps just possible that one or two of them will not yell at the set at this moment: "She's pregnant!" A later scene in which she emerges looking shattered from a lavatory stall is framed in mid-shot to obscure what she's holding in her hands. But can there be a viewer in Britain who would need a Predictor kit to tell them what the hidden object is? In newspapers, memoranda occasionally circulate warning writers against certain words and phrases which have appeared too often on the pages. ITV now needs to e-mail scriptwriters with a warning against dramas which use the moon-shots as symbolism or which depend for tension on whether a young woman is pregnant. But Reach For The Moon will nicely fill Friday nights with a bottle of wine for those young couples in Britain who remain married.

fields.trailText: Following Andrew Clements's centennial appreciation on these pages last Thursday, there's a chance to hear the music of Mexico's Silvestre Revueltas, seldom played in Britain. He and his compatriot Carlos Chavez are joint Composers Of The Week (9.0am, Radio 3), their work and influence discussed by Donald Macleod and the conductor Odaline de la Martinez. Unlike Revueltas, Chavez had no formal training, but his natural talent secured him the directorship of the Mexico Symphony Orchestra.

fields.headline: Play it again
fields.trailText: One of the most difficult problems for a controller of a television network is constructing an attitude towards repeats. It's generally assumed that viewers hate what is euphemistically called "another chance to see". Every summer - the peak-time for retreads because executives who are largely in Tuscany see no reason to spend money on viewers who are mainly in Spain - the tabloid papers and the feedback shows are over-run with moans about the moment in front of a detective programme when you realise you already know the killer.
fields.body:
One of the most difficult problems for a controller of a television network is constructing an attitude towards repeats. It's generally assumed that viewers hate what is euphemistically called "another chance to see". Every summer - the peak-time for retreads because executives who are largely in Tuscany see no reason to spend money on viewers who are mainly in Spain - the tabloid papers and the feedback shows are over-run with moans about the moment in front of a detective programme when you realise you already know the killer.

Television has never worked out a relationship with the classics of its past in the way that theatre, cinema and books have. Obsessed with immediacy, television is the only medium which fears its past. But a thoughtful and strategic repeat can be a service to the viewer and a way of answering the most important question about any art-work: has it lasted?

It's good, for example, to see again The Fall And Rise Of Reginald Perrin (Tuesday, 9pm, BBC2). This mid-70s comedy by David Nobbs was at the time one of the bravest creations in the history of sit-com. Nobbs took the already familiar territory of the English domestic telly comedy - the suburban worker-husband - and played it for cruel humour thickening into tragedy.

Nobbs showed Reggie, a corporate high-flyer, leaving his clothes on the beach and walking out on his life. Watching the programmes again, the dark laughter is still intact. A running mother-in-law gag - in which Reggie sees his wife's mum as a hippo - feels dated, but the moments in which Leonard Rossiter stares hopelessly into the distance as Reggie's derangement takes hold achieve a genuine despair, given additional power by the actor's unfairly young death.

I watched an episode shortly after seeing the buzz-film of this year - Sam Mendes's thematically very similar American Beauty - and Nobbs and Rossiter survived the competition impressively. This is a repeat to cheer.

webTitle: Work experience: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: Mandy Patinkin in Ragtime (Milos Forman, 1981)
fields.body:
Mandy Patinkin in Ragtime (Milos Forman, 1981)

Who? Chicago-born star of stage, records, screen and TV. Actor and singer Mandy (yes, we know it's a girl's name) has a great range - check out those high notes! - and appeared on stage in Evita and Sunday In The Park With George. He's also released a number of albums, including the winningly titled Dress Casual, and Mamaloshen, which was entirely comprised of Yiddish folk songs. On the big screen, his work ranges from Yentl to The Princess Bride, and his next screen role is alongside a load of muppets (literally) in The Adventures Of Elmo In Grouchland. Despite the length of his CV, however, he's probably still best known as the eternally cranky Doctor Jeffrey Geiger in Chicago Hope.

The role: Tateh, a Jewish immigrant in 1930s New York, who rises from struggling artist and cuckolded husband to movie svengali.

Best Line: Unquestionably his direction to starlet Evelyn Nesbit (Elizabeth McGovern): "Play it with your eyes, play it with your face, show it with your tongue. Forget about the belly or the pishy-pishy with the feet. Forget it."

Cringe factor: Low. Only a remarkably bushy (and stuck-on looking) beard to worry about.

Other wannabes: Jeff Daniels as a useless cop, and the ubiquitous Samuel L. Jackson as "Gang Member Number 2".

Also not starring in: A 1978 episode of Taxi as "New Father", "Pool Man" in The Big Fix in the same year, and as "First Commuter" in Last Embrace in 1979.

Ragtime, Carlton Cinema, Sunday February 13, 9.30pm

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Breaker Morant
fields.body:
Breaker Morant

(Bruce Beresford, 1979)

8pm, 3am, Carlton Cinema

Boer war drama about three Australian officers - Bryan Brown, Edward Woodward, Lewis Fitzgerald - courtmartialled for executing prisoners. Movingly told, with a quiet sense of outrage; Jack Thompson as the defending officer is pick of a strong cast.

Romeo Is Bleeding

(Peter Medak, 1993)

10pm, FilmFour

Life is sweet for Gary Oldman's New York cop Grimaldi: he's on the take from Roy Scheider's mob man and dividing his time between wife Annabella Sciorra and girlfriend Juliette Lewis. But then Lena Olin's Russian killer Mona Demarkov, the most fatal of femmes, hits town, and events quickly spiral out of control... Outrageous neo-noir, and in Olin's stunning dominatrix, a character who makes Oldman look introverted.

The Devil's Own

(Alan J Pakula, 1997)

12.25am, Sky Premier

A Hollywood excursion into the troubles of Northern Ireland: don't expect too many sophisticated insights into the situation. Harrison Ford is a humble Irish-American New York cop playing unwitting host to IRA man Brad Pitt, who's busy shipping missiles home. Pakula made better thrillers in his time (this was his last film before being killed in a road accident), but the two stars play off well against each other in a tale of political imperative versus a sense of justice.

The Nanny

(Seth Holt, 1965)

12midnight, FilmFour

A typical Hammer horror in that there's not really much horror, more a sense of unease to make it disturbing. Bette Davis (looking uncannily like Edward G Robinson in drag) is the sinisterly proprietorial presence of the title, inexplicably at odds with her tearaway 10-year-old charge (William Dix). His parents are too weak or absent to be bothered by their son's protests that Nanny is trying to murder him, and early references to "the accident" sustain the attention until the meltdown ending.

fields.headline: Lord Hughes of Hawkhill
fields.trailText: The achievements of Lord Hughes of Hawkhill, who has died aged 87, came late in his life as an active peer, and took the form of blistering attacks on the Conservative government during the last period of the Thatcher and Major era.
fields.body:
The achievements of Lord Hughes of Hawkhill, who has died aged 87, came late in his life as an active peer, and took the form of blistering attacks on the Conservative government during the last period of the Thatcher and Major era.

A junior Scottish minister for more than seven years in both of Harold Wilson's governments, chairman of the Glenrothes, and then the East Kilbride, development corporations, Hughes spent four years as chairman of the reforming royal commission on Scottish legal services. A supporter of Scottish home rule, in 1994 he criticised the anti-Labour gerrymandering of Scottish local government. In 1996, he ridiculed Tories who claimed Scottish self-government would inhibit foreign investment. His most scorching Lords speech was his attack on Margaret Thatcher in 1987 for trying out the poll tax on Scotland.

William Hughes was born in Dundee, educated at the local technical college and worked in the jute industry before switching to Argus Construction, of which he later became managing director. His social conscience led him into Labour politics; he was elected as a Dundee coun cillor at the age of 22, a post he held for nearly 30 years. He became city treasurer, lord provost and HM lieutenant of Dundee (1954-60).

During the second world war, Hughes served in India, Burma and Borneo, before being emobilised as a captain. He twice fought unsuccessfully to become and MP, and was elevated with a life peerage in 1961. His wife, Christian, died in 1994 and he leaves two daughters.

 William Hughes, Baron Hughes of Hawkhill, public servant, born January 22 1911; died December 31 1999

fields.headline: Carl Albert
fields.standfirst: Shrewd manager of Watergate investigation
fields.trailText: Congressman Carl Albert, who has died aged 91, had one of the oddest careers in American politics. A self-effacing country boy from a four-room shack in Bug Tussle, Oklahoma, he rose virtually without trace to the house of representatives speakership and twice came within a hair's breadth of the presidency.
fields.body:
Congressman Carl Albert, who has died aged 91, had one of the oddest careers in American politics. A self-effacing country boy from a four-room shack in Bug Tussle, Oklahoma, he rose virtually without trace to the house of representatives speakership and twice came within a hair's breadth of the presidency.

After Spiro Agnew's resignation for corruption in October 1973, President Nixon felt sufficiently besieged to offer Albert, a Democrat, the vice president's job, but was told: "No. I came to Washington to be a congressman". A similar situation arose in 1974, when Nixon himself resigned and Gerald Ford took office without a vice-president.

Though Albert had studied law at Oxford as a Rhodes scholar in 1931, and briefly practised before wartime service in the army air corps, a political career was his only ambition. A modest man - with much to be modest about - he scraped into congress in the 1946 election, representing the sparsely-populated third district of south-eastern Oklahoma, one of America's poorest areas and known as Little Dixie, with all the racial prejudices that implies.

By initially opposing President Eisenhower's civil rights bills, Albert secured the local popularity to hold his seat for 30 years. But, as a natural supporter of the Kennedy- Johnson anti-poverty measures, he eventually accepted the civil rights legislation that went with them. He also voted consistently for the mounting costs of the Vietnam war.

His luckiest political break came early, when he secured the patronage of the powerful speaker of the house, Sam Rayburn, who made Albert a Democratic party whip. His principal asset for the job was a deeply conciliatory approach, which ensured that he rarely offended anyone. So well did he survive the years of John McCormack's bulldozing reign as speaker that fellow Democrats elected him their leader in the house in 1962.

On McCormack's retirement in 1971, they voted Albert speaker, despite his poor performance at the disastrous 1968 Chicago convention, when the Vietnam war had split the Democrats. Albert had been the convention chairman when Mayor Daley's police teargassed and beat up both demonstrators and delegates. Mediation was hardly the name of the game, and he proved wholly ineffectual at controlling the mayhem.

Albert's greatest service to his country came with the Watergate scandal. Throughout his decades in Washington, he had studied the historic documents in the national archives and the US Library of Congress, a habit that gave him unprecedented knowledge to handle the constitutional crisis.

As the man who controlled the legislative programme of the house of representatives, the body which would have to draw up articles of impeachment against the president, Albert fought skilfully to ensure that constitutional requirements were followed to the letter. He later admitted that in the early stages he had thought Nixon was an innocent victim of his corrupt staff.

The president's abrupt dismissal of the original special prosecutor changed his mind. Nixon's action brought an avalanche of impeachment resolutions from outraged congressmen, and Albert, realising that the judicial process could be overwhelmed by a partisan frenzy, shrewdly put the issue into the hands of the house judiciary committee. No one was in a position to overrule the speaker, so the legislative mills began their inexorable grind in the hands of experienced members of both political parties working in a committee dedicated to due process.

It was brilliantly successful. By the time America had sat mesmerised by the committee's exhaustive debate - and seen it pass three damning articles of impeachment - the partisan passion had gone and the outcome seemed inevitable. It was a modest man's finest achievement.

Albert is survived by his wife, Mary Sue, his son and daughter and four grandchildren.

 Carl Bert Albert, politician, born May 10 1908; died February 4 2000

fields.headline: Doris Coley
fields.standfirst: A voice that changed the sound of pop
fields.trailText: Girls weren't supposed to sleep with their boyfriends in the teenage world of the late 1950s, so the release of the Shirelles's Will You Love Me Tomorrow in 1959 provided a double frisson for the record-buying public: four young black female soul voices moulded with the universal appeal of narrative lyrics. Here sex and love were inexorably entwined, with the added worry that once she succumbed to "a moment's pleasure", God knows what would happen "when the night meets the morning sun".
fields.body:
Girls weren't supposed to sleep with their boyfriends in the teenage world of the late 1950s, so the release of the Shirelles's Will You Love Me Tomorrow in 1959 provided a double frisson for the record-buying public: four young black female soul voices moulded with the universal appeal of narrative lyrics. Here sex and love were inexorably entwined, with the added worry that once she succumbed to "a moment's pleasure", God knows what would happen "when the night meets the morning sun".

Doris Kenner-Jackson, known publicly by her maiden name of Doris Coley, who has died of cancer at the age of 58, was one of the quartet who enjoyed a run of million-sellers in America between 1959 and 1965, and transformed popular music. With Addie "Micki" Harris, Beverly Lee and Shirley Owens, she formed the group that became the Shirelles for a high school talent show in 1957. There, as the Poquelles, they sang I Met Him On A Sunday - the song that was to be their first single.

Coley was born in the southern state of North Carolina but, like many black families, her parents moved north and she was brought up in Passaic, New Jersey. A classmate, Mary Jane Greenberg, told her music-business mother about the group's school appearance and Flo rence Greenberg became their manager, signing them to Scepter/Wand, her record label.

With their name now changed again, from the Honeytones, the Shirelles first million-seller was a bal lad, Tonight's The Night, but it was swiftly followed by the groundbreaking Will You Love Me. The Shirelles became a major influence on the young white British music scene of the early 1960s, where any musician clued in to mod culture was looking towards soul and r&b, and listening to a clutch of black female vocal groups: the Shirelles, Crystals, Chiffons and Marvelettes. Nowhere was this influence more noticeable than on the white female singers of the day, particularly Dusty Springfield, whose early records are homage to these groups.

Coley, Harris, Lee and Owens were leading exponents of "uptown r&b", so named because it came out of New York, rather than the southern states. In the 1950s, the city saw a blossoming of independent, black-run labels and black venues, like Harlem's Apollo and the Brooklyn Fox. New York also boasted the Brill Building music factory, where young white songwriting teams - including Burt Bacharach and Hal David, Barry Mann and Cynthia Weil, and Gerry Goffin and Carole King - put out thoughtful teenage love songs which were snapped up by the black groups.

Goffin and King provided the Shirelles with Will You Love Me, though it was transformed by Luther Dixon's production, overlaying an r&b rhythm section with lush mellow string arrangements behind the slightly nasal voices of the group.

With Greenberg and Dixon, the Shirelles had three more million-sellers: Baby It's You, Everybody Loves A Lover and Dedicated To The One I Love. The last, originally written by Lowman Pauling for his group the Five Royales, featured Doris Coley on lead, and also gave the white Californian group, the Mamas and Papas, a hit in 1967.

The Shirelles toured America and Europe through the 1960s, with Coley billed as Doris Kenner after her first marriage. But, by mid-decade - like many of the original girl groups - they had been superseded by the more sophisticated Motown female sound epitomised by the Supremes and Martha and the Vandellas. In 1968, Coley left the group to concentrate on her family - she had re-married and was now Doris Jackson - but she returned in 1975 when the Shirelles were playing the oldies circuit.

 Doris Kenner-Jackson (nee Coley), singer, born August 2 1941; died February 5 2000

There, as the Poquelles, they sang I Met Him On A Sunday - the song that was to be their first single. Coley was born in the southern state of North Carolina but, like many black families, her parents moved north and she was brought up in Passaic, New Jersey. A classmate, Mary Jane Greenberg, told her music-business mother about the group's school appearance and Flo rence Greenberg became their manager, signing them to Scepter/Wand, her record label. With their name now changed again, from the Honeytones, the Shirelles first million-seller was a bal lad, Tonight's The Night, but it was swiftly followed by the groundbreaking Will You Love Me. The Shirelles became a major influence on the young white British music scene of the early 1960s, where any musician clued in to mod culture was looking towards soul and r&b, and listening to a clutch of black female vocal groups: the Shirelles, Crystals, Chiffons and Marvelettes. Nowhere was this influence more noticeable than on the white female singers of the day, particularly Dusty Springfield, whose early records are homage to these groups. Coley, Harris, Lee and Owens were leading exponents of "uptown r&b", so named because it came out of New York, rather than the southern states. In the 1950s, the city saw a blossoming of independent, black-run labels and black venues, like Harlem's Apollo and the Brooklyn Fox. New York also boasted the Brill Building music factory, where young white songwriting teams - including Burt Bacharach and Hal David, Barry Mann and Cynthia Weil, and Gerry Goffin and Carole King - put out thoughtful teenage love songs which were snapped up by the black groups. Goffin and King provided the Shirelles with Will You Love Me, though it was transformed by Luther Dixon's production, overlaying an r&b rhythm section with lush mellow string arrangements behind the slightly nasal voices of the group. With Greenberg and Dixon, the Shirelles had three more million-sellers: Baby It's You, Everybody Loves A Lover and Dedicated To The One I Love. The last, originally written by Lowman Pauling for his group the Five Royales, featured Doris Coley on lead, and also gave the white Californian group, the Mamas and Papas, a hit in 1967. The Shirelles toured America and Europe through the 1960s, with Coley billed as Doris Kenner after her first marriage. But, by mid-decade - like many of the original girl groups - they had been superseded by the more sophisticated Motown female sound epitomised by the Supremes and Martha and the Vandellas. In 1968, Coley left the group to concentrate on her family - she had re-married and was now Doris Jackson - but she returned in 1975 when the Shirelles were playing the oldies circuit.  Doris Kenner-Jackson (nee Coley), singer, born August 2 1941; died February 5 2000

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Banned protein found in French cattle feed
fields.body:
Banned protein found in French cattle feed

A damning report by EU experts said yesterday that traces of outlawed meat and bone meal were still finding their way into French cattle feed last year, and warned that French farmers may be under-reporting cases of mad cow disease.

Notification of suspect cases "occurs with a certain hesitation, and a considerable delay in some cases", it said. The report will embarrass the French government, which has defied its European partners by maintaining its ban on British beef on the grounds that safety measures introduced in Britain in the wake of the BSE crisis were still not foolproof - and that it was putting consumers' health first.

The report, from an EU veterinary mission to France last June, said that 4.2% of samples of cattle feed analysed in the first five months of 1999 contained "traces" of meat and bone meal, while 1.4% contained "more than a trace".

Animal proteins were banned from cattle feed in 1996 after nearly a decade of testing found that meat and bone meal from cattle was the most likely cause of transmission of BSE, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy.

The French agriculture ministry declined to comment on the report yesterday. But a spokesman said France planned to set up a screening programme in the next few weeks to check that cattle ready for slaughter were not infected with mad cow disease.
Jon Henley, Paris

Iran asks for support in fighting terror

After a series of explosions in the heart of Tehran, the Iranian government yesterday called on the world community to help it fight the Iraqi-based opposition group that claimed responsibility.

A print worker was killed and six others injured when mortar rounds hit the eastern gate of the presidential palace on Saturday, damaging nearby government buildings.

The Mojahedin-e Khalq, an armed group classified as terrorist by the US, says it was behind the attack. Based in Iraq and going under a variety of names including the National Council of Resistance, it has worked for nearly two decades to overthrow Iran's Islamic system.

Tehran's foreign ministry said: "We demand [a] firm, serious and non-selective response from the international community, mainly countries which claim to be fighting terrorism."

Saturday's attack - coinciding with annual celebrations marking the 1979 Islamic revolution - seemed to be an attempt at destabilisation ahead of parliamen tary elections on February 18, when reformist adherents of President Mohammed Khatami hope to displace conservative MPs who dominate the parliament.
Geneive Abdo, Teheran

New light shed on Ben Barka mystery

A former French secret agent said yesterday that the killing of an exiled leftwing Morroccan opposition leader, Mehdi Ben Barka, in Paris 35 years ago was an accident.

Ben Barka was kidnapped on the Left Bank in October 1965. Antoine Lopez, now 76, was sentenced to eight years in jail in 1967 for his role in the affair. But he told Le Parisien newspaper that Ben Barka died "accidentally" at the hands of a French gangster, Georges Boucheseiche, at a house south of Paris, soon after the arrival of Morocco's then interior minister, General Mohammed Oufkir.

"Boucheseiche told me how Ben Barka had flown into a rage when he set eyes on Oufkir," Mr Lopez said. "He told me how he had delivered a first blow to Ben Barka, who was not even knocked out. Boucheseiche then jammed him by the throat and snapped his neck."
Jon Henley, Paris

Barak sticks to Lebanon plan despite killing

An Israeli soldier was killed and seven injured yesterday in a roadside bombing while on foot patrol inside south Lebanon, the fifth such death there in less than two weeks.

Hizbullah guerrillas claimed responsibility and a few hours later Israeli jets fired several missiles in two retaliatory bombing raids on Jebal al-Botom, a southern area from which guerillas are thought to launch attacks.

Ehud Barak, Israel's prime minister, who was visiting Jordan, reiterated his pledge to withdraw Israeli troops from south Lebanon by July. Mr Barak is demanding that Syria, the power in Lebanon, rein in Hizbullah.
AP, Marjayoun, Lebanon

Handful of votes could decide who leads Finns

Partial results in Finland's presidential election yesterday showed the opposition leader Esko Aho ahead by a hair's breadth in his run-off against the leftwing foreign minister, Tarja Halonen, according to the electoral commission's figures.

Based on 50% of the vote, the count gave the 45-year-old Mr Aho 50.5% and his rival 49.5%. But with such a tiny margin, Ms Halonen, a single mother aged 56, was not abandoning hopes of becoming the country's first woman president. Martti Ahtisaari, 62, is stepping down after a six-year term.
Reuters, Helsinki

fields.headline: Murder case grips sin city
fields.standfirst: Alleged lovers set for trial after Las Vegas casino owner's drugs death
fields.trailText: When casino multi-millionaire and all-round cowboy hellraiser Ted Binion died in the den of his luxury Las Vegas home 18 months ago, everyone assumed he had overdosed on drugs. But now Binion's ex-lover and his former business associate will stand trial for killing one of gambling's most colourful characters. The case will be heard just as America's fastest-growing city was hoping it had shed its image of Mafia-style lawlessness.
fields.body:
When casino multi-millionaire and all-round cowboy hellraiser Ted Binion died in the den of his luxury Las Vegas home 18 months ago, everyone assumed he had overdosed on drugs. But now Binion's ex-lover and his former business associate will stand trial for killing one of gambling's most colourful characters. The case will be heard just as America's fastest-growing city was hoping it had shed its image of Mafia-style lawlessness.

According to legend, Texas gambler Lester "Benny" Binion arrived in Las Vegas in 1946 in his 10-gallon hat and with a couple of suitcases crammed with $2m in cash. He set up the Horseshoe Club, for many years the landmark casino in the city and the home of the world series of poker.

His younger son, Lonnie "Ted" Binion, duly followed him into the business. But Binion junior became an alcoholic and also acquired a heavy heroin habit.

He was arrested on drugs charges in 1986, which led to his casino licence being suspended and subsequently revoked. It also drew him into friendships with gangsters like "Fat Herbie" Blitzstein and Tony "the Ant" Spilotro, both of whom have since met untimely deaths.

When he died, Binion's body was found by his lover, former topless dancer Sandy Murphy, 26, beside an empty bottle of the prescription drug Xanax and some heroin paraphernalia.

Jim Young, the police sergeant handling the case, described it delicately as an "an ingestion error in regards to medication". The local Las Vegas Review Journal at the time quoted two other responses to the death: local attorney Oscar Goodman, who is now the Mayor of Las Vegas, said: "he was one of the best guys I ever met"; Binion's friend and associate, Rick Tabish, called the death "a tragedy".

Time has moved on and Mr Tabish and Ms Murphy are both now charged with Binion's murder in a trial that will start next month.

The jury will hear that the bereaved Ms Murphy, whom Binion had met when she was a topless dancer at Cheetah's night club, was only interested in his money. She was, the prosecution will suggest, even prepared to put up with his violent beatings in order to inherit his $900,000 home and further settlements from the estate of a man worth $50m.

Mr Tabish will also be asked to explain his relationship with Binion. Twenty-four hours after Binion's death, Mr Tabish was found with two other men using an excavator to remove $5m in silver from a concrete vault he had helped build for Binion in the small Nevada town of Pahrump only two months earlier.

Why exactly Binion had wanted to move such a large sum to such an odd spot is still not clear, but police were not totally convinced by Mr Tabish's claim that he was merely fulfiling Binion's wishes that, should he die, the silver should be moved immediately elsewhere.

A note from Ms Murphy to Mr Tabish reading "Love you!" was also found, leading to the assumption that the pair had planned to fleece the wealthy, strung-out loser and share the proceeds of his wealth between them. But it was not until last June, nearly a year after the death that the pair were finally charged with murder.

In the meantime, Binion's family, who had not accepted the accidental overdose theory, hired a private detective to ensure that no potential evidence was missed. They have made it clear that they believe Murphy would only have pursued a fat, middle-aged, vodka-swilling addict for his money.

The case has already become highly charged; for pre-trial hearings, Ms Murphy painted her electronic tag, which she is required to wear as part of her bail conditions, different colours to match her outfit of the day and she flirted with Mr Tabish. Both claim they will be cleared.

The trial itself, which is the talk of the Las Vegas gambling world, may yet show that the death was just another spin of the roulette wheel for a city that had been hoping this century would change its image from that of godlessness to gentility.

fields.headline: Row over topless cancer posters
fields.standfirst: Mastectomy adverts taken down
fields.trailText: There are posters of near-naked Girls! Girls! Girls! informing tired businessmen of downtown nightclubs, and there are posters promising sexually explicit films. But it is another batch of posters with topless women that have so offended public decency that they have been removed from view round San Francisco: these ones warn of the risks of breast cancer.
fields.body:
There are posters of near-naked Girls! Girls! Girls! informing tired businessmen of downtown nightclubs, and there are posters promising sexually explicit films. But it is another batch of posters with topless women that have so offended public decency that they have been removed from view round San Francisco: these ones warn of the risks of breast cancer.

In an advertising campaign launched this month by the San Francisco-based Breast Cancer Fund, one poster headlined "It's no secret" shows a model in silky underwear - like that solde by Victoria's Secret - revealing a missing breast after a mastectomy. Another is a parody of a Cosmopolitan cover with the word Mastectomy inserted where the magazine's logo would be; the topless covergirl has had both breasts removed.

The posters have provoked such controversy that, in all but one of the areas displaying them, they have been taken down by authorities - such as transport - in control of poster sites. Only in Oakland can they still be seen.

"We will not run ads that anyone will find offensive," said the Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority. But Andrea Martin of the Breast Cancer Fund said: "This country is obsessed with breasts." Her group, founded eight years ago, was trying to use that obsession "to focus people's attention on the issue of detection of breast cancer".

The group had not sought to offend, she said, and was surprised at the hostility of some responses.

But the resulting publicity, it felt, might have ended up helping its cause and drawing people to the fund's website (www.breastcancerfund.org) to learn about diet and exercise techniques that would help to cut the risk.

The campaign was created by Ken Mandelbaum of the BBDO advertising agency. Models and the photographer also gave their services free.

In his weekend radio address to the nation, President Bill Clinton pledged $220m (£140m) over five years to pay for breast and cervical cancer treatment for lower-income women who are currently not being catered to. In the US about 180,000 women are diagnosed as having breast or cervical cancer each year.

"At a time when we know more about cancer than ever," said Mr Clinton, "we must not leave women to face cancer alone."

fields.headline: Rail tragedy
fields.standfirst: Holidaymakers die in German derailment
fields.trailText: An overnight express train filled with Alpine ski holidaymakers was racing far above the posted speed limit when it went off the tracks early yesterday south of Cologne, killing at least nine passengers and injuring almost 100, the authorities said.
fields.body:
An overnight express train filled with Alpine ski holidaymakers was racing far above the posted speed limit when it went off the tracks early yesterday south of Cologne, killing at least nine passengers and injuring almost 100, the authorities said.

One carriage flipped on to its side and another was crushed against a steel post as the train, travelling from Amsterdam to Basle, Switzerland, derailed shortly after midnight at a points switch, a German rail spokesman, Manfred Ziegerath, said.

The locomotive and several front carriages hurtled down an embankment and hit a house, police said. No one in the house was injured.

A police investigator, Winrich Granitzka, said that 16 Germans, four Americans and two Dutch passengers were unaccounted for, adding that they may have left the scene on their own. More bodies might be buried under carriages, police said.

The accident seems certain to revive questions about German rail safety. In June 1998 the derailment of an intercity express near Eschede killed 101 people, in Germany's worst train accident. The cause of the crash was a broken wheel.

Mr Granitzka said the train in yesterday's crash, carrying about 300 people, was travelling at 76 mph (122kmp) in a 25mph (40kmp) zone when it hit the points and derailed.

The driver was uninjured but was suffering from shock. Investigators said that they had found the train's speed recorder.

The train left Amsterdam at 8pm on Saturday and had barely pulled out of Cologne, heading south, when it derailed at the station of the small town of Brühl just after midnight.

Police said that at least nine people died and almost 100 were injured, 52 of them suffering serious injuries. Many passengers, who included Dutch, British, Japanese, Italians and Americans, were on their way to ski holidays in the Alps, officials said.

Just before Brühl, the express train had been switched on to a siding to avoid track maintenance work, Mr Ziegerath said. It derailed when it returned to the main line, he said.

fields.headline: Murder of Rwandan innocents
fields.trailText: Lieutenant Colonel Tharcisse Muvunyi is remembered in the city of Butare for one crime above all. On April 30 1994 - many of Rwanda's Tutsis had already been murdered and the hunt was under way for survivors of the genocide - the colonel allegedly sent his men to dispose of a group of witnesses.
fields.body:
Lieutenant Colonel Tharcisse Muvunyi is remembered in the city of Butare for one crime above all. On April 30 1994 - many of Rwanda's Tutsis had already been murdered and the hunt was under way for survivors of the genocide - the colonel allegedly sent his men to dispose of a group of witnesses.

They were 25 Tutsi children who had seen their parents murdered days earlier, after they sought sanctuary in a convent. Nuns hid the children in the convent in the hope that they would remain unnoticed.

But, it is alleged, Lt Col Muvunyi knew they were there. He sent one of his lieutenants, Idlefonse Hatiegimama, with a warrant to search the convent and take away the children. The soldiers arrived with members of the interahamwe, the notorious Hutu extremist militia, waving machetes.

The nuns tried to shield the children, but the killers worked their way through the building, pulling the victims from their hiding places.

The children were led out with promises of cake, forced to lie down in a lorry and driven into the forest. There they were butchered with machetes or shot. Their bodies were tipped into a mass grave.

The killing in Butare had been sparked 11 days earlier by President Theodore Sindikubwabo. The city had a history of good relations between Hutus and Tutsis and the president flew in to berate its political leaders for failing to follow the lead of other places, where Tutsis were being slaughtered systematically. The regional governor and police commander were dismissed. It was the signal for genocide to start.

The presidential guard arrived to start the killing, but it was allegedly left to the likes of Lt Col Muvunyi, an army commander for Butare and neighbouring Gikongoro, to keep up the momentum with the interahamwe and politicians.

Lt Col Muvunyi has claimed that he stopped massacres and saved Tutsis, but witnesses have linked him to a number of killings including a massacre at the hospital, where patients and doctors were killed.

The colonel also attended a meeting hosted by the prime minister of the genocidal regime, Jean Kambanda, at which it was decided to lure Tutsis from hiding with announcements that "order" had been restored. Mr Kambanda pleaded guilty to genocide at the international tribunal for Rwanda in 1998 and was sentenced to life imprisonment.

The international tribunal was apparently reluctant to consider Lt Col Muvunyi a candidate for trial because he was not deemed senior enough. It is unclear what caused its change of heart.

The colonel also attended a meeting hosted by the prime minister of the genocidal regime, Jean Kambanda, at which it was decided to lure Tutsis from hiding with announcements that "order" had been restored. Mr Kambanda pleaded guilty to genocide at the international tribunal for Rwanda in 1998 and was sentenced to life imprisonment. The international tribunal was apparently reluctant to consider Lt Col Muvunyi a candidate for trial because he was not deemed senior enough. It is unclear what caused its change of heart.

webTitle: Nato urged to join star wars shield

fields.headline: Nato urged to join star wars shield
fields.trailText: The United States is stepping up the pressure on its European allies to embrace its plans for a national anti-missile protective shield - dubbed the son of star wars - against "rogue" states and is urging them to develop a similar system of their own.
fields.body:
The United States is stepping up the pressure on its European allies to embrace its plans for a national anti-missile protective shield - dubbed the son of star wars - against "rogue" states and is urging them to develop a similar system of their own.

In his most enthusiastic backing yet for the project, William Cohen, the US defence secretary, yesterday made it clear at an international security conference in Munich that Washington would go ahead despite existing technical problems and opposition from Russia, China, Canada and most of its European allies, France and Germany in particular.

North Korea, Iraq, Iran and Libya "want long-range missiles to coerce and threaten us - the North American and European parts of Nato," he told the conference, which also exposed growing tensions between the allies on EU plans for closer security and defence cooperation.

"We project that in the next five to 10 years these rogue countries will be able to hold all of Nato at risk with their missile forces," Mr Cohen said.

Geoffrey Hoon, the British defence secretary said the US had yet to ask Britain to up date the early warning radar station at Fylingdales, in north Yorkshire, for the project.

He described that as "a complex issue" which would be "enormously expensive" - the US is committed to spending more than $2bn on testing the system alone.

However, Mr Hoon added: "We accept some countries of the world would not necessarily be intimidated by Britain's [present] ability to react" to rogue states.

General Leonid Ivashov, of the Russian army's central headquarters, suggested at the conference that the US project "looks more to me to be directed at China". This is even though China has far fewer missiles than Russia which could break through the proposed US missile shield.

Wang Guangya, China's deputy foreign minister, yesterday accused Washington of violating its "international legal obligations".

He told the Munich conference: "This move will undoubtedly inflict severe damage to global strategic balance and stability." It threatened to trigger a new arms race, Mr Wang warned.

China is also concerned that the US will use its planned anti-ballistic missile system to protect Taiwan, described by Mr Wang as "an inalienable part of Chinese territory".

webTitle: Hijacked Afghan jet lands in Moscow

fields.headline: Hijacked Afghan jet lands in Moscow
fields.trailText: A plane carrying 166 passengers on an internal flight in Afghanistan has been hijacked by fighters seeking the release of an Afghan warlord held by the ruling Taliban regime.
fields.body:
A plane carrying 166 passengers on an internal flight in Afghanistan has been hijacked by fighters seeking the release of an Afghan warlord held by the ruling Taliban regime.

Last night the plane landed at Moscow's Sheremetyevo-1 airport, the Russian emergencies ministry said.

The plane, belonging to Afghanistan's national carrier Ariana, earlier made brief stopovers at the Kazakh city of Aktyubinsk and the Uzbek capital Tashkent.

The Boeing 727 was hijacked soon after leaving Kabul airport at around 10am yesterday. Air traffic controllers lost contact with the Ariana plane minutes after it took off.

It failed to land in the northern city of Mazar-e-Sharif and headed to Tashkent, where 10 passengers were released. The plane was refuelled and flown to Aktyubinsk in Kazakhstan.

Last night it appeared that the hijackers were hoping to force the Taliban to release Ismail Khan, a commander in western Afghanistan who was captured by the militia in 1997.

However, Wakil Ahmed Muttawakil, the Taliban foreign minister, said the Afghan administration was unclear about the hijackers' demands. "When we hear exactly what they want, we will consider those demands."

The hijackers may have been inspired by Islamic extremists who in December seized an Indian Airlines plane flying from Kathmandu to New Delhi and flew it to Kandahar. India agreed to their demands in negotiations brokered by the Taliban and released three militants from jail.
