webTitle: Right to Rome  Italy bans the car for a day

fields.headline: Right to Rome  Italy bans the car for a day
fields.trailText: Disbelieving at first, Italians poured into city centres yesterday to inhale, taste and savour an unprecedented silence and stillness: life without the internal combustion engine.
fields.body:
Disbelieving at first, Italians poured into city centres yesterday to inhale, taste and savour an unprecedented silence and stillness: life without the internal combustion engine.

A national no-car day banished traffic from nearly 150 cities, allowing strollers, skaters, cyclists and horse riders to reclaim the cobblestones.

Rome, Florence, Milan and Naples coupled the ban with free or cheaper public transport in a bold effort to break a love affair with the car that shrouds cities in smog.

Museums and galleries were also made free yesterday to sweeten the pill for opponents.

Sunshine soothed the indignation of frustrated motorists as in Rome they joined throngs of tourists enjoying the absence of cacophony. Herds of pedestrians explored fountains, monuments and avenues that usually resemble a race track. Central Rome and Naples recorded sightings of joggers.

Hundreds of volunteers joined traffic police in enforcing the ban, which will be repeated on three more Sundays over the next three months. The cost of transgressing is £40. Yesterday's response encouraged those pressing for a permanent Sunday ban.

"A success!" said Edo Ronchi, the environment minister, as he strolled with his infant son through Piazza Venezia, eerily bereft of honking and screeching. For Scottish rugby fans digesting their defeat to Italy, it was the weekend's second shock.

A government honeypot of £300m encouraged regional capitals and dozens of smaller towns to sign up to the voluntary ban. It was proposed two decades ago but delayed by politicians fearful of provoking a car-addicted electorate. Italy has 32m vehicles for 57.5m people, one of the world's highest ratios.

Smog-related illnesses, including asthma and bronchitis attacks, kill more than 15,000 Italians and cost 16m working days each year, the World Health Organisation says.

During a trial day without cars last September eight cities recorded an average 35% drop in carbon monoxide levels.

Exemptions were made for taxis and those serving a useful social function, such as doctors.

Rome's ban lapsed at 6pm. On cue, hundreds of mopeds and cars emerged from sidestreets onto the avenues. Within 15 minutes it was business as usual.

fields.headline: German rail crash kills 9, injures 100
fields.trailText: At least nine people were killed and 100 injured yesterday when a train plunged off one of Europe's busiest railway routes and ploughed into a house near Cologne, Germany.
fields.body:
At least nine people were killed and 100 injured yesterday when a train plunged off one of Europe's busiest railway routes and ploughed into a house near Cologne, Germany.

Police said that the death toll could rise as rescue workers sifted through the wreckage of the train, which investigators said derailed after it broke the speed limit on a restricted section of the line.

The German government has announced an inquiry.

Eighteen hours after the accident in the early hours of Sunday, a handful of the most-severely injured were still fighting for their lives, while a further 22 people who were believed to be on the train were missing. They were listed as 16 German, four US and two Dutch citizens.

"We cannot rule out further deaths," a police spokesman, Winrich Granitzka, said in Brühl, scene of the accident 10 miles south of Cologne. He said workers using cranes and other heavy-duty machinery would continue searching for bodies.

Rail officials said the train, travelling from Amsterdam to Basle, Switzerland, with 300 passengers on board, was travelling at 75mph as it negotiated points intended to divert it past building work on the track just outside Brühl station. The speed limit for the diversion section was 25mph.

The crash was the worst in Germany since the Eschede disaster of 1998, the country's biggest post-war rail tragedy in which 101 people were killed.

The federal transport minister, Reinhard Klimmt, announced a "thorough and all-encompassing inquiry into the causes of this tragic accident".

Five carriages and the locomotive left the track just outside the station and two carriages then plummeted down an embankment into the house, landing in its living-room and front garden. The elderly couple living in the house were unharmed.

"We hit something hard and then the whole carriage flipped over," said a British passenger.

Rail officials said the train was not one of the high-speed inter-city express trains like the one in the Eschede crash, which smashed into a bridge after it developed a faulty wheel.

Police were waiting to question the 28-year-old German driver of the train, who survived the accident but was suffering from shock. The accident will raise further questions about safety on the German railways, the image of which had been hit by the Eschede tragedy.

Recordings taken by the train's "black box" showed the driver initially slowed in the run-up to the switch, but then accelerated to 75mph, the usual speed limit for the stretch without the diversion, officials said.

The Brühl accident is the latest in a series of recent serious rail crashes in Europe.

Nineteen people were killed in a blazing wreckage after two trains collided head-on in southern Norway last month. While, in October, two trains collided outside London's Paddington station, killing 31 people. Reuters

webTitle: Is it a bird? Is it a dinosaur? No, it's a fake

fields.headline: Is it a bird? Is it a dinosaur? No, it's a fake
fields.standfirst: It was a coup for National Geographic - the first pictures of a creature whose existence would turn the theory of bird evolution on its head. Then it was exposed as a hoax.  Julian Borger  on the missing link that never was
fields.trailText: Archaeoraptor first turned up in a hotel room in Tucson, Arizona. Stephen Czerkas, a dinosaur enthusiast who ran a small private museum, was wandering around a fossil fair when he heard that a Chinese dealer had something extraordinary.
fields.body:
Archaeoraptor first turned up in a hotel room in Tucson, Arizona. Stephen Czerkas, a dinosaur enthusiast who ran a small private museum, was wandering around a fossil fair when he heard that a Chinese dealer had something extraordinary.

When the dealer unwrapped a foot-long slab of rock, Czerkas experienced a paleontological epiphany. Embedded in the stone were the fossilised bones of an extraordinary prehistoric animal, with the complex limbs of a prototype bird and the distinctive tail of an earth-bound dromaeosaur, edged with the shadow of what seemed to be feathers. It looked like a dinosaur that could fly.

"It was stunning," Czerkas recalls. "I could see right away that it didn't belong on sale. It belonged in a museum."

He hastily contacted a patron who put up the $80,000 the dealer was asking for, and took his prize home in a state of high excitement, convinced he had discovered evidence of a pivotal moment in evolution.

That was last February. In the year since then, the dramatic rise and fall of Czerkas's new bird-dinosaur has been one of the strangest episodes in modern paleontology, and a scandal from which the science is still recovering.

After months of scrutiny involving x-rays and scans, Czerkas's bird dinosaur was proclaimed a new species, Archaeoraptor liaoningensis , by none other than the prestigious National Geographic journal. The magazine heralded the find as a crucial "missing link", representing conclusive proof that birds were the last living descendants of the dinosaurs.

But weeks later, archaeoraptor was unveiled as a hoax, wedged together with bits and pieces from at least two animals by canny Chinese farmers with a feel for what palaeontologists were looking for. It now appears to have been the dinosaur version of Piltdown Man, the notorious fossil hoax put together in Sussex in 1911 to provide the missing link between man and ape predicted by Charles Darwin.

Archaeoraptor's moment of truth came in December when a Chinese researcher, Xu Xing, visited Liaoning and found evidence that the creature's tail had been stolen from a land-bound dinosaur called a dromaeosaur.

National Geographic, having given archaeoraptor its name, was forced into a retraction, the most humiliating reversal anyone working on the journal can remember. To add salt to its wounds, the magazine was accused of handling a fossil which had been smuggled out of China.

Liaoning is a paleontologists' gold mine - a great expanse of powdery white siltstone deposited at the bottom of a lake 130m years ago. It is so dense it has preserved not only the bones of dinosaurs that died there but also some of their soft tissues.

In 1996, a Chinese team from the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology (IVPP) came across a fossil of a foot-long dinosaur the size of a hawk which they named sinornithosaurus (Chinese bird dinosaur). It had a wishbone and the tail of a theropod. But what caught their attention was a fossilised aura of downy hairs around the bones. The following year, another bird dinosaur was discovered, beipiaosaurus, an ungainly seven-foot theropod covered in two-inch-long feathers.

The Chinese discoveries were published in the scientific journal Nature and in National Geographic, revolutionising the perception of theropod dinosaurs. If Jurassic Park was remade now, National Geographic argued, even the T-rexes would have to have feathers.

Until that point, the most widespread theory was that birds evolved separately from and parallel to dinosaurs, from a common reptilian ancestor that roamed the earth over 250m years ago. These were small lizard-like animals that climbed trees and evolved feathers specifically for flight. A contradictory theory had emerged, according to which birds were direct descendants of larger, upright dinosaurs such as the velociraptors in the Spielberg film, but the Chinese fossils were the first real challenge to the orthodox view.

Furthermore, the Liaoning discoveries suggested that theropods had developed feathers for purposes like display or insulation, and only later did they become used for flight. Archaeoraptor seemed to be a telling milestone along that evolutionary journey. It actually had wings and big enough feathers to take off.

Archaeoraptor's downfall has energised a dwindling group of scientists who have stood by the traditional theory, that birds were more closely related to ancient gliding reptiles like pterodactyls, or even crocodiles.

They argue that the apparent "feathers" found on the Liaoning dinosaurs may be internal fibrous material, and they insist that the bone structure of the theropod claw is fundamentally different from a bird's wing.

Storrs Olson, an ornithological expert at Washington's Smithsonian Institution, has led the charge against the archaeoraptor. "National Geographic glorified this illicit specimen with their article," he thundered. "I told them they should close the exhibition and conduct their own investigation. They just stonewalled.

"They ignored all the contrary evidence and gave in to a campaign of propaganda. It is completely bogus. There is no such thing as a feathered dinosaur. It's like saying Elvis Presley is on the dark side of the moon."

Scientists on the other side of the debate insist that evidence for the bird-dinosaur link remains overwhelming, but concede that the archaeoraptor episode has been awkward. Henry Gee, a senior editor at Nature identified by Olson as the high priest of the bird-dinosaur "propaganda campaign", said: "The outfall has been extremely unfortunate. Of course, Piltdown man rears its ugly head. And it provides ammunition to a small and very vocal group of people who who are now starting to talk about collusion and conspiracy."

"That is absurd," Gee added. "But I do agree with Storson about one thing: that National Geographic has got itself badly burnt."

How National Geographic got itself into this mess is something its own staff are still trying to untangle. It seems to have got itself caught in the crack between its dual roles as a scientific journal and a popular magazine.

"It's a big disappointment, which hasn't happened since I've been here," Christopher Sloan, the senior assistant editor who wrote the ill-fated article, admitted. "We take a lot of pride in our work, and we go to great lengths to research every word and every picture."

Sloan went to see Czerkas and his bird-dinosaur last May and was sufficiently impressed for National Geographic to fund a study - led by Czerkas - of the find. The original idea was to publish the results in tandem with an academic journal like Nature or its competitor, Science, so that National Geographic would have academic cover.

A manuscript was sent to Henry Gee in London in September, but he was unimpressed. "This one looked like a real rush job," he said. "It seemed to be extremely amateurishly written. It didn't have any details of where it came from, or how old it was, which you would normally expect."

"Then something else occurred to me that was more disturbing. I thought it might have come out of China illegally, and the Chinese take a very dim view of that."

Gee sent the manuscript back, arguing that even if Nature were to appraise the specimen, there was no way it could do so in the timeframe National Geographic was suggesting. Science also turned down the manuscript after a peer review.

Meanwhile, rumours began to circulate that archaeoraptor was a fake. The tail was not joined to the rest of the body and the surrounding rock was cracked. Charlie Magovern, a fossil dealer and restorer, saw x-rays of archaeoraptor soon after it surfaced in Tucson and recalls: "I had a bad feeling about it. A lot of Chinese fossils are composited [from more than one specimen]. It's common practice in Liaoning, and they've become real craftsmen at putting these things together."

But the National Geographic study team, driven on by Czerkas's enthusiasm, were convinced. Xu Xing was sent out from Beijing by China's IVPP to see what was going on, but only arrived in time for National Geographic's triumphant press conference in October. By then, National Geographic had decided to go ahead with publication, even though the archaeoraptor had not been accepted by an academic journal. "The train had left the station and it was moving faster and faster," Sloan said ruefully.

The journal's editorial board grew concerned after Xu Xing, on returning to China, discovered that the tail had originally been found two yards from the body. "But nothing else had been found on that layer. It was still the most plausible theory that this was one animal. We had a meeting at National Geographic and felt reasonably confortable that would be end of it," Sloan said.

The fatal blow came on December 20, when an email from Xu Xing arrived. "After observing a new feathered dromaeosaur specimen in a private collection and comparing it with archaeoraptor, we concluded that archaeoraptor is a composite," Xu wrote. "Though I do not want to believe it, archaeoraptor appears to be composed of a dromaeosaur tail and a bird body."

The journal quickly published a statement to say that it was reevaluating archaeoraptor, but the damage had been done. As Sloan puts it: "Nine million kids already know about archaeoraptor."

Back in Utah, Czerkas remains confident that he might still be vindicated by a scientific comparison between the archaeoraptor and Xu Xing's dinosaur. "It's still possible that the tail is part of the archaeoraptor," he said. "And even if it does turn out it is a composite, it puts feathers on the tail of a dromaeosaur, so it still confirms that dinosaurs and birds are very closely related."

In an email from Beijing, however, Xu Xing said he was "100 per cent sure" that the tail belongs to a dinosaur, and not to Czerkas's bird, and complained that continued smuggling of Chinese fossils was wreaking irreparable damage on China's prehistoric legacy.

But one year on, at this year's Gem and Mineral Show in Tucson, there are just as many Chinese dealers roaming the corridors of the Ramada Inn Hotel with Liaoning fossils as there were when Stephen Czerkas first encountered archaeoraptor.

"I just saw a small bird with teeth in its skull and a tail. This one definitely has a tail," Charlie Magovern said on his cellphone. "I called to tell Chris Sloan about it, but he hasn't called back."

Storrs Olson, an ornithological expert at Washington's Smithsonian Institution, has led the charge against the archaeoraptor. "National Geographic glorified this illicit specimen with their article," he thundered. "I told them they should close the exhibition and conduct their own investigation. They just stonewalled. "They ignored all the contrary evidence and gave in to a campaign of propaganda. It is completely bogus. There is no such thing as a feathered dinosaur. It's like saying Elvis Presley is on the dark side of the moon." Scientists on the other side of the debate insist that evidence for the bird-dinosaur link remains overwhelming, but concede that the archaeoraptor episode has been awkward. Henry Gee, a senior editor at Nature identified by Olson as the high priest of the bird-dinosaur "propaganda campaign", said: "The outfall has been extremely unfortunate. Of course, Piltdown man rears its ugly head. And it provides ammunition to a small and very vocal group of people who who are now starting to talk about collusion and conspiracy." "That is absurd," Gee added. "But I do agree with Storson about one thing: that National Geographic has got itself badly burnt." How National Geographic got itself into this mess is something its own staff are still trying to untangle. It seems to have got itself caught in the crack between its dual roles as a scientific journal and a popular magazine. "It's a big disappointment, which hasn't happened since I've been here," Christopher Sloan, the senior assistant editor who wrote the ill-fated article, admitted. "We take a lot of pride in our work, and we go to great lengths to research every word and every picture." Sloan went to see Czerkas and his bird-dinosaur last May and was sufficiently impressed for National Geographic to fund a study - led by Czerkas - of the find. The original idea was to publish the results in tandem with an academic journal like Nature or its competitor, Science, so that National Geographic would have academic cover. A manuscript was sent to Henry Gee in London in September, but he was unimpressed. "This one looked like a real rush job," he said. "It seemed to be extremely amateurishly written. It didn't have any details of where it came from, or how old it was, which you would normally expect." "Then something else occurred to me that was more disturbing. I thought it might have come out of China illegally, and the Chinese take a very dim view of that." Gee sent the manuscript back, arguing that even if Nature were to appraise the specimen, there was no way it could do so in the timeframe National Geographic was suggesting. Science also turned down the manuscript after a peer review. Meanwhile, rumours began to circulate that archaeoraptor was a fake. The tail was not joined to the rest of the body and the surrounding rock was cracked. Charlie Magovern, a fossil dealer and restorer, saw x-rays of archaeoraptor soon after it surfaced in Tucson and recalls: "I had a bad feeling about it. A lot of Chinese fossils are composited [from more than one specimen]. It's common practice in Liaoning, and they've become real craftsmen at putting these things together." But the National Geographic study team, driven on by Czerkas's enthusiasm, were convinced. Xu Xing was sent out from Beijing by China's IVPP to see what was going on, but only arrived in time for National Geographic's triumphant press conference in October. By then, National Geographic had decided to go ahead with publication, even though the archaeoraptor had not been accepted by an academic journal. "The train had left the station and it was moving faster and faster," Sloan said ruefully. The journal's editorial board grew concerned after Xu Xing, on returning to China, discovered that the tail had originally been found two yards from the body. "But nothing else had been found on that layer. It was still the most plausible theory that this was one animal. We had a meeting at National Geographic and felt reasonably confortable that would be end of it," Sloan said. The fatal blow came on December 20, when an email from Xu Xing arrived. "After observing a new feathered dromaeosaur specimen in a private collection and comparing it with archaeoraptor, we concluded that archaeoraptor is a composite," Xu wrote. "Though I do not want to believe it, archaeoraptor appears to be composed of a dromaeosaur tail and a bird body." The journal quickly published a statement to say that it was reevaluating archaeoraptor, but the damage had been done. As Sloan puts it: "Nine million kids already know about archaeoraptor." Back in Utah, Czerkas remains confident that he might still be vindicated by a scientific comparison between the archaeoraptor and Xu Xing's dinosaur. "It's still possible that the tail is part of the archaeoraptor," he said. "And even if it does turn out it is a composite, it puts feathers on the tail of a dromaeosaur, so it still confirms that dinosaurs and birds are very closely related." In an email from Beijing, however, Xu Xing said he was "100 per cent sure" that the tail belongs to a dinosaur, and not to Czerkas's bird, and complained that continued smuggling of Chinese fossils was wreaking irreparable damage on China's prehistoric legacy. But one year on, at this year's Gem and Mineral Show in Tucson, there are just as many Chinese dealers roaming the corridors of the Ramada Inn Hotel with Liaoning fossils as there were when Stephen Czerkas first encountered archaeoraptor. "I just saw a small bird with teeth in its skull and a tail. This one definitely has a tail," Charlie Magovern said on his cellphone. "I called to tell Chris Sloan about it, but he hasn't called back."

fields.headline:
No: 1571
 Aden
fields.trailText: Breed: Five-year-old German shepherd.
fields.body:
Breed: Five-year-old German shepherd.

Status: The Mike Tyson of the dog world.

Does he hang with a pack of intimidating minders? No, just his owner Trevor Ireland, 79, who is blind.

OK. So he's a mean fighter with a habit of biting off opponents' ears and an unpleasant attitude towards females, then? Unfortunately, Aden's fighting prowess is not recorded. As a registered guide dog, he's likely to be a docile little fella, but, like Mike, he has found an interesting way round the immigration laws.

Worth a few bob is he? You don't need to be earning mega-bucks to get into Britain by the back door. Big brown eyes and a moving story will also do.

Moving story? Ireland became blind when he was badly wounded in the Normandy landings in 1944, but because of Britain's quarantine laws he has never been able to visit his comrades' graves with his guide dog. Until now. The ministry of agriculture has given Aden special licence to escape detention when he returns to Britain tomorrow, three weeks before the "passports for pets" scheme officially launches.

Aha! Rabid dog sneaks into Britain: I see the Tyson link now! Look, neither of them has rabies - at least, Aden doesn't. A ministry of agriculture spokesman was anxious to stress that the dog has been fully inoculated and tested, and fitted with a monitoring microchip. He is being allowed in early only because of "exceptional circumstances".

Well, I must say, it is heartwarming to see a listening government in action. It took a lot of listening. Mr Ireland has been lobbying the department for the past five years.

Do say: Aaah, isn't he cute, diddle fluffy-wuffy doggie.

Don't say: Odd how dogs and cats can walk straight into the country while political refugees get put in detention centres.

Not to be confused with: Shep, Zola Budd.

fields.trailText: "Political pie throwing has a long history," we wrote in a much-quoted item, page 5, February 3. But for Belgian surrealist Noel Godin to have pied Marilyn Monroe in 1973 would have been some feat. She had been dead since 1962.
fields.body:
"Political pie throwing has a long history," we wrote in a much-quoted item, page 5, February 3. But for Belgian surrealist Noel Godin to have pied Marilyn Monroe in 1973 would have been some feat. She had been dead since 1962.

A phrase in Online, page 12, February 3, seemed to place Beowulf in the 11th century. The epic poem is held to be an 8th-century composition, or even earlier.

Jeeves was born discreetly in a story entitled Extricating Gussie in PG Wodehouse's 1917 collection The Man with Two Left Feet. G2 Pass notes, February 3, mistook the book title for the specific story.

An article mentioning the 1827 lighthouse on the North Sea island of Buchaness, Page 11, January 29, attributed the engineering design to Robert Stephenson. But it was Robert Stevenson, grandfather of Robert Louis Stevenson, who was engineer to the Northern Lighthouse Board.

An obituary of actress Frances Drake, page 20, January 31, recapped her role opposite Peter Lorre in the 1935 horror classic Mad Love, where - obsessed by this beautiful woman - Lorre's crazed Dr Gogol grafts the hands of a murderer on to Drake's injured pianist husband. The film was issued in Britain as The Hands of Orlac and that, not "Orloff" as we gave it, was the husband's name. (A reader adds that a particularly exquisite still of Frances Drake from this movie was reprinted in Pleasure Dome, Graham Greene's 1935-40 collected film criticism.)

fields.headline: Green defends family honour
fields.standfirst: Wife's purchase of M&S shares under scrutiny
fields.trailText: Retail entrepreneur Philip Green last night insisted he and his wife Christina had not broken any City rules when she bought almost £25m worth of Marks & Spencer shares days before their value soared on the announcement that he might bid for the beleaguered store group.
fields.body:
Retail entrepreneur Philip Green last night insisted he and his wife Christina had not broken any City rules when she bought almost £25m worth of Marks & Spencer shares days before their value soared on the announcement that he might bid for the beleaguered store group.

The Monaco-based businessman said he and his advisers, led by US investment bank Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette, will issue a formal statement to that effect this morning.

Mr Green said he hoped to accompany it with written confirmation from the takeover panel stating that it had approved the dealings, which have netted his wife a paper profit of about £2m.

However, Marks & Spencer is expected to pass details of the share buying to the stock exchange, which investigates unusual transactions. The regulator is likely to press Mr Green, his advisers and the takeover panel for evidence that the dealings were cleared in advance. A Marks & Spencer official said last night: "We are keen to seek clarity on this matter."

Mr Green has confirmed in writing to Marks & Spencer that his wife bought 9.5m shares between December 7 and December 9 last year through a number of nominee companies, which had kept her identity a secret on the retailer's share register.

On December 13 the shares leapt in value when Mr Green was forced by watchdogs to announce that he was considering a bid for the firm.

Mr Green said he told the takeover panel that his wife was buying "in concert", meaning that if Mr Green ultimately decided to launch a bid for Marks & Spencer she would be deemed to be supporting his takeover attempt. It is not uncommon for individuals or companies to buy shares in concert with any potential bidder for a company.

"It was made perfectly clear to the takeover panel and my advisers that my wife has always been part of the concert party," Mr Green said. "It is pretty evident that is the case and I want to get this confusion resolved as soon as possible. Anyone who says she was not acting in concert is trying to make mischief."

However, Mr Green's letter to Marks & Spencer, written by his lawyers and declaring his wife's shareholdings, says that she is the sole beneficiary of the shares.

The confusion surrounding Mrs Green's shareholding is likely to intensify pressure on Mr Green to make a formal bid for the retailer or abandon his plans. The takeover panel generally gives a potential bidder eight weeks to confirm a bid or not. On the basis that Mr Green made his first announcement on December 13 his deadline expires this week.

Marks & Spencer's new chairman Luc Vandvelde has said that he believes current management can create more value than a takeover. Mr Green refused to comment on whether he will bid or not saying only "we have to get this rubbish cleared up and then we'll go to stage two".

The City is growing sceptical that Mr Green will actually launch a bid for Marks & Spencer, which is valued at £8bn. However, his City image was considerably improved last year when he successfully launched a hostile £550m takeover and break-up of Sears. The offer document for that deal revealed his wife had 1.8m shares in Sears and was backing his bid.

fields.headline: GMB buys into active investment
fields.trailText: The GMB union will become the first trade union in the world to invest in an activist fund manager. About 10% of the £180m fund managed by the UK pension fund is to be invested in Hermes Focus, managed by Hermes Lens.
fields.body:
The GMB union will become the first trade union in the world to invest in an activist fund manager. About 10% of the £180m fund managed by the UK pension fund is to be invested in Hermes Focus, managed by Hermes Lens.

Focus funds push for improvements at underperforming companies. The fund's first public victim was David Montgomery, who was ousted as chief executive of Mirror Group after complaints from shareholders led by Hermes.

The fund has also pushed for changes at BTR, the engineering group, and GRE, the insurance company. Peter Butler, chief executive of Hermes Lens, welcomed the £18m investment from the GMB.

"We believe that the GMB is the first union in the world to invest in an activist pension funds and we hope that others follow their lead," he said.

Unions manage a significant proportion of the UK's pension funds. However, the investment raises interesting questions for union pension funds as activist shareholders can demand job cuts or divestments.

Mr Butler said yesterday that Hermes' desire to enhance shareholder value did not conflict with the goals of the GMB pension fund.

"Our whole approach is about long-term value. We are not about a quick fix," he said.

webTitle: Royal Ordnance to sell Heckler & Koch

fields.headline: Royal Ordnance to sell Heckler & Koch
fields.trailText: Royal Ordnance is planning to sell gun-maker Heckler & Koch to its equally renowned American rival Colt by the end of this month, industry sources said last night.
fields.body:
Royal Ordnance is planning to sell gun-maker Heckler & Koch to its equally renowned American rival Colt by the end of this month, industry sources said last night.

RO, owned by BAE Systems, sees the proposed sale as an integral part of a shake-up that has seen the loss-making business that faced closure last year transformed into Europe's would-be leading player in "smart" munitions.

The company, run by managing director Clive Richardson, is understood to have received a letter of intent to buy Heckler from Zilkha Assets, the main shareholder in Colt Manufacturing.

Heckler, based in Oberndorf, Germany, makes pistols, assault rifles, sub-machine guns and grenade launchers as well as sporting guns and is seen as a non-core business within the new RO.

With a turnover of some £90m a year and staff of about 700, it is seen as a good fit for Colt which is famous for the handguns that have featured in virtually every Hollywood western.

Industry sources refused to disclose the sum being negotiated, though it is understood that RO is hoping to raise the book value of Heckler, acquired from the receivers in 1991 for a nominal sum.

The proposed deal coincides with the incorporation of the old Marconi Land and Naval Systems (LANS), acquired with the £8bn merger of BAe with GEC's defence arm last year, into the 440-year-old RO.

The new entity, which has yet to be given a name, will employ 4,500 (before the Heckler sale), have sales of about £400m a year, enjoy an order book of £1bn and, sources said, be healthily profitable.

LANS makes armaments, including the AS90 Braveheart self-propelled howitzer for combat ships, and is based in Barrow and Leicester.

webTitle: Heavy duty:  Drax power station gets 540-tonne refit

fields.headline: Heavy duty:  Drax power station gets 540-tonne refit
fields.trailText: A 540-tonne electrical transformer, above, is on its way from Scotland to the Drax power station in north Yorkshire.
fields.body:
A 540-tonne electrical transformer, above, is on its way from Scotland to the Drax power station in north Yorkshire.

The transformer, which is so large that it had to be dismantled and transported in three trips from ScottishPower's Inverkip power station, has been bought by Drax's owners AES as part of a multi-million pound project to replace equipment damaged in a fire last December.

Inverkip stopped generating electricity in the late 1980s after fuel prices rose to levels which made its uneconomic to run.

However, it still has two generating units and retains its role as a strategic reserve. The installation of the Inverkip transformer will allow Drax - the largest coal fired plant in Europe - to return to normal running capacity by the beginning of April.

fields.headline: Economics made easy
fields.trailText: Have taxes gone up under Labour?
fields.body:
Have taxes gone up under Labour?

In opposition Labour grabbed headlines with its pledge not to raise income tax. In government it has actually lowered income tax - the starting rate has been halved to 10p, and the basic rate is set to fall from 23p to 22p in April. But other taxes have gone up - excise duty and some tax reliefs have been scrapped.

Are these the chancellor's so-called stealth taxes?

Tories point to figures which show that the overall proportion of the national cake eaten up by taxes rose in Labour's first two years. It is a bit unfair though, because many of the tax rises in the early years of the parliament were actually left over from the Tories' last budget.

Is a higher tax burden economically harmful?

It means we have less choice about how we spend our money. The Adam Smith Institute celebrates tax freedom day each year - the day when we stop working for the government and start working for ourselves. This year it is May 27, and the institute calculates it is two days later as a result of tax rises since the election.

Could a party win an election calling for higher taxes?

Surveys consistently show that people are prepared to pay more taxes to improve public services such as health and education. The problem is, politicians do not believe them. Labour strategists are convinced that they lost the 1992 election because the public did not want higher taxes - whatever they say to the pollsters.

fields.headline: Trade debate diverted via Seattle
fields.trailText: For 40 years after the second world war, trade was left to the experts. It was all about tariffs, quota restrictions and export subsidies. When negotiators finally completed years of monastic endeavour, they produced documents of Proustian length only those initiated into the arcane language of trade could comprehend.
fields.body:
For 40 years after the second world war, trade was left to the experts. It was all about tariffs, quota restrictions and export subsidies. When negotiators finally completed years of monastic endeavour, they produced documents of Proustian length only those initiated into the arcane language of trade could comprehend.

Important though it was, trade was dull, dull, dull. Neither the press nor the public gave it a second thought. Seattle has changed all that. Trade is now a sexy issue - for one simple reason: it has stopped being about goods and started being about people.

While voters found it hard to get worked up about the precise details of the multifibre agreement, they care deeply about the new issues at the heart of trade negotiations - labour standards, the environment and the food they eat. In the context of the role of labour in the new global economy, the groundswell of opposition to what has been happening in Austria looks at first sight like a promising development.

The big gap at the heart of the globalisation project has always been that the increasing liberalisation of controls on capital have been accompanied by ever-more draconian curbs on the mobility of labour, of which the views expressed by Jörg Haider on immigration are merely one example.

In reality, the opposition to Mr Haider is somewhat synthetic. The French and German interior ministers agreed recently to push for Europe-wide harmonisation on the expulsion of immigrants under the forthcoming French presidency; developing countries have had to agree to take back illegal immigrants from the EU as the price of securing preferential access to Fortress Europe.

Moreover, discussions are at an advanced stage between Brussels and Beijing to secure the access of China to the World Trade Organisation, even though China is run by real fascists rather than bargain-basement Oswald Mosleys.

However, there are two lessons to be learned from the brouhaha of the past week, one specific, one general.

The first concerns immigration, where the EU should be encouraging liberalisation. If globalisation is to mean anything, it has to give rights of mobility to labour as well as goods and money. As one contributor to this page put it recently, when it comes to travelling around the world unencumbered, you are better off as a tin of baked beans than as a human being.

What is especially pernicious about this state of affairs is that labour bears the costs of adjustment in periods of global turbulence caused by uncontrolled flows of capital. Former World Bank economist Joseph Stiglitz put it well a couple of weeks ago when he said that in east Asia: "Workers were asked to listen to sermons about 'bearing pain' just a short while after hearing, from the same preachers, sermons about how globalisation and opening up capital markets would bring them unprecedented growth."

In the new world order capital can get out fast in times of trouble, but labour is stuck where it is. Any attempts by the global market for labour to put itself back into equilibrium are thwarted by border controls.

Labour constraints

From any standpoint - moral, historical or theoretical - the restrictions on labour are wrong. One of America's great strengths has been its willingness to open its frontiers to migrants and asylum seekers. According to Javier Ortega in the latest Economic Journal, immigration both reduces unemployment and increases wages.

What happens, Mr Ortega says, is that when immigrants arrive, firms create new jobs because hiring a worker becomes cheaper. As a result natives obtain jobs more easily since more are available. At the same time they can obtain higher wages from firms since during wage negotiations the higher availability of jobs makes competition for workers that much tougher. Europe has a specific problem of a declining population of working age trying to finance a generous welfare system. It desperately needs the workers developing countries can provide.

The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, reflecting the drift to the left, is revising its guidelines for multinationals, many of which are already showing a willingess to submit themselves to social audits.

More farsighted corporations have already worked out that acting unethically can hit them where it hurts - at the bottom line.

John Evans, head of the trade union advisory committee at the OECD, says that it is already a different world from that of the mid-1990s. Consumers are showing an increased willingness to boycott products from companies exploiting workforces or trashing the environment; trade unions are exploring ways of using their muscle on pension funds to ensure that funds accumulated by workers are invested in ethical funds. What unions would like more than anything else is a recognition that there should be a set of agreed global labour standards ultimately backed by threat of sanctions.

Arousing hostility

The problem with this is that any mention of labour rights arouses the hostility of developing countries, who sense back door protectionism, an attempt to impose a world minimum wage that would erode the competitive advantage of developing nations.

This threatens to become a sterlile debate but there are ways to make progress. Writing in American Prospect recently, the economist Dani Rodrik made two interesting points. The first is that trade is a means and not an end in itself, it is a way of achieving the things that make life worth living - freedom, stability, prosperity, eradication of poverty, a cleaner environment.

Mr Rodrik's second point is that non-democratic countries cannot count on the same trade privileges as democratic ones. In the case of trade and labour standards, poor countries argue they cannot afford to have the same standards as in democratic countries, and that if they were forced to abide by the same conditions it would result in fewer jobs and greater poverty. This is undoubtedly true, and a country like India can rightly claim its labour standards and environmental regime reflect the wishes of the world's biggest democracy.

But, says Mr Rodrik, non-democratic countries such as China "do not pass the same prima facie test, and exports of non-democratic countries deserve greater international scrutiny, particularly when they entail costly dislocations in other countries".

This goes to the heart of the new trade agenda, which is as much to do with workers' rights and human rights as with schedules of preferences. Is it right that US textiles workers should lose their jobs because Bangladeshi workers can make shirts more cheaply? The answer is probably yes. Is it right the same workers should lose their jobs because of imports from countries where there are no unions and the trappings of a police state? The answer should be a resounding no.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

America Online, the American internet company, is negotiating to buy German media combine Bertelsmann 's 50% stake in AOL Europe, the internet service provider which has 2.8m customers in nine countries. Sources in Germany said the talks were understood to have been taking place for several days. Analysts believe Bertelsmann's stake in the five-year-old joint venture could be worth up to $7bn (£4.4bn).

Vodafone AirTouch is close to following its historic merger with German group Mannesmann with a majority holding in Airtel of Spain - a vital piece in its pan-European jigsaw. That would be another setback for British Telecommunications , which wants to increase its stake in Spain's second largest mobile phone operator.

British Energy and Npower lead the £370m race to buy north western electricity supply business Norweb from United Utilities.

Sunday Times

British Telecommunications is planning the most radical restructuring since privatisation. The revamp will pave the way for the partial flotation of its high-growth divisions.

The Bank of England is set to increase base interest rates by a quarter point from 5.75% to 6% this week amid evidence that consumer demand and the housing market remain strong.

DaimlerChrysler's courtship of Fiat could be interrupted by the arrival of a former suitor of the Italian industrial group. Ford, which held extensive talks with Fiat more than a decade ago, is believed to be tracking the progress of the Fiat-Daimler talks and could intervene to head off a deal. Italian experts believe Daimler is negotiating to take a majority stake in Fiat Auto, the group's car making arm.

S

elegraph

British Energy, the nuclear electricity group, has approached United Utilities with a view to buying all or parts of the multi-utility group. United has become the focus of takeover speculation in recent months as the City anticipates the next round of industry rationalisation. United is capitalised at about £3bn.

The Bank of Scotland is to launch a mobile telephone banking service for its 3m customers with BT Cellnet, Britain's second largest mobile phone network operator. BoS is about to enter the final stages of its hostile bid for National Westminster Bank.

Bradford & Bingley, the building society, is understood to be lining up a big acquisition in an attempt to head off a delay in its plans to float on the London stock exchange this autumn.

Business

NTT DoCoMo, the Japanese telecommunications company is considering a $35bn (£22bn) bid for Orange, the British-based mobile phone operator which is to be demerged from Mannesmann following the takeover of the German company by Vodafone AirTouch last week. Orange's chief executive Hans Snook said recently that the firm was "looking forward" to returning to the market as an independent company.

Car company Ford is planning to sell new cars 5% cheaper than advertised prices over the internet across its entire model range in Britain in time for the British Motor Show in October. Britain is to be the first region of Europe to adopt the scheme which will enable consumers to make a typical saving of about £1,000 from the list price of a Mondeo.

Mail on Sunday

The European Union has launched an investigation into the world's two most powerful art auction houses, Christie's and Sotheby's over alleged commission fixing. The companies are already under investigation by the US justice department. And in London the office of fair trading has also begun a preliminary inquiry.

fields.headline: The nice package
fields.trailText: The final of the 1989 Cardiff Singer of the World was an event that made musical history and lingers in the memory. It was a controversial affair that confounded expectations and changed for ever the life of Dmitri Hvorostovsky, a 26-year-old baritone from Krasnoyarsk in Siberia, whose sexy voice, flawless technique and subtlety took everyone by surprise.
fields.body:
The final of the 1989 Cardiff Singer of the World was an event that made musical history and lingers in the memory. It was a controversial affair that confounded expectations and changed for ever the life of Dmitri Hvorostovsky, a 26-year-old baritone from Krasnoyarsk in Siberia, whose sexy voice, flawless technique and subtlety took everyone by surprise.

Many assumed the prize would go to Bryn Terfel. In the BBC commentary box, an element of chaos broke out: Hvorostovsky looks as good as he sounds, and the announcers were soon engaged in an uncommon display of ecstatic bawdry. "He's a nice package," said one. "Oh, definitely," sighed another. The "nice package" subsequently became one of the world's finest and most popular singers.

Fame came as a shock. He visited London after his victory, and recalls how "people kept coming up to me in the street". His voice is still tremulous with amazement more than 10 years after the event. "Everyone knew who I was. Suddenly I had a fan club. They used to send me presents, food and clothing, thinking I was poor, which wasn't far from the truth."

A media frenzy greeted him on his return to the Soviet Union. "They took the title of the competition literally. I was billed as The Greatest Singer in the World. They gave me an enormous apartment in Moscow. I could do anything - sing anything I wanted, anywhere.

"Two weeks ago," he continues, suddenly changing tack, "I went back to Siberia to see my mother and father and my grandma. I go back whenever I have a gap in my schedule - I need to from time to time. Over there, they still play the Cardiff tape. When I see it, I no longer recognise myself."

A certain ambivalence characterises Hvorostovsky's attitude to both his stardom and his glamour. We meet at the Savoy, where he makes one of his head-turning entrances, looking impeccably Byronic with his famous silver hair flowing over the collar of his black leather jacket, conscious of the scrutiny that his appearance inevitably causes. In the quiet of the reading room, however, he perceptibly relaxes, flings himself onto a sofa with an air of laddish raffishness, took a packet of Marlboro Lights from his pocket and lights up. I express astonishment that he smokes. "Many singers do," he remarks, shrugging his shoulders. "Most hide it. I don't bother."

Restlessly itinerant ("I've been everywhere except Africa"), Hvorostovsky is back in the UK for a concert at the Barbican. He's a tremendous recitalist, larger than life, sometimes overpowering, yet with an uncanny ability to communicate the shocking emotional intimacy of music to each listener individually. His performances inspire the curious sensation that the audience has been blotted out and you're alone with this hunk who's pouring out his private thoughts. His London audience could be in for a roller-coaster ride, for his programme - "a killer" he calls it - includes Mahler's harrowing Kindertotenlieder and Shostakovich's Suite on Verses of Michelangelo. The latter, incredibly taxing, are new to his repertoire. He shakes his head when I ask him whether he thinks that the songs constituted a covert protest on Shostakovich's part against the Soviet regime. "I don't see that," he says. "Shostakovich was a pure musician, a pure genius. The songs are about Italy, about the world of Michelangelo and Dante. They're very lyrical, restrained, very ascetic".

"Ascetic" is not a word one would expect from a man who has a reputation as a sex symbol, and who, shortly after his Cardiff triumph, caused an almighty controversy by releasing an erotic video to a track from his album of Russian songs. Squeezed into skin-tight leather pants, he soulfully intoned Tchaikovsky while camisole-clad Lolitas struck suggestive poses and couples twined in soft focus around him. "It was very sensual," he says. At the time, he also had a reputation for stand-offishness; now 37, he admits he has changed. "I was young and stupid," he says, "very stubborn. I'd always been assured I was the best, but when I listened to other singers I began to doubt myself. As I get older, I doubt myself more and more, but it's doubt that makes you change, makes you strive, makes you do things differently."

Perhaps the most remarkable thing about Hvorostovsky's career is that it nearly didn't happen at all. As a child, he had everything. His parents, of whom he speaks with tremendous affection, were anxiously supportive. The Soviet system fostered his talent (he began his musical training as a pianist). Yet there was one problem. "I was painfully shy," he admits, "then I had a breakdown." His choice of word is a tad unfortunate: what actually happened was that Hvorostovsky, in a moment of flaming teenage rebellion, junked classical music for rock.

"My father was horrified," he says. "I did keyboard and vocals in a band. It was hard rock, very Deep Purple. I liked Queen too: I used to do Freddie Mercury numbers." He and a friend started work on a rock opera based on Poe's Ligeia, a tale about a supernatural sexual being. "We never finished it," he says, "but we used to do numbers from it in discos."

After two years he'd had enough of headbanging, but he was stronger for the experience: his shyness was replaced by self-assurance; and he knew that he had a glorious voice. I ask him if he's ever contemplated "crossover". "I've been asked to," he says, "but what really interests me is film. Perhaps that's one way forward."

He's just finished his first movie, Leporello, directed by Barbara Willis Sweete. It's a take on Mozart's Don Giovanni: Leporello - who always envies the Don's philandering - is reincarnated as a Hollywood producer, and casts himself as his master in his own movie of Giovanni's life. Hvorostovsky, tellingly perhaps, plays both roles - the sexual icon and the man who creates and recreates him. "I haven't seen the finished film," he says, "but the rushes look good. I don't know what people will make of it, but Mozart's unique. He's like Shakespeare. Each era has to recast him in its own image."

Later, I realise I haven't asked what drew him to Ligeia. I read the story again and wallow in the atmosphere of decadence and transgression that could open vistas of new experience to a teenager. Yet what is also striking is Poe's vision of his central character as a free spirit who communicates "the eager vehemence of a desire for life" in "the thrilling and enthralling eloquence" of music rather than speech. Whether those words marked Hvorostovsky all those years ago in Siberia is something we shall never know - yet they remain an apt summary of this remarkable man and his achievement.

Dmitri Hvorostovsky's recital is at the Barbican, London EC2 (0171-638 8891), on Thursday.

He's just finished his first movie, Leporello, directed by Barbara Willis Sweete. It's a take on Mozart's Don Giovanni: Leporello - who always envies the Don's philandering - is reincarnated as a Hollywood producer, and casts himself as his master in his own movie of Giovanni's life. Hvorostovsky, tellingly perhaps, plays both roles - the sexual icon and the man who creates and recreates him. "I haven't seen the finished film," he says, "but the rushes look good. I don't know what people will make of it, but Mozart's unique. He's like Shakespeare. Each era has to recast him in its own image." Later, I realise I haven't asked what drew him to Ligeia. I read the story again and wallow in the atmosphere of decadence and transgression that could open vistas of new experience to a teenager. Yet what is also striking is Poe's vision of his central character as a free spirit who communicates "the eager vehemence of a desire for life" in "the thrilling and enthralling eloquence" of music rather than speech. Whether those words marked Hvorostovsky all those years ago in Siberia is something we shall never know - yet they remain an apt summary of this remarkable man and his achievement. Dmitri Hvorostovsky's recital is at the Barbican, London EC2 (0171-638 8891), on Thursday.

fields.headline: Fuelling debate
fields.standfirst: Nuclear power is still in its infancy but the industry will progress only if the public is convinced by its safety and reliability
fields.trailText: The nuclear industry is still youthful, hardly more than 30 years old. In the early 70s, it provided 2% of worldwide demand for electricity but in the 80s, after the first oil shock, it grew dramatically; today it provides 17%. Technologically, too, nuclear power is young. And organisationally: in most countries, the industry has not yet uncoupled itself from the state.
fields.body:
The nuclear industry is still youthful, hardly more than 30 years old. In the early 70s, it provided 2% of worldwide demand for electricity but in the 80s, after the first oil shock, it grew dramatically; today it provides 17%. Technologically, too, nuclear power is young. And organisationally: in most countries, the industry has not yet uncoupled itself from the state.

Recent World Energy Council conferences have highlighted the industry's problems: politics, short-termism in investment decisions and strong competition from gas and combined power producers. Energy demands are changing in today's information economy. Half the annual increase in demand for electricity comes from extra numbers of microprocessors - in supplying them, reliability and quality become key factors. Energy markets are being liberalised. In the UK nuclear power is on its way to becoming a "normal business" - though reduced gas prices mean the competitiveness of any new nuclear plant could not be guaranteed. Finland, however, which depends on a single source of natural gas, is thinking of building a fully commercial, unsubsidised nuclear power station.

Nuclear has recently stagnated (except in Japan, India, China, South Korea and France) but the industry is now asking how it might again raise its share of world energy production. WEC studies of market liberalisation are favourable. Some long-run projections - the chart, covering 100 years is based on the installation of a new generation of safe, small reactors - can be very favourable indeed. In some markets, the life of reactors will simply be extended, say in Finland and Sweden. In Asia new reactors will be built. In the longer run electorates and governments in Europe, Africa and North America will vote to build new reactors to meet growing needs for clean energy.

Of course attitudes within the industry itself present obstacles. Managers still hesitate to cut the umbilical cord to the state; they do not see liberalisation and privatisation as opportunities. Others simply want to survive nuclear's ice age in North America and Europe, extending the lives of existing reactors. Yet others believe there are short-run technical fixes, leading to reduced costs, better security and small, intelligent reactors. Here the nuclear industry is split, small vs big reactors, intelligent vs traditional design. The battle plays into the hands of those who give nuclear power no chance.

Some industry leaders believe they have the edge in delivering carbon dioxide (CO2)-free energy. That is naive for it ignores new technologies using cleaner fossil fuels which will secure their place in the 21st century's energy economy.

Yet our studies of world demand conclude that nuclear energy will play an essential role in electricity production and strategies against global warming. Unfortunately, the nuclear industry has stood aside from the global energy debate. Demand will grow. Nuclear has powerful potential in preparing for future reductions in CO2 emissions. Compared with a coal-fired station, a nuclear plant with equivalent electricity output can save 7m tonnes of CO2 a year; it produces 20 tonnes of nuclear waste most of which can be recycled. Europe produces a third of its electricity from nuclear and so saves as much CO2 as all of Europe's traffic now generates.

The emancipation of Europe from nuclear energy, even if it were theoretically possible, would have consequences which have not been thought through. A 1,000 Megawatt nuclear plant occupies 2sq km of land, while a solar park with the same output needs 30sq km, a wind park 100 and the comparable biomass (eg forest) would take up 5,000sq km.

The Kyoto summit on climate change did not give nuclear a free pass to the future. Instead, the nuclear industry can profit from the growing sovereignty of electricity consumers. It has the long-term potential to compete as a cost effective energy source. If the burden of high initial investment can be reduced, its advantageous lower running costs would show through - as they have done lately in the US, even against natural gas.

There is a lot to be done in developing reactors and fuel cycles but production costs of 2.5 to 3 cents per kilowatt hour, including all storage and future building costs, are reachable. By cutting building times to four years and increasing output, new reactors can become competitive in the new, liberalised energy market.

Existing reactors have been overwhelmingly accepted by the populations around them. That is not enough. Public assent depends on progress, on how waste is to be stored, even when from a technical point of view there are no pressing problems. The industry needs patiently and persistently to show its safety, reliability and credibility.

Here government can play an active role, enlightening society about nuclear waste but also about fossil waste, CO2 and other emissions. Electricity consumers who have the choice must start comparing the risks of all technologies, one with another. Politicians should initiate debate, assist poorer countries whose reactors are unsafe and ensure a level playing field in the energy market. But the nuclear industry has to become responsible for itself, more transparent, independent - and able to show through its long-term calculations of economic and safety performance that it can survive in the marketplace.

 Gerald Doucet is secretary general of the World Energy Council

fields.headline: Having it both ways
fields.standfirst:
The Pleasure Man
Citizens' Theatre, Glasgow
***
fields.trailText: WC Fields dubbed Mae West "a plumber's idea of Cleopatra". But she was also a substantial writer whose plays fell foul of the law. Unrevived until now, The Pleasure Man is a ramshackle backstage comedy drama that underscores West's gift for lewd innuendo, gay sympathies and old-fashioned morality.
fields.body:
WC Fields dubbed Mae West "a plumber's idea of Cleopatra". But she was also a substantial writer whose plays fell foul of the law. In 1926 Sex led to an obscenity trial and two years later The Pleasure Man was raided by the cops during its second performance. Unrevived until now, it's a ramshackle backstage comedy drama that underscores West's gift for lewd innuendo, gay sympathies and old-fashioned morality.

Set largely in a midwest vaudeville theatre, the play focuses on a lecherous headliner. He's having an affair with a married dancer, chats up all the hoofers and, when he spurns a local girl whose baby has been aborted, finds himself castrated by her brother.

What is revealing is West's hatred of hetero Don Juans and her love of the raffish side of showbiz. But, though West's heart was in the right place, her art was all over the shop: she had a talent for one-liners but little sense of structure.

My only complaint is that Stewart Laing's exuberant revival sacrifices too many of West's zingers to backstage atmosphere. But there are strong performances from Jason Merrells as the heartless crooner, Adrian Howells as a female impersonator and Tam Dean Burn as both the Scottish theatre manager and a befrocked camp follower. Gaudily watchable, the play is worth reviving as an historic curiosity that explains why West is both a gay and feminist icon.

Until February 26. Box office: 0141-429 0022

fields.headline: Look back in anger
fields.standfirst: From road to office  - Judi James looks at rages through the ages
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: From road to office - Judi James looks at rages through the ages.
fields.body:
Is it possible to suffer undue stress and angst caused by all the new rages that currently seem to be on offer in and around the workplace? Can I put my name to being the first person to identify the phenomenon of rage rage? This is where the victim becomes incensed by yet another survey showing up yet another trivial trigger that will make us lose our rag.

Road rage was possibly the first in this rather iffy pop-psycho genre, and perfectly acceptable as a behavioural phenomenon. Who hasn't wanted to brain a fellow motorist with a wheel-brace for daring to use eye contact at the traffic lights?

Trolley rage followed as we grappled the culprit in the five items only queue in Safeways to the ground and stuffed his or her homebake ciabatta where the sun don't shine for daring to sidle in with six tins of cat food in his basket.

Then came air rage, with banjaxed passengers being trussed like Hannibal Lecter; and office rage, where frustrated office workers held paperclip-and-elastic-band duels to the death over who failed to refill the photocopier after use. The latest rage - according to this week's press reports - is PC rage, a seething cauldron of unchecked anger that spills over in the form of PC abuse, a John Cleese-like psychotic episode where we set about beating our unsuspecting desktops with branches from a nearby tree.

Swearing at your PC when it crashes is a regular part of normal office life. Most colleagues understand the tooth-gnashing, own-limb-consuming stress involved and will happily turn a deaf ear to the unchecked outpourings.

In-house IT advisers worth their salt will even join in the ritual in a bid to create empathy with the victim, offering a few sympathetic terms of abuse of their own before explaining gently it was probably your fault, rather than the computer's.

Statistics have it, though, that more than a few of us are strolling a few steps further down barking-mad alley and taking it out on our machines physically, thumping the screen or punching the sides in an uncontrollable frenzy. Surely this means we can only be one tiny gnat's-whisker away from Doing a Keith Moon, ie taking the whole bloody machine and hurling through a window down into the atrium below?

So can this kind of rant over an inanimate object be avoided, or is it - like road rage - going to end in tears when someone finally goes right off their trolley and places a well-aimed size ten right through the middle of the screen-saver?

Save it

One option is to save the rage until you're off business premises and therefore less likely to play Russian roulette with your career. Parking your anger is rarely a viable option, though, especially if the outburst catches you unawares. Taking it home with you in some form of mental carrier bag will cause obvious problems as we will then be told by the psychologists that we are suffering from every indoors-based anger, from microwave rage to settee rage.

Calm it

Instant calmers kept by the terminal may help. These can come in any form that works for you, from stress balls to taped music to a flotation tank. These could be sponsored by the firm once they have been fed enough scare stories about large court payments to stressed-out employees.

Kiddie training Staff could be trained to regress to childhood the minute their machine crashes. A panic button to alert the IT department of the emergency would be the only adult response required. Following that, courses in thumb-sucking, rhythmical chair-rocking and unchecked sobbing and hair-twiddling could avert more aggressive responses to the problem.

If PC rage really is your thing you may find the only object that is not used to sate your anger on a regular basis is the mouse. This is purely and simply because it has a cute-sounding name and no-one wants to be seen causing GBH to something that sounds small and helpless.

Naming your PC after something equally playful and cuddly might help, then. Suggestions: My guinea pig My kitten My Dale Winton My Zoe Ball My Queen Mum, bless 'er.

fields.headline: Sex and the symphony
fields.standfirst:
Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra/Chailly
Royal Festival Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText: Is Bruckner's Seventh Symphony sexy? Most people, pressed on the matter, would respond in the negative, while Bruckner himself - a fervent Catholic, a mystic and probably a celibate, would have been horrified by the suggestion. Now we have a radical interpretation from Riccardo Chailly and the Concertgebouw that drains the work of ceremonial pomposity and fills it with a heady sensuality.
fields.body:
Is Bruckner's Seventh Symphony sexy? Most people, pressed on the matter, would respond in the negative, while Bruckner himself - a fervent Catholic, a mystic and probably a celibate, would have been horrified by the suggestion. The Seventh's supposed chastity of expression was called into question in 1954 when Luchino Visconti used it to accompany the furtive couplings of Alida Valli and Farley Granger in his film Senso. Now we have a radical interpretation from Riccardo Chailly and the Concertgebouw that drains the work of ceremonial pomposity and fills it with a heady sensuality.

Chailly forces home the point that Bruckner is approaching the divine in language derived from the swirling midsummer mating rituals of Meistersinger and the erotic chromaticism of Tristan und Isolde. It's Song of Songs stuff, a performance of genius, played to perfection by an orchestra that remains the finest Bruckner ensemble in the world.

Chailly couples it with Mozart's 23rd Piano Concerto with the fabulous Andreas Haefliger as soloist and the results are extraordinary. The music, ecstatic and soulful, seems to hover somewhere out of time. In the outer movements Haefliger is ruminatively gentle, quietly heroic, while the orchestra swings round him with Dionysian joy. One of the great concerts, no question.

fields.headline: Five O'Clock Angel
fields.standfirst:
King's Head, London
***
fields.trailText: There is no doubt that Kit Hesketh-Harvey's account of the friendship between the American playwright Tennessee Williams and the Russian Maria St Just is beautifully realised. It has an intense elegiac quality, just like Williams's own memory plays, particularly The Glass Menagerie.
fields.body:
There is no doubt that Kit Hesketh-Harvey's account of the friendship between the American playwright Tennessee Williams and the Russian Maria St Just is beautifully realised. It has an intense elegiac quality, just like Williams's own memory plays, particularly The Glass Menagerie.

There is also no doubt that it is brilliantly performed. Stefan Bednarczyk worries away like a terrier with a bone at the insecurities that brought the playwright close to breakdown, and Nichola McAuliffe, an actress whom we really should cherish rather more than we do, gives a characteristically spiky performance as Maria. She both ensnared and horrified Williams, and was his inspiration for Maggie in Cat on a Hot Tin Roof: "no-neck monsters" was her phrase.

McAuliffe demonstrates how much this wit was born of a terrible need to be loved. There is a wonderful scene where Maria nuzzles Tennessee's ear so fiercely that you think she might actually bite it off. She has a desperation that is terrifying, all-consuming and yet somehow oddly touching. But towards the end of Williams's life the tables were turned. She had married a fortune and become independent, and provided a kind of stability for the playwright, whose physical and emotional state was increasingly fragile. She was the rock upon whom he leaned and, in this way, he could finally reciprocate her love.

This is all well and good, and very deftly charted, making links between the couple's relationship and the plays themselves. But I wonder what this kind of well-bred entertainment is doing in a theatre when it should be on Radio 4. Who is it for? Tennessee Williams fans? Literary vultures who like to pick over the bones? People who want to know something about Williams's work but can't be fagged to sit through the plays?

At one point in Five O'Clock Angel Tennessee complains bitterly that one of his plays has closed early to be replaced by a show about Noel Coward and Gertie Lawrence, which he dismisses as sheer nostalgia. Same difference, surely?

Till March 12. Box office: 0171-226 1916.

fields.headline: Trading places
fields.standfirst: City companies are increasingly employing graduate secretaries for fast-track promotion to traders or other high-flying jobs. Kate Hilpern reports
fields.trailText: City companies are increasingly employing graduate secretaries for fast-track promotion to traders or other high-flying jobs. Kate Hilpern reports
fields.body:
Britain is swarming with City wannabes. The work-hard play-hard lifestyle, the unrivalled bonuses and the mammoth levels of responsibility and pressure are perceived by a certain type of character as, quite simply, the perfect package. Chances are you know one or two of them.

Suppose for a moment, then, that one of these characters tells you he or she has decided to apply for a secretarial post as a way in. The suggestion that one might progress from taking memos to trading in securities might have met with sniggers a couple of years ago. But a fast increasing number of graduates - even those with degrees in non-financial subjects - are aiming to do just that. What's more, they're succeeding.

"A few years ago, a City secretary remained a City secretary," says Susan McFarlane, marketing executive at financial recruitment consultants Crone Corkill. "But today, many are able to use their positions as the first rung in the ladder towards becoming a broker or alternatively towards getting a high-flying City role in marketing, accounting or human resources." Given that many of these positions have traditionally been filled by headhunting, argues McFarlane, we are witnessing a radical change.

The past few years have seen a marked trend towards graduates taking up secretarial roles in a wide variety of sectors. They meet that final essay deadline and are about to switch off their South Park screen- savers when they suddenly realise an immediate job is required if they are ever to pay off their monumental student debts. It occurs to them that they've built up a pretty good typing speed, not to mention a sound knowledge of the latest computer software. They're not bad at presentation and organisational skills and they can demonstrate that they are blessed with the odd brain cell or two. They might even have picked up a language en route.

In addition, secretarial qualifications and traditional secretarial skills such as shorthand - which new graduates aren't usually blessed with - are no longer a prerequisite for many administrative and support roles. In a climate where graduate recruitment schemes can take months to get on to, secretarial positions are often an obvious option.

"In many sectors, graduates have been thrilled to realise that following this path can be a short-cut to their dream job," says Jackie Campbell, manager at Reed Employment. "They prove their worth by being pro-active and going beyond the requirements of the job, and the boss recognises their potential and promotes them accordingly."

But this has not - until now - been possible within the Square Mile. First, because the City's traditional recruitment routes have been slow to change, and second because its most sought-after vacancies require particular qualifications. So why the sudden shift in attitude? "There has been a huge growth in the number of well-qualified graduates. Indeed, says Philip Ayling, associate director of recruitment consultants Jonathan Wren, the work of many City PAs is just as pressurised and challenging as any broker's. No longer is it about taking letters or running around with cups of tea - or something stronger - for the top dogs. It is about being an integral part of any team.

"The secretary in the City works closely with clients and analysts, travels, networks, researches, develops databases and websites and arranges conferences," agrees Emily Aldrich, managing director of recruitment consultants Aldrich & Co. "It has been strongly hinted at that, during the next month or so, I will be offered the chance to take my first exams towards becoming a trader," he says. "I definitely see a career for myself here." fields.headline: To boldly go...
fields.standfirst: So you've decided to resign. Nothing wrong with that, says Bill Saunders , as long as you're sure you know what you're doing
fields.trailText: So you've decided to resign. Nothing wrong with that, says Bill Saunders , as long as you're sure you know what you're doing
fields.body:
Bill Gates has just done it. So has Boris Yeltsin. Jeffrey Archer came under a bit of pressure before he did it, and during the last parliament Conservative MPs seemed to make a habit of it.

Resigning is something that most of us do several times during our working career, but our reasons for walking vary enormously from one position to the next. Certainly very few of us are in Gates' position, where as the chief exec we can design our next move ourselves. Sorting out the tricky problem of how to handle your manager is just as important as planning the next stage in your career.

Resignation is an agonising business, says Jane Littlefield, head of the secretarial division at City specialists Joslin Rowe, and it is important that you know your own mind before you make a move. "Do not resign in a fit of anger, or because your friend has resigned, or because it's the beginning of the year and everyone else seems to be doing it. Resign only when you have really weighed up why you want to leave and have no doubts that you are doing the right thing."

Above all, she says, don't threaten resignation as a bluff in order to get a pay rise. It is extremely humiliating to have one's resignation accepted with glee. "Before you resign, make sure that you can genuinely imagine yourself not working there any more. There is not always a way back."

If you are basically happy with the company, try to isolate what the problem is. "If you are no longer stimulated by your job, explore whether there is more you can take on, or another vacancy internally you can apply for, or put in a request for more training," says Littlefield.

Of course, not everyone follows this advice. "Dear M: No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No, No. I quit. SS." This purportedly real-life billet-doux was sent by an aggrieved artist in London to his boss after "aesthetic differences of opinion" became too much to handle. The manager's reply is sadly not recorded at www.i-resign.com.

Enjoyable as such letters are to read and, no doubt, to write, Littlefield cautions that it is best to take a more moderate approach. "However unhappy you may be, slating the company/your boss/your colleagues during your resignation will not do you many favours when you come to ask for a reference. Have a polite, business-like letter of resignation prepared when you go into the meeting: it will look professional and show you have really thought about your reasons for resigning."

Kauser Kanji, sales and marketing director at i-resign.com also sees the serious side. His highly entertaining website started as a spoof, but has evolved to include useful legal information on your rights as a resignee, as well as links to recruitment sites to help you plan your next move. "I was resigning myself," says Kanji, "and I thought it would be fun to see what other people had done." The site includes the resignation statements of Richard Nixon and King Edward VIII, though how relevant these may be to your situation is open to debate. "We soon saw that resignation is a pretty explosive event. So we began to add links to jobsites and put in a section on legal advice."

As far as legal commitments go, Littlefield suggests that at your resignation meeting you stress that you are happy to work out your notice period and that you will continue to do your best. You should mean it, too, because obviously it will be your most recent performance that will influence your final reference.

When you have decided to go, make sure that you know to whom you should hand in your resignation, and ensure they hear the news from you first. "You don't want your boss to find out through the grapevine that you are leaving," says Littlefield.
