fields.headline: On track with your training
fields.standfirst: Don't leave it to your company to decide on the skills you need. Think about your future career and make your own decisions, advises Melissa Lawrence
fields.trailText: Don't leave it to your company to decide on the skills you need. Think about your future career and make your own decisions, advises Melissa Lawrence
fields.body:
There are some things at work that it's OK to leave to other people, such as putting in a new fax roll or organising a whip-round for a departing colleague. Taking responsibility for your training, however, is not a thing you should expect someone else to take care of. According to the Industrial Society, only 11% of companies can be described as "learning organisations", actively promoting training among their staff. So if you want to stay ahead, you will have to take the initiative.

As a secretary, you should be particularly aware of the necessity to take control of your training schedule. If you allow your training to be dictated by the needs of your boss, or what is available through your company, you may find yourself stuck with non-transferable skills. This can cause problems if you want to progress within your own sector, and it will certainly hold you back if you want to move into another one.

Laurel Alexander, author of Learning New Job Skills (How To Books, £9.99), believes it's time to stop thinking of companies as benevolent parents and start taking responsibility for your own working life, including your training. "You have to identify the skills required, acquire them and then market yourself and your skills to potential employers," she says. "You need to see yourself as the supplier, fulfilling a need to the employer. By organising a training strategy for yourself, you can begin to take charge."

The first step is to do a skills audit. This should cover practical skills as well as personal ones. "Analyse your current skills and realistically evaluate where you might have a skill shortage," advises Richard Frodin, manager of Reed Training. "Highlight the need to keep up-to-date with new IT developments. The main benefit will be the speed with which you learn to do previously laborious tasks."

Once you've identified the skills you want to acquire, think about what your company's requirements are likely to be in the future. If you want to tailor your training to meet those requirements that's fine but, according to trainer Judi James, it's important to put your own needs first. "The changing nature of business means setting personal as well as corporate goals, but people need to realise they have to think of themselves as individuals as well as team players. It's OK to be selfish and put your training needs first, but you may be surprised how guilty you feel about doing this."

When you've decided what training you need, set goals. Decide what you want or need to learn, how it can be achieved and how long it will take. Break this information down into learning goals and objectives. For example, you may decide you want to obtain a management qualification. Your first goal will be to do some research. Your objectives could include discussing the situation with your boss, looking at what is available in-house and sending for distance-learning brochures.

Try to think beyond acquiring more secretarial skills. "It's vital for people to create their own roles in the company," says James. "You may need to say: 'I'm a secretary, but I'd also like to be responsible for x, y, z, otherwise I may get left behind.' If you think you've reached the glass ceiling, create a job for yourself that goes beyond your job description - such as mentor or trainer." Before you rush to book a place on an in-house training course, consider which training methods might best suit you. "Don't be too inflexible," advises James. "Many larger companies are now boosting their internal training by using consultants to come in and train the whole team, while some also have computerised training where you can log on to your PC and access a training programme without having to go through your line manager or HR department.

"If your boss is reluctant to allow you to pursue training, you need to be a salesperson," says James. "Put together a strong proposal as to why it's important, and if you get no joy, go to the next in line. If it's the culture of the job that is anti-training, get out of the job. If you've had no training, it looks very bad when you apply for jobs with other companies."

Right on course

 When talking to your boss, don't be negative about the skills you lack. Accentuate the positive aspects of new skills that can be learned quickly.

 Look for courses that offer satisfaction guarantees and free refresher courses, especially if your company is reluctant to fund your training.

 Don't worry about work mounting up while you're away from the office. You'll make up the time by working more effectively on your return.

 Remember to arrange a debriefing session with your boss after every piece of training, so he or she knows what you have achieved and what extra responsibilities you can take on.

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.trailText: • Ringing the changes
fields.byline: Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine
fields.body:
 Ringing the changes

Has your firm starting using the new phone numbers? If not, you could experience problems when the dialling codes change on April 22. Although old and new codes will work in parallel for a while, the old codes will eventually be withdrawn and any phone systems that use pre-programmed numbers - including ISDN lines and call logging features - must be updated before then. London, Portsmouth, Southampton, Coventry, Northern Ireland and Cardiff will all have new three-digit codes beginning 02. Businesses should contact their telecoms maintainers to check that their equipment is "Big Number" friendly. Call the free helpline on 0808 224 2000, or check out the codes on www.numberchange.org.

 A pain in the back

More than 11m working days are lost each year through back pain, at a cost of £5bn. In response, the department of health has launched Back in Work, to increase awareness of back pain and ways to avoid it. The government is hoping businesses will sign up to the scheme, part of the wider Healthy Workplace Initiative. See www.ohn.gov.uk or email signup@doh.gov.uk to register your firm.

 Web wise

Small businesses know they should be on the internet, but often have no idea where to start, or cannot afford the costs of consultant web designers. So says EasyWeb, a firm that has devised a simple way to help individuals and small firms to build their own websites. For £99, companies can select web pages to suit them, and EasyWeb claims it takes ten minutes and requires no special skills. For more information, visit www.easywebdirect.com or call 01892 617264.

 Employment law

Do you know who is affected by the national minimum wage? Are you aware of how fathers' rights have changed under the parental leave legislation? If you need to keep up with the changes from Brussels, you'll find Essentials of Employment Law invaluable. This updated guide from the Institute of Personnel and Development costs £19.95 from Plymbridge Distributors, tel: 01752 202301.

 All the right moves

Anyone who has coordinated an office move knows there is more to it than packing up the computers. A new resource, Office IQ 2000, aims to take the stress out of sourcing new premises or altering an existing set-up. The 300-page guide comes with a CD Rom with 33 printable checklists from the book, and has contact details for nearly 500 agents, surveyors and lawyers. It costs £200 from Property Futures Ltd, tel 020 7613 8822.

The moment the papers are delivered, I drop everything and riffle through the Times magazine looking for John Diamond's column. When it is not there, I wonder what his absence means. Is he merely sunning himself in Bermuda? Or has something more sinister happened?
fields.body:
Like many others, I have a little ritual on Saturday mornings. The moment the papers are delivered, I drop everything and riffle through the Times magazine looking for John Diamond's column. When it is not there, I wonder what his absence means. Is he merely sunning himself in Bermuda? Or has something more sinister happened?

For the past three years, since he was diagnosed with throat cancer, Diamond has been writing about his illness and the way it affects him, his family and his friends. There is nothing maudlin about these columns, and they are touched with the same intelligence and wit that characterised Diamond's work when he was more often to be found writing about wonky wheels on shopping trolleys.

I was not such a fan in those days, having a strong resistance to the idea of turning your whole life into journalism. Turning your own death - and death is what Diamond is staring in the face - into journalism turns out to be utterly compelling.

This stage adaptation of some of the weekly columns is no substitute for the real thing, but at its best it operates in exactly the same way as the original material by making you confront your own mortality. While he is waiting for the first of what will turn out to be many operations, he realises: "BUPA covers most contingencies but it doesn't cover fear." This is a typical Diamond sentence: it makes you smile and turn cold at the same time.

The weekly column is an unfolding saga, whose end may - barring miracles - be certain. And, like all our lives, it is a shapeless thing, a stream of consciousness. This stage version has the edge because it can shape and contextualise, so heightening the ironies. After all, there is something rather curious about a one-man show about a broadcaster who has been unable to speak since the removal of his tongue that nonetheless reveals him as an artful monologist. But then, this is also a man who is unable to eat but has a wife who writes cookery books for a living.

Robert Katz is not an actor, and it shows. But he gives a charming, self-effacing performance, never trying to impersonate Diamond, but rather presenting the writer and himself in parallel: two ordinary blokes of similar backgrounds - both Jewish, both with young families, both ironists - with so much in common and so much to live for. It is an evening with all the limitations of a one-man show. But the truth of the writing prevails. It will win Diamond more fans.

fields.headline: Gates joins lottery contest
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The company that has created several thousand millionaires among its employees yesterday announced that it was joining a consortium which aims to create a new millionaire every day.
fields.body:
The company that has created several thousand millionaires among its employees yesterday announced that it was joining a consortium which aims to create a new millionaire every day.

Microsoft said it was joining Sir Richard Branson's bid to run the National Lottery, which has created far fewer millionaires than the software firm has within its ranks.

As Sir Richard sought to stoke popular enthusiasm for his bid by promising a "millionaire a day" if he wins, Bill Gates upped the pressure on the existing lottery organiser, Camelot, by indicating that he would use new technology to broaden the appeal of the game.

Microsoft is planning to help the People's Lottery, as Sir Richard's consortium is called, to make the game accessible via mobile phones, interactive digital TV and computer.

Interviewed on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost, Mr Gates and Sir Richard pledged more payouts for winners and more cash for good causes.

Sir Richard said: "We've constructed it so you would still get these super big rollouts, but we are also going to be able to pledge a millionaire a day for every day of the year."

And in a reference to the fact that the People's Lottery would be a non-profit making organisation, Mr Gates said: "You need to ask is there not an approach which can cost a lot less money and can be a richer experience for the people who want to use it."

Sir Richard said Microsoft's use of technology would help win back some of the 12m people that he estimates to have stopped playing the lottery since its launch in 1994.

Sir Richard's consortium is bidding for the seven-year lottery licence due to come into effect next year. The winner will be announced in June.

Like other participants in the People's Lottery, Microsoft will not have a shareholding but will be paid for its services. The consortium includes J Walter Thompson, Compaq, Cisco, and KPMG Consulting.

The People's Lottery renewed its attack on Camelot's record yesterday by suggesting sales were continuing to fall, down by almost 7% in the six months to last September. Britain's lottery ranked only 30th among worldwide lotteries by sales per person.

Microsoft indicated that Mr Gates would not have thrown his personal prestige behind the other lottery bids, but felt Sir Richard's non-profit making organisation was one that he could back.

fields.headline: Joanna Trollope's top 10 nineteenth-century novels
fields.trailText: Joanna Trollope's novels include A Village Affair, Next of Kin and Other People's Children. Marrying the Mistress is published by Bloomsbury.
fields.body:
Joanna Trollope's novels include A Village Affair, Next of Kin and Other People's Children. Marrying the Mistress is published by Bloomsbury.

"The nineteenth century was, in my view, the golden age of fiction and the one I most admire."

1. Middlemarch by George Eliot

Perhaps the greatest novel of them all - an enormous canvas and a vast and poignant range of character. A marvellous portrait of nineteenth-century provincial life.

2. The Last Chronicle of Barset by Anthony Trollope

This novel contains that near impossibility - the sympathetic portrait of an incredibly unsympathetic hero. A masterpiece.

3. Persuasion by Jane Austen

A subtle and elegiac novel - more heartfelt than some of her earlier romances and with a truly appealing heroine.

4. Vanity Fair by WM Thackeray

The best thing he ever wrote - sharp, brilliant, touching, clever and cruel, with an unforgettable heroine.

5. The Mayor of Casterbridge by Thomas Hardy

A tale of true tragedy - a man of potential brought down by his own fatal flaw - but a wonderfully vivid and strong picture of early nineteenth-century rural life.

6. The Moonstone by Wilkie Collins

A great, bold, theatrical mystery story which never falters, written with huge confidence and style.

7. Bleak House by Charles Dickens

This has everything - joy, grief, success, failure, wealth, poverty, comedy, tragedy - and above all, atmosphere by the bucketload.

8. North and South by Mrs Gaskell

A really remarkable picture of the reality, as well as the prosperity, of northern industrial life, and an interesting examination of changing social conscience.

9. Portrait of a Lady by Henry James

A very different voice, this, subtle and sophisticated and concerned with psychological nuance and social acceptability.

10. Rob Roy by Sir Walter Scott

Scott is very out of fashion just now, but this is a true adventure story in the traditional mould of the "good-hearted" hero.
